Title: Sleeping Beauty Syndrome: Gentleman mixes class and mass elements: Guru Deshpande
Content: Filmmaker Guru Deshpande ’s heart was set on making a film called Thackeray with Prajwal Devaraj . But when the logistics for that did not work out, he wanted to do another project with Prajwal. Guru knew about a script that his close associate Jadesh Kumar had been working on for his directorial debut, and narrated it to the Prajwal. As it turns out, the actor was excited about the subject and came on board. “Initially, we were looking for a producer to back the film, but when Thackeray got delayed, I decided to make it as the first project under my home banner,” says Guru. The film, Gentleman, produced by G Cinemas Guru Deshpande Productions, releases today and Guru is very proud of his first as a producer. “I want films from my banner to have a novelty factor and be entertaining and Gentleman sets the tone just right. While it is film that deals with the sleeping beauty syndrome and the human egg trafficking mafia, it has the right mix of class and mass elements to make it a must-watch for all audiences,” he says.

Title: Now, Prabhu Mundkur too in a cameo in Pavan Wadeyar’s film
Content: Kannada film director Pavan Wadeyar ’s next sure has a lot of surprises in store, what with the number of actors being roped in for special appearances. While it was recently reported that actress Karunya Ram had been signed up for a cameo, the latest is that yet another actor from the industry is now going to make his presence felt in the currently under-production film, Raymo. Actor Prabhu Mundkur , who awaits the release of Ranchi, is now doing a cameo in this Ishan CV and Ashika Ranganath starrer. Confirming the news, Pavan says, “This is going to be very different from what people have seen of Prabhu onscreen so far. His cameo is very important to the narrative. While I cannot reveal the exact details, all I can say is that his presence in the film will bring a twist to the story.” Prabhu adds, “I am happy with the opportunity to work with Pavan, with a role that is very important to the narrative of his film.”

Title: A singer needs to be a good storyteller: Benny Dayal
Content: Singer Benny Dayal , who has multiple chartbusters in different languages to his credit, shares a special bond with Bengaluru. He had tied the knot with model Catherine Thangam in the city a few years ago. No wonder, then, he got a little nostalgic during his recent trip to namma ooru for the Under 25 summit. In a quick chat with us, he spoke about his absence from the Kannada music industry and his views on the country’s booming indie music scene. Excerpts:Right now, a lot of things are going on in the music sector, enabling more and more artistes to explore their talent. It’s a welcome trend. That way, audiences also have more options to choose from. Often, it’s seen that the unfamiliar and unconventional compositions stand out among these.Well, it’s not just about being a singer, but also about being a storyteller. A song’s lyrics are put together to tell a story. What matters is how you are able to convey that story, regardless of whether it’s been composed by someone else or yourself. It’s not about the tag of filmi music or indie music. What matters is whether or not people are being able to connect with your music.Sid Sriram, Arijit Singh Prateek Kuhad and Papon are some of my favourites. My ultimate idol, however, is Vishal Dadlani . He’s not only a singer, but a composer and a writer too.Saying the right thing at the right time is a skill that comes from knowledge and experience. The older you grow, the wiser you become. What I feel is that one should not be over-opinionated, and should use discretion while making a statement.To be honest, I’ve not been getting many calls for Kannada songs.My band, Funktuation, is all set to release a new single on Valentine’s Day. It’ll have a cool, cute video that shows how love can bring a freshness to life.My connection with Bengaluru dates back to my college days. I studied in Chennai, but I often used to visit this city for inter-collegiate competitions. I used to perform at small gigs too. I also have a lot of friends here. What makes Bengaluru more special for me, however, is the fact that I got married here. My wife is from America, and because her family couldn’t handle the heat in Chennai and Kerala, we decided to have the wedding here.

Title: Remya Nambeesan Anjaam Pathiraa: The insecurities of actresses have come down to an extent: Remya Nambeesan
Content: In Anjaam Pathiraa , when Fathima, wife of Anwar Hussain appears on screen, the audience get a surprise glimpse of Remya Nambeesan . The actress’ last full-length role in Malayalam was almost five years back in 2015, though she was busy in Tamil, both as an actor and a singer. Ask her why and she doesn’t give us a specific reason, but asserts that she would love do films in her mother tongue.Remya, who was last seen in an extended cameo in Virus alongside an ensemble cast, is happy about her role in Anjaam Pathiraa, the way her career has shaped up in the Tamil film industry and how she takes forward her passion for music and dance.In a candid chat, the Chaappa Kurish actress who has been always vocal about the injustice towards women in the industry, speaks about returning to Mollywood and other subjects.It was because I became really busy in Tamil after Sethupathi. Suddenly, offers dried up in Malayalam from 2015. If you ask me to specify the reasons, I am really not sure. Was it because I asked for the remuneration that I felt I deserved? And, they thought it was a sudden rise? Luckily, I was getting very good offers from Tamil. Also, I wasn’t able to take up some projects that came to me from Malayalam as I had already given my dates to Tamil projects.I took up Virus after a long time. Till then, many people thought that I had stopped acting in Malayalam.I really loved the script and felt the technical team was very sensible. Also, each character is integral to the story, no matter how much screen space each has. I am someone who has never bothered about the length of my character in any film, but only about the importance of the role. In Traffic, I hardly have one or two scenes, but my role is pivotal for the story’s progression. When I read Anjaam Pathiraa’s script, I felt I shouldn’t miss it as none of the dialogues by the character is irrelevant. Midhun is a director who gives enough freedom to the actors and I really had a relaxed shoot. I think everyone had the same feeling and that has reflected in the performance of each actor.I have five projects in Tamil now. My next release is Thamezharasan with Vijay Antony , then Ranger with Sibiraj. I am also part of a typical fun Tamil road movie named Plan Panni Pannanum and I am also doing an offtrack movie. I am associating again with Prabhu Deva.Never. My mother tongue is Malayalam and it is in my blood. So, doing a character in our own language is a very different feeling and a unique comfort. It really feels good. However, for me acting is my job and as an actor, I grab a good opportunity wherever I get one. Cinema has now become more universal due to online platforms and people from anywhere in the world can now watch movies from any language. For me, my work and talent have to be recognised. I am doing well in Tamil and received good offers, so I stayed back. If I get good scripts in Malayalam, I will definitely come back here.(Laughs) It is a three-minute video titled Unhide which I am planning to release on February 14. I wasn’t sure if I could do but I did. It is a small theme that I had in my mind and I have just tried to visualise it.It is a part of my life. I had sung for Dabaang 3 in Tamil and for my upcoming movie which has Yuvan Shankar Raja composing music. I am doing concerts, judging reality shows and in dance, I am doing stage performances and shows.There will be definitely be opposition when we speak up about injustice. That’s quite natural. When you react or talk, people treat us, especially women, as aliens. It is not necessary that we say something intellectual. Even if we speak up about basic things, it can make people uncomfortable. I do not know why.We are now living in a world undergoing big changes, but most people here aren’t happy when we speak out. They should understand that it is the beginning of change and only through discussion, will there be transformation. I have taken it all in a sportsman spirit as, I believe, things will change eventually. When we speak out initially, there will be hatred and as we continue to do so, people will evolve. If you believe in yourself and work hard, and stay strong without being afraid of the opposition, you will definitely have your space in the industry.What I have understood is that the insecurities that prevailed in the minds of women in the industry have come down to an extent. Of late, in Malayalam, I have been working with young filmmakers and I felt really comfortable, be it on Aashiq Abu’s set or Midhun’s set. There is a very good working atmosphere. I feel things are slowly changing and we will have a comfortable working atmosphere. However, it isn't true that there are no issues in the industry. What we need is equal space and opportunity. All aspiring actresses should walk into films without any fear or apprehension. They should feel free and at peace to work in the industry.

Title: Bigg Boss 13: Shehnaz Gill discusses her kids names with Sidharth Shukla; the latter pokes fun at her
Content: Bigg Boss 13 contestants Shehnaz Gill and Sidharth Shukla are inseparable in the game. No matter how much they fight, they can't live without talking and spending time with each other. In the latest episode of the show, Shehnaz Gill was seen discussing about her future. She tells her bestie Sidharth Shukla what she plans to name her kids in future. She shares with Sidharth Shukla that she wants to name her son something which reflects a warrior attitude. She adds that the name should directly touch your heart when you listen to it. Sidharth asks her if she has a name in mind.Shehnaz tells him she wants to name her son Zorawar. Sidharth immediately pokes fun at her and asks which of her boyfriends was named Zorawar. Shehnaz gets angry and scolds Sidharth that why he is always interested in her boyfriends and takes matters in that direction. She tells him she is talking about her son here. He makes fun of her and suggests why doesn't she name her son Khanjar (knife). Arti, who is also seated close to them bursts out laughing.The episode also saw Shehnaz Gill, Mahira Sharma Arti Singh and Paras Chhabra competing for immunity task. They were unable to survive in a turtle shell and no one from the four got through.Later, the two enact how will they talk over the phone once they are out of the house. They have a hearty laugh together and enjoy each other's company.In one of the recent episodes, Shehnaz had an emotional breakdown after she was questioned her loyalty towards Sidharth Shukla. Sidharth and Shehnaz had a showdown as Sidharth asked her why she was talking ill about him to Asim.Keep reading this space for more updates for Bigg Boss 13.

Title: Madhya Pradesh: 12-year-old boy dies emulating Bhagat Singh's hanging
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

INDORE: A 12-year-old child in Mandsaur, who played a British police officer in a school drama on Bhagat Singh , accidentally hanged himself at home while trying to replicate the execution of the revolutionary.

According to local police, the victim, Priyansh Malviya of Bholiya village, was found hanging in a hut on his father's farm on Sunday evening. An upturned cot lay on the floor, along with a smartphone with a video clip of the play he had acted in the previous evening. News of the accident trickled out on Thursday.

"Preliminary investigation revealed that the child had participated in a play in his school's annual event. The next day, he was watching a video clip of the drama and was trying to recreate the scene. He couldn't maintain balance, and the cot he was standing on collapsed, leaving him hanging from the rope. It was not suicide but a tragic accident," Mandsaur SP Hitesh Choudhary said. The postmortem report confirmed suffocation as cause of death. His body was handed over to the family for the last rites.

Priyansh's father Vinod Malviya is a government teacher. "On his parents' wish, we had given the role of a British police officer to Priyansh in the short, three-minute-long play. We came to know about the tragic incident today,'' Gyan Sagar School principal Arun Jain said.

Title: Tollywood remembers Queen of Cabaret
Content: There was a time in the ’60s when Miss Shefali née Arati Das would dance the night away at the poshest nightclubs in the city. Dressed in glamorous cabaret costumes, she would sway to the beats of live music. On Thursday morning, the first Bengali cabaret dancer — popular as the Queen of Cabaret — passed away at her residence, marking the end of an era. She reigned for many years, moving up the ladder of financial stability, before the cabaret culture faded into oblivion. Her extraordinary life has inspired commercial and arthouse filmmakers alike. However, despite the fame she enjoyed in her prime, the last few years of her life were spent alone, struggling to make ends meet. We spoke to a few Tollywood celebrities who shared fond memories of the legend.Rituparna SenguptaShefalidi was a stalwart who made cabaret a popular dance form. I interacted with her several times and she always treated me with a lot of affection. It is sad that an artiste of her stature had to go through severe financial crisis in old age. I tried to help her as much as I could. She was once felicitated by my company for being a woman of power, which she truly was. There were days when she would call me up and cry while sharing her plight of not getting any work. It’s hard to believe that this is the sameperson who had acted in two of Satyajit Ray ’s films? Shefalidi used to love Bengali food and I remember gifting her a Dhakai, which she wished to have after seeing me wear one at an event. She also taught me a few dance moves. I will soon start working on a film based on her life, as it was Shefalidi’s wish to see me play her on screen.Miss Shefali worked in two of Baba’s (Satyajit Ray) films — Seemabaddha and Pratidwandi. A thorough professional, she was an easy actress to work with. Baba used to explain the scene just once and she’d do it perfectly. She was a natural in front of the camera. We all know she was a great cabaret dancer. So, Baba put a spotlight on her talent in Seemabaddha.Arati Das, better known as Miss Shefali, is more than a cabaret dancer to us. I’d love to remember her as a veteran dancer who made cabaret so famous. For me, she’ll always be Shefali aunty, as she was my mother’s friend and also close to rest of the family. I’ve accompanied Ma to Shefali aunty’s Park Circus house several times. She used to help girls from villages realise their dreams of becoming cabaret dancers. I have seen her live performances and the way she used to maintain her dignity and poise is really praiseworthy. It is sad that our Sandhya Raater Shefali had to suffer financial crisis and lead a lonely life in the last few years. But our Queen of Cabaret will forever be a part of Kolkata’s history.When I was offered Miss Rupali’s character in Bhobishyoter Bhoot, inspired by Miss Shefali’s life, I was both nervous and excited. Shefali had an aura about herself. She started from scratch and reached the pinnacle of fame, mesmerising everyone with her dance moves. But she went into a cocoon and suffered. It was challenging to play a character like that. It is sad that someone, as popular as her, died in penury.Miss Shefali had a dance number in one of Ma’s (Suchitra Sen) films. Once the shoot was over, she came up to Ma to get a picture clicked with her. But before that, she wrapped a shawl around herself as she was not comfortable in her cabaret costume. Also, this was her way of showing respect to Ma. I remember going to a night club with Ma’s friend, where I saw her perform live. She was graceful in her moves. Years later, I met her during a show in North Bengal. She was not well. I helped her with the makeup. Once she was in her costume, she set the stage on fire. I heard the last few years of her life were quite depressing. The Queen of Cabaret will always be alive in our hearts.The news of Shefali’s demise has caused me a lot of grief. I knew her personally, she was full of life and laughter. The very thought that someone as successful as her in the world of cabaret had to lead such a lonely life — devoid of work and financial stability — makes me very sad. I did whatever little I could for Shefali, but she deserved much more as an artiste.Shefali and I shared the stage a couple of times. It was for a play, Porostree, where she had a dance performance. She was also part of many popular plays, like Samrat o Sundari, Saheb Bibi Golam , Ashlil to name a few. Once we went to Kokrajhar in Assam for a show, where we bonded really well. She was an extremely good soul. I met her at an event few months ago. She was crying and looking for work. It’s sad that Shefali, who was a cabaret sensation in ’60s and ’70s had to suffer so much!

Title: Ishtiyak Khan: Salman bhai is a great human being: Ishtiyak Khan
Content: Actor Ishtiyak Khan , who was last seen in Salman Khan and Katrina Kaif starrer Bharat, loves visiting Lucknow. While relishing the food on his third trip to the city, the actor said, “The food in Lucknow is just so incredible and delicious that I believe every other day during my stay here I would go out and have my dinner. Even the food on the streets is so good. One day I would have kebab parantha, the other day, biryani. The food here just never ceases to amaze me.” The Tamasha actor added, “Lakhnawi architecture also catches and pleases my eyes. Every building here has such beautiful artwork attached to it. My favourite is the Imambara, however.” After speaking at length about the state capital, Ishtiyak opened up about the struggles of a supporting actor.He said, “Although I feel that supporting actors have to struggle a lot to get the roles and to get recognised, they gain power once they manage to build a strong image in the film industry. A supporting actor is required and seen in quite many films. It takes long for a supporting actor to get established and once he does, there’s no looking back. He’s got a long way to go from there.” Adding further Ishtiyak said, “Having said that, I feel 30% of the people get recognition from these kinds of roles like Nawaz Bhai, Pankaj Tripathi , Irrfan, Gajraj Rao, Rajkummar Rao, etc. All these actors started from the bottom, they started their journeys as supporting actors and now you see where they stand. Similarly, I started with roles comprising of 2-3 dialogues and now that people have started recognising me, I feel I’m getting to play better characters. It’s all about perseverance and luck I feel.”Ishtiyak Khan (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)Ishtiyak, who was in Lucknow to shoot for the film Maidaan starring Ajay Devgn, revealed, “I’m playing this character named Hari, jo poore samay Rahim (who is the main lead) ke saath rehta hai. Hari stays with Rahim throughout his journey, through thick and thin.”Speaking about his role in the film Bharat opposite Salman Khan, Ishtiyak said, “I played this notorious and fearless peon who carries out his work by taking bribes.” When asked about his experience of working with Salman Khan, he said, “Not only is Salman Bhai a great human being, but an incredible actor as well. He helped me improvise a couple of scenes like there was this one scene in the film, ek aadmi ka wazan kaafi kam tha, toh he was like iska weight toh bahot kam hai, isko zero bol doh. Jab yeh thoda hawa bhare tab iska wazan badhega.” He added, “Despite the fact that he is such a big star, he doesn’t let it dominate the other person. In order to make the other person feel at ease Salman bhai will start a random conversation about the person’s family and general stuff. He ensures that the other person feels like they’re talking to the character in the film and not Salman Khan the superstar.” — Yashi Agarwal

Title: Restaurant Review: Play The Lounge
Content: It was 11 pm. Dining alone was kickstarting my adrenaline. The music was loud, the lighting was soft and the restaurant was packed, as was the dance floor. I was happy to get back to my old practice of dining alone. I’d done it for several years while writing one of the world’s first vegetarian guides to Paris, and also for Pune’s Food Guide and Mumbai’s Nightlife Guide. There’s a certain joy in dining alone. It also keeps one focussed and razor-sharp alert on the food, service and ambiance without any distractions from chatting with one’s dining companions. In that crowded, hammered by loud music, darkness enrobed space, could the food really be up to anything much? Was ‘Play’ going to only live up to its name? At 1 am, an enjoyable two hours later, I got the answer.Chilled air-conditioning and a lively young vibe here. Play The Lounge, opened in July last year, on the first floor of The Orb in Andheri. It sprawls into two rooms — the glassed-in sheesha room as well as the dining area decked around the dance floor.The menu whizzes around the globe. The very first surprise was the mushroom baklava. Neat little crisp pastry pockets hold a mushy, tasty mushroom pate. A tasty Burmese khowsuey with a balanced creamy coconut-infused curry perked up with crunchy condiments and sparkled with lemon juice. The robustly spiced paneer meal was served in the “housefull” bento box complete with fragrant rice, spicy mint chutney. Chef Ranjit Nath (formerly of 212) ensures that even the John Dory was cooked just right and tiramisu had just the right sweetness. Attentive service helmed by Ishwar Pradhan. Plenty of innovative drinks, too.Dining in the dark to the sound of loud music is not my idea of a great meal. The overcooked, rubbery Angare Chicken Tikka and the hard biscuity base of the pizza disappointed, as did the chalky blueberry cheesecake.Happy surprises here. In what appears to be a noisy, dance-play (gaming zone et al) booze-centric space, food does play a prominent role. Sure, they have many a hook for everything else — on Monday, alcohol is served at MRP prices and there are exciting drinking games, too. But, the strange-sounding hotch-potch of a menu was tasty and worth trying. Play offers more than just play, for there is playful food served through the day as well.Play The LoungeThe Orb, Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj International Airport, IA Project Road, Andheri (E)Timings: 12 pm to 1.30 amContact: 089065 58888Meal for two: Rs.2,500Rating:Food: 3.5Service: 3.5Décor: 3.5

Title: Bidding a warm adieu!
Content: Om Prakash Singh, the former Director General of Police , UP, threw a lavish retirement party at his former residence, recently. Singh, along with wife Neelam , greeted everyone and ensured each of his special guests was well looked after. The incoming DGP, HC Awasthi was given a warm welcome hug by Singh. The who's who from the city was present to bid a warm adieu to Singh, who said with a smile, “Everyone is gifting me bouquets as if to say that it’s time now for me to sit back, relax and smell the flowers.”(L) Malini Awasthi and Shaan (R) UP CM Yogi Adityanath (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)A police band struck up some lively tunes while people made a beeline for selfies with Bollywood singer Shaan who was also present at the party.Sulkhan Singh (L) and Surya Kumar (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)(L) Dulari and Shree Prakash (R) Mukesh Meshram (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)(L) Priya and Anand Kumar (R) Rajendra Tiwari (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)(L) Rajoo and PC Meena (R) Annu Singh and Shweta Gupta (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)(L) Renu Singh and Amitabh Yash (R) Bhuvnesh Kumar (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)(L) Sanjay and Pooja Prasad (R) SK Bhagat and Shefali Bhagat (BCCL/ Farhan Ahmad Siddiqui)

Title: AMIT SARIN: Varanasi is and will always remain a special place for me: Amit Sarin
Content: Home coming is always special, so was for Banaras-born actor Amit Sarin , who was recently, on a trip to his hometown, along with his family. The Kyunki Saas Bhi Kabhi Bahu Thi and Kkusum fame actor says, “I wanted my kids to connect with their grandparents and rest of the extended family who still live in Banaras. Varanasi is and will always remain a very special place for me as I was born and brought up there. I value the place more now, ever since I moved to Los Angeles and am living in a different part of the world.There is a certain pull towards the place despite its small town existence. The simplicity of the place starts to encroach upon you. Banaras is one of the very few places in the world that has a very different charm. Apart from its religious significance, it is the people of Banaras that makes it really special, they are really warm. The city has a Ganga Jamuni tehzeeb which the people still believe in. The place still holds on to things which are gradually becoming unique. It still has its simplicity, minimalistic way of life, while the world is becoming complex.” Amit, who recently connected with Hollywood actor Gerard Butler, says,”These are the small things which makes Banaras special and even the West is recognising this. These are very profound messages the city gives and those who have gone through various cycles of life understand this. The extensions like the Ganga aarti, etc add to the value of Banaras. Recently actor Gerard Butler was in Banaras and a common friend of ours connected me to him. She told me that Gerard loves Banaras and also conveyed to him that I hail from the city. Though we could not meet as we were there on different dates but Gerard messaged me that he was heartbroken on leaving Banaras as he loves the place so much.”Almost a veteran on television Amit says the medium has very steadily moved to web or OTT platform, which is an extension of television. The approach and functioning of OTT platform is same as television but for a better quality and in a very finite way. The choice to the target audience is given keeping the quality in mind. Television has in a way migrated to the OTT platform. Most of the content providers for this platform are from the television industry , though other people are also coming, because the fundamentals are the same. Even TV producers get to explore more here, as there are certain restriction on networks, like there are certain things you cannot show on TV and the target audience have to be met. But OTT platform gives the producers to really explore themselves, to show the content in the real self as is should be, not with conditions,” he says.Amit Sarin (inset) with Vineesha Arora Sarin at Assi Ghat (BCCL/ Arvind Kumar)Apart from moving to the web platform, television, as a medium has changed, believes the actor. “At the time I did shows like Kyunki, Kkusum, Pavitra Rishtra, there was no alternative. Either there were films or television. Obviously the viewership for television show was huge, the tenure of shows spanned across six –seven years, so the relationship you shared with your audience was very long. Recently at Vegas, a couple came up to me and addressed me by the name of the character which I played in one of the television shows. The connect with those on- screen characters is still strong. The characters were very popular then. Today the tenure of the television show is very short, barring few that have a very long life. Also people have moved to different kind of shows like sports channel have evolved, there are life style channels , so there is much more variety for people now. Earlier this was not the case. In those times, if your mother, sister or your wife had to see their daily soaps you had no other choice, either to join them or to entertain yourself. Now there are many options of entertainment so television has limited its reach,” he says.Amrit Sarin, who has moved to LA, did feel restricted as an actor, becoming one of the reasons to shift base. “I feel every actor goes through that cycle. Yes, I did shows in which I mostly played the boy-next-door, the lover boy, the guy who sacrifices his love. Later on to explore more, I did some negative roles also, honestly I never liked it as my father would feel bad about it as he could not see me in negative roles. Every actor wants to explore more but television as a platform is not ready for it. It still needs to do what the general demand is. Producers still need to make shows what the audience want but cannot make the way the actor wants it to be. Like any other actor I also went through that cycle. You reach a point when you want to explore something else. I also had this rather disruptive attitude towards my career, I mean, I always wanted to break that comfort zone. I was never ever happy with ke paise aa rahe hain and doing shows after shows for this. That was never the kick for me, I wanted to break my boundaries. This came with its share of apprehensions. At times it scares you, you feel oh God what you are doing and also have a feeling that whether it will work or not. But now when I look back, I feel humbled that God has always helped me in everything new I tried. I guess, this is how you grow.” Life has completely changed for the actor on shifting to LA. “Moving was a huge cultural shift for me as I have lived all my life in India. I have built my career bit by bit in Mumbai. It took me 20 years, without a Godfather to establish myself as an actor. I really struggled for seven years to get my first show Kkusum that gave me recognition. All of a sudden I left everything and now I am in LA, it’s a different set of people. It is more of a system driven country contrary to India which is people driven. In India we take each other’s help, we talk to each other. In US the system is in place for everyone, which has to be followed by everyone. There you don’t depend on people to get things done. This is a huge change,” he says.The actor who is both in production and acting says, “Acting is my first love but right now I am producing and acting both. To set up my production house along with my wife Vineesha, was not an easy task. At the moment we are working on a feature film and a finite series for OTT platform. Doing both these things, to set up everything up in the Mecca of entertainment, which is LA, needed gigantic efforts. I am happy we are doing well. The film is titled Tiger Heart and we have roped in director Dwight H Little , known for films like Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid, Free Willy 2: The Adventure Home for this. We are in the final stages of closing the names of the lead actors of the film who are very promising Hollywood stars. The entire film will be shot in India, the shooting of the film will begin in October-November this year.”

Title: More than 25 films registered with words ‘Section’ & ‘Article’ in titles
Content: 'Section' and 'Article' seem to be the new favourite words in film titles as producers are making a beeline at the production association offices to register the titles of their films. Last year, after the central government revoked Article 370 (which granted Jammu and Kashmir special status), the associations received multiple applications for titles with Article 370 as well as Article 35 A, and Dhara 370 in them. An official of Indian Film and TV Producers Council (IFTPC) says, "Those titles which are registered with us are Section 364, Section 376, Section 302, Section 420, Section 484, Section 424, Article 14, Article 370, Article 35A, Dhara 370."An official of the Indian Motion Picture Producers' Association (IMPPA), says, "IMPPA has received around 20 applications for the title of films which include the words 'Article', 'Dhara', 'Section' in them. As the films Article 15 and Section 375 created quite a buzz, many producers are also interested in having these words in the titles. A committee will look into the plot and other aspects of the films and then decide who should be granted the titles."A source from the Indian Film & Television Directors' Association (IFTDA), says, "We've registered 15 titles with 'Section' and 'Article' in them for feature films. We also have several other applications for titles including Citizenship (Amendment) Act in them." Gautam Chintamani , a film historian says, "It's not surprising that filmmakers are making a beeline for these titles because filmmakers and audience both find movies with such titles intriguing. Also, titles with 'Section' or 'Article' are good for social media campaigns – in forming hashtags and get the film trending, making it topical. Article 15 should get the credit of coming up with the title first."While film experts now praise the film Article 15 for its title, director Anubhav Sinha says that his judgment was questioned when people from the film industry first heard about the title of his film. Speaking at a session in Delhi, he said, "When I named my film Article 15, people in the industry were wondering, 'What kind of a name is this for a film?' But that film did more business than many big budget movies and what's more important is that the title Article 15 struck an emotional chord with the audience."Ajay Bahl, director of the film Section 375, adds, "When Manish Gupta wrote the film, he titled it Section 375 because that was the story (based on Section 375 of Indian Penal Code ) , and it made perfect sense. But honestly, I thought that we should use another title instead. But we couldn’t come up with anything better than this for this film, so we kept it. And it worked."Pointing out how Bollywood has the habit of following trends, Gautam Chintamani, says, "Knowing the Bombay film industry, it's likely that producers will tell the writers to just go through the Constitution and see on which Article/Section a film's title can be based!"There are several film producers' associations and to avoid duplication of titles, all these associations cross-check with each other before registering the film titles.

Title: Want to know the connection between Mumbai’s water fountain and Napoleon?
Content: Mumbai city is a veritable treasure house of history, especially South Mumbai with its buildings and monuments that are architectural proofs to the time gone by. Numerous heritage walks are conducted at this place as it’s an open air museum for history buffs, photographers and artists. One such walk, being conducted as part of The Kala Ghoda Arts Festival, in association with The Times Of India, has a group of Mumbaikars wanting to change the general belief that history is only about iconic structures. Passionate about the city, they want city dwellers and tourists to reacquaint themselves with the City That Never Sleeps, create an awareness about its history and heritage and archive and conserve it. Dr Preeti Kelkar and Dr Mirgank Warrier, who conducted the Wodehouse Walk, had their group gawking and gasping in surprise as they names-dropped names as varied as the French autocrat Napoleon Bonaparte to Indian cinema’s first shero, Fearless Nadia in connection with this city. "I’ve passed these structures so many times but never knew the history behind it. This walk gives you a perspective and you get to know the importance of these structures and how they came to be," said Puneet, an art and history lover, who participated in the walk.Built in 1865, the Wellington Fountain in South Bombay is nearly 155 years-old. But did you know that it was the defeat of the French emperor Napoleon Bonaparte in the Battle of Waterloo in 1815 that led to the construction of the fountain? Dr Preeti shares, “Napoleon Bonaparte was admired as a great military leader as he never lost a battle, except the battle of Waterloo. This was a historical moment for the British as he was defeated by the Duke of Wellington, Arthur Wellesley. They built Wellington Fountain to honour him.”They say history is written by the victor, however, it’s also subject to people’s interpretations, and a lot of it is also lost in translation. To understand Mumbai, which was known as Bombay then, you need to go back to how the city has evolved. Dr Preeti explains, “Initially, the East India Company came looking at earning revenue and encouraged traders from all over to settle here in exchange for that. They also promised religious tolerance.” Dr Mirgank adds that since Hindus were afraid to lose their caste by crossing the sea, they chose to live in places like Girgaum, while Muslims settled in places like Dongri. You can also get a glimpse of Mumbai in the 1700s at an ongoing exhibit, showcasing paintings by James Wales juxtaposed against photographs taken in the same locations now.1. The Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj Vastu Sangrahalaya, formerly known as the Prince of Wales Museum, functioned as a temporary hospital during the First World War to nurse British and Indian troops.2. Schoen House was once a home to Mary Ann Evans and her husband, filmmaker Homi Wadia. Popular as Fearless Nadia and Hunterwali, India’s first stuntwoman, went on to star in many action films made by Wadia.3. Colaba’s Rafia Manzil, now a Naval accommodation, was originally owned by former Pakistan prime minister, late Zulfikar Ali Bhutto.

Title: Kashmir News: After 6 months’ detention, Omar Abdullah, Mehbooba Mufti booked under Public Safety Act
Content:
File photo

SRINAGAR: In a clear demonstration of its tough intent, the Union Territory administration on Thursday invoked the Public Safety Act ( PSA ) to extend the detention of former CMs Omar Abdullah and Mehbooba Mufti along with NC general secretary Ali Muhammad Sagar and senior PDP functionary Sartaj Madani.The move came amid strong demands from the opposition for the freeing of the former CMs. Highly placed sources said Srinagar deputy commissioner and district magistrate Shahid Iqbal Chowdhary signed the police dossiers on Omar and Mehbooba as part of the procedure to detain them for another three months under the PSA. In August, the same law had been invoked to put Omar’s father Farooq Abdullah , also a former CM, un der house arrest in his private Gupkar Road residence.The decision to detain Omar and Mehbooba under the PSA “to prevent breach of peace” was taken at a meeting between the police brass and chief secretary BVR Subrahmanyam. It means that all three former CMs of J&K are now detained under PSA.Both Omar and Mehbooba have been in detention since August 5, when the Centre tabled a bill in Parliament to nullify Articles 370 and 35A of the Constitution and revoke J&K’s special status. In the months since, several foreign governments have urged the Centre to release all political prisoners.Omar and Mehbooba had earlier been detained under Section 107 of the CrPC. Following completion of six months’ detention, continuing to hold them under the same law would have become untenable, though they could have been detained again after going through the motions of “releasing” them.Instead, authorities decided to invoke the PSA. Earlier in the day, Sagar and Madani, who is Mehbooba’s maternal uncle, were moved from the MLA Hostel here to a guesthouse that has been converted into a sub-jail. Madani’s detention under the PSA was approved by the district magistrate of Kulgam on the basis of a police dossier stating that “he played a vital role in mobilising anti-social elements in the Valley” in the aftermath of the 2009 Asiya and Neelofar rape-murder case in Shopian.The dossier also accuses him of “provoking people to come onto the streets and actively support separatists, and propagate secession of J&K from the Union of India, especially after Afzal Guru’s hanging”. In Sagar’s case, the dossier submitted by the police to the district magistrate of Srinagar states that “he was very vocal” against the nullification of Articles 370 and 35A and had “instigated” people to protest against it.“His capacity to disturb public order can be gauged from the fact that he succeeded in mobilising voters in the peak of militancy for poll boycotts,” the dossier reads. Bashir Ahmad Veeri, another NC leader and former MLC in detention for over six months, was on Thursday taken from the MLA Hostel to his official residence in Srinagar’s Jawahar Nagar and put under house arrest.In the past 24 hours, he is the third political functionary to be moved from preventive detention to house arrest.

Title: Google Maps marks 15th anniversary with new features, fresh look
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

NEW DELHI: Google Maps is completing its 15th anniversary and the tech giant is marking the occasion with a brand new look for its landmark navigation app and key product updates to enhance user experience.

"Starting today, you'll see an updated Google Maps app for Android and iOS that gives you everything you need at your fingertips with five easy-to-access tabs: Explore, Commute, Saved, Contribute and Updates," Vice President (Product) of Google Maps Dane Glasgow said in a statement.

The redesigned look will have a "Contribute" tab at the bottom that will allow users to share local knowledge, such as details about roads and addresses, missing places, business reviews and photos, the search giant said.

The "commute" tab on the app will be tuned further to user needs to help them get from point A to point B more efficiently, the company said.

A new "updates" tab will showcase "must-see" spots that are recommended by local experts and publishers aside from letting users chat with businesses to get answers to questions.

Google said it has also added new transit features in the app to help users plan their travel better. For instance, public transport commuters can now access details such as the temperature inside a bus or train, accommodation for people with disabilities, designated areas for women and whether there is security on board.

Talking about the India-specific features, senior vice-president of Google Maps Jen Fitzpatrick told reporters that they have introduced several updates that were directly inspired by markets like India.

She said that India has contributed significantly when it comes to the improvement of Google Maps by offering inspiration to numerous innovations.

For instance, the public transport tab on Google Maps for Android now informs users about a journey that combines auto-rickshaw and public transport and indicates how much time it will take, and which station they should take an auto-rickshaw to/from.

The feature, which is currently available in Delhi and Bengaluru, will soon be rolled out in several other cities.

Glasgow said the company plans to roll out the new features globally starting March.

He said the new Google Maps icon will reflect the evolution it has made by mapping the world.

Once solid-red "pins" pointing out map locations is now made up of the four colors used in other Google logos.

Title: India eyes Chabahar Port, more air corridors to boost central Asia link
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PTI photo

NEW DELHI: Chabahar port and more air corridors could overcome the problem of direct connectivity between India and the five central Asian countries, foreign minister S Jaishankar said on Thursday.

Launching the India Central Asia business council, Jaishankar said India would host the second India Central Asia Dialogue this year, which would include Afghanistan along with five central Asian countries. Emphasising their importance, Jaishankar said, “As developing countries, we share common perspectives and... we also work together to meet common challenges such as terrorism, extremism, radicalisation, drug trafficking etc. which affect our region.”

As Afghanistan moves to wards a peace process with the Taliban and an uncertain future post the US drawdown, India reckons that its synergies in the security sphere with these states would be that much more.

“Clearly, a great potential exists in enhancing trade and economic engagement between India and central Asia. There is the challenge of lack of efficient overland connectivity. India proposes to overcome this challenge through the Chabahar route.” The Centre’s budget allocated an additional Rs 100 crore to develop the port.

“We had discussed with Mr Javad Zarif (Iranian foreign minister) how to make the Chabahar port commercially more attractive. I think both sides will take some additional measures to make the port more relevant to the current traffic... This is part of our larger commitment to the International North South Transport Corridor and the Ashgabat Agreement . The combination of all these factors could be a partial game changer for our trade with central Asia.”

The minister said “we should also examine the viability of establishing air corridors between India and the central Asian states”. “Availability of air corridors can boost trade in perishable goods, agricultural and food product.”

Title: New retail loans set to get cheaper as RBI tweaks CRR
Content:
ANI photo

MUMBAI: Loans for housing, auto and small businesses are likely to get cheaper even without the Reserve Bank of India's (RBI's) monetary policy committee reducing interest rates.RBI governor Shatikanta Das on Thursday took some unconventional steps to bring down borrowing costs.In his last monetary policy for the current financial year, Das said RBI would provide cheap long-term financing to banks for up to Rs 1 lakh crore through long-term (one-year to three-year) repos. He also said cash reserve requirements would be waived on deposits that are used to provide retail loans between January 21, 2020 and July 31, 2020. This will make housing, auto and SME loans cheaper as 4% of deposits impounded in cash reserves will be freed.The third measure announced to bring down cost of loans was benchmarking loans to medium-sized enterprises to RBI's repo rate (the rate at which RBI lends to banks). The measures were received positively by the markets, with shares of banks, housing finance and real estate companies rallying sharply.The rupee and bond markets also registered gains.SBI chairman Rajnish Kumar said while the decision to hold policy rates was universally anticipated, the bouquet of developmental and regulatory steps was a positive surprise to the financial ecosystem. Bankers said the measures were clearly aimed at bringing down the cost of borrowing even though the six-member MPC voted to retain RBI's repo rate at a 10-year low of 5.15%.In Video: Repo rate remains unchanged at 5.15%: RBI

Title: Bodos ready to welcome PM Modi; Ulfa sets talks terms
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

File photo

GUWAHATI: On the eve of Prime Minister Narendra Modi's visit to Assam , Ulfa (Independent) chief Paresh Baruah said on Thursday that he was ready to hold peace talks with the Centre if the PM agreed to discuss his organisation's demand for "sovereignty".

The state government, as announced earlier by finance minister Himanta Biswa Sarma , is expected to raise the Ulfa (I) issue with Modi on Friday in Kokrajhar where the PM will be attending a thanksgiving rally organised by the Bodos to commemorate the signing of the Bodo accord last month.

Earthern lamps lining the streets and in front of homes have lit up Kokrajhar, about 220 km from Guwahati, to welcome Modi. The PM will arrive at Kokrajhar by noon on Friday. It will be his first visit to Assam after the anti-CAA protests exploded in the state.

Modi tweeted, "Tomorrow, I look forward to being in Assam. I will be in Kokrajhar to address a public meeting. We will mark the successful signing of the Bodo Accord, which brings to an end a problem that had been persisting for decades. It marks the start of a new era of peace and progress."

The Assam government has declared a public holiday in the Bodo autonomous area on Friday to enable people to hear Modi.

Northeast Frontier Railway is running four special trains from different locations to Kokrajhar ferrying participants. Talking to TOI from an undisclosed location, Baruah the militant leader said, "Assam minister Himanta Biswa Sarma recently told the media that the government of India will examine if a democratically elected government can sit for discussions on the issue of sovereignty and he has been courteous enough.

Baruah, 63, who is believed to be holed up in China now, told TOI, "If Modi is determined, all we need from him is a written assurance that only sovereignty will be discussed and we will come for talks. We will hold the discussions in Assam, and not on foreign soil. The PM should think about India's and Assam's good."

Title: Right to internet not fundamental, services can be cut, says govt
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

File photo

NEW DELHI: Union law and communication minister Ravi Shankar Prasad justified snapping of internet services for maintaining law and order and national security on Thursday, while saying that the right to internet is not fundamental. He said the right to expression is subject to reasonable restrictions as provided in the Constitution.

Responding to a question whether internet is a fundamental right based on a recent Supreme Court observation, Prasad said there is a misconception that needs to be cleared. He said that the decision to stop internet services is taken by the local authorities taking into consideration the law and order situation.

Though he did not specify how many times such measures have been taken, sources said there were over 700 such instances since 2017. Only in one case, Centre had stopped internet services in Delhi as the Centre is responsible for law and order in the UT.

Sources said internet services were snapped across several states including Maharashtra , West Bengal , Gujarat, Punjab, north-eastern states, the erstwhile state of J&K, and Uttar Pradesh.

During the Question Hour in Rajya Sabha, Prasad said that communication of ideas and opinions through the internet is part of the fundamental right to speech and expressions. "The SC has stated that no lawyer argued that right to the internet is a fundamental right. What the top court has commented is that for communication of your ideas and opinions, the use of the internet will also be holding a part of your fundamental right of speech and expression," Prasad said. He said no one can deny the abuse of the internet for spreading violence and terrorism, and Pakistan has been doing it in Kashmir .

"Once the SC has announced that the use of the internet to propagate one's opinion and ideas will be held to be fundamental rights and I will like to flag...this will also be subject to reasonable restrictions...for public order, security and integrity of India," he added.

Title: Narendra Modi: A few hours earlier, PM Modi had slammed ‘unacceptable’ remarks by J&K ex-CMs
Content:
PTI photo

NEW DELHI: “There have been statements made by former Jammu & Kashmir chief ministers that are not acceptable to us and should bother anyone raising issues relating to the Constitution,” Prime Minister Narendra Modi said in Parliament on Thursday while replying to the debate on the motion of thanks to the President’s address.Hours before former CMs Mehbooba Mufti and Omar Abdullah were booked under the Public Safety Act at the end of their six-month detention, Modi quoted Mufti as having said, “Humne jis desh ke saath rahne ka faisla kiya, us ne dhokha kiya hai... aisa lagta hai humne 1947 mein galat chunav kiya tha (The country with which we decided to stay has betrayed us, it seems we made a wrong choice in 1947).”He then added, “How can someone endorse such a statement... has the Constitution deceived her?” He criticised the former CMs for remarks on scrapping the state’s special status.Asserting that Kashmir was the “crown jewel” of India, Prime Minister Narendra Modi said, “My government has pushed development in Jammu & Kashmir. We had faith in the people of the Valley but the leaders in the state didn’t have.”Modi said Kashmir’s identity was buried on January 19, 1990 when Kashmiri Pandits started leaving the Valley due to militancy. He said Ladakh would be developed as a carbon-neutral Union territory. Modi also said those opposing the Citizenship (Amendment) Act that seeks to provide Indian citizenship to minorities from Pakistan, Afghanistan and Bangladesh were hand in glove with the “tukde-tukde” gang.“What Pakistan has been trying for decades, a hypothetical fear is being created by Congress... Those opposing the law are seen being clicked with the tukde-tukde gang,” the PM said. In lengthy interventions in the Lok Sabha and the Rajya Sabha, the PM countered the charge that the government is “dividing” the country with CAA, quoting Jawaharlal Nehru and Lal Bahadur Shastri to argue that a special dispensation for nonMuslims from Pakistan was acknowledged by the Congress icons.“Was Nehru communal? Did he discriminate between Hindus and Muslims? Did he want a Hindu rashtra?” he asked. Modi said Congress’s opposition to the CAA was opportunistic and driven by “vote-bank politics”. He asked Congress if its members could be labelled “communal” for voicing concern over problems faced by minorities in Pakistan. “Why did Nehru not include all citizens but mention only religious minorities in the Nehru-Liaquat agreement,” Modi asked, and said his government was doing what India’s first PM had said decades ago.He asserted that several reports, including those of parliamentary panels, had recommended a law like the CAA. He, however, was critical of Nehru when he said, “There is nothing wrong in having the ambition to be Prime Minister. But there was a time when because of one person’s ambition to be PM, a line was drawn that caused the Partition of India.”The PM said Congress would always choose votebank politics to development and asked if it was unable to relate to the pain suffered by persecuted minorities in the neighbourhood. He recalled Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan’s remark that extremist elements may have infiltrated anti-CAA protests. Modi said if the government had followed its predecessor’s footsteps, it would never have been able to undo Article 370, pass the Enemy Property Act and bring CAA. In a strong defence of CAA and the National Population Register, he referred to Nehru’s letter to Assam’s first CM, Gopinath Bordoloi, asking him to distinguish between Hindu refugees and Muslim migrants from Pakistan.Modi said Nehru noted that if required, the law should be amended to grant citizenship to the refugees. In the Rajya Sabha, Modi said NPR was being updated to allow rightful beneficiaries the benefit of government welfare schemes. He said NPR was first done in 2010 and updated in 2015.“Don’t try to mislead people,” he said, asking opposition parties to not “politicise the issue”. “They are opposing (NPR) for narrow and frivolous political narrative. This is antipoor,” he said, adding his government had made productive use of data collected by the previous NPR to deliver benefits to the poor. While talking of the CAA, Modi cited the examples of Bhupendra Kumar Dutta and Jogendra Nath Mandal, two freedom fighters who stayed back in Pakistan after Partition but came to India in the face of the persecution of minorities.“Both Dutta and Mandal came to India and died here,” he said and added, “Mandal was the first law minister of Pakistan and he too flagged systematic ethnic targeting of religious minorities in Pakistan.” The PM said in his youth, he had touched the feet of Khan Abdul Ghaffar Khan (popularly called Frontier Gandhi) and named other greats such as Ashfaqullah Khan, Begum Hazrat Mahal and A P J Abdul Kalam to assert that they were all Indians. Referring to the continuing protests, Modi warned street agitations against decisions of Parliament and state assemblies may lead to “anarchy” and should worry everyone.He pointedly reiterated that the CAA does not affect any Indian citizen and poses no harm to minorities. “What would happen if the decisions of the Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh assembly were opposed?” he asked. On NPR questions which have generated a controversy, Modi said this was more a governance and administrative issue and there was no sinister agenda behind it. “Since there is a lot of migration happening these days, it’s important for the government to be more aware,” he said.The PM quoted socialist leader R M Lohia pledging support for minority communities in the neighbourhood and also recalled a late 1947 Congress Working Committee proposal calling for protection of “non-Muslims” in Pakistan. Modi also mentioned Bhimrao Ambedkar’s call to the Dalit community to come to India from Pakistan.

Title: 'Wadhawan used laundered money for Australia, UK assets'
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Dewan Housing Finance Ltd's chairman Kapil Wadhawan (File photo)

NEW DELHI: In its money laundering probe against Dewan Housing Finance Ltd's chairman Kapil Wadhawan, currently in Enforcement Directorate's (ED's) custody, the agency has unearthed a 12,000 sqm land in Melbourne, Australia, and some other properties allegedly purchased by Wadhawan for Rs 1,000 crore, sources said.

The ED's money trail in the case has unearthed several properties acquired by Wadhawan across the globe, allegedly laundering funds from DHFL. Among assets unearthed so far, the agency has found two flats of the DHFL chairman in New York, a flat and an office space in London, a villa in Koh Samui in Thailand, Hotel Radisson Blu in Pune, Hotel Country Inn in Mysore, four flats in Khar's DB Breeze and a flat in Mumbai's Sea View Palace, another flat in Juhu, a bungalow in Mahabaleshwar, a housing society with 570 flats in Kurla, besides others.

The agency sources said all these properties have been linked to Wadhawan and many of them were acquired using laundered funds from DHFL.

Agency sources said Wadhawan is also being questioned about his high-value transactions with Yes Bank and IndiaBulls from where he had availed huge credits. The accused, booked under Prevention of Money Laundering Act, is also being questioned for his association with one middleman, Sudhakar Setty, with whom he had transactions worth over Rs 2,000 crore, sources said.

Wadhawan was arrested last month by ED officials as the agency claimed he refused to cooperate in its ongoing investigation against dead gangster Iqbal Mirchi. Wadhawan's company Sunblink is allegedly involved in purchasing Mirchi's Mumbai properties and transferring funds to the gangster's associates. The probe is on for which he has been remanded to ED custody by a PMLA court till Friday.

Sources said, the ED probe and money trail in the case has unearthed association of several high-profile Maharashtra politicians with Pakistan-based Dawood Ibrahim.

Title: Works pending, Cantt residents upset over delay in SCB elections
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

SECUNDERABAD: The orders issued by the Ministry of Defence (MoD) over the extension of the term of the existing Secunderabad Cantonment Board (SCB) elected body by another six months has triggered a row among residents of the cantonment areas here.

The orders evoked mixed response from the residents, who have urged the MoD to conduct the SCB elections as per schedule.

“As the tenure of the elected ward members has been extended, they may indulge in corruption, as several development works are pending due to inadequate funds. Now, the board members will mount pressure on the board to obtain clearances for the works so that they get commission,” BK Bhaskar, a resident of Bowenpally, told TOI.

Another resident, V Lakshman Rao of Trimulgherry, said, “The MoD must issue poll notification for the conduct of free and fair elections and development of cantonment areas. In fact, the SCB was recently in the news for ranking among the worst cantonments in the country in terms of sanitation. If new members are elected soon, it may usher in some change.”

Moreover, the extension of the SCB’s tenure is not new to voters. “The Centre did the same previously too. The voters and those deciding to contest the election were mentally prepared for the poll. Rules must be amended so that elections are held as per schedule,” said M Ganapathy Reddy, a retired bank employee.

Meanwhile, a few elected ward members said that the move was upsetting as they had already begun campaigning in their respective civilian wards in anticipation that the MoD will issue the election notification.

“We have no other option but to wait for another six months. There is no guarantee that the MoD will issue election notification even after six months,” said a ward member who began preparations for the poll six months ago. However, another ward member said that the decision gives them more time to get pending proposals cleared and win the elections.

Title: Day 4: Patna sanitation workers continue strike as talks fail
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Group D employees of Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC), mainly sanitation workers, continued their strike for ... Read More

PATNA: Group D employees of Patna Municipal Corporation ( PMC ), mainly sanitation workers , continued their strike for the fourth day on Thursday.

With garbage and carcass of animals lying on the roads, the city virtually turned into a dumping yard. Thousands of sanitation workers remained off duty and sat on dharna at PMC headquarters at Maurya Lok here.

Police personnel were deployed at Maurya Lok for the first time since the strike started on Monday. An FIR was also lodged against six union leaders and workers at Kotwali police station on Tuesday for creating hindrance in carrying out government’s work, inciting the workers and hanging the carcass of an animal outside PMC office at Maurya Lok.

People against on whom FIR was lodged included Patna Nagar Nigam Staff union president Chandra Prakash, PMC fourth grade union general secretary Nand Kishor Das, Rairatan Prasad, Neeraj Kumar, Arjun Prasad and Satish Mishra.

The agitating sanitation workers did not call off their strike even after their representatives had a meeting with urban development and housing department (UDHD) minister Suresh Kumar Sharma and senior officials of the department on Thursday.

Even though Patna Nagar Nigam Staff union president Chandra Prakash said their meeting with the minister and officials was positive, he denied calling off the strike. “UDHD officials said the department is bound to adhere to the order of Lokyukta and cannot accept our demand of continuing the service of daily wage workers. Hence, we will continue our strike and move Patna high court on Friday,” Prakash added.

Incidentally, the UDHD has asked all urban local bodies (ULBs) to outsource the service of Group D workers and end the services of daily wage sanitation workers of PMC from March 31.

Councillor of ward number 69 Vikas Kumar alias Vicky Maurya, who is also a member of empowered standing committee of PMC, said, “The meeting with UDHD minister and officials was not much fruitful as the department is not taking this matter seriously. Being a public representative, we are facing the wrath of residents as well as the sanitation workers. If the government fails to intervene immediately, diseases might spread in the city.”

UDHD secretary Anand Kishor said the agitating workers were assured that their important demands would be fulfilled soon. “District magistrates have been asked to ensure removal of garbage on a war footing and take help of workers of private agencies,” Kishor added.

“Garbage removal work has started in many localities of Patna and the results will be visible from Friday. Of around 30 ULBs where sanitation workers are on strike, work has resumed in 14,” Kishor said.

Currently, around 2,200 sanitation workers are employed with the PMC through outsourcing. Around 4,300 are daily-wage sanitation workers and 1,100 are permanent group D employees.

Many sanitation workers of outsourcing agencies have also extended moral support to the strike, citing exploitation by the private companies and delay in their payment.

One such worker of a private outsourcing agency, said, “Our condition is even worse than permanent daily-wage workers of PMC. They are at least paid every month. We have not got a penny from our agency for past five months. Being a graduate, I get Rs 9,150 and the agency claims that it deducts some amount as my provident fund (PF). However there is no proof of PF as I never got any salary slip. Hence, we do not want others to face this situation.”

Title: Cognizant’s 4.2% growth in Q4 beats expectations
Content:
(File photo)

CHENNAI: Cognizant ’s revenue in constant currency increased by 4.2% year-on-year in the quarter ended December. This was better than investor and analyst expectations, leading to an 8% surge in its share price in morning trade on the Nasdaq.The company, which for years was the fastest growing among the India-heritage IT services companies, slowed sharply in the past two years. The performance in the latest quarter was significantly weaker than those of HCL, Infosys and TCS. But the growth is being viewed as the likely beginning of a turnaround.New CEO Brian Humphries has been taking steps to re-energise the company, putting sharper focus on growing markets beyond the US, on new digital technologies, on restructuring the workforce to cater to these emerging requirements, and on providing sales staff with greater incentives.“Our steady progress against key initiatives is increasingly evident in our commercial and financial performance,” said Humphries. “We enter 2020 with renewed vigour and optimism.”Cognizant said it expected current-quarter revenue to grow at 2.8% to 3.8% in constant currency, and the full-year 2020 revenue to be between 2% and 4% in constant currency (the company follows a January-December financial calendar). The full-year forecast includes the estimate of a negative 110 bps impact from the exit of certain content services business, which the company announced in October. A like-for-like comparison will imply higher growth rates.While revenue in Q4 was up at $4.3 billion, net income dropped 40% to $395 million, from $648 million in the year-ago quarter, because of restructuring costs, including severance charges related to those being asked to leave the company. The company announced a 10% increase to its quarterly cash dividend. “Our operating performance and strong free cash flows in the fourth quarter reflect the actions taken throughout 2019 to improve our cost structure and instill greater operating discipline across the company,” said CFO Karen McLoughlin in a statement.In the quarter, the poorly performing financial services segment, which contributed 34.3% of revenues, looked to be recovering, primarily driven by insurance.Analysts said the company is recovering from a slump. Phil Fersht, CEO of HfS Research, said, “Cognizant is recovering from its first financial wobble over the past couple of years and is being cautious as the business stabilises and it beds in a host of new leaders it has hired (and is hiring) and reinvents its value. Humphries is driving an aggressive agenda to energise the firm’s culture and attack the market with a refocused approach to digital transformation.”

Title: Ayodhya trust announcement has no link with Delhi polls: Swatantra Dev Singh
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

BJP state chief Swatantra Dev Singh coming out of Kaal Bhairo temple on Thursday morning

VARANASI: Bharatiya Janata Party state chief Swatantra Dev Singh targeted the Opposition parties for questioning the timing of announcement of trust formation for constructing temple at Ramjanmabhoomi in Ayodhya and said that the announcement has no connection with the Delhi elections.

During a brief chat with reporters here on Thursday, Singh said that PM Narendra Modi never waits for taking major decisions whether it is abrogation of article 370 or formation of a trust in view of the Supreme Court’s directive for the construction of Ram temple in Ayodhya.

Targeting the Samajwadi Party and Bahujan Samaj Party, Singh said that instead of taunting the government on law and order, the SP and the BSP should review themselves to find out why they failed to retain power in the state. he accused them of promoting goonda elements and discrimination on basis of caste and region.

Before leaving the city for Sonbhadra, Singh offered prayers at Kashi Vishwanath and Kaal Bhairo temples. He also met party workers and office bearers in the district.

Title: Form panel to suggest ways for renovation of Mundeshwari temple: Patna high court
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: The Patna high court on Thursday ordered formation of a committee headed by principal secretary of art, culture and youth affairs department to chalk out plans for preservation and renovation of Mundeshwari temple atop Kaimur hills and submit a report on it within five weeks.

Bihar Religious Trust Board (BRTB) president, Archaeological Survey of India’s regional head and Kaimur district magistrate would also be a member of the committee headed by principal secretary, who has also been made a respondent in the case. The matter will come up for hearing again on March 16 when the committee will have to submit its report.

The temple, constructed in 108AD, is considered as oldest living temple in country.

One Gaurav Kumar Singh had filed a PIL in high court, urging it to direct the officials concerned to take steps for protection and preservation of temple and its deities, construction of boundary wall, deployment of CISF for security and development of the area as a pilgrimage and tourist spot.

A division bench of Chief Justice Sanjay Karol and Justice Mohit Kumar Shah passed the order after petitioner’s counsel Sumeet Kumar Singh claimed that there was lack of coordination between separate wings of the state government on the matter.

Senior advocate Ganpati Trivedi, who appeared for BRTB, informed the court that the board was ready to reconstruct the temple if given the responsibility. However, additional solicitor general S D Sanjay, appearing for ASI, submitted that it was a protected monument and construction cannot be made by any entity.

HC lawyers may refrain from work: The coordination committee of all three associations of lawyers in Patna high court on Thursday once again passed a resolution, urging the lawyers to refrain from work on Friday and Monday over alleged problems arising out of the listing pattern of the case. The committee will against hold a meeting on Monday to decide its further course of action. Committee chairman Yogesh Chandra Verma said that there was massive resentment among lawyers over the issue of case listing pattern.

Title: Bihar: Woman among 4 held in murder case
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: Police on Thursday arrested four people, including one Rakhi Devi (26), her husband Randhir Singh (28) and her alleged paramour Gopal Kumar (22), in connection with the murder of a 22-year-old youth. The victim was cousin brother-in-law of Rakhi with whom also she allegedly had an illicit relation.

The deceased was identified as Rahul, a resident of Sikandarpur village under the Punpun police station area in eastern Patna. Rahul was shot dead at a secluded place at Jolbigha village under the same police station area on January 31 when he was returning after meeting Rakhi from Walidad village in Alwar district.

Police said it was Gopal who had shot Rahul in head using a country-made pistol which was later recovered from the spot.

The fourth arrested person was one Atal Bharti alias Sunil Kumar (20), who was present at the spot with Gopal when the incident occurred.

City SP (east) Jitendra Kumar said Rakhi and Randhir were arrested as they kept mum despite knowing about the murder plot.

Body found: Police recovered an unidentified body stuffed in an iron trunk from Tulsi Mandi at Gulzarbagh under the Alamganj police station area on the intervening night of Wednesday and Thursday. Patna City SDPO Manish Kumar said, “We have begun an inquiry into the case.”

Title: Surat: Income tax department starts probe into Rs 135 crore cash deals of realty firm
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

SURAT: Income tax department has started investigation against a real estate firm in connection with Rs135 crore cash transactions in its projects across the city.

The I-T department has sought details of the cash transactions and property documents seized by Directorate General of GST Intelligence (DGGI) from the real estate firm for GST evasion to the tune of Rs18 crore.

The DGGI’s Surat regional unit had arrested a real estate developer from the city for evading GST payments to the tune of Rs18 crore on Tuesday. The accused was presented before Surat district and sessions court which sent him to judicial custody for 14 days.

The officials had conducted searches at various locations in the city owned by Raj Mahal Developers , a partnership firm engaged in construction of commercial projects and shopping malls in November 2019. The DGGI sleuths had received intelligence that the firm was indulging in GST evasion on a huge scale.

Sources said the officials had recovered many incriminating documents, including dairies relating to investments and cash received from their clients after sale of various projects to them in the city.

The partner of the firm had admitted to cash receipts of more than Rs135 crore on which more than Rs16 crore of GST was not paid. In addition, he had also not paid GST of more than Rs2.8 crore from April 2018 onwards on cheque components of sale proceeds.

I-T department sources said the real estate firm has done cash dealings worth Rs135 crore and that the realtor did not pay tax to the government and also evaded GST. Details of cash receipts and other documents have been sought from DGGI for further investigation.

Title: Surat: Samples of third patient sent for tests
Content:
A 33-year-old Adajan resident has been admitted to NCH.

SURAT: Samples of one more patient who complained of chronic cough and cold in the city were sent for tests at National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune on Thursday. A 33-year-old Adajan resident has been admitted to New Civil Hospital (NCH).Results of the two other patients — a 41-year-old Varachha resident and the 21-year-old MBBS girl student from Puna area — are likely to come in a couple of days. Meanwhile, they are admitted in the isolation ward of the SMIMER hospital.The patient approached the NCH on his own, and he was not under observation of the health department of the Surat Municipal Corporation ( SMC ). According to the procedure, local health officials are supposed to keep a traveller, who has returned from China recently, under observation for 14 days.The SMC’s health department was not provided name and details of the patient by the central government to keep him under medical observation. So far, the state and city health officials claimed that they were keeping a watch on all the individual who had returned from China.“The man was not in our list and we were not examining him on daily basis. He approached the NCH on his own since he noticed symptoms similar to the infection,” said an health official from the SMC.Inquiry by the health officials revealed that the man did not return to the city directly from China, but he had gone to Cambodia and then arrived in India. He returned on January 21, and since his health did not improve, he approached the NCH on Thursday.“Since the man did not come directly from China it was not in the list provided by the central government. There are many passengers who go to some other country from China and later come to India. The patients’ travel history to China can be known only if the patients themselves contact the health officials and provide the actual travel history,” said a health official.The SMC’s health department has already issued instructions to doctors and hospital to issue an alert, if a patient informs about his travel to a coronavirus affected country. Apart from isolation wards in the NCH and SMIMER, the SMC has instructed some top private hospitals to keep isolation wards ready if needed in the time of emergency.

Title: Bihar: Hundreds bid adieu to martyred CRPF jawan
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

CRPF officers lay a wreath on the coffin of martyred CRPF jawan Ramesh Ranjan at Patna airport.

PATNA/ARA: With moist eyes and a heavy heart, hundreds of people bade farewell to martyred CRPF jawan , Ramesh Ranjan (30), who was killed in a gunbattle with militants on the outskirts of Srinagar on Wednesday. His mortal remains were consigned to flames at Isadhi Dev Tola, his native village under Jagdishpur block in Bhojpur district, with full state honours on Thursday.

Governor Phagu Chauhan and chief minister Nitish Kumar expressed their grief over the death of Ranjan and said in their condolence messages that the people of the state would always remember the valour and bravery of the son of the soil. State transport minister Santosh Kumar Nirala was also present at the funeral of the departed jawan in his native village.

Wails and cries of family members and close relatives rent the air when the slain jawan’s body reached the village from the Patna airport in a truck. His wife, Baby Devi, and mother, Sumitra Devi, paid tributes to him before the body draped in the national flag was taken for the last rites to an agricultural field near his ancestral house.

Talking to mediapersons, Ranjan’s father, Radhamohan Singh, a retired sub-inspector of police, said, “We do not need any compensation. Awarding the Param Vir Chakra to my son will be a real tribute to him for the supreme sacrifice that he made at the altar of the nation. A gate should also be constructed at our village in his memory.”

Singh had talked to Ranjan around 5pm on Tuesday. “Everything was fine. He had promised to come home either on Holi or after the festival, but destiny had something else in store for him and us. I am proud of my son, who sacrificed his life for the sake of the country,” the slain jawan’s father said.

Ranjan, the youngest of four siblings, had married Baby in 2016, but the couple has no children. He joined the CRPF’s 73rd battalion in 2011 and got his first posting in Odisha’s Sambalpur district.

“I am more concerned about Ranjan’s wife because she is too young to know the harsh reality of the world,” a close relative rued.

Earlier, a number of VIPs, including road construction minister Nand Kishor Yadav, additional chief secretary Amir Subhani, DGP Gupteshwar Pandey, Patna DM Kumar Ravi, former Union minister Kanti Singh, state Congress president Madan Mohan Jha and several senior officials of the CRPF paid floral tributes to the martyred jawan when his body landed at the Patna airport from Jammu in the morning. People shouted slogans like ‘Bharat Maata Ki Jai’ and ‘Veer Saput Amar Rahe’.

The Bihar police were embarrassed after rifles fell ‘silent’ during the funeral of martyred CRPF jawan , Ramesh Ranjan, at his native village in Bhojpur district on Thursday. Eyewitnesses said only two guns fired bullets while others fell silent on the occasion. A similar scene was witnessed during the last rites of former chief minister Jagannath Mishra in Supaul district last year.

Title: ‘Treat sanitation workers with respect’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020
