Nashik: Mukesh Sarwan, chairman of Safai Karmachari Aayog, has said that sanitation workers are often neglected, therefore, government establishments and officials must ensure that they are treated with respect .

Sarwan, who was on a one-day visit to the city, conducted a meeting of various government institutions, including local civic bodies, municipal councils, Mahatma Phule Vikas Mahamandal and others, to get first-hand information about state of sanitation workers. The meeting was held at the district collectorate office.

He asked the officials to ensure that the problems faced by sanitation workers were resolved at the earliest. Sarwan also took review of the recommendations about the Lad-Page committee and asked the officials to ensure that all the recommendations were implemented within the next 30 days.

Title: After battling controversies, SVNIT now on a makeover mission
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Existing two common classroom buildings will be demolished to build two multi-storey classroom complexes

Surat: Sardar Vallabhbhai National Institute of Technology, which has been grappling with controversies and financial problems for the past five years, is all set for a makeover which aims at providing better facilities to over 4,500 students. The institute will soon be taking up six construction projects on its campus which include a multi-storey administrative building, two classroom complexes , a mega food mess , residential quarters for non-teaching staff and a boys hostel. Currently, top officials of the institute operate from a single storey structure which is not in good condition.

The existing administrative building will be demolished and important administrative offices will be accommodated at one place. The existing two common classroom buildings will be also demolished to build two multi-storey classroom complexes. The classroom complexes are for expert lectures on subjects common in different branches of engineering. The bigger classrooms with seating capacity for over 200 students will make it convenient for teachers, who now have to teach in small groups in different departments.

The mega food mess is a new concept in the institute which has separate messes in eight hostels. “Students have to go to their respective hostels which are at the other end for lunch. Now, we are developing a common mess for all boy students near the academic area,” said S R Gandhi, director, SVNIT.

“The common mess means good quality food at better rates because the mess operator will be providing food in quantity. Cost on infrastructure will also get reduced,” Gandhi added.

A new hostel for 500 boy students and two residential towers for non-teaching staff are also being built for which Ministry of Human Resource Development is providing grants.

Water harvesting project

A mega water harvesting project is also coming up on the south western border of the institute. “The project is being developed under Jalshakti campaign. The water that used to flow into storm water drainage will be collected on campus now,” S R Gandhi said. At present, the project is at planning level.

Title: Free treatment to survivors, Rs 2L for family of deceased
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Indore: Health minister Tulsi Silawat on Thursday announced free treatment of the four farmers injured in the mob attack in Dhar’s Manawar area.

Silawat visited the survivors — Jagdish Radheshyam Sharma, 45, Vinod Tulsiram Mukati, 43, Ravi Patel, 38, and Jagdish Poonamchand Sharma — at Choithram Hospital, and announced a compensation of Rs 2 lakh to the family of Ganesh, who was killed in the brutal attack. All four are stable in ICU, but they will be under observation for 24 hours because of head injuries, said Dr Amit Bhatt, deputy director medical services at Choithram.

Silawat condemned the violence and assured that every guilty person would be brought to justice. Police have identified around 30 people, and arrested three, he added.

DGP V K Singh, who was in the city on Thursday, said, “It is an unfortunate incident. I appeal to people not to be a part of any violent activity and use their mind before believing any rumour."

Asked about allegations that some policemen were seen standing on the site of the lynching, the DGP said: “Police have a limitation in case of mob attack. But police can’t shy away from their responsibility. We have suspended five policemen, including a sub-inspector, and departmental action will be taken against all responsible for it. However, the people filming and watching the gruesome incident should have also tried to stop it.” Higher education minister Jitu Patwari met the bereaved family of Ganesh and attended his last rites. He then visited the injured in hospital. Congress MLAs Sanjay Shukla and Kunal Choudhary accompanied Patwari. “It is a very shameful incident. The CM has directed police to take stringent action against culprits,” he said.

Sumitra Mahajan in Indore said the incident showed the people were not happy with the police in the Congress-ruled state.

"We have to ponder why our society is losing cool over petty issues and indulging in violence. Common people are dissatisfied with the police," the former Indore MP said.

"This tendency of mob violence is increasing, and it is obviously not a good thing. We have to remain human," she added. TNN

Title: Realty firm in I-T net: Cash, jewellery seized; dozen lockers sealed
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Surat: The investigation wing of income tax department carried out search and seizure operation on a leading real estate group and its partners, brokers and a couple of farmers for tax evasion on Thursday.

About 150 I-T sleuths from Surat, Ahmedabad, Rajkot and Vadodara swooped down at more than 35 locations across the city including the five real estate projects located in Saroli on Puna-Kumbharia road and Sahara Darwaja and residences of the realtors and its partners on Thursday morning.

Sources said that the I-T sleuths recovered Rs 1 crore in cash, jewellery worth Rs 50 lakh and property documents to the tune of over Rs 40 crore during the search and seizure operation.

Official said that the operation also covered about 12 partners of the real estate firm, 15 brokers and three farmers. The farmers and brokers are connected with the real estate group.

Sources said that the real estate firm has constructed more than five textile markets in Saroli on Puna-Kumbharia and other commercial projects in the city’s Vesu, Ghod Dod Road and Majura Gate areas. The firm has recently launched new commercial projects in Saroli, where they are coming up with huge textile markets.

According to the I-T officials, over a dozen bank lockers belonging to the realtors, farmers and the brokers have been sealed. The search operation was till on and it is expected that a huge tax evasion is likely to be unearthed.

Title: Have an issue with boss? Speak up: Cos
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Namrata Singh | TNN

Mumbai: Employees are becoming more vocal in expressing their concerns at the workplace, but the fear of retaliation is still very palpable. What people today seek from their workplace — apart from the usual satisfaction factors that a job provides — is psychological safety. Most organisations have policies to ensure the physical and mental well-being of their employees. Now some are creating a comfort culture for employees to speak up without the fear of retaliation.

In her previous role as a sales manager at a telecom company, Shachi Irde recalls how sales meetings used to be brutal and scathing for those who had failed to meet their targets. Offsites, however, were a time when employees would get back at their boss. They would take up issues with the boss on how the requisite support was not provided to meet targets and, yet, how they were humiliated during sales meetings.

“Offsite time was used by all — right from the junior most to the senior most employee — to give vent to their feelings. It was a time to get the negativity out of our system. The offsite remained a psychologically safe place for me as I knew I could say what was on my mind without the fear of retaliation. The next day was business as usual,” recalls Irde, who is now the chief consulting partner at Interweave, a diversity and inclusion consulting firm.

Organisations are increasingly talking about how a workplace can be a psychologically safe place for employees across levels to speak up if they feel they have been wronged or if they see bad behaviour at work. Schneider Electric enables psychological safety at the workplace through a combination of interventions for physical, mental, social and emotional well-being.

Schneider Electric India director (rewards) Barun Sen said, “An interesting practice that a lot of us have started doing is a ‘well-being’ check — whether it’s at the start of a meeting, a conference call or even a townhall. It’s simple — we put up a slide with a whole lot of emoticons (sad, angry, curious, bored, happy) and ask our teammates to choose the one with which they identify the most. It creates a culture of starting off on a fun note and for the leader of the meeting/session, it’s also an easy pulse check of your teammates. This, according to us, is a very practical way of ensuring psychological safety.”

On the other hand, an anonymous “red line” mechanism for reporting a violation is managed centrally and is meant to assure people that their grievances will be heard and addressed. “If an employee is not allowed to speak up and voice their concerns, Schneider Electric as an organisation will not be able to learn and move ahead. Similarly, if a team member feels ‘heard’ by her/his team and manager, she/he is better able to innovate, to brainstorm and to offer ideas that will ultimately strengthen the organisation,” said Sen.

Experts, however, argue that a workplace is not entirely psychologically safe if an employee feels the need to hide behind anonymity while raising issues. Professional services firm EY has a programme called ‘Counselling Families’, wherein a leader meets his team of 20-30 people once every two months to not only apprise them about the business but also to listen to their queries.

EY India partner and talent leader Sandeep Kohli said, “At Counselling Families, employees are encouraged to speak up on any issue of concern, without the fear of retaliation. Two years since this programme was started, anonymous complaints as a percentage of total strength has come down.”

The second leg of the policy framework is that EY is conducting inclusive leadership workshops in which leaders are sensitised. Then these leaders, in turn, are trained to sensitise managers and senior managers down the line to build a culture where people can openly come up and raise concerns, if any. “The key highlight of our policies is that there cannot be any retaliation if a concern is raised. Since we have initiated frameworks through which we listen to employees and connect with them on a regular basis, we see that the need to use the formal forums is reducing,” said Kohli.

Title: Man who killed wife convicted of culpable homicide
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Vadodara: A sessions court on Thursday sentenced a 37-year-old labourer to five years imprisonment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder. Rohit Chauhan was arrested in 2018 for killing his wife Lalli at their home in Kalali.

Lalli’s mother Sharda Ninama, who is a ragpicker, had filed a complaint against Rohit, who had married Lalli nine years ago. They had six children, three boys and three girls. In August 2018, Lalli wasn’t keeping well so Sharda went to see her daughter at her home. When Sharda reached Lalli’s home, Rohit was present along with his two daughters.

He told Sharda that Lalli was sleeping and requested her not to wake her up. But Sharda tried to wake up Lalli who didn’t respond. She then noticed blood flowing out of Lalli’s nose and some injury on her forehead. When Sharda confronted Rohit, he admitted to have had a fight with Lalli following which he smashed her head on the wall. Lalli’s daughters too told Sharda that there was a fight between their parents the previous night.

The court ruled that the accused committed culpable homicide not amounting to murder and sentenced him to five years of rigorous imprisonment. Rohit has been ordered to pay fine of Rs 10,000 and if he doesn’t pay the fine, he will have to undergo a further one year simple imprisonment. Out of the fine received, Rs 9,000 would be given to Sharda as compensation.

Title: RJD plays quota card to woo EBCs, dalits in Bihar
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

An RJD poster in Patna on Thursday.

PATNA: Apart from its traditional voter base of Muslims and Yadavs, Lalu Prasad-led Rashtriya Janata Dal ( RJD ) is also trying to woo extremely backward caste (EBC) and dalit voters ahead of the assembly elections in the state. It has announced 27% reservation for EBCs and 18% for dalits as far as appointment of district presidents of the party is concerned. The list of 50 district presidents of the party is likely to be released on Friday.

Earlier, the party had made Rajput stalwart Jagdanand Singh its state president to attract upper caste votes. “RJD is the only party in the state to give such reservation to its functionaries. We treat all castes and communities equally,” party spokesperson Chitranjan Gagan said.

Jagdanand said though the new list of district presidents of RJD was initially supposed to be released on Wednesday, it was postponed by two days as leader of opposition in Bihar assembly Tejashwi Prasad Yadav was campaigning for Delhi polls.

Party sources said the new list may not have names of some old war horses of RJD who have served the party for more than two or three terms as district president. “The number of Yadavs and Muslims in the list will come down. However, party will accommodate these netas in other cells,” said an RJD functionary.

Sources said there was uncertainty regarding the retention of party’s Patna district president Devmuni Singh Yadav and Patna Mahanagar president Aftab Alam as well. “After finalizing the names, Laluji sent the list to Tejashwi,” said another RJD functionary.

The party may also announce the names of its 135 state level office-bearers on Friday with representation from different castes. Sources, however, said reservation formula as applied in selection of district president would not be applied in case of office-bearers.

The meeting of RJD’s legislature party members will be held on February 8. It will be followed by the meeting of its new district presidents on February 9 and state office-bearers on February 10.

Title: Mah foresters given no papers on T-19 probe by MP
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nagpur: Madhya Pradesh forest officials investigating the Sharmili (T-19) tigress death case at Khandasa on Maharashtra border , near Deolapar, have refused to share relevant papers related to the investigations with forest officials here.

On February 1, Seoni forest officials had publicly alleged that Deolapar foresters had moved the carcass of Sharmili with the help of a bullock cart to dump it at Khandasa in Madhya Pradesh, near Khawasa.

The allegations are based on confessional statement by temporary forest labourer Dhamsingh Khandate, who, after being arrested by MP officials, had told them that Deolapar round officer Salim Razzak Khan had directed him to shift the carcass on the night of December 10, 2019, towards Khawasa.

Stunned by the allegations, Nagpur chief conservator of forests (CCF) P Kalyan Kumar had ordered a probe and spoken to his counterpart RS Kori in Seoni, who promised to hand over relevant papers to the team from Nagpur.

However, according to sources, Ramtek ACF Sandeep Giri and Deolapar RFO SG Parihar went to Seoni twice on February 3 and 5, but MP officials refused to share the investigation papers.

Kori said, “Maharashtra officials had met me and deputy conservator (DyCF) but I’m not aware whether the papers have been handed over or not. I will confirm and let you know.”

Kori further added, “No further arrests have been made.”

Maharashtra officials said on condition of anonymity, “A tiger cannot be dumped by a lone person and there must be at least 5-6 persons. Why were the others not arrested? We are doing a parallel investigations. MP officials have promised to hand over probe papers.”

Title: Mega screen to be launched at Gandhi Maidan by month-end
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Smart Cities Mission director Rahul Kapoor has suggested that the launch of the 72-foot-high mega screen at Ga... Read More

PATNA: Smart Cities Mission director Rahul Kapoor has suggested that the launch of the 72-foot-high mega screen at Gandhi Maidan should be a grand affair. He along with other officials had inspected several ongoing projects under the Patna Smart City Limited (PSCL) on Wednesday.

According to sources, the mega screen was used on a trial basis on February 1 and is likely to be launched by the end of February.

PSCL public relations officer (PRO) Harshita told this newspaper that the videos to be played on the mega screen would first be shortlisted.

“Altogether 5,000 people will be able to watch films, matches and popular shows on the screen. It will also be used for displaying events that require outdoor projection,” she said and added that additional security forces would be deployed at Gandhi Maidan after the launch of the screen.

The mega screen, which was installed utilizing an estimated outlay of Rs 6.98 crore, will help create an amphitheatre experience at Gandhi Maidan.

Patnaites, especially youngsters, are elated by the mega screen project. “Patna lacks an amphitheatre where a large number of people can watch matches together. With the launch of the mega screen at Gandhi Maidan, we will have a common place to watch football, cricket and hockey matches,” said Yash Singh, a resident of Kankarbagh.

The Smart Cities Mission director also asked the PSCL officials to complete redevelopment work of the Adalatganj pond before the upcoming assembly elections.

The pond, which is being redeveloped at a cost of Rs 9.8 crore, will have attractions like open-air theatre, musical-cum-lighting fountain, aeration fountain, playing area for kids, benches, walking pathways, garden and vehicle-parking space.

Title: Patna airport: Four more flights included in revised winter schedule
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Flyers outside Patna airport on Thursday.

PATNA: The number of flights operating from Jayaprakash Narayan International Airport , Patna is set to touch 49 with addition of four new flights on different routes, including Chandigarh, Bagdogra, Delhi and Hyderabad, from February and March.

The new flights have been added under revised winter schedule approved by the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) and released by Patna airport on Wednesday. The new schedule came into effect from February 1 and will remain effective till April- end.

Budget-carrier IndiGo will start first-ever flight on Patna-Chandigarh and Patna-Bagdogra routes from March 5.

The Chandigarh-Patna-Bagdogra flight 6E-6148 will arrive at Patna airport at 8am and depart for Bagdogra at 8.30am. The Bagdogra-Patna-Chandigarh flight (6E-6149) will land at Patna airport at 11.35am and depart for Chandigarh at 12.05pm.

IndiGo will also commence two more flights to Delhi and Hyderabad, respectively, from February 16 under the revised winter schedule. The number of Delhi-bound flight of IndiGo from Patna airport will increase to eight.

Patna airport presently handles 45 daily scheduled flights, out of which 21 are Delhi-bound, seven Kolkata-bound, five Mumbai- bound, four Bengaluru-bound, three Hyderabad-bound, two each Ranchi and Lucknow-bound and one each Amritsar and Ahmedabad-bound.

Meanwhile, GoAir resumed operation of four flights at Patna airport from February 1 – two each in morning and late evening hours. It includes two Delhi bound flights (G8-135/136 and G8-149/150). The other two flights are Delhi-Patna-Bengaluru (G8-143/ 273) and Bengaluru-Patna-Delhi (G8-274/144).

SpiceJet, on the other hand, has suspended two Chennai- bound flights (SG-731/767 and SG- 323/ 324) due to technical reasons. The airline currently operates eight flights from city airport.

Patna airport director Bhupesh C H Negi said more flights would be introduced in the forthcoming summer schedule. “It is a major challenge for Patna airport to handle the ever-increasing passenger movement. We have already implemented several measures in this regard, including modification of the existing terminal building and passenger services,” Negi added.

Title: Industry leaders demand textile machinery park in city
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Surat: The Southern Gujarat Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SGCCI) has submitted a representation to the Union Textile ministry for setting up of the textile machinery park in the city for promoting the indigenous manufacturing.

Representatives from the textile industry led by SGCCI president Ketan Desai, held discussions with the special secretary of textile ministry at New Delhi for promoting the indigenous manufacturing of textile machinery and reducing the dependence on the countries like China, Japan, Korea and Taiwan for the import of high-end textile machinery.

Talking with TOI, Desai said, “Majority of the high-end machinery in the textile sector is imported from Far East countries including China. There are textile machinery manufacturers in Surat and south Gujarat who are capable to match the standards of the machine manufacturers in foreign countries. We have represented the government for setting up textile machinery park in the city.”

Desai added, “In a meeting with Prime Minister Narendra Modi, we had discussed to promote indigenous manufacturing of textile machinery and that he had instructed the respective departments to work out a strategy.”

According to Desai, about 7,500 embroidery machines and more than 3,000 water-jet and air-jet machines are imported from in the city per annum.

Hetal Mehta, former president of SGCCI said, “We are going to prepare a detailed reported on the imports of textile machinery and that it will be submitted to the textile ministry for further action. Along with the textile machinery park, we have demanded that the indigenous manufacturers should be given facilities for the research and development of new products.”

Title: 350 stalls put up at ‘Destination Bihar Expo’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PATNA: More than 350 stalls have been put up by different government departments and private firms at the sixth edition of the ‘ Destination Bihar Expo ’ which began at Gandhi Maidan on Thursday.

Jointly organised by the Bihar Industries Association (BIA) and the state industries department, the five-day expo will conclude on February 10.

Road construction minister Nand Kishor Yadav, who inaugurated the event, said, “Bihar has everything — from cheap raw materials to electricity and land — required for setting up industries. Several new roads, flyovers and highways have been constructed to provide smooth transportation to everyone.”

During the five-day expo, February 7 will be celebrated as ‘Infrastructure Day’, February 8 as ‘Tourism Day’ and February 9 as ‘Industries Day’. BIA president Ram Lal Khetan said, “Hospitals like the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) and the Indira Gandhi Institute of Medical Sciences (IGIMS) have also put up their stalls while the Mahavir Cancer Sansthan has set up blood donation camps at the venue.”

Meanwhile, entrepreneurs and businessmen were happy to get a huge platform for showcasing their products.

Patna-based entrepreneur Arun Prakash, who had started a business of natural soaps in 2004, told this newspaper, “I was the first person to sell natural, chemical-free soaps in the state. With the help of the government and the industries department, I reached here. I have expanded my business and am selling my products in Bengaluru, Delhi and even Australia.”

Dak Bungalow resident Jaya, who has also put up her stall of bridal accessories, said, “Like every year, I am expecting to do good business and earn well.”

Stalls selling handmade products are attracting many customers at the expo. Chetna, an entrepreneur from Nawada, said, “I sell handmade embroidered clothes and bags with Madhubani paintings on them."

A large number of visitors thronged Gandhi Maidan on Day 1 of the expo. Appreciating the initiative of promoting solar panels at the expo, Phulwarisharif resident Saima Hassan said, “This is a great platform to promote the use of renewable sources of energy.”

Title: ‘Use nuclear energy to boost national economy’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PATNA: Atomic Energy Commission’s former chairman and nuclear scientist Ratan Kumar Sinha has asserted that India has now become self-dependent in energy sector by generating surplus energy.

Addressing the students and faculty members of Munger University on Thursday, Sinha observed that by developing thorium, a weakly radioactive metallic chemical element, as an alternative to uranium (not plenty in India) scientists have been able to enhance the energy production considerably in recent years.

“Today, India is not only meeting its own energy requirements, but also exporting them to other countries,” he said.

Sinha clarified that nuclear energy can be safely used to boost production and enhance national economy. He pointed out that coal-based energy results in carbon emission, leading to global warming.

“Due to erratic climate pattern, more coolers and heaters are being used, resulting in greater carbon emission. Thus, a vicious cycle is formed, making life miserable,” Sinha said, adding youths should utilize their scientific knowledge in meeting the challenges of nature and mitigating the sufferings of the people.

Sinha, who is currently associated with Bhabha Atomic Research Centre (BARC), accepted the proposal of Munger University’s vice-chancellor Ranjit Kumar Verma for counselling local university students by BARC scientists.

Title: Patna: 45-year-old woman dies in celebratory firing
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

PATNA: A 45-year-old woman watching a wedding procession from the window of her house died in celebratory firing by those participating in it late on Wednesday night. The deceased was identified as Kiran Devi.

The incident took place in Badi Patandevi locality under the Alamganj police station area in Patna City. The wedding party members fled from the spot after realising that the woman was dead.

Patna City SDPO Manish Kumar said Kiran was watching the wedding procession along with some other women family members. “One of the bullets fired by someone in the wedding party hit the woman’s temple,” he said, adding the victim was rushed to Nalanda Medical College and Hospital (NMCH), where the doctors declared her brought dead.

“None from the victim’s family informed the police about the incident. We got to know about it from locals,” he said. “Some suspects have been identified. Police will arrest them soon,” the SDPO added.

Title: 3-day English teachers’ conference begins in Magadh University
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

GAYA: More than 200 delegates from different parts of the country are attending the three-day ‘All-India English Teachers’ Conference’, which began in Magadh University (MU) on Thursday.

This is for the first time that the annual conference is being organized in Bihar . Its theme is ‘An Overview of Literatures in English Language: Continuity and Departure’.

Delivering the keynote address during the inaugural session, Nalanda University vice-chancellor (VC) Sunaina Singh exhorted the participants to religiously follow the teaching protocol and enter the classrooms fully prepared. She regretted that the level of dedication among teachers had diminished and the trend needed early and effective reversal.

The VC also denounced the tendency to look westward for quality literature. She said, “With a 5000-year-long history, the Indian literary treasure is very rich. For a long time, India enjoyed the position of ‘vishva guru’. It is high time we rediscovered our country’s glorious past and lived it once again.”

MU VC Rajendra Prasad requested littérateurs to spread the message of love and compassion. He said, “The atmosphere of hate has to be replaced with mutual love and respect.”

Referring to the threat posed to human existence by global warming, he pointed out it was the responsibility of littérateurs to create awareness about its dangers.

Delivering the presidential address, C P Singh, former head of the postgraduate department of English in MU, said literature was the spontaneous outflow of human emotions.

Title: Bihar: Taiwan scholars worried as Odantapuri remains ‘vanish’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Buddhist scholars from Taiwan at Biharsharif.

BIHARSHARIF: A 30-member delegation of Buddhist scholars from Taiwan were disappointed after they failed to locate the remains of the ancient Odantapuri University in Biharsharif on Wednesday. It is believed to have existed till the 13th century AD.

Li Wen, one of the scholars from Taiwan, told this newspaper on Thursday, “According to ancient scriptures, the founder of the Pala dynasty, King Gopala, had built a university of Buddhist learning called ‘vihara’ inside his fort at Odantapuri in the 7th century AD. It was referred to as ‘Adband’ by Arab writers and as ‘Odyantapuri’ by Taranatha, a Lama of the Jonang school of Tibetan Buddhism. In 1197AD, Turkish invader Bakhtiyar Khilji attacked the fort and destroyed the university.”

Wen pointed out that the present government should have taken steps to ensure that some parts of the ancient structure were preserved. “An excavation can still bring out the structure buried underneath,” he said.

Executive director of Bihar Heritage Development Society , Bijoy Kumar Chaudhary, however, claimed that there was limited scope for excavation as the present day Biharsharif was densely populated.

“No remains of Odantapuri University, which was a seat of learning of Buddhism in the early medieval period, could be found because it was largely destroyed by Khilji. Besides, the dense population of Biharsharif leaves very little scope for excavation of the site,” Chaudhary claimed.

Patna-based author Naushad Ansari said, “Odantapuri Vihara was damaged when the Turkish Army led by Bakhtiyar Khilji had invaded the fort.”

Title: Health threat looms as garbage piles up on roads
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PATNA: Efforts made by Patna DM Kumar Ravi to introduce alternative measures for removal of garbage and continuation of other civic services in the city failed to yield desired results as garbage strewn on roads could be removed from only two of six circles of Patna Municipal Corporation (PMC) on Thursday.

The sanitation work resumed in several areas in Patliputra and New Capital circles, including Fraser road, Dak Bunglow crossing, Punaichak, Raj Bhavan, Secretariat, Eco Park, Maurya Lok Complex and Boring road. Garbage strewn on roads was carted away using automatic sweeping machines amid heavy deployment of police forces.

The DM had issued an order on Wednesday for formation of one team each in all six circles of PMC for removal of garbage accumulated on roads due to the indefinite strike of group D employees of PMC, mainly sanitation workers. However, the additional teams were confronted by the agitating sanitation workers in two circles late on Wednesday evening, following which police action was initiated.

“Three separate FIRs were lodged at Sachivalaya, Bahadurpur and Alamganj police stations against more than 25 unidentified people for causing hindrance in garbage removal work. Three sanitary inspectors of Patna City circle were suspended for not joining the alternative measures proposed by the district administration,” the DM said on Thursday.

Shailesh Kumar, executive officer of New Capital Circle of PMC, said cleanliness work was carried out in several localities. “We have started with cleaning the main roads, which will be followed by removal of garbage from other localities. All the auto tippers parked at Mithapur yard were punctured by the protesting sanitation workers,” he said.

Kumar added, “Anti-mosquito fumigation also started on Fraser Road and at Dak Bunglow crossing and Punaichak.”

S K Mishra, executive officer of Patna City and Azimabad circles of PMC, said garbage cleaning work had not resumed in the circle due to lack of police force. “On Wednesday night, we cleaned the dumped garbage from Chowk area and Shikarpur Chowk in Patna City area. But we cannot carry out the cleaning work without force. Most police officers are on Intermediate examination duty,” he said.

Bankipore’s executive officer Tarun said some permanent sanitation workers along with senior officials had tried to collect auto tippers from Mithapur yard, but they were chased away by the striking sanitation workers.

Title: ‘Bihar Mahotsava’ in Ahmedabad from February 28 to March 1
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PATNA: The art, culture and youth department is set to organize a three-day ‘ Bihar Mahotsava ’ in Ahmedabad from February 28 to March 1. Altogether 25 stalls and an art gallery will be put up at the fest, which will promote the rich cultural heritage of Bihar.

According to sources, the bidding process for selecting an event management firm is underway.

Art, culture and youth department minister Pramod Kumar told this newspaper that the ‘Bihar Mahotsava’ had been organized in cities like New Delhi, Kolkata, Goa and Jaipur.

“It is known for playing a major role in connecting the Bihari diaspora to its roots and introducing the rich and diverse culture of the state to outsiders,” Kumar said.

Various folk artistes from Bihar will also perform at the three-day fest. “Performances by regional singers like Pawan Singh, Kumud Jha Diwan and Maithili Thakur will be major attractions,” an official of the art, culture and youth department said and added that the stalls would showcase the popular handicrafts, tourist spots, agricultural innovations, food items and small scale industries of Bihar.

Meanwhile, Gujaratis are excited to get a glimpse of Bihar’s culture in their state. Ahmedabad resident Krunal Solanki, who had visited Bihar few years ago, said, “I really loved Bihar as there are so many things to explore, especially the food. I cannot wait to eat ‘litti-chokha’ at the fest.”

Arth Desai, a resident of Ambawadi in Ahmedabad, said, “I have heard a lot about Bihari cuisine and handicrafts. I am looking forward to buying Madhubani paintings at the three-day festival.”

Title: PSBs education loans approval rate shrinks 24% in three years
Content: Chennai: Stringent disbursement norms coupled with downturn in engineering education admissions resulted in a 24% decline in education loan approvals by State-owned banks in the last three years.In a Lok Sabha reply, the Ministry of Finance said the approval of education loans decreased to 1.64 lakh applications as of December, 2019 from 2.16 lakh reported in 2017-18.This drop is seen after an increase recorded in the number of loan applications approved from 1.96 lakh to 2.16 lakh between 2016-17 and 2017-18.These are loans under the guidelines of Model Educational Loan Scheme laid down by Indian Banks’ Association (IBA) which have to disposed off by banks within 15 days to one month of the receipt of loan application and communication of decision on sanction or rejection within 15-day deadline.Seeing not much uptake in the educational loan approval rate, a Canara Bank official said, “We are maintaining education loans sanctioned at the level of 30,000 applications. We have seen a marginal drop in education loans sanctioned by 200-300 applications this year. Many people not choosing professional courses — engineering, agriculture, veterinary sciences, law — compared to last few years, and instead opt for basic degrees courses which do not require a loan.”Canara Bank’s approved applications remain stagnant at 30,000 for the last three years.However, the State-owned bank's value of education loan sanctioned and disbursed were rising.The official also said, “While, underemployment is the biggest concern for us, if we take nursing courses where fees are charged exorbitantly like 5-6 lakh, and another 2-3 lakh will be added to the principle borrowed amount if there is no interest subsidy adding up to a total of 8 lakh. In such a case, the interest payment stands at 10,000-15,000 per month for a nurse who earns 6,000-7,000 per month. Similar situations of unemployment and underemployment is seen in the engineering space, where the fees are much higher with poor job guarantee.”“It is not just the responsibility of public sector banks to provide financial aid to students of low-end income group, while politicians must fight for it too. No political party seem to push this pressing issue of slowdown in sanction of education loans,” K Srinivasan of the Education Loan Task Force, a voluntary organization that seeks to raise awareness about how to go about applying for an education loan. The Reserve Bank of India’s monthly report on deployment of bank credit by major sectors showed disbursement by select 39 scheduled commercial banks stands at fell 6% year-on-year in educational loans under the priority sector segment and 3.2% under the personal loan segment as of December 20, 2019.

Title: Standing committee discusses budget proposals
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Surat: Standing committee and general board of Surat Municipal Corporation (SMC) are likely to pass the draft budget of Rs6,003 crore for the year 2020-21 presented by municipal commissioner Banchhanidhi Pani on January 23 by this month-end. Local body elections are due to be held this year and hence no new taxes were proposed by the corporation ruled by the BJP. The standing committee started to scrutinize the budget on Thursday.

“Some good projects have been introduced. However, lots of money goes into operations and maintenance of the projects and corrupt practices by officials only make things further difficult,” said a member, who had been chairman of the standing committee in past.

BJP corporators are likely to advocate inclusion of projects worth Rs100 crore and also allocate additional money for public utility services, sources said. The standing committee is likely to be approve the budget on Friday and the general board by the month-end.

Title: SRO, index to boost digital payments
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Mumbai: The spread of digital payments will improve with the RBI proposing a self-regulatory organisation ( SRO ) to improve standards and a digital payments index (DPI) to track usage.

“The DPI will capture the extent of the transition of payments to digital. The RBI shall construct and periodically publish the index. We will also put in place a framework for establishing an SRO for orderly operations of the entities in the digital payment system,” said RBI governor Shaktikanta Das .

“The index will enable companies to gauge the ground level effectiveness of various programs running across the country. The index will also assist the financial payments ecosystem to identify areas of growth and improvement for widespread permeation of cashless payments, said Anand Kumar Bajaj, MD & CEO, PayNearby.

The RBI has said the framework for an SRO will be in place by April this year and will standardise practices on security, customer protection and pricing.

Title: ‘Will act ahead of time on rate cuts’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Mumbai: In his opening statement following the monetary policy committee, RBI governor Shaktikanta Das warned against trying to second-guess the central bank.

“While the decision may be along expected lines, and perhaps widely discounted, it is important not to discount the RBI,” Das said. RBI’s policy did not cut rates on Thursday, but there was a slew of measures to ensure that the 135-basis-point (100bps = 1 percentage point) reduction in policy rates in 2019 gets passed on to borrowers. Excerpts from a press conference:

Are the measures to reduce reserve requirement and infuse liquidity in the money markets like a hidden rate cut in the policy?

It is an effort to ensure better monetary policy transmission. We want to inject Rs 1 lakh crore into the banking system. Because we are lending it at the policy rate, it will enable banks to bring down their lending rates. Notwithstanding the 135bps reduction in the repo rate, there is also a need for sufficient liquidity. Corporate bonds are benchmarked to rates in the government securities segment. If we are able to bring down yields on government bonds, that acts as a benchmark for lending. When the banks get cheaper funds, it will quicken the process of transmission.

On room to cut rates in future...

In 2019, there were a lot of surprises, including unseasonal rains that increased the price of onions, which contributed over 200bps to inflation. We have policy space, but it will depend on the evolving situation, and the monetary policy committee in 2020 will be very proactive and act ahead of time, as it has done in 2019.

What is the purpose of having special government securities in the Budget where non-residents can invest without limits?

The primary objective of this is to ensure that it reflects the robustness of the Indian economy...that we can mobilise and absorb so much foreign capital to meet our domestic requirement. But this investment will flow in rupees and not dollars. By mobilising foreign savings, the pressure on domestic savings to meet the requirements of the government — to that extent they also get minimised.

The FRBM Act trigger clause allows the government to monetise fiscal deficit with the RBI. Is that a concern?

Let me be very clear: Now there is no plan of monetising the fiscal deficit. Despite the fiscal deficit going to 3.8%, market borrowing remains the same. Next year, it goes up by only Rs 70,000 crore which, as a percentage of GDP, is lower than the current year.

Title: What’s going on isn’t right, Tai to Nath on anti-CAA protests
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Indore: Former Lok Sabha Speaker and senior BJP leader Sumitra Mahajan has written to chief minister Kamal Nath , objecting to the ongoing statewide protests against CAA , NRC and NPA.

Urging the CM to ensure peace, Mahajan writes: “For many days, dharna/protests are going on against CAA, NRC and NPA, but as you know, the central government is not implementing NRC and the Union home minister cleared the same today in his reply to a question in Lok Sabha.” Mahajan mentions that CAA has been amended to give shelter to people of minority communities in Afghanistan, Bangladesh and Pakistan, “who are facing anarchy and injustice there”. “It is clear that nobody’s rights (In India) will be snatched (due to the Act). Still, protests are going on,” she writes.

“I get tense when outsiders participate in such protests and give inflammatory speeches. A similar incident was reported recently in Indore. Someone dared to say that citizenship ‘should also be given to intruders’,” says her letter, urging the CM to “pay attention to such incidents”.

“As you know, citizenship comes under central government’s jurisdiction. It can make a law on it and if states have any objection, they can move Supreme Court. But what’s going on is not right. The country — and specially Indore — are on the path of peace and progress and we are all working for it. In this scenario, everybody wishes that peace should be maintained,” she writes.

Reacting to the letter, MPCC spokesperson Nilabh Shukla said: “It is an unnecessary attempt by Mahajan to show she is active during her political exile. All her allegations are baseless. I would urge the former Lok Sabha Speaker to expose the so-called ‘outsiders’, who gave inflammatory speeches, with proof.” TNN

Title: Deposit cover premium to increase marginally
Content: MUMBAI: The five-fold increase in deposit insurance will not have a significant impact on banks’ balance sheets. The RBI has increased the premium on bank deposits by only 20% to 12 paise from 10 paise for every Rs 100.“The premium is something which we are considering. It will be increased from 10 paise to 12 paise per hundred rupees for the time being. So, the impact on the banks’ balance — it is not likely to be so much,” said RBI deputy governor B P Kanungo .Earlier, analysts had estimated that a five-fold increase in the deposit insurance cover might add up to 25 basis points (100bps = 1 percentage point) of their aggregate deposits. Given that total bank deposits are Rs 131 lakh crore, the increase in premium for one year will boost the deposit insurance fund by Rs 2,620 crore.Kanungo pointed out that the Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation (DICGC) pays out claims only at the time of liquidation. However, he added, there is also a scheme where the DICGC provides compensation under restructuring plans for reviving the bank. This is a big positive for stressed co-operative banks as it would be possible for the DICGC to fill in to make a takeover proposal viable. Responding to a query on Punjab and Maharashtra Co-operative (PMC) Bank, RBI governor Shaktikanta Das said that the administrator and the advisory committee are having greater clarity with regard to the financial position of the bank and are working on their next course of action.The DICGC received total premium income of Rs 12,043 crore from banks in 2018-19. The deposit insurance fund amounted to Rs 93,750 crore in FY19. It insured deposits of Rs 33.70 lakh crore out of total deposits of Rs 120 lakh crore of 2,098 banks.

Title: Youths will express their love for Surat this Valentine's Day
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Sarvajanik Education Society along with SMC and police will organize a programme called ‘My city, my Valentine... Read More

SURAT: Numerous stories are associated with Valentine 's Day from martyrdom to that of romance between two lovers. The Diamond City is going to add one more- dedicating oneself to the service of people. Sarvajanik Education Society , which runs 22 schools and colleges, along with Surat Municipal Corporation and police will organize a fun-filled programme called ‘My city, my Valentine’ on Surat-Dumas Road on February 14. The 1km stretch of Surat-Dumas Road from Rahulraj Mall to Big Bazaar will be the venue. People will come dressed in traditional costumes with banners of national integration, ‘Save the girl child,’ and cleaner and greener Surat among others. Youths will make murals from waste plastic bottles, attend painting workshop and distribute free saplings. Students will also take oath not to use single use plastic. Programmes have also been planned for disabled children and those with spastic cerebral palsy , and elderly citizens.

Percy Engineer, principal of architecture college run by Sarvajanik Education Society, said, “The idea is to give a socially relevant message to the youth. We plan to inspire the youths to love their city. Love is all-encompassing and is not limited to two persons alone. If the youths could be motivated to channelize their energy to making the city better, there is not going to be anything more appropriate than this for them as well as others.”

Sarvajanik Education Society chairman Kamlesh Yagnik said, “This is an attempt to motivate students to do something for the city. Respecting your city means you love your heroes and what better day than the Valentine's Day to acknowledge this.”

Title: NDA netas slam Tej Pratap Yadav
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s elder son Tej Pratap Yadav

PATNA: RJD chief Lalu Prasad’s elder son Tej Pratap Yadav came under attack from ruling NDA as well as senior functionaries of his own party on Thursday for using indecent words for CM Nitish Kumar and deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi .

At an anti-CAA public meeting at Masaurhi on Wednesday, Tej had said, “I have given new name to Nitish Kumar and henceforth he is Nitish Kumari, similarly Sushil Kumar Modi is Sushil Kumari,” Tej said.

Training guns at another NDA leader, Tej had said, “Do not sit at home wearing bangles, rather come and talk directly.”

Tej’s statements irked the NDA functionaries who demanded an apology from him as well as the RJD. JD(U) spokesperson Rajiv Ranjan asked Tej to apologize from entire Bihar for insulting the CM and the deputy CM. “He has even embarrassed his party people. Such statements are Tej Pratap’s identity,” Ranjan said.

Another JD(U) leader, Ajay Alok, described Tej as “mentally unstable” and advised RJD to send the latter to Ranchi for treatment.

The elder Yadav scion even got a piece of advice from senior RJD functionary Raghuvansh Prasad Singh. “I often criticize, but in a modest way. We are in opposition and it is our duty to fight and work. However, we should not cross the limit,” Singh said.

Title: Surat: 11-year-old boy steals mother’s Rs 49,000 for game zone
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

SURAT: An 11-year-old boy, who disappeared from his school a day ago, was found in Man Darwaja area of the city on Thursday morning. He ran away from school after his mother found that he had stolen Rs49,000 cash from home. He spent a portion of the money in a game zone and on food at a mall near Udhna crossroads.

Earlier, a complaint of kidnapping of the boy was registered by cops at Salabatpura police station after his mother approached them.

A schoolteacher found Rs26,000 cash and a mobile phone with the boy on Wednesday and the former called his mother and asked her to come to school. The boy’s mother told school officials that Rs49,000 was stolen from her house but she had no idea who stole it. Before she could return home with him, the boy disappeared from the school.

“The boy told us he was scared of his mother’s scolding and also wanted to enjoy with the money and therefore ran away. After he disappeared, he went to the game zone and spent the night roaming on Udhna crossroads,” a police officer said.

The boy’s mother is a domestic help and lives with her three children. She separated from her husband some time ago.

Title: Bihar: Rs 7.1 lakh seized from Narkatiaganj BDO
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

PATNA/BAGAHA: Acting on a tip-off, police detained Narkatiaganj block development officer ( BDO ) Raghvendra Tripathy from whom Rs 7.1 lakh in cash was recovered at Nautan Bazaar under the same police station area in Bettiah town of West Champaran district on Wednesday.

However, after quizzing the BDO for around 12 hours, economic offences unit (EOU) of the state police set him free on a personal bond with condition that he would appear before police when called for in course of investigation.

The BDO was detained at around 11pm on Wednesday and set free at 10am on Thursday. His office and government residence were also searched by EOU.

Bettiah SP (incharge) Vivek Kumar said the police urged the EOU on Thursday to take over the case for further investigation.

Sources said after receiving the tip-off, police conducted vehicle checking at multiple locations under Town, Nautan and Bairia police station areas in Bettiah.

“The BDO was on way to his house in Gopalganj town. He would have entered Gopalganj after crossing Bairia,” a police source said, adding the EOU would now investigate the bank accounts of the BDO.

SHO of Nautan police station Anuj Kumar Pandey said the BDO claimed during interrogation that he had taken the money as loan from someone.

Title: Gujarat: MLA’s call clip with abuses goes viral
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Waghodiya BJP MLA and Gujarat Agro Industries Corporation (GAIC) chairman Madhu Shrivastava

VADODARA: Waghodiya BJP MLA and Gujarat Agro Industries Corporation (GAIC) chairman Madhu Shrivastava is mired in yet another controversy.

This time around an audio clip of a conversation replete with expletives exchanged between him and a man belonging to Porbandar is making rounds on the social media.

In the audio, the conversation begins with the man named Raj Odedara expressing sympathy with Shrivastava over the MLA’s recent comments accusing government officials of not taking up his suggested works.

The conversation, however, soon turned ugly with Shrivastava hurling an abuse at Odedara. The caller too shot back with a deluge of abuses.

The exchange continues throughout the call with both Shrivastava and Odedara claiming in the conversation that they were in an inebriated condition. In the last part of the conversation, somebody else can also be heard abusing Odedara.

When contacted, Odedara admitted that he had called Shrivastava. “I have interest in politics. Shrivastava abused me first and hence I loss my cool too,” Odedara said. He added that he had not been called by Shrivastava or the police later. In the call, Shrivastava had threatened to take up the matter with the police.

Odedara added that on Thursday he had received a call from a person claiming to be a builder. “He told me that Shrivastava was not a bad person and helped poor people a lot,” he claimed. He added that he used to work for former state Congress president Arjun Modhwadia before 2012, but later parted ways and even canvassed against Modhwadia.

Title: Nitish Kumar to open 5-day shooting contest on February 10
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Bihar CM Nitish Kumar

PATNA: Chief minister Nitish Kumar will inaugurate the 20th All India Police Duty Meet Shooting Competition on the campus of the second battalion of the Bihar Military Police (BMP) at Dehri-on-Sone in Rohtas district on February 10 .

Additional director general (headquarters) Jitendra Kumar said on Thursday that Bihar would host the five-day mega event beginning February 10 for the first time. Police teams from 25 states and the central armed forces have already confirmed their participation in the competition.

Kumar said around 800 participants were expected to take part in 13 events to be held between February 10 and February 15. Altogether 16 committees have been set up to make proper arrangements for the event. DGP Gupteshwar Pandey is the chairman of the organizing committee.

Title: Fly ash bricks for Bihar govt buildings to be made mandatory: Sushil Kumar Modi
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Bihar deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi

PATNA: Deputy CM Sushil Kumar Modi on Thursday said the state government would adopt a policy soon making the use of fly ash-based bricks in the construction of all government buildings mandatory, as part of its initiative to protect the fertile top soil of arable and other land which is otherwise used in the making of bricks.

Modi said the government has periodically taken initiatives to improve and monitor air quality too. “In accordance with the same, the use of all 15-year-old diesel-based government vehicles was banned in the state. Similarly, the use of 15-year-old vehicles has been banned in the areas falling under Patna Municipal Corporation and urban local bodies of Danapur, Khagaul and Phulwarisharif,” Modi said.

The deputy CM was addressing the pre-budget consultative meet on environment conservation and pollution control organized at the auditorium of old secretariat to solicit suggestions from participants for likely consideration for inclusion in the 2020-21 state budget. Principal secretaries of finance and environment departments – S Siddharth and Dipak Kumar Singh, respectively – and Bihar Pollution Control Board chairman A K Ghosh also participated in it.

Modi gave details of the other recent initiatives taken by the government to address environmental concerns of people in the state and improve air quality in Patna, Muzaffarpur, Gaya, Bhagalpur and Hajipur.

“UNDP and Hindustan Coca Cola Beverages Private Limited have been engaged to establish a unit at Gardanibagh (Patna) for processing plastic waste materials with 5 tonne per day processing capacity. Four medical waste material management units have also been working – one each at Patna, Muzaffarpur, Bhagalpur and Gaya,” Modi said.

Title: Stressed commercial realty projects get relief from RBI
Content:
(Representative image)

MUMBAI: In a major relief for developers of commercial real estate (CRE), the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has allowed banks to restructure loans by delaying the completion date. This means that in the case of stressed borrowers, banks can give them more time to repay without classifying the developer as a defaulter, or the loan as a non-performing asset (NPA).Commercial real estate refers to projects other than housing, which include office buildings. In its policy, RBI said banks can extend the date of commercial operation of project loans for CRE projects by one year without downgrading the asset classification.“This is a big move and will bring much-needed relief to the cash-starved real estate sector, and to both developers and the housing finance corporations (HFCs) from the liquidity perspective. It will help ease out the time for maintaining and managing cash flows for cash-strapped developers and help them to complete several stuck projects,” said Anarock Property Consultants chairman Anuj Puri.However, he added that this will not address the other main issue prevailing in the real estate sector — the continuing low demand. Also, while the move will prevent stressed projects from falling into the NPA category, it will not enable banks to lend to projects classified as NPA.Stocks of real estate companies gained following the announcement (see graphic). Among realty companies, Godrej Properties rose 1.8%, Sobha jumped 1.4%, Indiabulls Real Estate 1.16%, Prestige Estates Projects 1.09%, and Oberoi Realty 0.5%. Indiabulls Housing Finance, which has a significant exposure to real estate, was the biggest gainer with share price closing 15% up at Rs 319. LIC housing finance too gained 8% to close at Rs 438.Announcing the relaxation in his post-policy press conference, RBI governor Shaktikanta Das said that it would complement the measures taken by the government in the Union Budget. “In the commercial estate sector, there are many incomplete projects. The dispensation is basically to deal with incomplete projects, which got delayed for reasons beyond their control because of some environment clearance getting delayed, or some court case or some other kind of impediment which came in their way,” said Das.“It is estimated that around Rs 400 crore loans to commercial real estate could be benefited. This will help banks, developers to overcome the stressed issues in the sector,” said SBI Group chief economist Soumya Kanti Ghosh.“After the asset quality review of 2015, RBI has been avoiding forebearance for stressed loans. This is the first time that RBI has permitted this for large loans. At this time the economy needs such decisions as real estate is already facing lack of demand. Giving them relief instead of tightening the screws is a good move,” said Union Bank of India managing director & CEO Rajkiran Rai.

Title: Man shot at by neighbour over land dispute in Ballia
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Varanasi: One Prakash Tiwari (43) suffered serious injuries when his neighbours opened fire in a dispute of land in Juthi Tiwari ka Tola village under the limits of Revati police station in Ballia district on Thursday morning.

CO Bairia Ashok Singh said that a named FIR has been lodged against the neighbour Umashankar Shah and his family members. Raids are being conducted at possible hideouts of the accused, said the police. Tiwari was admitted to Trauma Centre of BHU in Varanasi where his condition was stated to be stable, said Singh.

Tiwari and Shah had a dispute over a piece of land between their houses. Both the families had a fight on Thursday morning after Tiwari started construction of a toilet on the disputed land. In the meantime someone from Shah’s family opened fire on Tiwari.

Tiwari suffered serious injuries and was rushed to the district hospital. On noticing deterioration in his health condition, doctors referred him to Varanasi. SP Ballia Devendra Nath also took stock of the spot.

Title: Leopard injured in infighting
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Vadodara: A leopard was found injured at the Karoli village in Kalol taluka of Panchmahal district on Thursday. It was rescued and sent to the rescue centre near Halol for treatment. The leopard is believed to have been injured in infighting with another male.

Villagers in Karoli panicked after seeing the leopard sitting in a farm on the outskirts of the village. Forest as well as police officials were immediately informed. Sources said that the injured leopard was slow and did not create any trouble in the village.

Forest officials took about two hours to capture the injured animal using a net before sending it to the rescue centre for treatment.

Title: Cousins end lives by jumping into Mahi river in Savli
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Vadodara: In an incident that left their families and friends shocked, two cousin brothers jumped into Mahi river in Savli taluka of Vadodara district on Wednesday evening.

Their bodies were fished out of the river by fire brigade men on Thursday morning. Savli police have registered a case of accidental death and begun investigations.

Yuvraj Chauhan, 20, and Nilesh Chauhan, 20, both residents of Khorvad village in Anand, called up their friends before taking the plunge into the river. “They first called their relatives and told them that they are leaving their home and planning to end their lives. The relatives frantically asked them the reason, but the duo didn’t reveal anything,” a police official said.

“They then reached the bridge in Poicha village on motorbike and parked it there. Moments before jumping off, they called their friends and said they were going to end their lives. When the friends didn’t believe, the duo made a video call to their friends from the bridge,” the police said. They then kept their mobile phones on the bridge and jumped at about 6.30pm.

Passersby saw them jumping into the river and immediately informed police. Even firemen rushed to the spot but they couldn’t find their bodies in dark.

On Thursday morning, their bodies were found about 50 feet away from the spot where they had jumped.

“The duo belongs to the same family and shared a close bond with each other. They stayed in the same village and were always together. We asked their families but they have no clue why the duo took the extreme step,” said Ganpat Khant, head constable, Savli police station.

While Nilesh is married, Yuvraj is single. The cops are probing if the duo had any financial problems that pushed them to end their lives.

Sources said the loan they took for buying costly mobile phones may be one of the reasons for the suicide.

Title: Bangalore Traffic: Mangaluru to Bengaluru zero traffic saves 40-day baby
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

MANGALURU: Heroics of an ambulance driver , whom a news website identified as Haneef Balanja , gave a 40-day infant a new lease of life.

The driver aided by help from jurisdictional police rushed the infant battling a serious heart condition from Fr Muller Medical College Hospital to Jayadeva Institute of Cardiovascular Sciences and Research in Bengaluru with zero traffic being provided right from Mangaluru to Bengaluru.

With jurisdictional police en route already aware of this development, the motorists cooperated with their direction to ensure that the ambulance had an unhindered passage to the Institute in Jayanagar. Bengaluru police helped the ambulance cruise from Nelamangala to the institute. This stretch of road is otherwise notorious for traffic snarls. The infant is the child of Harris Gerukatte that was in need of immediate medical intervention. Saiful suffers from total anomalous pulmonary venous connection, a defect in the veins leading from the lungs to the heart.

Title: AMC body rejects Rs 218 crore property tax hike proposal
Content:
Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation has abandoned the plan proposed by municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra to add a... Read More

AHMEDABAD: The Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation has abandoned the plan proposed by municipal commissioner Vijay Nehra to add a net property tax burden of Rs 218 crore on the shoulders of Amdavadis. The tax hike proposed on January 17 was withdrawn by the standing committee of the AMC on Thursday. Nehra’s proposal, had suggested hiking property tax rates by 64% to 93% for bungalows and 48% for apartments. Nehra’s proposal to increase total vehicle tax collection by Rs 26 crore by increasing rates has been approved, said standing committee chairman, Amul Bhatt.The standing committee has retained all current rates of municipal tax without any increase, except vehicle tax. A key announcement made during the budget was a Rs 30 lakh hike in municipal councillors funds to be spent on various ward works.AMC’s budget 2020-21 will now be passed by the general board. The committee made additional proposals worth Rs 777crore, including Rs 443 crore for capital projects .The new budget proposal takes the AMC budget to Rs 9,685 crore from Rs 8,907 crore (earlier proposed by the municipal commissioner). In all, the 2020-21 budget has seen an increase of Rs 1,400 crore over the previous financial year’s budget.

Title: Smart tourism projects still in limbo
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: The ambitious heritage tourism development projects proposed under the smart cities mission by Trichy City Corporation two years ago are yet to take off. The only exception is the illumination of World War memorial. The proposals to beautify the city’s iconic landmarks such Teppakulam tank, Main Guard gate and Rockfort hillock are nowhere in the scene.

In 2018, the urban local body chalked out a plan to illuminate the 83-metre tall Rockfort hillock and façade of Main Guard gate fort. There was also plan to set up a historical laser and sound show at the Teppakulam tank near the Rockfort. The high-power steering committee of the smart cities mission gave administrative and technical sanctions for the projects in July and October 2018. It’s more than a year now, and nothing has happened on the proposals so far.

As the sites are protected monuments, it is mandatory for the corporation to get clearances from the Archaeological Survey of India (ASI), which has enforced stiff restrictions on carrying out such beautification works on the sites. The ASI had asked for a revised proposal from the local body to host laser show at Teppakulam tank, said corporation officials.

Since landmarks such as World War Memorial at Gandhi Market and Puradhana Park are not ASI protected monuments, the civic body could complete the beautification work in time.

"ASI has strictly told us not to disturb the physical structures. We are in the process of revising the detailed project report for the proposal to beautify Teppakulam," an official source said.

Trichy City Corporation, however, maintained that they have obtained the mandatory clearances from the ASI by rendering an assurance that illumination of the Rockfort hillock and Main Guard gate entrance will not affect the structures and public movement. "The proposed mode of illuminating the Main Guard gate has to be modified," the official added.

The corporation maintained that work on illuminating the Rockfort hillock and Main Guard gate will be initiated shortly. The civic body, however, is uncertain about the fate of the much-hyped historical laser show proposed at Teppakulam tank due to the ASI’s restrictions as well as rampant encroachments near the tank.

Title: Many dalits quit BJP over CAA: Leader
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

MALAPPURAM: Around 150 dalit BJP members have reportedly resigned from the party in Kuzhimanna panchayat in Malappuram district as a mark of protest against the Citizenship (Amendment) Act ( CAA ).

A group of party workers in Kalathingal-Pullanchery SC colony in Kuzhimanna have submitted their resignation letter to the district committee office.

Meanwhile, BJP district president Ravi Thelath confirmed that he has received the resignation letter from four members.

Jayesh M, joint secretary of the BJP SC colony committee, said that around 30 families in the colony had joined the party six months ago and all of them have decided to quit in protest against CAA. “We feel that the act will divide people on religious grounds. We cannot agree with it,” said Jayesh. He said that they are yet to take a decision on joining any other party.

Meanwhile, Ravi ruled out that the resignation was in protest against CAA.

“Around 40 families of the colony had joined the party six months ago, seeking help to reclaim their graveyard from a man, who claimed ownership rights over it. BJP had offered support to them. But they expected huge financial support from the party for the legal fight. As BJP couldn’t fund their cause, they were disappointed. Now, they are being misguided by some organizations with ulterior motives and are citing CAA as a reason to snap ties,” he said.

Title: Kolkata: Cops find ‘gaps’ in Tangra woman’s statement
Content:
Locals block Gobinda Khatick Road on Thursday, demanding that cops bring out the truth

KOLKATA: Two days after an ambulance ran over 52-year-old Gopal Pramanick, seconds after the occupants of the vehicle allegedly tried to kidnap his daughter-in-law Priyanka Pramanick (28), the police claimed to have found several inconsistencies in her statement. After studying a CCTV footage , a senior police officer said: “If the evidence does not add up during the probe, we will lodge an FIR against the complainant.”The cops, however, have started a case under IPC sections 357 (assault or criminal force in attempt wrongfully to confine a person) and 341 (wrongful restraint) along with Section 34, based on the woman’s complaint. This is besides the case under IPC section pertaining to culpable homicide not amounting to murder, which had already been registered.According to police, not only did she conceal the fact that another relative was walking right next to her and her three-year-old daughter, she had also failed to explain why she failed to lodge her complaint immediately after the accident. The CCTV footage runs for 74 seconds from 11.53pm on Tuesday. After the first 32 seconds, Priyanka is seen walking — her daughter on her right and her aunt (mami-shasuri) Rita Pramanik her left — along the left side of the road.A couple of steps behind, Gopal is seen following them. He is actually spotted on the road. Four more relatives — in batches of two each — are seen moving towards their home.The accident took place between 55 and 59 seconds in the 74-second footage and by the 60th second the ambulance is visible with the family members running behind it. “How is it that everything took place in seconds? How can someone stop, converse and then pick up speed that can kill a person by dragging him along?” questioned an IPs officer at Lalbazar.Lalbazar’s response came barely hours after residents of Christopher Road in Tangra took to the road and blocked it claiming the police was deliberately trying to pass off a serious crime against woman and a culpable homicide leading to the death of a 52-year-old man as a mere accident.The protestors blocked GK Road using drums and carried currency notes. “We want to bribe the cops, just as a bribe has let them change the course of this case. May be once we bribe them, they will bring out the truth,” claimed Tapan Pramanick, a relative of the victim.

Title: Bomb hoax sends cops in a tizzy
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Mild tension prevailed at Secunderabad railway station on Thursday after officials received a hoax call stating that a bomb was planted on Vijayawada-Secunderabad Intercity Express train on Thursday.

Soon after the call was received, the Railway Protection Force (RPF), local police, sniffer dogs and bomb disposal squad conducted a thorough checking of the train, but did not find anything.

According to officials, they received the call at around 5.30 am, the train’s departure time. “The train had just left the station when we received the information about the bomb. The train was brought back to the yard and after proper checking, it was found to be a hoax call,” said an SCR spokesperson, adding that the train left over an hour late at 7 am. “We are yet to identify the accused, who told us that two to three persons were involved, while the bomb was planted in Coach 1 and Coach 2,” said a Secunderabad railway police officer.

A case was registered against the offender under relevant sections of the IPC.

Title: Surplus rain scatters bird population, 38% drop in Thamirabarani basin
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Madurai: A total of 24,411 birds belonging to 74 species were recorded during the 10th edition of Thamirabarani Waterbird Count (TWC) 2020. This is a drastic drop from the 39,231 birds that were spotted in the last year’s count and 34,189 birds that were spotted in the 8th edition in 2018. Abundance of water in waterbodies spread across the southern districts is said to be the main reason for the drop in numbers.

More than 100 students, farmers, entrepreneurs, housewives, physicians and wildlife and nature enthusiasts from various parts of state took part in the three-day exercise from January 24 to 26. The census was jointly organised by ATREE’s Agasthyamalai Community Conservation Centre, Manimuthar, St John’s College, Palayamkottai, Pearly City Nature Society, Thoothukudi, and Nellai Nature Club.

The participants were divided into six teams to conduct the census in 51 irrigation tanks in Tirunelveli, Thoothukudi and Tenkasi districts. Despite the 38% drop in the total number of birds, there was some excitement in citing the Fulvous Whistling Duck (Dendrocygna Bicolor) for the first time in the census since a decade. It was spotted at Veinthankulam and Karungulam in Thoothukudi district.

Cattle Egret (Bubulcus Ibis) was the bird that was sighted the most in this year’s census. More than 3,840 of these common egrets were spotted this year. A good number of birds were recorded in Vellur (1,602) followed by 1,447 in Kadambakulam, 1,389 in Kaspa, 1,132 in Kuppakurichi and 1,125 in Manur. Bird breeding was recorded at Kazhuvur, Manur, Maranthai and Nainarkulam. Hundreds of Pelicans and Asian Openbills were spotted breeding at Kazhuvur that is located close to Koonthankulam bird sanctuary, Tirunelveli district.

Arjuna (Marutham), Mahua (Illupai) and Palm trees on the bunds at Nainarkulam supported breeding of birds such as Grey Heron and Oriental Darter. Babul trees at Manur and Maranthai supported breeding of Black-headed Ibis, Oriental Darter, Little Cormorant, Indian Shag, Glossy Ibis and the like.

ATREE’s senior research associate M Mathivanan said that bird spotting directly reflects the rainfall received in the region. “The number of birds visiting Tirunelveli and Tuticorin goes down drastically when there is surplus rain across the region during the northeast monsoon. The population gets scattered, with a sizeable population of migratory birds flying to those waterbodies too,” he said.

He observed that last year good rainfall was recorded in neighbouring Ramanathapuram and Virudhunagar districts, which have attracted a share of the birds that used to visit the waterbodies in Thamirabarani basin. According to him, surplus water also makes it difficult for plovers and waders to get food, due to which they could not be spotted in large numbers this time.

Mathivanan who coordinated the census said that the drop this year is not an issue of concern. He said that 67,194 birds, the highest in the TMC census till date, were spotted in 2014 when Thamirabarani received moderate rainfall, while many waterbodies in neighbouring districts such as Virudhunagar and Ramanathapuram went dry. In 2017, the number dropped to a mere 8,256 due to the poor NE monsoon.

Title: Rajwada garden 2.0 to have open-air theatre, fountains
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Indore: Garden in front of Rajwada will soon become the main attraction of the city with an open-air theatre, more lightings and fountains .

Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) is now working on preparing a plan to re-develop the garden space which will be used for public gatherings and events.

IMC commissioner Asheesh Singh said that this garden re-development project is a part of their plan to make the entire Rajwada area a ‘no-vehicle’ zone. The project will be taken up under Smart City initiative, and its estimate cost would be around Rs12 crore.

“An initial design has been prepared and a detailed project report is being worked out. If found feasible, then we will implement the project,” said Singh. Officials said that this project is being prepared to improve scenic beauty of the entire area and increase open space.

As per a tentative plan, the entire garden space will be redeveloped as an open-air theatre with steps to provide seating space for visitors.

The garden’s boundary wall near the palace building side will be removed and all palm trees that obstruct building’s view from opposite side will be shifted from the area. However, the statue of Rani Ahilyabai Holkar will be kept intact.

Fountains and decorative lightings will be installed with presence of green islands. A shed, bus stop and parking space will also be developed near MG Road area.

“This design has been prepared while keeping in mind to provide a clear view of Rajwada to visitors from any point of the entire area,” said Vijay Marathe, a consultant with Indore Smart City Development Limited (ISCDL).

The corporation has already decided to completely restrict entry of vehicles in the entire Rajwada Chowk area. And multi-level parking lots have also been planned in the area before enforcing this restriction.

Title: Three held for attack on cops
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative Image

MALAPPURAM: Nilambur police have arrested three members of a gang and launched a hunt for a fourth person for verbally abusing and attempting to attack police officers in the station and damaging properties, including CCTV cameras, in the station on Thursday.

Those arrested have been identified as Palottil Fazil alias Irachi Fazil , 28, of Chandakunnu , Ahamad Ashik alias Kunjava, 25, of Karulai and Shabhin Rushed , 28, of Chandakunnu. The fourth member of the gang, Cyril is absconding.

Police said the incident occurred on Wednesday morning. The gang brought Nimshad, 21, a resident of Mampad, to the police station and demanded to register a case against him. They alleged Nimshad conspired to attack them. Nimshad was tired when he reached the station as the gang had beaten him up. The move of the police to take the injured Nimshad to a nearby hospital provoked the gang.
