Title: State awards for two Nashik artists
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nashik: The Maharashtra government has announced the names of two Nashik artists for the Yashwantrao Chavan Vangmay Award for the exemplary work in the field of Marathi language.

Author G T Patil and filmmaker Prajakt Deshmukh are the two literary artists to receive the award that will be presented in Mumbai. The date of the award ceremony is yet to be declared.

G T Patil has received the Laxmibai Tilak award for his autobiography ‘Oal Antarichi’. The 78-year-old will receive Rs 1 lakh and a memento from the state government .

“I have been in the literary world for the past 45 years and have seen many ups and downs. The best thing is that I have met fantastic Marathi authors who have made my journey priceless,” said Patil to TOI.

Dramatist and filmmaker Prajakt Deshmukh is the other winner, who received the Vijay Tendulkar Award for his two-act play ‘Devbabhali’. The play was published after the successful enactment across the state. The dramatist will receive Rs 50,000 and a memento.

“We have recently staged our 300th show of the play in Thane. A musical play receiving such a warm response since the past two years is a great achievement,” Deshmukh told TOI.

The duo is among 35 award winners.

Title: Man mistaken as pickpocket, thrashed at Deoria Mahotsav
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Gorakhpur: A man was thrashed by some people at Deoria Mahotsav venue on suspicion of pickpocket, on Wednesday late evening. Police have lodged an FIR against unidentified assailants in this connection. The man was admitted to BRD Medical College.

The mahotsav formally concluded on Tuesday, however, some shops are still doing business at the venue.

According to reports, Tayyab Ansari (35) of Ahmad Nagar Mohalla under Kotwali police station limit went to Deoria Mahotsav on Wednesday evening where some people started beating him calling him a pickpocket. Someone alerted the police following which the police rescued him.

“On the complaint of Tayyab, an FIR has been lodged against unidentified assailants and a probe has been launched. The man was admitted to district hospital on Thursday from where he was referred to BRD Medical College,” SHO Kotwali TJ Singh said. tnn

Title: Pune: Empire Estate flyover ramps will open for traffic today
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The civic body will open the ramps of the Empire Estate flyover in Chinchwad for vehicular traffic on Friday. ... Read More

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The civic body will open the ramps of the Empire Estate flyover in Chinchwad for vehicular traffic on Friday with BJP corporator Shailesh More withdrawing his opposition to it.

Vijay Bhojane, spokesperson, BRTS cell, PCMC, said, mayor Usha alias Mai Dhore will inaugurate the ramps on Friday.”

In a letter to Shravan Hardikar, municipal commissioner, Pimpri Chinchwad Municipal Corporation (PCMC), on February 3, More had pointed out that many works had not yet been completed due to which the residents of Empire Estate were facing traffic issues.

The BJP corporator said that a meeting was held with the civic officials in presence of prominent residents at his office in Empire Estate in Chinchwad on Thursday. “The officials have assured to start the beautification work under the flyover immediately. Parking for four-wheelers and two-wheelers will be conducted between flyover and ramp pillars. A play area will be created next to senior citizens’ park,” he said.

Sanjeev Shewale, secretary, Empire Estate Federation, said, “We have been opposing the flyover construction before it began five years back but still the flyover was constructed with the assurance that our hardships would be reduced. We had opposed the construction of the ramps too as it is a violation of development control (DC) rules.”

Sachin Jadhav, a resident of Chikhali, said, “Commuters coming from Chikhali and proceeding towards Empire Estate, Chinchwad station or Nigdi will be able to use the flyover and get down at the ramp of Empire Estate to go to their destinations quickly without any hassle.”

Title: Two rescued brothers made to live 60-km apart
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Agra: Their lives in disarray, they had each other’s tiny shoulders to cry on. Now, they have none. They grew up together and humbly accepted some of the worst that the life had to offer: Their mother went missing in 2013 and the father was sent to gallows for raping and killing their sister six years later.

Suddenly, the siblings-- aged 8 and 13 years-- found themselves on the streets of Agra. They were living along the roadside near Saiyan toll plaza on Agra-Gwalior highway.

On a rainy day of September last year, days after their father’s incarceration, a neighbour spotted the two boys, drenched and waiting for a truck to sell the trash they had collected the entire day. They used to handover the daily earnings to a woman who used to offer them food in its lieu. When TOI highlighted the plight of the brothers, they were rescued and sent to a shelter home about four months ago.

Now, a few months on, the two brothers were found to be living in separate government-run protection homes. The younger boy, who is eight years old, is currently living in Agra’s children shelter home while the elder, who is 13 years old, is in Firozabad. When contacted, the district administration said “their age differences have separated them.” But, officials said that efforts were on to house them together in a better shelter home.

Ritu Verma Indolia, district coordinator of ‘Childline Agra’, an NGO, said, “The younger one misses his brother and has expressed his wish to meet him.” A similar wish was reiterated by the elder brother.

Zafar Alam, a member of child welfare committee (CWC) of Firozabad, said, “The boy wants to meet his younger brother. We are exploring a way to help them. If necessary, we will write to district child protection unit to arrange a meeting of the two kids.”

According to Juvenile Justice Act, there should be separate shelter homes for children between 0 and 10 years, and for those above the age of 10. In Agra region, all rescued children below 10 years are kept in Shahganj child protection unit, while those above 10 years are sent to Firozabad.

But, CWC Agra’s member Gopal Sharma told TOI that a plan was ready to shift the two brothers to a better shelter home, together. However, there was a glitch or two.

“We were ready to transfer the brothers to an orphanage in Varanasi for a better life, as the proposal sent to us was suitable. But, we didn’t receive the social investigation report (SIR) of one of the brothers on time by district probation officer (DPO) of Agra and CWC Firozabad. Two days ago, the CWC of the entire state was also dissolved. But, I’m sure the next CWC will clear the hurdle.”

But, when contacted, DPO of Agra, Luvkush Bhargav denied receiving any request.

“CWC Agra didn’t give any request for the social investigation report. However, since the CWC is now dissolved, we are waiting for district magistrate of Agra to designate new executive magistrate, so that the boys’ case could be presented to them and they could be transferred to the orphanage for a better life,” Bhargav said.

Taking cognizance of the duo’s condition, a TOI reader, managing director of a private consulting firm in Gurugram, Anjali Misra along with a private orphanage ‘SOS Childline’ approached CWC Agra to shift the boys to a better shelter and offered to provide education and other help till the two brothers become self-reliant to take care of themselves.

Speaking to TOI, Anjali Misra said, “Even after several efforts to get the boys together, nothing concrete has been done by CWC Agra or by the DPO, and the two siblings continue to live 50-km apart. Those boys lost their younger sister, there mother is missing for more than seven-years and the father is set for gallows. Yet the authorities remain heartless.”

“After reading TOI report published on September 28 last year, I offered all help to DPO of Agra to help the children. I therefore contacted private orphanage in Varanasi, where several rescued children have achieved a good life after been funded by individuals,” said Misra.

Title: ‘High pension budget hurdle to military modernisation’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: An increasing pension budget has become a major hurdle to the implementation of the military’s modernization plans, said former senior officers of the Armed Forces during a panel discussion on Friday.

The discussion on the topic, ‘Analysis of Defence Budget 2020: Can Jointness Minimize The Shortfall?’, was organized by the Centre for Advanced Strategic Studies and the National Academy of Defence Finance Management.

The former officers pointed out that the government was spending more on pension than modernization of the forces. They further said jointmanship among the forces, indigenization and preventing duplication of roles can help reduce expenditure.

“If you want to improve modernization of the Armed Forces, reducing revenue budget is necessary to increase capital budget,” said Major General Nitin Gadkari (retired), who served in the Regiment of Artillery . “One of the key components of this is manpower, which forms 60% of the total budget. In the past few decades, the pension budget has grown faster than the modernization budget. In 1950, about 3.80 lakh personnel were drawing pension. The number has now grown to 26 lakh. If this continues, the pension expenditure will be eight times more than what it was in the 1970s,” Gadkari added.

Air Marshal S S Soman (retired), former Air Officer Commanding in Chief of the Western Air Command, said modernization parameters were inversely proportional to human resources parameters, such as pensions and salaries. “The pension budget has been growing at a rate of 14%. For the first time, the pension bill of the Army is more than the salary bill. Since pension and revenue bills are on the rise, the Armed Forces get only 8% budgetary allocation for modernization. This has severely affected the military’s acquisition plans,” Soman said.

Soman said jointness, or synergy of the forces, would minimize the shortfall in the defence budget. “Every effort to promote it would be worthwhile, particularly when defence budgets are marred by fiscal constraints. The appointment of the Chief of Defence Staff (CDS) was a positive step and we are looking forward to effective synergy in combat arms and operations among the services,” he said.

Rear Admiral Satish Godbole (retired) said indigenisation was necessary to reduce procurement cost by 3-4 times. “Duplication of work needs to be eliminated. For example, the Indian Coast Guard was carved out of the Navy. Now, it has its own infrastructure, ships, etc. If the Coast Guard is merged with the Navy, we can use the (extra) funds to build ships and submarines,” Godbole said.

Title: Srirangam bus stand project stuck, corporation to set up parking lot on site
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Proposal to establish a bus stand at Srirangam is likely to be delayed further as the site chosen for the proj... Read More

TRICHY: The proposal to establish a bus stand on the Panchakarai Kollidam Flood Bank Road at Srirangam under the smart cities mission is likely to be delayed further as the site chosen for the project falls outside the key focus area of the smart cities mission. Meanwhile, Trichy City Corporation has launched work on a parking lot for corporation vehicles at the same site, hinting at further delay in materializing the bus stand project or dropping the proposal.

As the civic body’s efforts to establish a bus stand at Srirangam since 2013 has failed to yield a result, the corporation revived it under the smart cities programme in July 2019. A detailed project report (DPR) was also prepared after identifying the 6.2-acre land of the local body on Panchakarai Kollidam Flood Bank Road near Yatri Nivas. The site is familiar to the local people as the previous proposal for a bus stand at the same site was shelved after finding out that the location is low-lying and flood-prone. While the residents of Srirangam were waiting for a solution through smart cities mission, the proposal seems to have hit a roadblock again. Sources said that the site chosen for the bus stand falls outside the Area Based Development (ABD) zone, the core focus area of smart cities mission. This might have forced the smart cities mission to desist from giving approvals for the proposal as there is a cap in sanctioning high-budget projects outside the ABD zone.

"We have approached the committees of the smart city mission seeking inclusion of the bus stand proposal under the mission’s ambit, and the discussion is under way," a corporation official said. However, indicating a significant delay in the proposal, the corporation has launched work on a parking lot at the site. Using the soil dug from Chathiram bus stand and the debris, the civic body is filling up the low-lying site to set up a parking lot for more than 50 corporation vehicles including trucks. "Bus stand for Srirangam is the need of the hour, the civic body should find a solution," S Deivakumar, a resident of Thiruvanaikoil said.

Title: Thermal pulsation to treat dry eye syndrome in patients
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Pune: IT professional Rashid (32) had been complaining of terrible eye strain lately. The persistent stinging, burning and scratchy sensation in his eyes almost drove him to tender his resignation at a job that required him to be seated in front of a computer screen for long.

Despite undergoing conventional treatment, Rashid’s condition continued to deteriorate. The situation used to become worse when seated in an airplane or an air-conditioned room. He recalled that watching television at night and smoking added to his woes. Upon examination, he was diagnosed with blocked eyelid glands, a condition medically known as meibomian gland dysfunction.

Eye surgeons at a city hospital used a thermal pulsation technology to treat Rashid’s chronic dry eye condition by targeting the blocked meibomian glands, which secrete oils onto the surface of the eyes to keep them lubricated.

“Meibomian gland dysfunction (MGD) is a common but often neglected eye condition,” eye surgeon Aditya Kelkar said.

Kelkar, also the director of the National Institute of Ophthalmology (NIO), has treated over 200 patients with MGD using the latest thermal pulsation therapy over the last six months. “The therapy benefits most patients with dry eye syndrome. However, it does not work in a small subset of patients who have tear deficiency condition, or in those with missing meibomian glands,” he said.

The risk of MGD increases with age. People over the age of 40 have a significantly greater risk of developing it. “Heightened use of electronic devices has made even younger generation prone to it,” Kelkar said.

The conventional treatments of MGD comprise warm compresses and eyelid hygiene to unclog the glands. Antibiotics and anti-inflammatory agents are prescribed to improve the quality of the oil.

“Thermal pulsation treatment is a drug-free approach. It is the US Food and Drug Administration-approved procedure, designed to treat the root cause of evaporative dry eye, blocked or deteriorated meibomian glands. It combines heat with physical massage to liquefy and clear the obstructions that caused the symptoms,” Ahmedabad-based eye surgeon Ashish Nagpal said.

“Correction of other factors like limiting laptop use, screen time, frequent use of lubricating eye drops, regular blinking while using computers, removal of make-up before going to bed, helps in limiting the dryness in eyes,” eye surgeon Jai Kelkar said.

Title: Gujarat: Two accused of duping beverage firm denied bail
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

VADODARA: A local court in Savli has rejected the anticipatory bail application of six persons accused of duping Manpasand Beverages Ltd (MBL).

The accused, who are associated with a private financial firm, were booked by the Bhadarva police last year for duping MBL of hundreds of crores by promising the company owners loans worth Rs 100 crore.

Police said the accused identified as Bharat Patel, Hardik Patel and Ajay Agrawal, all residents of Mumbai and Vishal Jariwala, a resident of Ahmedabad, Parashiva Bassapamurthy, a resident of Bangalore and Pavan Rathi of Vadodara, had approached MBL management and offered to give a loan of Rs 100 crores. MBL was in trouble last year when the goods and services tax (GST) officials raided the company’s premises over tax evasion.

MBL’s several directors had resigned from the company and even the banks refused to give them loans. The accused promised to give MBL a loan in lieu mortgaged the company’s properties worth Rs 600 to Rs 700 crores. MBL management said that it got loans of just Rs 12 crores.

It was also alleged that the accused kept their directors in MBL and relieved the employees from accounts and other departments.

While the accused promised to cooperate in investigations, the court observed that they didn’t turn up when the police sent them summons thrice last year. The court also considered the big amount of money involved in the cheating case and rejected the anticipatory bail application of the accused on Wednesday.

The GST officials had raided MBL premises last year and unveiled a racket of creating fake/dummy units for availing fraudulent credit and committing tax evasion of Rs 40 crores and involving turnover of Rs 300 crore. GST officials had said the investigation unearthed a network of more than 30 fake units located in various parts of the country which were used for committing fraud by availing illegal credit. MBL had registered a net loss Rs 206 crore for 2018-19.

Title: Man thrashed by gau rakshaks is arrested by Rajasthan cops
Content:
Representative image

KOTA: An MP villager suspected to be smuggling cattle from Rajasthan was allegedly assaulted by cow vigilantes in Baran district early on Thursday before being reported to police, who arrested and booked him for transporting calves in excess of the vehicle's capacity.Laxminarayan Lodha , 40, told the police he had purchased three pairs of calves in Baran for farming and was transporting them to a village in Rajgarh district of MP when he was accosted and thrashed by a dozen Gau Rakshak Dal members .Although he was injured in the assault, Lodha has refused to file a complaint against the vigilantes, the police said.A video clip purportedly showing Lodha being held by the vigilantes and beaten up has since surfaced on social media. He is heard in the video apologising repeatedly and insisting that he is a farmer.Parmanand Meena, SHO of Sarthal police station, said Lodha's arrest was based on a case filed by Ajay Tyagi , head of the Gau Rakshak Dal. "Lodha has been booked for transporting cattle in excess of the capacity of the vehicle," the police said .

Title: Pune: Thief held, kin booked for helping him flee
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A man was arrested the second time on Thursday afternoon in Pimpri village after he escaped from police custody owing to a chaotic situation that his relatives created on Wednesday afternoon.

The Pimpri police have booked five persons, including family members of the thief, for helping him flee from Samarthnagar in Pimpri.

Nadim Gafoor Shaikh (19) of Pimpri was arrested by the Government Railway Police (GRP), Pune, on Sunday for stealing valuables from railway passengers. In order to search his house, the GRP officials had taken him to Samarthnagar.

According to the Pimpri police, when the GRP officials took him to Samarthnagar, his relatives gathered there. They started shouting and created a chaotic situation at the spot. Shaikh took advantage of the situation and ran away.

The GRP officials conducted a search and lodged a complaint against Shaikh and his relatives with the Pimpri police.

Shaikh ran out of luck when the Pimpri police received a tip-off on Thursday stating that he would be visiting the area again. A police team laid a trap at a PMPML bus stop and apprehended him when he alighted from the bus.

The police have booked Shaikh and his relatives under Section 353 (assault or criminal force to deter public servant from discharge of his duty) of the Indian Penal Code .

Title: Head to Undri to make most of fun activities tomorrow morning
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Pune: The latest edition of the fun-filled Happy Streets will be held at Corinthians Resort & Club in Undri between 7am and 9.30am on Sunday. The event makes sure nobody is left out, with a range of activities available for all.

Always fancied shaking a leg at Zumba or Aerobics? The main dance stage will electrify the crowd, dishing out peppy music and setting the right tune as the instructors will lead the way.

For those who have always wanted to know more about yoga and meditation, there will be stalls set up. The stalls will have instructors, who will talk about meditation, yoga with props, dynamic yoga and pranayam. A dedicated mind and body relaxation zone will help de-stress and unclutter the mind.

You can practise your doodling skills with chalk at the art and craft section and also learn how to make key chains, lanterns and pinwheels.

Bookworms will have their own niche at this carnival too, with activities tailor-made for them. There will be a reading corner and writing workshops.

Games such as Uno and Jenga will be available as well for all. Children can play games, such as Hopscotch, musical chairs, giant snakes and ladders and participate in colouring activities, among other activities.

Make sure to check out the science section where one can play with robots, parachutes and fly drones.

Fitness enthusiasts will have their own area as well. They can indulge in agility training activities, cardio kick-boxing and cycling, among others. Experts will provide tips and techniques about combat and kick-boxing.

Happy Streets is an initiative of The Times of India in association with the Pune police, Pune traffic police, and Pune Municipal Corporation, and is powered by Nyati.

Title: TN: BSNL customers begin to feel pinch of poor service
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: Almost a week after more than 50% BSNL employees made an exodus, availing themselves of the voluntary retirement scheme (VRS), subscribers have started feeling the pinch of poor services. While city residents are witnessing the impact on mobile services, those in suburbs are complaining about drop in broadband internet speed .

Sadagopan, a resident of Pattabiram on the western outskirts of the city, and a long-time subscriber of BSNL’s broadband facility, said he was forced to surrender the service. “Services have gone from bad to worse in the last one week. I have just surrendered my broadband connection and switched over to another service provider,” he said.

According to him, the exodus of employees that left the state-owned telecom provider services further dwindling, has resulted in virtual sabotaging of communication services. “We can see the impact at BSNL telephone exchanges and customer service centres, which are struggling due to acute shortage of workers. Suburbs in Tiruvallur district are the worst hit as several localities are dependent only on BSNL for broadband services since there was no alternative or competitors,” he said.

BSNL mobile phone subscribers in the southern suburbs of Guduvancherry, besides core parts of the city, said they are running from pillar to post in search of better signal. Another long-time BSNL subscriber, who has his office at Anna Nagar, said several customers are continuing with BSNL landline connections due to their affinity towards phone numbers. “I have been using this telephone number for the past three decades. The issue is there is poor response to attend to problems,” Sridharan said.

BSNL Chennai circle chief general manager Santhosham said necessary steps are being taken to attend complaints of customers. "We are re-deploying the existing staff to all exchanges to ensure that none remain unmanned. Moreover, we are in the process of outsourcing certain technical works such as attending complaints at customer’s location,” he added.

Title: MSBSHSE serves notice to Jalgaon school
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nashik: The Nashik division of Maharashtra State Board for Secondary and Higher Secondary Education (MSBSHSE) has served a show-cause notice to a school in Jalgaon for failing to furnish the complete list of teachers for evaluating HSC examination papers.

The school, situated at Pimpalgaon (Hare) in Jalgaon district, was issued the notice on Tuesday. “We have issued a show-cause notice to the school as it concealed the names of three teachers who are approved by the board for paper evaluation. Such acts are against the rules and regulations of the board and would lead to serious consequences for the school and teachers,” divisional secretary of the board (Nashik division) Nitin Upasani said.

The schools and junior colleges were asked to submit their panel details with the list of subject-wise teachers and moderators to the board for the current academic year.

“We had to do some investigation at our end when we found out that there are schools and junior colleges that do not declare correct number of teachers and moderators which leads to extra burden of papers for the listed teachers. To do away with such practices, we have decided to take strict actions if any institute or teacher is found guilty,” Upasani added.

As the number of students has increased by over 6,000 students this year, the board will require more teachers to evaluate the papers. If the correct list of approved teachers is not shared with the board, the listed teachers have to correct more papers which may delay the declaration of results.

The board has warned the schools and junior colleges of serious consequences for such lapses. It has also asked the schools and colleges to inform the board immediately if they come across any such case in their institute.

“It is a serious misconduct. Action might lead to stoppage of increment and spoiled service record of the teacher concerned,” Upasani said.

Title: Vadodara: CA student jumps to death from 10th floor
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Highrise on Vasna-Bhayli road from where the student jumped.

VADODARA: A 21-year-old student of chartered accountancy (CA) committed suicide by jumping off a plush high-rise on Vasna-Bhayli Road in wee hours of Thursday.

The deceased identified as Pratik Gupta, jumped off the 10th floor of Milestone Apartments at about 2.30 am. He died on the spot. The police have registered a case of accidental death .

According to the police, Pratik had recently appeared for CA exams and he was tense about the results. He went to the terrace of the Milestone Apartment where he lives and jumped to his death. Security guard of the building heard a thud and rushed to the spot only to see Pratik lying in the pool of blood.

Pratik’s father Rajesh Gupta works for a multi-national company while his mother is a doctor. He was their only son. His family is in state of shock as no one had expected that Pratik would take such extreme step due to nervousness of CA results.

Title: Talapady toll fee hike due to completion of flyovers
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

A file photo of the Talapady toll booth

Mangaluru: With the completion of Pumpwell and Thokkottu flyovers, the fare at the Talapady toll booth will be hiked , said Shishu Mohan , project director, NHAI . The two flyovers—Thokkottu and Pumpwell—which took a long time to complete, were opened for traffic recently.

While Thokkottu flyover opened for traffic in June last year, Pumpwell flyover, which took almost a decade to be completed, was opened for traffic on January 31.

“So far toll fee is collected for the completed road stretch on the highway. The toll will be hiked as the two flyovers are completed and allowed for the use of commuters. The amount will be decided by the ministry of road transport and highways. NHAI will send a proposal for toll hike, and the same will be decided by the ministry,” he told TOI.

On being asked whether the toll hike is applicable to nearby toll booths such as Surathkal and Brahmarakootlu in Bantwal taluk, Shishu answered that it is only applicable for Talapady. He also added there are no current plans to construct flyovers at Nanthoor and KPT junction.

Currently, commuters travelling in undivided Dakshina Kannada pay toll at Brahmarakootlu, Talapady, Surathkal, Hejamady and Sastan. A new toll booth is planned at Shiroor.

Title: CM attacker plea verdict on Feb 13
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Vijayawada: The National Investigative Agency ( NIA ) special court in Vijayawada on Thursday heard the petition filed by Janipalli Srinivasa Rao accused of attempting to kill chief minister YS Jagan Mohan Reddy.

Abdus Saleem, the advocate representing Srinivasa Rao, argued that Srinivasa Rao did not intend to kill Jagan. He argued that Srinivas hadn’t committed any offence as alleged by the prosecution. The advocate argued that Jagan himself had called the injury minor and pointed out that Jagan was the head of the state and Srinivas nothing but a common man.

The prosecution strongly objected to the discharge petition and said that the evidence collected from the spot prove Srinivas as guilty.

Court after listening to the arguments reserved the verdict to February 13. The accused had stabbed then opposition leader Jagan’s hand at Visakhapatnam International Airport on October 25, 2018.

Title: Boost for Guntur division as Centre allots funds for prime rail projects
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Amaravati: In what could be called a practical approach to the development of railway infrastructure and boost industrial development in the state, the Centre has alloted funds to strengthen the existing rail network under Guntur division.

Meanwhile, the railway board has added the doubling of Guntur-Bibi Nagar project to its list of priorities by listing it in the pink book, which registers projects to be taken up across the country. The projects listed in the pink book get automatic clearance from the finance ministry. The doubling of Guntur-Bibi Nagar would help both Guntur and Vijayawada divisions get more new trains as it will improve connectivity with Hyderabad and other metro cities. The railway board has granted permission for the final survey of the railway line and is likely to begin allocation of funds after getting the location survey report.

The 248-km long second line to connect Guntur with Hyderabad is expected to cost Rs 2,500 crore. Many of the trains running between Guntur and Hyderabad usually take nearly six-eight hours because it is a single-line track. Since many of the major cement plants are located near Nadikudi and Miryalaguda stations in Guntur division, freight movement also gets affected due to the single-line track.

The double lining of Guntur-Bibi Nagar would help the entire South Central Railway (SCR) reap rich dividends by operating more trains to facilitate the freight movement. This is also expected to help upland areas of Guntur and Krishna districts get more industries. In another significant move, the finance ministry spared nearly Rs 1,198 crore for ongoing Nadikudi-Srikalahasthi new railway project. The 308-km long project is expected to cost around Rs 3,500 crore.

The Nadikudi-Srikalahasthi project is already in the Prime Minister’s priority projects list and has been getting funds from the Centre. The first phase of the project between New Piduguralla and Savalyapuram stations in Guntur districts is nearing completion and expected to begin operating by March. Fresh allocation of budget will put the second phase of works, which passes through the most under-developed region of Prakasam and Nellore districts, on the fast track.

Meanwhile, Centre seems to have junked the dream Amaravati rail line project. Although, the railway board had given its green signal to the first-phase of the rail project about two years ago, the then TDP government had failed to put it on fast track that has helped the Centre to put it on the backburner.

Title: Absconding blackmailer held in Amreli
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Rajkot: An absconding accused wanted in a blackmailing case was nabbed from Bhurakhia Chowkadi on Damnagar-Dhasa Road in Amreli district on Thursday.

Police said the accused, Munna Bhuva (21), had allegedly shot a video of the complainant showing him in a compromising position with a woman, and had demanded Rs one lakh from him on September 6 last year. Bhuva threatened to circulate the video clip on social media and make it viral, if he did not pay.

“At the request of the victim, Bhuva scaled down the amount to Rs 40,000 and took Rs 2,000 from the victim as a token amount. After this, the complainant approached us with a complaint and we launched a manhunt for Bhuva,” said an official from Damnagar police station.

Title: Coronavirus: Indore airport authorities distribute masks to security personnel, staff
Content:
Representative image.

INDORE: Airport authorities on Thursday distributed masks and other safety gear to security personnel, on-ground staff and other employees posted at medical inspection room and customs and immigration counters as a precautionary measure against coronavirus infection.The authorities also put up messages including do’s and don’ts in the whole airport area to sensitize passengers about the virus and ways to avoid getting infected by it.A medical team from district health department is also checking passengers with symptoms like cough and cold, round the clock.At MY hospital, condition of two persons who had been admitted to isolation ward on suspicion of having contracted the virus, was reported to be stable. “They have improved. We are waiting for report of their samples that have been sent to Pune,” hospital superintendent Dr PS Thakur said.In Dewas, district health department has begun daily monitoring of six youngsters who had returned from China last month. The youngsters, including two females, were provided with masks and other safety gear as a precautionary measure.District nodal officer, Dr SS Malviya said, “We have been going to houses of six youngsters who had returned from China and are collecting some basic information about them. Till now, I have received information about two and information about two others will be updated late in night by block medical officer. Information about two youngsters couldn’t be fetched as their addresses weren’t found. These youngsters haven’t developed any symptoms till date.”

Title: Runkuta to get nagar panchayat status
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Runkuta is located adjacent to the National Highway-2. It is around 12 kilometres from the city and has a popu... Read More

AGRA: Runkuta gram panchayat will soon get the status of a nagar panchayat. Following the proposal of minister of state Chaudhary Udaybhan Singh , the district administration has sent a report to the state government for approval.

A village of Kiraoli sub-division, Runkuta is located adjacent to the National Highway-2. It is around 12 kilometres from the city and has a population of around 30,000.

After getting elected as an MLA from Fatehpur Sikri assembly constituency, Chaudhary Udaybhan Singh started working on a plan to get nagar panchayat status for Runkuta.

Sub-divisional magistrate of Kiraoli Mahesh Prakash Gupta said, “A report has been sent to the urban development ministry of the state government to provide the status of nagar panchayat to Runkuta. A proposal was sent by the local MLA.”

Gram Pradhan of Runkuta Maya Devi said, “Local residents have been demanding for a nagar panchayat status to Runkuta since past several years. The area will see rapid development after the final approval from the state government.”

Singh said, “Runkuta fulfills all the conditions to get the status of a nagar panchayat. Soon, the state government will provide the final approval in this regard. The area will see rapid development related to water supply, sewer and road infrastructure.”

In the report sent to the state government, district administration has mentioned that out of around 30,000 local residents, only 500 to 600 people are dependent on agriculture. Runkuta has 10 residential colonies, eight branches of banks, post offices, markets, four private hospitals etc.

According to sources, the status of nagar panchayat to Runkuta will be beneficial for the Soor Sarovar Bird Sanctuary located nearby. Last week, state forest minister Dara Singh Chauhan declared that Soor Sarovar Bird Sanctuary will be developed as an eco-tourism destination. In this regard, the state government is likely to make announcement in the state budget.

Title: Long-stay home for people who overcome mental problems
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Indore: In a bid to rehabilitate people with mental problems, district administration is setting up a long-stay home for patients, who are discharged from hospital. The step has been taken as per guideline set by Supreme Court.

In Madhya Pradesh, Indore and Gwalior have government-run mental hospitals and provide halfway home facility but don’t have any provision to provide shelters to the patients, who have been cured but their family members have refused to accept them. The facility of long-stay home being set up in both cities is meant to provide shelter, food, clothes and treatment, if required any, who have been cured two years ago.

“In OPD, we examine 250-300 patients daily while there are around 900 admissions in the hospital in a year. We have recorded almost 100 per cent discharge of male patients after they are cured while for female patients, this percentage is around 70-80, which is very painful as society doesn’t want to accept them,” superintendent and professor Dr Ramgulam Razdan told TOI.

He added that the hospital has a 30-bed halfway home but setting up of long-stay home will be for people, who are cured or need long term medication.

“It will be a 50-bed long-stay home for people mostly destitute or whose family members have denied accepting them. There is a provision to seek legal help for them to protect their rights including their claim in family property. But during this, they will be provided shelter in new facility,” zila panchayat CEO Neha Meena told TOI.

To rehabilitate cured persons, state social justice department has formed a district-level committee to be headed by district collector as chairman. At the centre, records of inmates will be maintained and they will be provided treatment and medication if required, along with food, clothes and different means of entertainment. For the facility, department will make appointments at as many as 10 posts while psychologist, general physician and occupational therapist will also serve as part-time.

The centre is likely to start by next month.

Title: 10-year target to be carbon neutral
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Pune: A think tank which works on reversing the impact of climate change, Pune Climate Collective (CLiC), has outlined goals to ensure that the city becomes carbon neutral over the next ten years.

A document — Making Pune Metropolitan Region Carbon Neutral by 2030 — released by CLiC recently has outlined the ways to ensure maximum carbon sequestration in the Pune Metropolitan Regional Development Authority (PMRDA) region.

Aditi Kale, a coordinator at the CLiC, said, “We have been preparing this report for the last one year. We came out with the document to make the PMRDA region carbon neutral by 2030”.

Whatever you’re emitting is compensated by the sequestration, that is, storage or the carbon sinks, Kale said. “Right now, about 97% of the emissions are not getting sequestered”, she said.

The document proposed a two-way action plan. “We would focus on emission reduction and carbon sequestration. We need to ensure proper emission reduction with a 70% cut on emissions. Our sequestration capacity is thrice of what it is right now. So, with this we could reduce the emission gap significantly”, she said.

Title: Habitats of water birds should be protected
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

10th edition of Thamirabarani Waterbird Court observed

MADURAI: Wildlife enthusiasts and organisers of the 10th edition of Thamirabarani Waterbird Court (TWC) observed that many irrigation tanks have been desilted and maintained to collect more water. But they expressed concerned over the poor maintenance of the waterbodies by the villagers and residents around them.

They said that the villagers, who are the primary stakeholders of the waterbodies, are unaware of the water resources. They observed that the tanks are exploited by dumping loads of garbage. The survey stated that a lot of used liquor bottles and plastic were found in nearly 90% of the tanks that were surveyed.

There is a sharp decline in the number of birds at Kadambakulam that had attracted more than 10,000 water birds – mostly ducks – this year as the tank was encroached and polluted by invasive species such as Ipomea Carnea and Eichhornia. They killed native species that ducks feed on and also shrunk the surface water needed for the birds.

They lamented over waterbodies turning into open bars by boozers who throw bottles and waste in and around the tank. Another issue of concern was hunting the winged visitors using coracle and dogs.

Urging the government and district administrations to take strong action against such anti-social elements, they pressed for local community monitoring to save the habitats. They said awareness programmes should be conducted for the local community for the conservation of tanks and birds.

Emphasising the need for a proper management plan to develop irrigation tanks by involving line departments, farmer groups and experts in the field of wetland ecology, they also emphasised on biodiversity monitoring by forming local committees in select wetlands that are critical for biodiversity.

Title: Man held for Kumbh blast threat on social media
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

GORAKHPUR: A 45-year-old man was arrested and sent to Deoria district jail on Thursday for allegedly issuing threats on social media to trigger blasts at Kumbh Mela and Deoria Mahotsav. The message went viral, prompting police action.

Kotwali inspector TJ Singh said accused Nasiruddin Ansari was a resident of Vishnupur Chirkihwa under Rampur Karkhana police station in Deoria. “The in-charge of Rampur Karkhana thana received a screenshot of the incendiary message, which was sent from the mobile number 9517244848. We put the number on surveillance and it led us to Ansari,” Singh said.

Based on the complaint of the police station in-charge, a case was registered against Ansari under Sections 153, 505(1)B and 507 of the IPC and Section 66C of the IT Act. He was arrested from Kotwali following a tip-off, Singh added.

Title: Parking fee row: Traders turn docs to ‘treat’ to ‘corrupt’ AMC, mayor
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Agra: Traders of Sanjay Place, who have been protesting for the past 24 days against parking fee imposed by Agra Municipal Corporation (AMC) in the market, turned “doctors” to attend to the “ailing mayor Naveen Jain and the civic body” on Thursday.

As a mark of protest, the traders set up a symbolic ICU at the dharna spot in the parking space. Two traders lay down on the beds as “patients” named after mayor Jain and AMC”. A team of traders playing the role of “untrained doctors with over 10 years of experience” treated “the patients”. The “doctors” claimed that “the patients” were in a bad condition as they had consumed “garbage and sewage”.

As “lucky charm”, brand new shoes were hung on the bed of both “patients” to keep evil spirits away.

Vice-president of Sanjay Place welfare association Brijendra Baghel said, “The AMC is seriously affected by the disease of corruption. They are exploiting traders by illegally charging a parking fee. Only public awareness can bring any relief.”

Since January 14, traders of Sanjay Place have been sitting on an indefinite dharna against imposition of parking fee at 38 places in the market premises by AMC. They claimed it violates norms as they had already paid a one-time parking fee at the time of purchasing the property.

Secretary of Sanjay Place Market Association Hiren Agarwal said, “AMC has flouted norms as traders of the market have already paid a fee for parking space at the time of purchasing property. The dictatorship of AMC administration will not be tolerated at any cost. The protest will continue till the fee is rolled back.”

The dispute over parking fees between Sanjay Place traders and AMC is sub judice. Traders want AMC to cancel parking contracts till the court delivers its verdict in the matter.

Association's treasurer Vinay Mittal alleged, “Despite the ongoing case at the sessions court, AMC administration has issued parking contracts for three years to people associated with BJP. AMC officials also get a share of the parking fee illegally collected at the market. We will not withdraw our protest till the AMC rolls back its decision.”

Title: Vadodara Municipal Corporation not likely to burden GCMMF
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

VADODARA: The Vadodara Municipal Corporation (VMC) is looking to amend the conditions for allocation of dairy parlous to Gujarat Cooperative Milk Marketing Federation (VMC). The VMC had put up condition that GCMMF would maintain the gardens where it had the parlours including the Sayajibaug, but VMC wants to make an exception for Sayajibaug after a missive from GCMMF in this regard.

After a major row regarding the parlours located in eight gardens that had also reached the Gujarat high court, the VMC had last year agreed to allocate the eight parlours to GCMMF on the condition of the gardens’ maintenance. GCMMF wrote to the VMC in October expressing inability to maintain the Sayajibaug better known as Kamatibaug.

The situation is understandable given the size of the garden and the expenses involved. The VMC has now come up with a proposal that the maintenance of Sayajibaug should not be included in the conditions for allocation of booths in the gardens to GCMMF. The standing committee of the civic body will take a decision in this regard in its meeting on Friday.

Title: PMPML mulls stringent punishment for drivers
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Pune: The Pune Mahanagar Parivahan Mahamandal Limited (PMPML) is mulling stricter punishments like suspension or dismissal from service for bus drivers speaking on phones while driving.

The PMPML officials are also contemplating reviving an old system which involved giving rewards to people for clicking photographs of PMPML drivers speaking on cellphones while driving. Sources said the monetary reward system was abolished because there were only a certain set of people providing photographs of drivers to the PMPML.

Recently, nine drivers were fined Rs 1,000 each. One of them caught repeating the offence for the second time, was slapped with a penalty of Rs 2,000. The authorities recently fined five drivers Rs 1,000 each for using cellphones while they were at the wheel. “The punishment for drivers needs to be made stricter. They may be suspended for an indefinite period or dismissed if found violating the same rule repeatedly,” an official told TOI.

Title: Jodhpur AIIMS team surveys site near city
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Team at the Pandit Deendayal Upadyay Medical College, Rajkot

Rajkot: A four-member team of All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS), Jodhpur visited Rajkot on Thursday to start a medical college in the city from the next academic year. The central government had given approval for an AIIMS in Rajkot with Jodhpur AIIMS as its parent hospital.

The dean of Pandit Deendayal Upadyay Medical College, Rajkot, Gauravi Dhruva told TOI: “AIIMS authorities want to start a 50-seat medical college from June for which the four-member team visited the city. They surveyed the site for starting the education facility.”

The team has also visited the government medical college as well as a few private colleges too. “They will now take a final decision looking at the suitable facility,” Dhruva added.

State’s first super multi-speciality hospital will come up between Khandheri and Parapiriya on Jamnagar road in the outskirts of Rajkot.

The district administration has already allotted 200 acre land for which acquisition work is expected to complete by the end of current financial year.

The AIIMS hospital in Rajkot is expected to be fully functional by 2022.

Title: Kia plans to ramp up annual output to three lakh units
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Vijayawada/Tirupati: Moving swiftly to scotch reports that Kia Motors India was negotiating with the Tamil Nadu government to move its car-assembly unit in Anantapur district to the neighbouring state, the state government on Thursday said the Korean carmaker is planning to ramp up its production capacity in the state from 2 lakh units per annum to 3 lakh units by the end of this year.

Both the AP government and Kia Motors dubbed media reports that the carmaker was negotiating with the Tamil Nadu government to relocate its unit as “false”, “unfounded” and “untrue”.

In a separate press statement, Rajat Bhargava, special chief secretary (industries & infrastructure), AP government, dismissed the report as baseless. “The government of AP condemns the false report. This is a completely baseless story as Kia Motors and Andhra Pradesh are continuing their strong partnership with Kia planning to ramp up their production capacity in the state from 2 lakh units per annum to 3 lakh units by end of this year or earlier,” Bhargava said.

Bhargava added that the principal secretary to industries department of Tamil Nadu has conveyed that they are not in talks with Kia Motors and that there were no discussions between the two parties in this regard.

A Kia Motors India spokesperson too dismissed the “unfounded and untrue” report. “Kia has a long-term commitment to India market. We have made an investment of $1.1 billion for our state-of-the-art manufacturing facility at Anantapur. We do not have any plans to shift our production facility from the current location and we are on the right track to utilize the full capacity of the facility. We will continue to offer world-class, made-in-Anantapur vehicles and innovative mobility experience to our valuable customers in India,” he said in a statement.

The AP government also refuted media reports that suggested Kia Motors was planning to drive out due to the July 2019 law brought in by the state to set aside 75% of private sector jobs in AP for locals. “Reports of the state government not fulfilling the commitment in terms of industrial incentives and problems on account of the state government’s 75% reservation for locals in jobs etc are not true. The government is committed to fulfil all the obligations extended to Kia Motors, whether it is with respect to incentives,” Industries minister Mekapati Goutham Reddy said.

Finance minister Buggana Rajendranath and YSRC parliamentary party leader V Vijaysai Reddy too strongly condemned the report, saying the state government enjoys excellent relations with Kia Motors. The issue reached the corridors of Parliament when TDP MP K Rammohan Naidu raised it in the Lok Sabha, seeking the Centre’s interference to save the state’s resources. YSRC MP Peddireddy Mithun Reddy, refuted the charge and asserted the plant would remain in AP.

Title: 195 excise teams crack down on illicit liquor
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Vijayawada: Excise sleuths conducted massive crackdown on illicit liquor across all districts in Andhra Pradesh on Thursday. According to officials, 195 teams lead by respective circle inspectors and sub-inspectors carried out the raids. In Krishna district, 27 teams raided eight areas in Machilipatnam, Bantumilli, Vissannapet and Tiruvuru areas.

They arrested and registered four cases against four persons. They also seized and destroyed 43 illicit distillations, 137 kilograms of black jaggery and other ingredients. Across the state, they raided 82 habitations, booked 13 cases and arrested 15 persons in total. They also destroyed 521 distillations, 84115 litres of illicit liquor and 1482 kgs of black jaggery and 137 kgs of white jaggery.

The most number of cases (5) and arrests (8) were made in East Godavari district, followed by Krishna district and Guntur district.

In many places, persons who are manufacturing country liquor through klins have been arrested. TNN

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Mother, three kids found dead in trans-Ganga village home
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Police investigate the crime scene on Thursday

ALLAHABAD: A 35-year-old widow and her three minor daughters were found dead at their Aswa Daudpur village home in trans-Ganga area, 40km from the district headquarters, on Thursday morning.

While circumstantial evidence and preliminary investigation indicate that Manju Devi, a bidi worker, committed suicide with her children, Priya (8), Annu (6) and Ritika (4), police are waiting for autopsy reports to confirm the same.

Parents of the woman have accused her two brothers-in-law, Mahesh and Dinesh, of harassing her since her husband Ramesh Bharatiya passed away four years ago. Following claims of abetment and even murder, police have detained Mahesh and Manju’s father-in-law Shri Nath for questioning.

SSP Satyarth Anirudh Pankaj, who inspected the scene along with SP (trans-Ganga), however, said there were no external marks of injury on the bodies and all household items were in place, suggesting no forced entry.

Neighbours told police that Manju and her children were last seen at a dinner at a local villager’s home on Wednesday. “When the kids did not come out to play this morning, neighbours became curious. Some peeped through a window and found the girls lying unresponsive on two separate cots. They broke in and found Manju on the floor, lifeless too,” the SSP said.

Demanding immediate action, family members blocked vehicles when police tried to take the bodies away for postmortem examination. They relented after senior officers intervened and promised thorough investigations.

SSP Pankaj said forensic experts were working on the case and both abetment to suicide and murder angles would be probed.

Title: T N Prathapan gets 10,000 books as donation
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Thrissur MP T N Prathapan received books at a function by Kerala Pradesh School Teachers Association

THRISSUR: T N Prathapan , MP, received nearly 10,000 books in a day as donation at a function of Kerala Pradesh School Teachers Association (KPSTA) state meeting in Thrissur.

In the public meeting, teachers from across the state gifted the books to Prathapan. G K Girija, teacher of Kasaragod Cheruvathoor GLP School presented the first book ‘Ente Sathyanweshana Pareekshakal’ by Mahatma Gandhi. All the teachers who were present at the function gifted a book each. KPSTA Kasaragod and Kannur district committees offered 1,000 books each and Varkala education district offered 500 books to the initiative.

The presented books were of various genres including science, comics, poetry, novels and history. “The gifted books will be distributed to the best school and college libraries of the district, Snehatheeram Library and the main libraries of the seven assembly constituencies within Thrissur’s parliament constituency. I have received immense support from various quarters after my decision to collect books,” said Prathapan.

Universal record forum representatives Sunil Joseph , Sathar Aathoor and Lijo George inspected the books and presented a certificate for garnering such a vast number of books in a single day. The certificate was handed over to former KPCC president M M Hassan, who was present at the function.

Prathapan had announced that he would not accept flowers or other items during his programmes as mementoes at a function on June 19, 2019 when he was sworn in as MP. Since the last six months, he has received over 8,000 books from various functions.

Prathapan’s decision to accept only books as gifts was widely appreciated on the social media. Thiruvananthapuram M P Shashi Tharoor too had supported this initiative.

Recently, Prathapan had set up a library at Viyyur high security prison where he had donated over 2,000 books to it.

Title: Enrolment of convicts at YCMOU courses dips
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nashik: The number of convicts enrolling for studying different courses offered by Nashik-based Yashwantrao Chavan Maharashtra Open University ( YCMOU ) has gone down by around 50%.

In the academic year 2018-19, as many as 1,803 convicts from across seven central jails in the state had took admission in various undergraduate courses at YCMOU. However, for the ongoing academic session, the total number is 998.

“The enrolment of convicts to pursue any educational course largely depends on jail authorities as they have to encourage the prisoners to study and get educated during their stay in the jail,” an official from the university told TOI.

Teaching in jails was started in the year 2008-09 and since then YCMOU has made seven jails across the state as its study centres. Till now, several certificate and undergraduate courses offered by the university have been completed by the convicts.

Other than Nashik Road Central Jail , central prisons in Amravati, Kolhapur, Nagpur, Thane and district prisons in Dhule and Aurangabad are the study centres of YCMOU.

“While most of the convicts only join the undergraduate courses, seven convicts in Nagpur jail are pursuing Masters of Arts,” the varsity official said, adding 23 convicts from Thane have opted for English being their medium of learning as English, while rest have opted for Marathi-medium.

E Vayunandan, vice-chancellor of YCMOU, said “It was a novel move by the university that has benefited thousands of convicts who wanted to educate themselves. It is a positive move that helps them in coming out of their gloomy past and take a leap in the future.”

He added, “Being an open varsity, the convicts receive the study material in jail. If someone requires help, other educated convicts help them in understanding the concepts. The examination is conducted in the jail itself and the answer sheets are sent to the varsity for correction.”

Pramod Wagh, superintendent of Nashik Road central jail, said, “Last year 59 convicts showed interest in studying from the YCMOU whereas 65 convicts enrolled for the undergraduate courses in 2019-20. For 2020-21, the admissions are still on and around 50 convicts have taken admission.”

Since all convicts are not eligible for an under-graduate course, the varsity started a six-month preparatory course for them. The course teaches basic subjects to the convicts and after passing that course, they can join any undergraduate course from the varsity.

Title: Transporters’ body seeks dedicated parking space
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Pune: The transporter’s body has approached municipal commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad regarding a dedicated space to park buses and trucks. The civic chief had listed “improvement in city’s transport” among his top priorities.

The transporters’ body recently submitted a memorandum to Gaikwad to allot land for parking of larger commercial vehicles to avoid roadside parking that may create a nuisance for road users.

As per estimates, on a daily basis over 800 buses travel through the city, including private luxury buses and buses hired by citizens or industries. A similar numbers of trucks enter the city with goods and food items. The transporters’ body has pointed out that the city lacked dedicated truck or bus terminus.

“We have urged the civic chief to organize a meeting with the transporters at the earliest to discuss the issues. We will have a positive approach and we are ready to extend the required support to the civic administration,” said Baba Shinde, leader of the transporters’ body.

Shinde added that issues pertaining to provision of truck and bus terminus have been raised over the years on various platforms but transporters still await concrete solutions. “Since the new civic chief has expressed willingness to work on solutions to improve the city’s traffic, we are hoping for a breakthrough,” he added.

The proposal to allot land of octroi posts and vacant plots for buses and trucks is already under consideration. The transporters’ body has said that they were ready to utilize the spaces after payment of due charges. The civic administration must give recommendations to develop the plots that are reserved as parking spaces for trucks.

The transporters’ body have said that they would prefer parking bays located on the outskirts of the city. This will avoid entry of bigger vehicles on the city roads. The transporters also want at least one parking bay in every direction of the city or near major roads leading out of the city.

Title: MP: Doctors clear heart block with shockwave therapy
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image.

INDORE: In a first for the state, a team of doctors of Apollo Hospital have performed Lithotripsy — a shock wave therapy used for breaking down kidney stones — to clear the calcified blockage from the arteries of a senior citizen in the city.

A team comprising interventional cardiologists Dr K Roshan Rao and Dr Sarita Rao along with Dr Shirish Agarwal and Dr Vikas Gupta performed rotashock surgery using shock wave lithoplasty on a 75-year-old man.

Dr K Roshan Rao said that the man had suffered an acute heart attack a couple of days back and his left side arteries had deposition of very hard calcium chunks. In this situation, the conventional balloons failed even at higher pressure, he said.

The team, after explaining the patient ’s situation to his family members, decided to perform lithoplasty. “We used a combination of ballooning with intravascular lithotripsy to break down the calcium deposition inside and around the arteries for clearing blockages, he said.

Dr Sarita Rao said that using a console machine generating acoustic sonic waves at very low pressure ranging between four and six atmospheric pressure, a patient can be given eight cycles of ten second-shock each for breaking and clearing the blockage in the arteries. The waves are proved to impact according to the rigidity of the hard surface hence lowering the risk, she said.

When asked about the advantage of the new console technology over earlier ones used for angioplasty, she said, “This technology of clearing blockages in the artery will reduce risks involved in angioplasty including perforation and dissection, risking patient’s life.”

Angioplasty through this technique is quicker than the traditional one. This technique takes around half an hour for the entire process in comparison to four hours in traditional ones, she said.

This technique will prove to be a major help to elderly people, people with diabetes and those who don’t want bypass surgery or for those on whom it couldn’t be performed, she said.

Title: Bhusawal railway division gets Rs 5,362 crore this fiscal
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Rs 4984 crore has been assigned for the Manmad- Indore railway line

NASHIK: The central government has allocated Rs 5 ,362 crore for Bhusawal division of the Central Railway (CR) in the Union Budget specifically for construction of new lines.

The bulk of the money (Rs 4,984 crore) has been assigned for the newly-proposed Manmad-Indore railway line project, the ground breaking ceremony for which carried out last year by Prime Minister Narendra Modi. The Manmad-Indore railway track project is around of 368-km-long and the work will be carried out in one go.

“This is the biggest work that has been sanctioned for the division so far. Funds allocated for Manmad-Indore track is on the lines of Extra Budgetary Resources (Partnerships), indicating that the work can be taken up with investment from states and even others,” a senior official from Bhusawal division said.

The new track will cut down the traveling distance to New Delhi by more than 150-km and benefit the future plans of the railways of running high speed trains between Mumbai and Delhi.

As of now the railways favour the western route for Delhi and many trains coming from South are also diverted from the Western route which is shorter than the current Central route between Mumbai and Delhi.

The 265-km Pune-Nashik route, however, has seen no allocation of funds in the budget. But construction of 56-km line between Dhule and Nardana has got allocation of Rs 1 crore. Apart from this, the budget has also proposed Rs 262 crore for construction of third lines at four different locations.

The works include 24-km Jalgaon-Bhusawal track (Rs 10 crore), 247-km track between Daund and Manmad (Rs 42 crore), 160–km Manmad-Jalgaon track (Rs 200 crore) and 124-km Igatpur-Manmad track (Rs 10 crore). The 67-km Kasara-Kalyan track has also been allocated Rs 55 crore.

The budgetary provision of Rs 50 crore for the fourth track between Jalgaon and Bhusawal (24 km) has also been made, the railway sources said.

Rs 10 crore has been allotted for setting up a workshop for overhauling and repairing of wheels at Traction Machine Workshop. The budget has also allocated Rs 63 lakh for construction of road over bridge (ROB) between Nashik Road and Deolali.

Title: Two months on, investigation moves at a snail’s pace
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Mangaluru: Even as police are still questioning school students of Shaheen School in Bidar for staging an anti-CAA play, the Dakshina Kannada police are still investigating a case filed two months ago for recreating the Babri mosque demolition at a school run by RSS member Kalladka Prabhakar Bhat .

The police, who have come under heavy criticism over a biased investigation , have not made any arrest, according to complainants.

On December 17, Bantwal Town Police had filed a case for hurting religious sentiments, based on a complaint filed by Abubakar Siddiq, 42, a PFI member. The case was registered after students of Sri Rama Vidya Kendra at Kalladka, in Bantwal taluk, about 35 km away from Mangaluru, re-created the demolition of the Babri Masjid , at its Sports Day event.

The case was filed against Dr Kalladka Prabhakar Bhat, president, Vivekananda Vidhyavardhaka Sanga, Narayana Somayaji, president, Sri Rama School, Kalladka, headmaster of the school, Vasantha Madhava, co-ordinator of the school and Chennappa Kotyan, member of the school. A case was filed under sections 295 (a) (deliberate and malicious acts, intended to outrage religious feelings of any class by insulting its religion or religious beliefs) and 298 (uttering, words with deliberate intent to wound the religious feelings of any person) of the Indian Penal Code.

“The case is still under investigation. Police haven’t made any arrest or interrogated anyone so far in this connection. We have sent a video to the Forensic Science Laboratory and are waiting for their report,” said a police officer, who is investigating the case.

The programme also had witnessed participation of many dignitaries including Puducherry lieutenant governor Kiran Bedi and prominent political representatives’ from the current state government.

“We have not arrested or interrogated anyone so far in this case and only witness statements have been recorded. The video has been sent to the FSL to check its veracity, and it will take another six months to get a report from them,” said superintendent of police B M Laxmi Prasad.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Three held with rare snake worth Rs 10 lakh
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Police with the rescued snake in Allahabad on Thursday

ALLAHABAD: Three members of an inter-district gang involved in smuggling rare species of animals were arrested from near Lalapur-Bara trisection on Thursday while they were planning to smuggle out an endangered snake to Bihar.

The sand boa, a non-venomous snake carrying a price tag of Rs 10 lakh for myths like two heads and special powers, was found in a blue bag inside an SUV. It was rescued and handed over to the forest authorities.

The arrested trio have been identified as Tuntun Singh, Nitish Singh and Nanhak Singh, all residents of Bhojpur , Bihar. Police are looking for three other members of the gang — Munna Singh, Abhishek Singh and Vimlesh Singh, also residents of Bhojpur.

Title: Fleeing bootleggers in SUV hit cop’s car
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Ramkrishna Bishnoi

Rajkot: A bootlegger was booked for attempt to murder when he rammed his SUV loaded with IMFL bottles into a cop’s private car in Chela village on Jamnagar bypass on Thursday.

Cops were on a lookout in Chela village, after they had received a tip-off about the liquor-laden SUV. When cops intercepted the SUV, the bootlegger tried to flee and rammed into the car where constable Rushirajsinh Jadeja of Jamnagar C division police station, was seated.

“After the accident, the SUV stopped and the bootleggers tried to run away. We managed to catch hold of one identified as Ramkrishna Bishnoi (28),” said inspector M J Zalu. Apart from Bishnoi, police booked Sunil Bishnoi, Pruthvirajsinh, Vijay Manek on attempt to murder charges and launched a manhunt for the absconding criminals. They abandoned the SUV at the spot which had BJP’s lotus symbol on its number plate. “We are investigating if it belonged to any BJP leader or was misuse of the party symbol. We had seized 360 IMFL bottles worth Rs 1.80 lakh from the SUV,” added Zalu.

In a similar incident, a truck loaded with IMFL bottles was seized and a bootlegger was arrested at Bamanbor GIDC near Rajkot on Wednesday night.

The truck carrying 5,346 IMFL bottles worth Rs 21.50 lakh was seized and a bootlegger identified as Harish Chaudhary (22) arrested.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Stepmother strangles minor boy to death
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: A 35-year-old woman was arrested on charges of strangling her six-year-old step son to death in Pipri area of Kaushambi district on Thursday.

The arrested woman was identified as Minta Devi, wife of Chandan Pasi and resident of Giriya Khalsa village. Additional SP (Kaushambi) Ashok Kumar said, “The matter came to light when the body of a six-year-old boy, Arun Kumar, was found inside his home in Giriya village on Tuesday night. A case under section 302 of the IPC was registered at Pipri police station.”

“On Wednesday, the postmortem report of the minor revealed strangulation as the cause of death,” the SP said. “When police rigorously interrogated Minta, she confessed to have killed the minor boy out of jealousy,” he added.

Police informed that Minta had left her first husband—with whom she had two kids—six years ago and had later married another man named Chandan Pasi.

Even after four years into the marriage, she had no child with Chandan. Arun was Chandan’s only child from his first wife who died around four years ago.

Irked over not having a child with Chandan for the past four years, Minta hatched a conspiracy to kill Arun out of jealousy.

Title: Maharashtra: 67-year-old held for exploiting 7-year-old granddaughter
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Illustration used for representational purpose.

Title: MoD increases term of 55 cantt boards
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PIMPRI CHINCHWAD: The defence ministry has extended the term of elected members of 55 cantonment boards, including Pune, Khadki and Dehu Road, across the country by six months.

The ministry issued an order on Wednesday extending the tenure of the boards. The cantonment boards of Deolali , Ahmednagar, Aurangabad and Kamptee in the state also got an extension.

The elections of these cantonment boards were held in January 2015 and they came into existence on February 10, 2015. Their five-year tenure would end on February 10, but fresh elections have not been conducted till now to replace the elected members of the boards.

Resultantly, the defence ministry issued an order on Wednesday to extend the tenure of the cantonment boards by six months.

The order from the defence ministry stated that the central government exercised the power vested in it under the provision to sub-section (1) of Section 14 of the Cantonments Act, 2006, and extended the term of office of all the elected members of the 55 cantonment boards up to a period of six months or till the date of constitution of the board, whichever was earlier.

Suresh Kamble, member and former vice-president of the Khadki Cantonment Board (KCB), said, “The process of reserving wards for Scheduled Castes (SC), Scheduled Tribes (ST) and women could not be completed on time.”

He said, “Also, the election code of conduct for cantonment elections has to come into force 45 days before the polls are held.”

Pramod Singh, the chief executive officer of the KCB, and R Haritwal, the chief executive member of the Dehu Road Cantonment Board (DCB), could not be contacted despite repeated attempts to reach them.

Former vice-president of KCB Kamble said a similar extension was granted to the cantonment boards in May 2013.

“The five-year tenure of 2008-13 of the cantonment boards had ended in May 2013. So, the defence ministry had given two six-month extensions to the cantonment boards then,” said Kamble.

Title: NIA cites SC and HC rulings for Elgar case proceedings shift
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PUNE: The National Investigation Agency on Thursday relied on two superior court judgments to push its case for transfer of the Elgar Parishad case records, seized properties and proceedings from the UAPA court in the city to the NIA court in Mumbai.

Defence lawyers as well as one of the arrested activists, Surendra Gadling , opposed the plea, arguing that the National Investigation Agency (NIA) ought to have moved the Bombay high court as the Pune court had no competence/jurisdiction to entertain the plea for transfer of the case proceedings from one district to another.

Special UAPA judge S R Navander posted the matter for next hearing on Friday morning after district government pleader Ujjwala Pawar sought time to study the citations put forth by the NIA and the defence in support of their respective submissions.

NIA’s lawyer Namdev Taralgatti referred to Supreme Court’s 2017 judgment in CBI vs Prakashan C case and submitted, the probe agency was legally entitled to take over the investigation. He referred to a 2013 Kerala high court ruling, which held that re-registration of FIR and renumbering of case did not amount to a second FIR but was merely an administrative exercise.

Taralgatti read out various sections under the NIA Act and pointed out that the national agency had taken over further probe, an FIR had been re-registered and submitted to the Mumbai court and the NIA’s chargesheet, in future, would be filed in the Mumbai court. As such, it was imperative that the case records, seized properties and proceedings be moved to the Mumbai court, he said.

Defence lawyer Siddharth Patil argued the home ministry’s January 24 order only referred to transfer of investigation and made no mention about transfer of the case proceedings. The NIA’s plea was not maintainable as only the high court had the power to transfer case proceedings from one district to another, he said. Even the cases relied on by the NIA involved matters before the high court, he added.

Gadling argued there was no provision in the Code of Criminal Procedure entitling the NIA to make the instant plea as it ought to have moved the high court. He referred to a Bombay high court ruling that mere notification transferring investigation did not bring the NIA Act into play unless the state physically handed over the case records to the agency. He said the high court was to hear on February 10 a plea by the accused challenging the very proceeding before the Pune court as illegal. As such, judicial propriety called for the Pune court to desist from entertaining the NIA plea, he added.

Lawyer Shahid Akhtar argued the NIA plea was bereft of any specific provision to justify transfer considering that the Pune police had already filed chargesheets. A further investigation was subject to the investigating officer getting new material and a re-investigation could only be ordered by the superior court, he said.

Lawyer Rohan Nahar submitted that the NIA had not come to the Pune court with clean hands as its plea suffered from casual prayers to “send” case records and the cause title referred to “state represented by NIA” without clarifying what it meant by the word “state”.

Later, prosecutor Pawar told the court she would make her submissions on Friday.

Title: Sexagenarian sexually assaults 10-year-old
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Vijayawada: A 65-year-old man allegedly raped a 10-year-old girl in Kalidindi mandal of Krishna district on Wednesday. The incident, however, came to light on Thursday after a police complaint was lodged by the victim’s family.

The police identified the accused as Parasa Brahmaiah, 65, an agriculturist. Kalidindi police sub-inspector Janardhan said Brahmaiah lured the girl to his house while she was playing outside and raped her. The girl’s parents, who were searching for her, heard her screams and found Bramaiah sexually assaulting the child. The accused was thrashed by locals before being handed over to the police. Brahmaiah’s son allegedly aided him in the sexual assault on the girl, her parents alleged. The police, however, said Brahmaiah’s son was not present at the scene of crime. “As of now, the facts of the case are that the accused was handed over to us by the villagers after he was caught red-handed. We are investigating the case. We are also looking at other allegations like the involvement of Brahmaiah’s son,” Janardhan told TOI. The police have arrested Brahmaiah and registered a case under relevant sections of the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act, 2012.

The girl was sent to a local government hospital for medical examination. On Thursday, villagers protested near the police station demanding stringent action against the accused. The protesters dispersed after the police assured them the accused won’t be spared if guilty.

Title: Pune Municipal Corporation's debris disposal service fails to find takers
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Pune Municipal Corporation

PUNE: The civic body’s special service for collection and disposal of construction waste has failed to find any takers so far.

The service, aimed at checking disposal of construction debris into river bed or vacant plots, was started in June last year. As a part of the initiative, the Pune Municipal Corporation (PMC) had set up ward-wise debris collection centres.
