Civic officials, however, said they were yet to receive any requests for debris collection from citizens and real estate developers.

“We have been approaching those responsible for debris generation since the launch of the service. We continue to appeal to them to register with us so we can go ahead with the lifting process, but there has been no response so far,” said Dnyaneshwar Molak, head of the PMC’s solid waste management.

The civic body has also appealed to the citizens to provide details about the debris dumped in their areas or any other part of the city through a toll-free number (18002339595), following which it would be lifted by the civic body workers.

Title: Three robbers arrested, cellphones seized
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

ALLAHABAD: With the arrest of three men near Narayanpur crossing in Pratapgarh, cops on Thursday claimed to have busted an inter-district gang of robbers and seized five mobile phones , two bikes, ATM cards, Adhar cards and cash from their possession.

The accused were identified as Badal Saroj of Lakhipur, Vishal Sagar of Kodhur and Sarvajeet Gautam of Pratapgarh. Pratapgarh SP Abhishek Singh said the robbers were arrested near Narayanpur crossing .

“They had looted Rs 5000 cash, two mobile phones and other valuables from a woman near Diwanganj Chilbila when she was travelling in an auto last month. Besides, the trio had also snatched a mobile phone from a student on January 14,” said Singh.

Title: Pune: Suggestion of bikes in BRTS corridors provokes activists
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Road safety activists from the city have opposed the idea of utilizing the BRTS corridor for movement of two-w... Read More

PUNE: Road safety activists from the city have opposed the idea of utilizing the Bus Rapid Transit System ( BRTS ) corridor for movement of two-wheelers citing safety concerns.

Pune Municipal Corporation commissioner Shekhar Gaikwad suggested allowing two-wheelers to use the BRTS lane while tabling the draft civic budget.

Gaikwad had said that dedicated lanes for two-wheelers would ensure faster movement and the BRTS corridors, which are only meant for buses, could be utilized for movement of two-wheelers, especially in congestion prone areas.

However, road safety activists have voiced their concerns about the move. Samaiirah from Safe Road Foundation said, “In Pune, vehicles do not follow the lane system. Buses and two-wheelers moving at high speed within the corridor make a recipe for disaster. We could see an increase in fatalities on roads if this is permitted. Either the corridors must be kept open for all vehicles or solely buses.”

Convener of another NGO, Pedestrians FIRST, Prashant Inamdar has written to the civic chief, city police and chairman and managing director of PMPML about the matter.

Title: Meat vendors may feel ‘bird-hit’ heat
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Photo for representative purpose only

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The corporation is mulling prosecution measures against meat vendors and butchers operating unauthorizedly in the airport’s vicinity after Airfield environment management committee (AEMC) and district collector have called for stringent measures to check bird menace. A joint inspection by airport authorities, city corporation officials and police was held on February 1 to identify the places, where birds were found in large numbers. Open markets, meat vending spots and dump yards were spotted during the visit.

In the latest AEMC meeting held on February 3, the committee discussed the cost of bird strikes to civil aviation. It has been learnt that the committee held the view that since it was the civic body’s responsibility to prevent formation of dump yards and illegal meat stalls in the airport’s buffer zone, it could be held accountable for the loss incurred because of the bird hits . However, no final decision was made at the meeting.

During the past three months, two bird hits were reported, the meeting noted.

At a meeting held in October 2019, airport director who is also the convenor of AEMC, had informed that the bird strikes happening at Trivandrum airport was on the higher side and that in 2018, as many as 55 bird strikes were reported.

He pointed out that open meat/fish/chicken stalls must be curbed to avoid bird menace. Garbage accumulation was also reported in areas near Brahmos/Kochuveli railway station/Titanium and SN Nagar, Paruthikuzhy and Muttathara .

The civic body has identified four major meat vendors functioning near the airport’s vicinity. Meat shops operating without licences and those who dump waste near secured zone are likely to face prosecution measures.

The district collector has asked the corporation to identify the illegal meat vendors and issue notices following the meeting.

The corporation has been planning to constitute a special team comprising health officials to ensure that no dump yards are formed near the buffer zone around airport and to check functioning of illegal meat vendors. There has also been a demand to close the open fish market near Kochuveli which attracts birds. The corporation also deployed a team to clear piles of waste being dumped at Muttathara.

In the coming days, levelling will be done in the area to prevent further dumping of waste. With regards to the Kochuveli open market, the corporation plans to introduce a facility to manage waste at source. It was also found that some of its cleaning staff regularly dumped waste near airport which was recently cleared.

Title: Coronavirus: Kerala heaves sigh of relief
Content:
People wearing masks near the isolation ward at Ernakulam Government Medical College

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: For the third consecutive day, no positive case of novel coronavirus has been reported from the people who are under observation. At present, 2,826 people who have come from virus-hit regions to the state are under observation. Of this, only 83 people have been isolated in the hospital since they have developed fever symptoms.Till date, 263 samples of the people who are under observation have been dispatched for testing at National Institute of Virology in Pune. Of this, 229 results have come as negative. The surveillance and the monitoring of the people under observation are still continuing. The health department has constituted a team of 191 volunteers for providing counselling to the people under isolation and observation.According to a statement issued by the Press Information Bureau, as on Thursday, 1,38,750 passengers from 1,265 flights have been screened for novel coronavirus.Till now, no new case has been detected. All 645 evacuees from the Chinese city of Wuhan have tested negative. In addition, 510 samples have been tested by ICMR network laboratories, of which all have tested negative except for three already reported positive who are from Kerala . The Union ministry of health & family welfare in coordination with central ministries and all states and UTs is taking adequate measures for management of novel coronavirus in the country. In case of fever, cough and symptoms of pneumonia, seek medical attention immediately, said the statement.

Title: Friend’s suicide drives man to kill self
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

One of the deceased

Rajkot: Not being able to bear the untimely death of his friend, a man also decided to take his own life in Bhadreshwer village of Mundra taluka in Kutch district on Wednesday.

According to police, Mahavirsinh Jadeja (32) hanged himself to death from the ceiling of the room of his house in Bhadreshwer village. Jadeja’s brother Kuldeepsinh told the cops that Jadeja had taken the drastic step as he was tired of unemployment and financial crisis.

Seven hours after Jadeja’s death, his friend Jaideepsinh Jadeja (30), also hanged himself to death from the ceiling of his house in the same village.

“Jaideepsinh, who participated in the funeral procession and last rites of Jadeja, committed suicide after coming home on Wednesday evening. Before taking the drastic step, he wrote on his WhatsApp status: ‘Miss you jigara (best friend). Hue aavu chhoon. Tension na le' (I am also coming to join you, don’t take tension),” said S A Gadhvi, sub-inspector with Mundra marine police station.

Two days ago, Jadeja and Jaideepsinh had made a Tik-Tok video with a song on friendship. “It seems that Jadeja’s demise was unbearable for Jaideepsinh that he too decided to end his life,” said Gadhvi.

Title: HRD committee visits AU, invites complaints against ex-VC Hangloo
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Allahabad: A three-member committee constituted by the ministry of human resources development to probe allegations of irregularities against Allahabad University’s (AU) former vice-chancellor RL Hangloo visited the the varsity’s campus on Thursday.

Headed by IGNOU vice-chancellor Nageshwar Rao, the team visited various departments including the biochemistry department, central library and the Vizanagram Hall. The team returned the same day. INGNTU VC Prakash Mani Tripathi and vice-chancellor of Gujarat Central University Rama Shankar Dubey were the other of members of the team.

The panel met AU’s officiating vice-chancellor RR Tewari for a closed-door 20-minute meeting.

In a brief interaction with the media, the team members said that AU registrar NK Shukla has been appointed the nodal officer of the inquiry committee. “Whosoever has any complaint or allegation related to any irregularity can submit the same to the nodal officer along with supporting documents,” they added.

A notification issued by AU registrar NK Shukla on Thursday stated that anyone with a complain against Hangloo can submit the same at the registrar’s office by February 16. The notification also says that the inquiry committee finds any substance in the allegations, they will also schedule an appointment with the complainant for clarification.

However, the appointment of the registrar as the nodal officer of the inquiry committee did raise some questions among the faculty members. Many teachers questioned the move as there Shukla’s appointment as the AU registrar is steeped in several allegations.

Reacting to the questions, Rao said, “It was the decision of the ministry to appoint the registrar as the nodal officer. Our inquiry will be least affected by the fact that who is taking care of the logistics. Our contact details are already available in the public domain and anyone can send us a complaint with supporting enclosures.”

The team members also said that they can again visit AU over the next few days and would request the government to extend the deadline for submitting their report which presently a month. They said that their report would include recommendations made National Commission for Women and how well AU has implemented them.

Title: Maha home dept officials to study AP’s Disha Act
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Pune: State home minister Anil Deshmukh and key officials from the police department will visit Andhra Pradesh to study its Disha Act.

“I will be going with some key officials to Andhra Pradesh to study the Act,’’ Deshmukh told TOI recently.

The Andhra Pradesh Disha Act Criminal Law (AP Amendment) Act, 2019 was passed by the southern state on December 13 last year.

The new law mandates completion of investigation into cases of sexual offences within seven working days from the time of record and trial within 14 working days from the date of filing the chargesheet.

The appeal against the sentence passed under the new law has to be disposed of within six months. State home officials said the act would be studied so that it can be implemented in Maharashtra.

The government at present has 25 special and 27 fast track courts for expediting trials in such cases.

On tackling the rising number of cyber crimes, the state government had said of the proposed 47 special police stations for dealing with such cases, 43 have already started. About 164 posts in these stations would be filled up within two months.

The act calls for a national registry of sexual offenders made public and available to law enforcement agencies.

At present, the provision for punishing an offender in a rape case is a fixed jail term leading to life imprisonment or the death sentence.

The Disha Act 2019 has prescribed the death penalty for rape crimes where there is adequate conclusive evidence.

Provision is given by amending Section 376 of the Indian Penal Code, 1860. The act also presses for stringent punishment for sexual offences against children.

In the Andhra Pradesh Disha Act 2019, apart from rape, the government prescribes life imprisonment for other sexual offences against children.

Punishment for harassment of women through social media too has been included in the act.

Reducing the appeal time to three months for disposal of rape cases too has been included while the act also calls for constitution of special police teams and appointment of the special public prosecutor in special courts.

Sena functionary Eknath Shinde in December had said the Maharashtra government is serious about enacting a Disha like legislation, which was implemented by the Andhra Pradesh Government after the brutal rape and murder of a 26-year-old veterinarian in Hyderabad, to curb crimes against women in the state.

While replying to a calling attention motion by MLC Manisha Kayande in the legislative council on Wednesday, Shinde informed the upper house that such legislations were must to create an atmosphere where girls and women could move freely without any fear. According to him, such deterrent laws instill a sense of fear among criminals. Shiv Sena MLA Pratap Sarnaik had moved a private member bill in the assembly for a law like the Disha Act.

Title: Telangana: Lakhs rush to witness procession
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

SP Sangramsingh G Patil fired several rounds in the air, signifying the arrival of the deity

MEDARAM: Lakhs of pilgrims rushed to witness the arrival of deity Sammakka from the Chilakalgutta hillocks on Thursday. SP Sangramsingh G Patil fired several rounds in the air, signifying the arrival of the deity.

Hereditary priests brought a vermilion casket and a bamboo pole wrapped in a red cloth while the deity proceeded towards the altar at Medaram . Scores of police personnel, who accompanied the deity, kept the thronging devotees at bay, making way for the procession.

Devotees sprinkled turmeric and vermilion on the priests and welcomed the goddess. Tribal priests leading the procession marked the arrival of the tribal deity Sammakka at the holy pedestal in Medaram.

Drum beaters, folk singers, and Shivasattulu dancers performed during the festival. Devotees from various parts of the country have converged at the tiny village of Medaram to offer prayers and blocks of jaggery and coconuts to the tribal deities.

Title: Pune: Kin vandalize Kondhwa hospital over teen’s ‘cause of death’ letter
Content:
A mob of around 200 people was inside and outside the hospital

PUNE: Angry relatives of a 17-year-old boy vandalized Welfare Hospital at Ashirwad Chowk in Kondhwa Khurd on Wednesday night. They also attacked its staff, including the doctor who runs the hospital, for not issuing a death certificate. The teen had been admitted to the medical facility, but had not died there.The Kondhwa police on Thursday booked at least five people on charges of rioting and others of the Indian Penal Code and Maharashtra Medical Service Person and Medical Service Institution (Prevention of Violence and Damage or Loss to Property).Inspector Mahadeo Kumbhar from the Kondhwa police said, “Investigations show that the relatives abused the hospital staff and damaged the glass door by pelting stones.”Investigation officer assistant inspector Sandip Madhale said an FIR has been lodged and the relatives who damaged the hospital will be arrested.Sadique Khan, the doctor who runs the hospital, told TOI that the patient came to his hospital from another medical facility.In his FIR, Khan said, the relatives of the teen had admitted him in his hospital on Tuesday around 8.30pm as he was suffering from chest infection and a low platelet count.The doctor treating the patient on Wednesday around noon did not find any improvement in his condition and advised his parents to take him to another hospital for treatment. The parents got their son discharged at 6.30pm, the FIR read.According to the FIR, “Around 10.15pm, four to five men walked into the hospital and told me (Khan) that the boy had passed away because I did not provide him proper treatment and attacked me and my staff. They also abused us. They vandalised the main glass door, benches and threw the landline phones on the floor. They ran away after a crowd assembled inside the hospital.”Khan said the teen was suffering from breathing problems. “We advised his parents to shift him to another hospital because we were not equipped with medical facilities to treat his condition. We learned from the patient’s relatives that the boy was taken to two other hospitals after they took discharge from my hospital. The authorities there refused to admit him. His relatives then said the boy passed away on the way to Sassoon General Hospital.”Khan said the relatives told him that the parents took the body home as they did not want a postmortem. “The relatives came to me demanding a letter stating the details of his death. I refused on the grounds that he had been admitted to my hospital for a few hours and he had not died here.”The relatives then vandalised the hospital property on the ground and first floors, Khan said. A mob of over 200 men had assembled inside and outside the hospital, he added.“We have handed over the CCTV footage to the police. It shows the men responsible for vandalizing the hospital,” Khan said.Kumbhar said the patient’s body was handed over to his family after the autopsy at the Sassoon hospital and the report is awaited.The teen’s father told TOI that they were anxious about the boy’s health. “My son passed away because he was not given proper treatment at the Kondhwa hospital. We are not responsible for vandalising the hospital and attacking its staff. We don’t known the vandals. We will decide about any action against the hospital for negligence in providing treatment,” he added.

Title: There was delay on part of cops in reaching spot: Report
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The Nedumangad DSP has reportedly filed an inquiry report before the superintendent of police (Rural District), stating that there were lapses on the part of officials of Kattakkada police station, who were on night duty on January 24 when 37-year-old Sangeeth Balan was allegedly attacked and killed by a group of men.

According to sources in the department, DSP Stuart Keeler submitted his inquiry report before rural SP B Ashok on Thursday stating that there was merit in the allegations levelled by the family of Sangeeth that there was delay on the part of the police in arriving at the spot, which gave ample time to the accused to carry out the attack and flee from the scene. The victim’s family had also alleged that the police worked in collusion with the mafia. It was based on these allegations, an inquiry was launched.

The rural SP is yet to confirm receiving the report. Hence, it is yet to be known what action the police officers in question will face.

The alleged murder took place during the early hours of January 24, while Sangeeth was trying to prevent the gang from digging up earth from his property. Though the police were alerted, they took more than an hour to reach the spot. By this time, the gang attacked Sangeeth by hitting him using an earthmover, critically injuring him. He eventually died of the injuries. The police reached the spot only after all the accused fled from the scene.

In the subsequent days, the police managed to arrest 10 accused. On Monday, the police have secured custody of seven of the accused persons from the court as part of further investigation. They are currently being taken to locations where they hid to evade arrest and also places where they have hidden the vehicles involved in the crime. They will be returned to judicial custody on Saturday.

Title: Janhvi Kapoor misses her sister Khushi Kapoor; shares a sweet post on her Instagram
Content: Sushant Singh Rajput’s untimely demise on June 14 has brought his relationship with girlfriend Rhea Chakraborty in the limelight. The actress is being interrogated by the Central Bureau of Investigation as well as the Enforcement Directorate. Even a drugs angle is being probed by the Narcotics Control Bureau. Amidst this controversy, Rhea Chakraborty has found some support in Bollywood, while there are a few who have raised questions against the actress. Here’s taking a look at Bollywood celebrities who are in support of Rhea and those standing against her.

Title: Conservationists raise alarm over fort panel removal
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PUNE: The cancellation of memberships of all non-governmental members of the five-year old Maharashtra Fort Conservation Committee by the Maha Vikas Aghadi (MVA) government could hamper fort restoration activities in the state, conservation experts said.

The committee, comprising several non-governmental members from the field of archaeology and heritage, including experts from the Deccan College , was constituted five years ago to oversee fort conservation in Maharashtra.

Officials from the state archaeology department said that the committee had hitherto proved to be a major support for expediting conservation measures in over 28 forts.

A state archaeology department official told TOI that the government was currently revamping the memberships of all such committees. “While the fort conservation committee still has its government official memberships intact, the non-governmental members have been removed. It is a policy decision by the new government to discard existing non-governmental members from such committees. But the committee will soon have new memberships and expertise from the field of heritage and archaeology,” he said.

He added that the committee had made substantial contribution towards bringing to light issues concerning the state’s forts in the last five years. “Conservation work worth Rs84crore was carried out in 28 forts. It would not have been possible without the committee,” he said.

A senior official from the state’s tourism and culture department told TOI that all government committees were going through the same process. Memberships of all non-governmental officials are being cancelled and new members are in the process of being instated.

“The official members are still a part of the committee, while the non-official members will be reinstated. We are receiving nominations and applications of such members. Once we arrive at a decision, the committee will be reconstituted soon,” he said.

Sachin Joshi, a researcher with archaeology department of Deccan College, who was also a member of the State Fort Conservation Committee, said, “The earlier committee had members from organisations working in the field of fort conservation. Their contribution was in the form of overseeing conservation works, surveying forts, preparing conservation guidelines, conducting meetings with the archaeology department to reviewing the qualitative aspects of works undertaken etc. With these members gone, there is currently no non-governmental expert to oversee the conservation work, which could affect the ongoing fort conservation efforts.”

Amar Adake, a fort conservation expert from Kolhapur and a former member of the committee, said, “The aim of forming the committee was to make proper fort documentation and conservation of masterplans. Hence it is necessary that the government reinstate new members into the committee as soon as possible. It was only because of the committee that close to 83 forts in the state are in the process of being granted protected status. Till the committee is not reconstituted, ongoing and new fort conservation work may be affected.”

Title: Virology institute to open in June: CM
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Thiruvananthapuram: Chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan said the Institute of Advanced Virology (IAV) in Thiruvananthapuram will start functioning from June. The installation of the equipment and deployment of the scientists will be completed by April. The CM said this after the high-level meeting convened by him to review the progress of the project. tnn

Title: Rajasthan: Barmer man throws son into tank, ends life
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

JAISALMER: A man threw his 12-year-old son into water tank and then committed suicide by jumping into another water tank under Chauhatan police station in Barmer late on Wednesday night. The reason of suicide is not known yet.

Police have registered a case and started investigation. The accused’s wife had gone to her parents’ house at the time of the incident.

Chauhatan dySP Ajit Singh said, “Gordhan Ram lodged a report with the police saying that his brother Kala Ram Meghwal (50), who was mentally disturbed on Wednesday, threw his 12-year-old son Bhoja Ram into a water tank at his house and himself jumped into another water tank in the neighbourhood”.

Bhojaram (12) was mute and deaf, the report said. Police reached the spot and took out the bodies from the tank. tnn

Title: Consumers and solar industry players term grid support charges regressive
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Consumers vehemently opposed the grid support charges and tariff revision proposal at the public hearing organ... Read More

PUNE: Consumers and industry representatives on Thursday vehemently opposed the MSEDCL ’s proposal to levy Rs 4-8 in grid support charges on power generated from rooftop solar plants.

They termed the proposed charges as “unjust” and “regressive” during a public hearing organised by the Maharashtra Electricity Regulatory Commission (MERC). The hearing was held on the multi-year electricity tariff proposal of the Maharashtra State Electricity Distribution Company Limited, through which it aims to mop up Rs 60,313 crore between 2020 and 2025.

MSEDCL, in its petition submitted to MERC, had stated that solar rooftop load had increased from 20.44 MW in 2016-17 to 288.80 MW in 2018-19. The company said if paying consumers go out of its net, it would have to increase the tariff for remaining consumers.

The representatives of the solar power manufacturers’ association said the levy would adversely impact the Union government’s National Solar Mission as nobody would come forward to opt for the green energy option. There are 42 lakh agricultural pumps in Maharashtra that are powered by solar energy and even they will be hit by the levy, the association representatives said.

A representative of the Vasantdada Sugar Institute said they stopped the work for installing a 600 kilowatt-hour (Kwh) rooftop solar power plant because of the MSEDCL’s grid support charge proposal.

Consumers also came down heavily on the tariff revision proposal and termed it exorbitant. ND Patil of the Peasants and Workers Party alleged that the tariff was being increased to hide the inefficiencies of the power distribution company and its failure to check power thefts and transmission losses.

Shantanu Dixit of the Prayas Energy Group, which represents common consumers, said the distribution company was expected to propose tariff revision only to the extent of Rs 30,000 crore to make up for the gap in revenue and expenditure.

He suggested that the regulatory commission should allow tariff revision only to the extent of 35 paise per unit for the next five years. Although he supported the grid support charges for those using net metering, he said the charges should not exceed Re 1 per unit.

The industry representatives also objected to the proposed increase in fixed charges for small industries saying that it would affect the rural economy. They also pointed out that the government was taking steps to encourage small and medium industries, but the excessive power tariff would be counter-productive.

Title: Early detection and treatment key to managing cancer: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative Image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Early detection and providing basic treatment are crucial in managing cancer, especially in countries like India, experts said at the annual conference of Indian Association of Cancer Research (ICAR) held in Kovalam on Thursday. However, they said that it should not lead to neglect of advanced research in the late-stage multi-modality treatment of the ‘killer disease’.

The conference, hosted by Rajiv Gandhi Centre for Biotechnology (RGCB), witnessed in-depth deliberations on the topic ‘cancer research investment should shift from late-stage treatment to early-stage detection’.

Dr R Sankaranarayanan, former director of Cancer Prevention, IARC, Lyons, France, said that early detection and treatment are crucial and the efficacy of this approach has been validated by data from different countries. “This strategy is much more cost-effective than late-stage multi-modality targeted treatment, especially for countries like India,” he asserted.

Noting that data on survival rates support this approach, he said, “Cancer is a journey where chances of recurrence are low if detected and managed in early stage, compared to the late-stage aggressive treatment”.

Underscoring need to give greater focus to cancer research, Dr Sankaranarayanan said that prices of drugs for cancer must come down. “The challenge is how we will put in place enablers and how to make basic treatment and follow-up accessible, by stepping up funding for detection and prevention programmes,” he said.

In another session, the participants observed that despite significant scientific and technological research being carried out by India’s excellent academic institutions, the benefits have not filtered down to the people due to lack of commercialization of the outcomes. “It is important to transfer the results of research to the market, so that they will reach the people that need them. Without that possibility, you will not get the returns of your work,” said Manu S Nair , vice-president, Technology Ventures, Oklahoma Medical Research Foundation . He was speaking on the topic ‘Love it or hate it: IP protection & limited monopoly in drug development/commercialization’ at the conference. The three-day conference will conclude on Friday.

Title: Uttar Pradesh: Farmer found murdered in home
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

KANPUR: A 54-year-old farmer , Ram Prasad of Hansa village under the limits of Kadaura police station of Jalaun district, was hacked to death late on Wednesday night. His body was found lying in a pool of blood in the verandah of his house on Thursday morning. Personal enmity is stated to be probable reason behind the murder. The police have registered a case and launched an investigation in this regard.

Ram Prasad, used to sleep in the verandah of his house. “His orchard is located at a distance of about a kilometre from his house. As per his family members, recently he had cut down some trees in the orchard. The family suspected it to be reason behind the murder. However, we are exploring all possible angles,” said circle officer Kalpi Sanjay Sharma .

The body was sent for postmortem examination and a case under section 302 of IPC was registered in this regards. Further investigations are on to nab the accused.
