Title: To screen or not to screen? NFAI in a bind over Begunah “rip-off” taint
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The poster of the 1957 Kishore Kumar and Shakila starrer Begunah, released by the National Film Archive of Ind... Read More

PUNE: The National Film Archive of India (NFAI) is no stranger to discovering reels, considered lost, among its vast archives of films, but the recovery of two 16mm reels of the 1957 Kishore Kumar starrer Begunah, 60 years after the Bombay High Court ordered that all prints of the film be destroyed, has brought its own dilemma -- should a legally-tainted film be screened?

The film was banned by the high court after Paramount Pictures, the US, alleged it was a copy of their 1954 movie, Knock on Wood. Paramount won the case and the court ordered that all the prints of the film be destroyed.

The discovery of rare films is generally followed by a public screening but the legal history of Begunah has prompted the NFAI to play safe, including seeking legal advice from copyright law experts. It has written to the Bombay High Court, seeking the original judgment to find out the extent of the 1957 ruling.

“We have written to the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting, so that we can reach out to the Ministry of Law and Justice and find out about the future course of action before scheduling any screening. We have even informed Paramount Pictures about the development, and in our communication, we have mentioned the fair-use principle that film archives abide by, especially the non-commercial use,” Prakash Magdum, the NFAI director, told TOI.

“The discovery is simply a pure coincidence. The fact that prints of a film, ordered to be destroyed, have been discovered is simply incredible, even though the recovered reels have only about 60 minutes of footage. There are too many interesting things about the movie, such as Danny Kaye being one of Kishore Kumar’s idols. The rip-off was discovered by Paramount as Kaye was travelling to India at the time of Begunah’s release. Kaye alerted Paramount, following which they filed a suit,” Magdum said.

Apart from Kishore Kumar, the film starred actress Shakila. The music was by Shankar-Jaikishan . What movie buffs most remember about the film are the songs sung by three of the Mangeshkar sisters- Lata, Usha, Meena, as well as by Manna Dey, Mukesh, and Kishore Kumar.

Title: Coronavirus scare: Chinese youth hale and hearty, but hoteliers scared to host him
Content:
A Kerala ambulance driver on duty wearing masks on Wednesday. (Photo: PTI)

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Health department officials have confirmed that the 27-year-old Chinese youth presently admitted in the isolation ward of General Hospital here is not affected by novel coronavirus and is perfectly healthy. Yet, he continues to be in the hospital as hotel and homestay owners in the city are reluctant to offer him a room despite the intervention of tourism department authorities.“As of now, the young man is not quarantined. It can be said that health department has offered asylum to him as hoteliers refused to provide him accommodation,” said district medical officer Dr Jose G D’cruz. Even the government-run tourist home, Yatri Nivas, could not provide him accommodation as the staff there were terrified when they learned that he was from China.He said that barring some preliminary examinations, no detailed tests were done on the young man. “Such tests only need to be done if the subject shows symptoms of the infection. Since he did not show any such symptoms, no further tests were done,” the doctor said. The DMO added that the Chinese youth is freely roaming around in the hospital premises.“All he wishes is to spend a few days in the city and experience a nice time. But, he can do it only after this existing uncertainty over his accommodation ends,” Dr D’cruz said.Though tourists from several countries are still arriving in the city, none of them have faced an ordeal similar to what the Chinese man went through.

Title: 200 SHGs to display their work at Jodhpur fair
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

JODHPUR: Over 200 women’s self-help groups will be displaying their work at the Jodhpur Saras National Craft Fair from February 7 to 17.

To be organised by the Rajasthan Rural Livelihood Development Council (Rajeevika) with support from the ministry of rural development, the fair aims at providing a platform to women to market and sell the products made by the group members. State mission director (Rajeevika) Aruna Rajoriya said besides various districts of Rajasthan, SHGs from 25 states of the country will be participating in this fair and be showcasing their products.

Title: Evicted from flat, student torches three motorcycles
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PUNE: Six months after he was evicted for defaulting on rent, a student tried to set his erstwhile landlord’s motorcycle on fire in revenge. His plan went up in smoke, however, when he was caught by alert residents.

The incident happened at Morya Colony in Kalewadi on Tuesday night. The Wakad police arrested the 19-year-old on Wednesday. Three of the youth’s accomplices, who had fled from the spot after the incident, were eventually tracked down and detained.

The police have invoked sections 427 (mischief) and 392 (robbery) of the Indian Penal Code .

Police said Mhaske is a student first-year of a college in Kalewadi. “His accomplices are junior college students at the same institute,” senior inspector Vivek Muglikar said.

He said Mhaske used stay on rent in a flat owned by Babasaheb Prabhakar Pandhawale (49). “Mhaske defaulted on rent. Pandhawale gave him two or three months to pay the dues. But when Mhaske failed to do so, Pandhawale told him to vacate the flat,” Muglikar said.

“This enraged Mhaske, who plotted revenge,” Muglikar said.

Late on Tuesday night, Mhaske and his friends — armed with sticks and sharp weapons — gathered at a spot in Kalewadi. They also carried a bottle of petrol.

“Around midnight they entered the society, doused the motorcycles with petrol and set them ablaze,” Muglikar said. “This woke up one of the residents, who raised an alarm,” he added.

A group of residents rushed to the parking lot. “The suspects threatened the residents with the weapons. Pandhawale tried to stop them, but the suspects tore his shirt and robbed Rs2,000,” he said.

Before he could flee, the residents caught Mhaske. “His juvenile accomplices managed to escape, but we tracked them down,” he said.

Police said the residents quickly put out the flames. “Only the motorcycle saddles were damaged,” police said.

Title: Students of L’école Chempaka Silver Rocks win Times NIE Quiz
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

From left: Anantha Padmanabhan and Adithya Krishnan A of The Trivandrum Scottish School; Malavika and Ganga of... Read More

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The grand hall of Tagore Theatre was full when quiz master Lloyd Saldanha threw the first question. There were 300 teams, each comprising two students from different schools in the district. They were keen to listen to Saldanha’s questions of the preliminary round and prove their mettle so that they get into the coveted finals meant for only six teams.

The Inter-School Fundamental Quiz conducted by Times NIE and Empathy on Thursday was noted for the huge participation of students. From early morning, students began flocking to the registration counter. Some schools arranged special transport facilities for their students.

Empathy project principal investigator Dr Neeraj Raizada, who led the Empathy campaign titled ‘Empowering People Against Hepatitis’, declared the quiz open.

Conceptualized by the Institute of Liver and Biliary Sciences (ILBS) director Dr Shiv Kumar Sarin, the campaign aims to create awareness on hepatitis and the funding support is from Airports Authority of India. Lloyd Saldanha from Greycaps took over and led the preliminary round which was a written one. The performance of students in the preliminary round was so impressive that the quiz master had to resort to tie-breaker to finalize the six teams in the final round.

The thrilling finals saw Adithya Sivaramakrishnan and Badrinath Nandan of L’école Chempaka Silver Rocks, Sreekariyam, winning the quiz by scoring 100 points. Navaneeth Sivadas and Aakarsh Y Nair of Loyola School, Sreekariyam, won the second position with 50 points. Ganga Nair and Malavika Arun of L’école Chempaka, Serene Valley , Kallayam came third with 40 points.

Rohan and Aadithya of Christ Nagar Higher Secondary School , Kowdiar, and Arjun S and Adhithyan A K of Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya, Vithura, shared the fourth place. Adithya Krishnan A and Anantha Padmanabhan of The Trivandrum Scottish School , Thundathil, came fifth.

Dr Neeraj and Deepthi Katyal, advocacy coordinator, project Empathy, gave away the prizes to the first six teams.

“It was a really good platform to boost our knowledge by exposing ourselves to what is going on in society, including the rising deaths owing to hepatitis,” said Adithya Sivaramakrishnan and Badrinath Nandan. “We enjoyed it and want more such quizzes,” said Navaneeth and Aakarsh.

“It was wonderful. The questions were very intricate, and the rounds were different from the quizzes we usually attend,” said Ganga and Malavika.

The lucky dip prizes went to Chinmaya Vidyalaya, Kunnumpuram; Government Higher Secondary School, Karipoor; Sree Sethu Parvathy Bhai High School, Kadakkavur; and Chinmaya Vidyalaya, Vazhuthacaud.

Title: HC notice to Centre, Rajasthan over gender parity in marriageable age
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

JODHPUR: The Rajasthan High Court has issued notices to the state and Central governments and Central Law Commission seeking reply in six weeks, while hearing a petition challenging the legal age of bride and groom for marriage as mentioned in the law.

Petitioner Abdul Mannan, in his petition, stated that the difference of three years in the marriageable age between bride and the groom was discriminatory and hence a violation of fundamental rights. “The groom is legally allowed to marry at the age of 21 years while a bride’s legal age of marriage is 18 years. This gap of three years is discriminatory,” he argued.

When the division bench of chief justice Indrajit Mahanty and justice P S Bhatir enquired about the age according to the petitioner, he replied that both should have the same age of 21 years as the legal age for marriage. Mannan, in his petition, attributed the age difference an indicator of patriarchal mentality in the society and stated that there was no scientific basis of this perception.

“The law commission of India has also observed that there was no scientific ground for this perception and it bolsters the conservatism that bride should be younger than the groom,” he argued. Terming the practice as encouraging inequality for women, he stated that this was anti-global trends, as well as in contradiction to gender equality, gender justice and dignity of womenfolk.

He also termed it to be violative of Articles 14, 15 and 21 and stated that the age of bride and groom is the same in 125 countries. Citing a national conference on child marriage, he said that the issue had also been taken up by the National Human Rights Commission in this conference and a recommendation had been given to bring parity in the marriageable ages of both.

Convinced by the arguments, the court allowed the petition and issued notices returnable in six weeks.

Title: Rajkot: Two held for milk, petrol theft in Sayla
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: Two persons were arrested for allegedly stealing milk and petrol from tankers at a highway hotel near Aya village of Sayla taluka in Surendranagar district on Wednesday night.

The accused were identified as Bakaram Chaudhary, owner of Mahadev Chaudhary Hotel, and Devraj Parmar .

“We raided the hotel after we received a tip-off about theft of milk and petrol from tankers. We recovered 280 litre milk and 550 litre petrol from the hotel. We also seized two mini trucks and Rs 2.27 lakh cash from the accused,” said M P Vala, inspector with Rajkot rapid response cell.

The police also booked Jalam Jogarana , Yuvraj Kathi, Ravu Kathi, Raju and an unidentified person, who fled from the spot before the police arrived, for the crime.

Title: Desirable demand for eco-friendly products in world markets, say experts
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Participants were told to utilize the subsidies and assistance provided by the state and central governments t... Read More

TRICHY: Entrepreneurs at an export awareness programme on Thursday were told to go after eco-friendly products instead of plastics as they are in decent demand at the international market. Suggestions were also given to export the value-added agriculture products to the aspiring exporters.

The event was conducted by Tiruchirapalli District Tiny & Small Scale Industries Association (TIDITSSIA) in association with Director-General of Foreign Trade (DGFT) and MSME development institute and Federation of Indian Export Organisations (FIEO). Around 75 entrepreneurs participated in the programme at the TIDITSSIA complex in Ariyamangalam.

Entrepreneurs were told to watch the global markets and explore the research tools available in the online platforms to extract the data for narrowing down the desirable market and product to export.

“The markets of the United States of America and Australia have a good number of takers for eco-friendly products such as bamboo straws and betel nut plates. Exporters should attend the international trade fair and interact with the local stakeholders to understand the unique demand,” K Jayakumar, assistant director, FIEO told TOI.

Participants were told to utilize the subsidies and assistance provided by the state and central governments to participate in the international buyer-seller meetings.

Stakeholders including the District Industries Centre (DIC) urged the entrepreneurs to export their products to the countries where there is a demand.

“Value-added agro products and engineering products like valves and casings besides the windmill components from Trichy can be considered for export. We are planning to conduct buyer-seller meets to promote exports,” R Ilango, president, TIDITSSIA said.

Title: Coronavirus outbreak: 21 students stuck at Kunming airport
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

A few from the group of 21 students stuck at Kunming airport. Of the 21 students, 20 are from Kerala and one i... Read More

KOCHI: Twenty one students of Dalian Medical University are stuck at Kunming airport in China after Singapore disallowed their transit to India through their airport on Thursday over concerns of Novel Coronavirus (nCov).

Of the 21 students, 20 are from Kerala. One student is a native of Tamil Nadu. The students decided to leave as the number of coronavirus cases has been increasing in the region where the university is located. Students said they booked tickets on February 3 from Kunming to Thiruvananthapuram via Singapore by Scoot airlines.

“When we arrived at Kunming airport we are told that only Singapore citizens will be allowed to board the flight and they will not carry Chinese citizens or any other nationals,” said Keerthana Rani , a house surgeon at Dalian university. The students said that though they pleaded with the officials of Scoot airlines, they expressed helplessness.

“We are now being told that the Norka is trying to get us to New Delhi via Bangkok and then to Thiruvananthapuram,” said Keerthana, who hails from Paravoor in Kollam.

Norka officials said that they were looking at all available options to fly them to Thiruvananthapuram but it is a task that is increasingly becoming difficult. “Airlines are not allowing transit. Countries like Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia and airlines like AirAsia, Singapore Airlines , Thai Airlines are not allowing transit of passengers from China,” said Norka Roots CEO Harikrishnan Namboothiri K.

Reports said Union minister of state for external affairs V Muraleedharan has asked Indian embassy in Beijing to help the students travel to India.

Students explored options of other flights operating to India but were told that for the next two days there will be no flights. “Even though we got in touch with the Indian embassy, there was no response,” said Keerthana. They cannot return to the university as they had ignored the message to stay back.

Relatives of the students are anxiously waiting for an information from the Centre. “They booked tickets via Singapore but were not informed that the country would impose a travel ban on people travelling from regions hit by coronavirus,” said Keerthana’s sister Karthika.

Title: Netherlands government sets up centre of excellence in Kanpur
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Kanpur: In a step towards preventing pollution and promoting efficient water use in leather industry, the Netherlands government established a Centre of Excellence at Banthar on Thursday.

The centre was inaugurated on the concluding day of the two-day meet of Kanpur Unnao Leather cluster for rejuvenation of river Ganga on Thursday.

Representatives of the leather industry and distinguished guests including Dutch Ambassador Marten Van Den Berg were present on the occasion. The meet was inaugurated on Wednesday.

The centre will facilitate the city leather industry with a cleaner technology and will also help in preventing pollution and creating better products with efficient water usage, said secretary of Leather Industry Welfare Association Asad Iraqi.

Talking to TOI, Asad Iraqi stated the Centre for Excellence has been established by Dutch company Stahl with an aim to share the knowledge and best practices with the industry and work together with non-profit organisations, Solidaridad and PUM. “Our shared goal is to reduce pollution in the Ganga and increase efficient water use,” he added.

Huub Van Beijeren CEO and the board member of Stahl said, “We search for ways to reduce our industry’s impact.” “Its how we slowly move towards a more responsible sustainable future,” he said.

Consulate of Dutch embassy stated that the centre of Excellence was an example of Indo-Dutch cooperation and Dutch government’s commitment to clean river Ganga. He also discussed the ongoing activities under the project in detail.

Former chairman Council for Leather Industry (CLI) Mukhtarul Amin representing the leather industry stated that Kanpur Unnao leather cluster was facing the challenges of environmental problems and the Centre of Excellence in Kanpur would play a significant role in promoting the industry here.

Title: Rajkot: Three held for adulteration of groundnut bought at minimum support price
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Accused at the market yard

RAJKOT: Three persons were arrested for mixing inferior quality groundnut in 156 gunny bags (weighing 35kg each) stored at Junagadh Market Yard on Thursday. The accused used to take out good quality groundnut procured at minimum support price (MSP) and mix it with poor quality nuts bought from the open market.

The accused, Pratik Sojitra (36), Keshu Vagadia (62) and Ramesh Makwana (42), were nabbed after CCTVs footage from the market yard examined on Saturday last showed the accused mixing the groundnut.

The inspection was conducted on Saturday after a farmer’s body Khedut Hit Rakshak Samiti, alleged possibility of a scam on January 30.

“Though the accused had covered the CCTVs with gunny bags before committing the crime, they were caught on the other CCTV cameras installed inside the market yard. The fourth accused shown in the footage along with the other accused turned out to be a labourer,” said Pradeepsinh Jadeja , Junagadh deputy superintendent of police.

During his interrogation, Sojitra, who has a firm in the market yard, told the cops that he would buy poor quality groundnut from the farmers in the day and mix it in the bags containing good quality groundnut, procured at MSP at night.

While Vagadia was the accountant in Sojitra’s firm, Makwana was a labour contractor.

Yogesh Vala, manager of Gujarat Civil Supply Department, Junagadh, said: “When we carried out inspection, we found 156 gunny bags containing groundnut were either wet or had nuts of inferior quality. The bags, which were supposed to be sealed in the presence of farmers, were not done so.”

“When we checked the CCTV footages we saw four unidentified men sneaking into the yard who later covered the CCTVs with gunny bags. After this, the miscreants may have allegedly culled out good quality groundnut from the bags and mixed inferior quality nuts into the bags to maintain weight,” Vala said.

Apart from the adulteration, the gunny bags also weighed less, he added.

In August last year, a total of 30,000 sacks of groundnut (containing 35kg each) were found to be mixed with sand and pebbles in Jetpur town of Rajkot district.

Title: Diarrhoea claims lives of three Kota kids in five months
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

KOTA: Following the report of deaths of three children at Udiya Basti in Dadabari area of Kota in last five months, the district administration and medical and health department took several measures on Thursday. The deaths were reportedly due to diarrhoea caused by drinking contaminated water.

District collector Om Kasera called a meeting of officials and ordered a probe to ascertain the actual reason of death of three children in the last five months. He ordered immediate cleaning drive, survey and medical camps.

He also asked the officials of departments concerned to carry out door-to-door survey to collect samples, to repair leakages in drinking water pipelines and to start a cleanliness drive in the area.

A seven-member medical team led by deputy CMHO Ghanshyam Meena carried out door-to-door survey in 250 houses and examined 15 children suffering from cold and cough who were immediately administered proper medical treatment. Fogging was carried out in the area.

“No child was diagnosed with symptoms of diarrhoea in Udiya Basti,” the medical official said.

“Water samples collected from drinking water pipelines in Udiya Basti were in examined and found accurate to the standards,” executive engineer of PHED Bharat Bhushan Miglani said. In physical test, 7.5 PH, 1.2 turbidity was found and in chemical test, drinking water was examined up to the standards,” he added.

“During investigation, three children were found to have died on September 27, October 23 and February 1, respectively. The death audit of the three children to ascertain actual reason of death would be conducted,” said Kota CMHO B S Tanwar.

The three children who died were in paediatric age group, he added.

There are 483 houses in the Basti and door-to-door survey at every house would be carried out, he added.

Title: Candidates sceptical on BDU distance education courses
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: After Bharathidasan University (BDU) omitted the status of approval from distance education bureau (DEB) of University Grants Commission (UGC) in the admission advertisement for distance education programmes, candidates are now sceptical about applying.

BDU, which is yet to get DEB approval chose to omit the same in its advertisement that was published in newspapers last week. Offering many undergraduate and postgraduate courses, the university had mentioned February 28 as the last date to submit applications.

Getting approval from DEB is essential for any institution to offer various programmes through distance mode. State universities like Alagappa, Madurai Kamaraj , Manonmaniam Sundaranar and Tamil University which had recently advertised for their programmes offered through distance mode had mentioned that they possess DEB approval. This has created confusion among students if the courses offered through distance mode by BDU will be valid. “When other state universities could manage to get approval why couldn’t BDU?” asked M Senthil from Woriayur who was planning to join a course in the centre for distance education (CDE) of BDU.

A Ilangovan, director in-charge of CDE, BDU said the university has applied for approval and it may get it any time. He further said that students need not panic as BDU got better score in the recent NAAC assessment which makes the university eligible to offer programmes in distance mode.

The university was unable to apply for DEB approval in mid 2018 through online mode in the absence of better NAAC score. Other universities managed to get approval by giving an undertaking that they will fare well in the NAAC assessment. BDU chose the NAAC way instead of giving undertaking, he said. “DEB portal was open from mid November last year and we have applied for the same. We have satisfied all the criteria and we will get the approval without any hassle,” Illangovan said.

Asked why it wasn’t mentioned in the advertisement, Ilangovan said that the university didn’t wanted to create unnecessary confusion and chose to avoid it as anyway it is eligible to offer the distance education programmes.

Title: Congress MLA among four hurt as car overturns in Sikar
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Parasram Mordiya’s car which was damaged in the mishap

JAIPUR: Five-time Congress MLA from Laxmangarh of Sikar Parasram Mordiya (69) suffered fractures in his leg along with other minor injuries when the car he was travelling in turned turtle near Bosana village on the road connecting Dhod and Losal of Sikar on Thursday.

He was rushed to a private hospital in Jaipur where doctors kept him in emergency care till late Thursday evening. According to hospital administration, he has fracture in one leg and injuries in one hand and neck. “He will require a surgery for treatment of fracture in his leg,” said an official of the hospital.

While expressing his concern, chief minister Ashok Gehlot tweeted, “Concerned about the well-being of MLA and senior Congress leader Sh Parasram Mordia ji who has been injured in a road accident. I wish him speedy recovery.#Rajasthan.”

He was sitting on the front seat when the accident took place. “The accident happened as the driver tried to avoid a crash with another vehicle and hit a pole on the road. After hitting the pole, the vehicle turned turtle,” said Rajesh Arya, circle officer, Sikar rural. He said that there were three other persons along with him including a driver, personal security officer and Pradhan Omprakash Jhinger were travelling in the vehicle when the accident happened. All other three persons suffered minor injuries and they were rushed to a government hospital in Sikar for treatment.

Title: Coronavirus: Cial to screen flyers from Hong Kong, 3 more countries
Content:
Representative Image

KOCHI: Cochin International Airport Limited (Cial) has started health screening of passengers coming from three more countries and Chinese territory of Hong Kong . Earlier, only travellers from mainland China were screened.All passengers of flights from Hong Kong, South Korea Thailand and Singapore will now have to undergo health checks and more medical teams have been deployed for this. The decision follows a spike in the number of novel coronavirus (nCoV) cases in these countries.On Thursday, around 81 passengers were screened, but none had flu-related symptoms.Moreover, the health checks have now started at the aerobridge itself instead of the screening at health counters inside the immigration area. Suspected passengers will be directly shifted from the aerobridge to isolation ward at Ernakulam Government Medical College, without allowing them to enter the terminal or airport building.

Title: Pune: Trains to start from Hadapsar satellite terminus from June
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Once the Hadapsar railway station becomes a satellite terminus., many express trains would start from there

PUNE: The development of the Hadapsar railway station into a satellite terminus would be completed by June.

The Central Railway general manager, Sanjeev Mittal, on Thursday said the developed station would start functioning from June, decongesting the Pune station and easing the pressure of trains on it.

Once the Hadapsar railway station becomes a satellite terminus., many express trains would start from there. Issues related to land acquisition were delaying the project for the past five years. “The matter has been sorted out,” Mittal said.

Speaking on the sidelines of his annual Pune division visit-cum-inspection, Mittal also said, “The first phase of the Pune station yard remodelling would be completed by December.”

An official said, “The Pune yard remodelling project has been divided into four phases. In the first phase extension of all the six platforms to accommodate 26-coach trains and LHB coaches would be completed. The tracks would also be developed to ensure that trains enter the Pune station at a speed of 30km per hour instead of 10km per hour, prevalent now.”

Mittal said plans for the re-development of the Shivajinagar railway station was also progressing.

Title: Man booked for objectionable Facebook post in Tamil Nadu
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: A week after being assaulted by three people, Srirangam resident Rengarajan Narasimhan, the complainant in the alleged idol theft cases at the Srirangam Renganathar temple, was booked on Wednesday on charges of posting a picture of Lord Renganathar without armour on social media.

A case was registered against him based on a complaint from joint commissioner of the temple P Jayaraman. According to the complaint, Narasimhan posted the pictures on social media with the intention to hurt religious beliefs. He was arrested in November 2019 on charges of defaming the temple administration and disrupting religious sentiments by his posts on Facebook . The Trichy district court released him without remanding him with an advice not to post any derogatory remarks. It was the second time now that he was booked based on the complaint from Jayaraman.

Title: Extension to ‘toothless’ Marathwada Development Board questioned
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

AURANGABAD: The extended term of the Marathwada Development Board (MDB) is set to end by April, triggering debate whether the statutory body should be given another extension in view of its image as a ‘toothless’ body.

The crucial body has been accused of being powerless and reduced to making mere recommendations , with many of them said to be falling on deaf ears for years.

While the MDB itself does not have any executive or financial powers, things have gone from bad to worse as it has been cash-starved too.

Established with two other development boards — Vidarbha and Rest of Maharashtra — on May 1, 1994, the MDB got its term extended till April 30, 2020, by a Presidential Order five years ago.

Ashok Belkhode, an expert member of the MDB, from the health sector, said, “As per its constitution, the board submits its recommendations to the governor, who in turn is expected to prevail upon the state government for acting on such proposals. The recommendations remained on paper only.”

Citing an example, Belkhode said the state government has not taken any steps to set up a nursing school and a paramedical institute in the region despite repeated recommendations. He said the purpose of setting up the body to achieve real progress and development of the region could not be achieved due to “official apathy”.

Shankar Nagare, expert member (irrigation), said the governor and the state government must ensure meaningful existence for the statutory body concerned.

Chairman says board can provide a roadmap

Bhagwat Karad, the chairman of the board, said, “It is a bitter truth that the governments in the past did not pay attention to the board. Key recommendations of the statutory body did not receive official response. However, the Marathwada region needs a think-tank to overcome developmental backlog. The board can give a roadmap.”

Title: Going green: e-rickshaws launched at NIT Trichy
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The vehicles will cover major locations like the library, central avenue, main gate, convention centre, shoppi... Read More

TRICHY: The National Institute of Technology (NIT) Trichy on Thursday introduced e-rickshaws to promote the green campus concept. NIT Trichy director Mini Shaji Thomas flagged off the e-rickshaws.

Transvahan - a private firm, will operate the e-rickshaws on a trial basis. Based on the response, it will add two more e-rickshaws. Subsequently, the number may go up to 10.

The vehicles will cover major locations like the library, central avenue, main gate, convention centre, shopping centre, staff quarters and hostels.

The cost of the e-rickshaws and the operating expenses including battery maintenance and driver salary will be borne by Transvahan. The charging stations will be metered with Transvahan paying the electricity charges.

The e-rickshaw will have the capacity to carry four people. A flat fare of Rs 10 per head per trip will be collected, irrespective of the distance, electronically by scanning the QR code in an e-wallet such as Paytm. The director said the facility would benefit students. There are 25 hostels on the campus which are located quite far from the departments. The facility will help them while returning from hostels after lunch break which is a time-consuming affair for many, she said.

Transvahan, Bengaluru who had been successfully running 10 e-rickshaws in the Indian Institute of Science (IISc) campus Bengaluru for the last two years for the use of the students, staff and visitors. Recently, it started operations in the Jawaharlal Nehru Technological University (JNTU) Hyderabad.

Title: Farmers to protest cut in MGNREGA fund
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

TRICHY: Condemning the union government’s decision to reduce the fund allotted for the Mahatma Gandhi National Rural Employment Guarantee ( MGNREGA ) Scheme in the Union budget, Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association will hold a massive protest on February 12 urging the government to enhance it.

Allocations in the union budget for various schemes under the rural development department has been reduced to Rs 1.2 lakh crore from Rs 1.22 lakh crore, while the funds allotted for MGNREGA came down by Rs 9,500 to Rs 61,500 crore, farmers alleged.

“At a time when thousands of agriculture labourers have lost their income as there is no proper employment in farming, this employment guarantee scheme has been helping them to a certain extent. However, the union government has cut down the fund. This is unfair,” said secretary of Thanjavur District Cauvery Farmers Protection Association Swamimalai S Vimalnathan alleged.

The protest will be held near Gandhi park in Kumbakonam, Vimalnathan added.

Title: Girl architecture student kills self in Rajkot
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

RAJKOT: A 20-year-old architecture student hanged herself to death from the ceiling of her house in Ravi Park on Kalawad Road in Rajkot on Thursday morning. Police said the deceased, Rutwi Kothia (20), could not bear the pressure of her studies and took the drastic step. Kothia’s father Nitin Kothia works as a contractor. In her suicide note, Kothia wrote: “Next life better”.

Title: District adminstrations convene meet of religious leaders
Content: KOZHIKODE/THRISSUR/KOTTAYAM: Awareness programmes about novel coronavirus infection and safeguards to be taken against the virus will be imparted at various places of worship in Wayanad district, including temples, mosques and churches.A decision in this regard was taken at the meeting organized by Wayanad district authorities with religious leaders held at the district collectorate on Thursday. ADM Thankachan Antony said that the district administration has roped in religious leaders also to spread awareness regarding coronavirus.Meanwhile in Thrissur, a meeting of leaders of various religious groups, convened by the district administration, appealed to the society as a whole not to stigmatize those under coronavirus surveillance at hospitals and homes. District collector S Shanawaz appealed to the religious groups to provide spiritual support to those under home quarantine, if they request.In Kottayam , Dr P S Rakesh, a representative from WHO, led an awareness programme for the stakeholders in the tourism industry at Kumarakom . He directed resort owners to inform the district coronavirus control room on tourists from China, Japan, Korea , Germany, Thailand, Malaysia and Singapore . The resort owners’ association said that currently there were no tourists from China in Kumarakom.

Title: Medaram Jatara: Two more die of cardiac arrest at Jatara
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

MEDARAM: Two devotees died on the second day of the tribal jatara at Medaram on Thursday, taking the total death toll to five. Both suffered a cardiac arrest, officials said.

According to witnesses, Narsaiah (65) complained of chest pain after taking a dip in the Jampanna Vagu. Before he could get help, the resident of Kambalapally village in Mahabubabad district passed away. Narsaiah was visiting Medaram along with his family. Another youth from Shivanagar, Warangal district , also suffered a cardiac arrest at the Jampanna Vagu. He was identified as 30-year-old Gunde Venu.

Title: Rs 15cr facelift for Lal Bagh campus to restore its glamour
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Indore: Lal Bagh is not just a historic palace in Indore. The whole campus is a part of Indore’ identity and heritage, for which administration now plans to pump in Rs 15crore to conserve and renovate the whole premises including Champa Bawari and turn into smart heritage — an encroachment free green campus with all modern amenities for visitors’ entertainment and restored to its long lost glory.

The plan by divisional commissioner Akash Tripathi with help of tourism department, Indore Municipal Corporation (IMC) and other government agencies aims to restore and conserve the palace with World Monuments Fund (WFM).

Tripathi has instructed IMC for conservation of Champa Bawari on Lal Bagh campus while dilapidated structures, which have been illegally constructed, will be removed. A restaurant and souvenir shop will be set up there. During a meeting to review proposed work of conservation of the palace, senior officials from different departments concerned agreed on developing separate kitchen to cook veg and non-veg dishes to serve to customers in the restaurant.

Besides, Japanese Miyawaki method of afforestation will be implemented to grow urban forest and increase greenery in appropriate and available land on palace’s campus in next one year.

As RTO office had been shifted from Kesharbagh Road to Nayta Mundla, commissioner instructed to remove unused furniture and other stuffs kept inside. A huge record is found stored in this building but the same doesn’t belong to RTO. The officials have been asked to remove it.

During the meeting, divisional commissioner instructed officials to explore ways to make Lal Bagh Palace as a major tourist destination again and ensure better implementation of the plan.

Title: Kolkata: Schools start finding ways to keep private cars away
Content:
City schools to ensure students avail of either carpools or school buses from April and restricted the use of ... Read More

KOLKATA: Acting on the order from the school education department commissioner, who had issued a circular asking 26 prominent city schools to ensure that their students avail of either carpools or school buses from April and restricted the use of personal vehicles to “exceptional cases”, several institutes have set the ball rolling for the changeover.La Martiniere Boys School principal John Rafi has issued a circular requesting parents to stop ferrying students in individual private cars. To transport kids in hired carpools, the school management will help in identifying carpools to assist guardians. Rafi has also written a letter to the school education department regarding the inability of the school to purchase buses or take responsibility of carpools due to infrastructure and funds constraints.“This is the first time the school has assured to take responsibility for arranging or informing about carpools,” said the father of a Class III student. “If they facilitate such a move, more and more parents will be convinced to shun private cars,” he added. In the notice, the school clearly stated that from April 1, the school will not take any responsibility for individual private cars. According to a senior school official, the move was “inevitable and necessary” after the state order.“Once we receive the letter from La Martiniere School, we shall forward it to the chief minister’s office,” said a Nabanna source. However, he added that the schools were “bound” to make alternative arrangements to ensure no individual private cars ferry students to and from schools.Modern High School For Girls is holding talks with the transport department to make arrangements for renting buses. There are five school buses and 2,500 students. “We are finding ways to facilitate the order. The school administrators are discussing the matter with transport officials and we hope to find a solution soon. Also, a circular will be sent to the guardians informing them about the order,” said director Devi Kar. The school will ask for suggestions from parents.At Don Bosco School, Park Circus , too, a governing body meeting was held on Thursday to find ways to implement the order. “We will not buy buses. However, the school shall facilitate the arrangements. We will hold discussions with the transport department and, if necessary, rent buses to commute students. But first, we shall hold meetings with the parents,” said principal Bikash Mondal.St James’ School principal TH Ireland said a list of carpools and chartered buses will be put up along with the phone numbers ahead of the next academic session. “The parents will have to coordinate and arrange for carpools. In our school, around 65% of students arrive in carpools. Soon, we shall distribute the government order and inform the parents about the ban on private cars,” Ireland said.St Xavier’s Collegiate School has not yet received the circular from the school education directorate. “We shall comply with the order and inform parents to stop ferrying kids in private cars. We will facilitate carpools once we receive the circular,” said Father M Thamacin Arulappan, principal of the school.On schools who are yet not interested in taking the responsibility of transporting students and have left the decision on parents, Subhas Datta, a green crusader and key litigant in NGT on the city's air pollution, said it was a shameless act on the part of the schools not to take the onus of congestion and pollution caused by school-bound private cars. “What are they teaching students — not owning responsibility and the art of passing the buck? If any school refuses to comply with the norms, I will drag that school to court,” he said.

Title: Shivaji Park Gymkhana away from Thackeray memorial plot, BMC tells HC
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Mumbai: The Shivaji Park Gymkhana is away from the plot where the Bal Thackeray memorial is to come up, BMC told the Bombay High Court on Thursday. This response came after a petitioner , challenging the validity of the conversion of the land housing the Mayor’s Bungalow, told the court there is apprehension that the memorial will affect the gymkhana as well.

A bench of Justices Satyaranjan Dharmadhikari and Riyaz Chagla heard four public interest litigations (PILs) in respect to the conversion of reservation of the Mayor’s Bungalow for the late Shiv Sena leader’s memorial.

Even as the judges were posting the PILs for admission, advocate Sunip Sen sought a stay and said the gymkhana may be affected as well. Senior advocate for BMC, Anil Sakhare, said the gymkhana is not a subject matter of the PILs. “Three big buildings are in between,” Sakhare said, adding that the Savarkar Memorial, Mahatma Gandhi swimming pool and Vanita Samaj are situated before the gymkhana.

Advocate Pradeep Havnur said his client was not opposed to the memorial, but it cannot be at the cost of conversion of the Mayor’s Bungalow. “They are also putting up a memorial at Aurangabad,” he said. The judges questioned whether there is no power in law for the BMC to effect a conversion or take back property which vests originally in it.

Senior advocate Darius Khambata, for the Balasaheb Thackeray Rashtriya Smarak, said the BMC Act was amended specifically to provide for this memorial. The judges posted for admission in March so that a final hearing can be held.

Title: Smart city to fund civic body’s hot mix plant
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

AURANGABAD: The Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) has decided to set up its own hot mix plant for maintenance of roads using smart city funds. A decision in this regard will be taken by the smart city board of directors.

In a TOI report published on February 3, municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey had said that the municipal corporation plans to raise its own hot mix plant for maintenance of roads.

During the general body meeting on Thursday, corporators raised several issues pertaining to bad shape of roads in their wards. In the presence of Pandey, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said the AMC has decided to set up the hot mix plant using the smart city funds. “The matter will be taken up in the next meeting with the smart city board of directors,” he said. Ghodele asked executive engineer to prepare an action plan on priority and submit it to the board.

All major roads in the city are either under the care of the Public Works Department (PWD) or the national highway division. Other key roads are being concretised under various projects funded by the state government. However, the internal roads in every ward of the civic body are riddled with potholes.

When asked, the municipal corporation expressed its inability to repair these roads or reconstruct them due to shortage of funds.

Every year before the Ganesh festival, the civic body issues a tender inviting private agencies to carry out repair works on these roads and spends up to Rs 5 crore on the same. However, the work is far from satisfactory as the patchwork comes of within a couple of days.

To address this issue, Pandey proposed the hot mix plant. The municipal commissioner, who is also the CEO of the Aurangabad Smart City Development Corporation Ltd, has the authority to take a decision in this regard.

Title: NRCB to hold international conference
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

TRICHY: National Research Centre for Banana, ( NRCB ), Trichy , is organising an international conference on the topic ‘Innovations in Sustainable Production and Value Chain Management in Banana’ from February 22. The four-day conference will begin with a satellite workshop for farmers from China and Indonesia, followed by a banana expo and ending with a visit to Theni where the participants will be taken to banana export units, where handling, processing, storage, ripening facilities could be seen.

“The conference will provide an interdisciplinary forum to discuss the opportunities and threats faced by the banana industry, help to develop mitigating strategies and solutions and identify research gap,” S Uma, director of NRCB, Trichy said.

Title: Coronavirus in Kerala: 13 discharged from isolation wards in three Kerala districts
Content:
Representative image

THRISSUR: Ten people under observation in isolation wards were discharged on Thursday, eight from the isolation ward at Thrissur Medical College Hospital and two from the one at general hospital. They will now have to be under home quarantine for the remaining period of the 28-day coronavirus surveillance.In all, 251 people are under coronavirus surveillance in Thrissur district as per the data available on Thursday, and out of them, 22 people have been admitted to different hospitals. The condition of the patient with novel coronavirus (nCoV) is stable.In Alappuzha, the condition of the student, who tested positive for nCoV and is in the isolation ward of Alappuzha Medical College Hospital , is satisfactory, said district collector M Anjana. One person, who was under observation at an isolation ward, was discharged on Thursday. Now, only seven people are in isolation wards in the district.Meanwhile in Kottayam, two persons, who were under observation in the isolation ward in Government Medical College Hospital, were allowed to return home. They were allowed to leave after it was confirmed that their samples tested negative for nCoV. However, both will have to remain under home quarantine. Now, only one person is in the MCH isolation ward.Eight more persons arrived in Kottayam from nCoV-affected countries on Thursday. They have been directed by the health department to remain under home quarantine. The number of home-quarantined people in Kottayam has now reached 100.In Wayanad, health authorities said that the test result of the samples taken from a youth, who had arrived in the district from China was negative. The test was conducted at the virology institute at Alappuzha. Meanwhile, the number of persons who were kept under observation in the district rose to 54 with the addition of five individuals who arrived recently from Thailand, Singapore and Saudi Arabia.(Inputs from Kottayam Alappuzha Kozhikode)

Title: Only King Institute is authorised to test coronavirus: Health department
Content:
Representative image

TRICHY: The department of public health and preventive medicines has categorically stated that no other lab except King Institute in Chennai has been authenticated to conduct tests to confirm novel coronavirus (nCoV) in the state.“Taking serious view of information from some other places in the state that private hospitals performed lab test to confirm nCoV, I want to make it clear that no one has been authorised except King Institute to carry out the lab test to check the infection of the new strain of the coronavirus,” said deputy director of health services (DDHS) Dr A Subramani, here on Thursday.He was speaking at the awareness meetings for the staff of 117 private hospitals, 82 PHCs including UPHCs, 13 government hospitals and one government medical college hospital (Mahatma Gandhi Memorial (MGM) government hospital) in the city.“Though we have no such complaints here, private hospitals should be clearly communicated about the matter as it will trigger panic among the people in case of any misleading results. Of the seven strains of corona virus, four are non-lethal but the three others including nCoV are lethal. If one conducts a swab test, it may indicate infection of any one of the four corona viruses, but it may not be the latest nCoV,” DDHS told TOI.He also said that the treatment for the suspects should also be done at MGM government hospital.

Title: Aurangabad: Mayor, civic chief forced to leave in autorickshaws
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele left the general body meeting venue in an autorickshaw after protesters obstructed the... Read More

AURANGABAD: People with disabilities seeking honorariums from the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) blocked the vehicles of the mayor and the municipal commissioner after Monday’s general body meeting — forcing both of them to leave in autorickshaws instead.

Following the protest, the municipal corporation released the honorariums of 476 people with disabilities.

Incidentally, the disabled people have been demanding honorariums from the AMC for their welfare and rehabilitation since the past two years. The AMC has even verified the number of registered people with disabilities in its jurisdiction. However, citing poor financial condition, the civic body had not released honorariums to all.

As a result, activists representing the people with disabilities, under the banner of Prahar Apang Kranti Andolan, have been protesting after every general body meeting in past few months.

On Monday, they barged into the AMC compound and raised slogans. When municipal commissioner Astik Kumar Pandey was heading out of the building in his official vehicle, his way was blocked by the agitating crowd. Pandey had to hear out the concerns of the protesters and was forced to leave in an autorickshaw.

A few minutes later, mayor Nandkumar Ghodele’s vehicle too was blocked in a similar fashion, compelling him to take an autorickshaw as well.

Notably, the stir resulted in the municipal corporation immediately releasing the honorariums of 476 people with disabilities.

Apang Kranti Andolan’s Shivaji Gade said that all people with disabilities who were verified by the AMC have received their honorariums. “People with disabilities were informed that this is the last general body meeting before the model code of conduct kicks in for the AMC election, which is why they were persistent that the money is released,” he said.

Title: No proposal to privatise power firms in Bihar: Union minister R K Singh
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Union power minister R K Singh. (Photo: Twitter/@RajKSinghIndia)

PATNA: Union power minister R K Singh on Thursday categorically ruled out any proposal for privatization of Bihar State Power Holding Company Limited (BSPHCL) as well as its subsidiary companies. “There will be no privatisation of BSPHCL and its subsidiary companies,” the minister said in a telephonic conversation with BSPHCL CMD-cum-principal secretary of energy department Pratyaya Amrit.

The minister’s remark came after the recent announcement of five workers’ union bodies of the power companies under the banner of Vidyut Kamgar Padhadhikari Abhiyanta Sanyukt Sangharsh Morcha regarding a “symbolic” 24-hour power shutdown across the state on February 11 and 12 against the move to privatise the company.

Pratyaya seconded minister Singh’s remark and said the company would treat the proposed strike as “illegal” under Bihar State Essential Service Maintenance Act and Essential Service Maintenance Regulation (ESMR), 2020.

“Action will be taken against such employees and engineers who join the strike proposed to be held from 6am on February 11 to 6am on February 12,” he said.

Addressing media persons at Vidyut Bhawan here, Pratyaya said he as well as state energy minister Bijendra Prasad Yadav have made it clear on several occasions that there was no proposal to privatise BSPHCL and its subsidiary companies.

“I even held several video-conferencing sessions in January and February and addressed the employees and engineers of all the circles in the state. However, some rumourmongers are still misleading the employees,” Pratyaya said.

However, PESA general secretary Surendra Kumar refused to budge. “How can we trust the CMD? He did not even issue a single letter in support of his assertion that privatisation will not take place. Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman had announced on February 1 that in order to ensure continuous power supply, certain models will be adopted, such as privatizing state-run discoms and multiple supply, network and distribution franchisees,” Kumar said.

Title: Private shipyard fined for delay in delivery of ferry boats
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The river navigation department (RND) has imposed a penalty on Aquarius shipyard pvt ltd, based in Tivim for f... Read More

PANAJI: The river navigation department (RND) has imposed a penalty on Aquarius shipyard pvt ltd, based in Tivim for failing to deliver three ferry boats within the stipulated time.

An order signed by the captain of ports (CoP), James Braganza, and issued to the private shipyard states that a penalty will be imposed. “You are required to complete the construction of the ferry boats and hand over the new ferry boats immediately,” the order signed by CoP read.

The delivery date for the three ferry boats was November 24, 2019, which is 100 days from August 14, 2019 when the work was to be completed, as per the agreement.

“We have intimated the company about the fine. The company was supposed to build and hand over three ferry boats, and will be imposed with a penalty of Rs 2,000 per ferry boat. They will have to pay Rs 6,000 per day,” an official of the RND said while speaking to TOI.

The RND’s survey report however indicates that not much progress has been made and the construction is “very slow”. The shipyard has therefore been ordered to pay the penalty as “liquidated damages” from November 25, 2019 onwards till the construction is completed.

The penalty amount will be deducted from Aquarius’s bill.

Three new ferries were to be intorduced to replace some of the oldest ferries in the state; Canacona and Cumbharjua. The new vessels are expected to be built with single-engine machines of 100 horse power.

Title: Follow hygiene practices to prevent infection: Minister
Content:
Health minister C Vijayabaskar attending an awareness program on preventive measures to be taken against coron... Read More

TRICHY: More than 13,000 people from abroad, including Indians, who visited Tamil Nadu in the last two weeks were screened and found negative for novel coronavirus infection, said health minister C Vijayabaskar on Thursday.Out of the 13112 people who were screened, 1353 of them were from affected countries, the minister added.The minister was speaking at a programme in Pudukkottai to create awareness about the coronavirus infection.He said that extensive awareness campaigns were being held in schools and colleges on preventive measures to be taken against spread of the virus (2019-nCoV).The minister asked students to wash hands properly for 15 times a day, cover their face with hands while sneezing and maintain personal hygiene to prevent themselves from getting infected by 2019-nCoV.

Title: Miss Shefali Death: With Miss Shefali, a slice of Ray’s Calcutta passes away
Content:
Miss Shefali and her Sodepur house

KOLKATA: When Miss Shefali succumbed to cardiac arrest at her Sodepur house on Thursday, it marked the end of not just the journey of an artiste, but also of an era. Her death at the age of 73 ended another chapter of Bengal’s lust for romanticism with the art and artistes.Born Arati Das, Shefali’s teenage years saw a meteoric rise — from being a domestic help at an Anglo-Indian household to becoming Kolkata’s cabaret queen, who was a rage at Firpo’s and the Oberoi Grand. Films and theatre followed and legend has it that Satyajit Ray had come to pick her up on her first day of shooting for ‘Pratidwandi’, where she was cast as a nurse. Director Sandip Ray remembers her as a “respectful” and “affectionate” professional. “Baba had wanted to see the room where she performed and so we went there. At the end of her performance, she made Baba wear the garland that she was wearing. This act inspired Baba to replicate a similar scene in ‘Seemabadha’,” he said.Was it the Ray factor that set her apart from so many other cabaret dancers? According to her ‘Seemabadha’ co-actor Barun Chanda, the Ray factor was certainly a part of it, but it was not the only factor responsible. “She might have started as a cabaret girl, but she certainly went beyond it,” Chanda said. Aishika Chakraborty, professor of Jadavpur University’s School of Women’s Studies and author of ‘Kolkatar Cabaret: Bangali, Jounata Ebang Miss Shefali’, attributes her enigma to her “supreme talent” and training. “Here was a gifted teenage refugee dancer from a half-broke family of east Pakistan who, in a patriarchal world, refused to play the victim card. She danced till as late as 2000, did jatra, went to villages to do macha shows and even had her own dance group,” Chakraborty said.Yet, the last years of her life saw her in deep financial crisis. Her number of dependents were unlimited. “She had supported so many girls during her heyday but never thought that one day she herself would face financial crunch,” said niece Elvina Shefali. “She would pick up beggars from streets and give them two options — get married or become a cabaret dancer. If they chose to marry, she would buy their gold ornaments. If not, she would train and give them shows,” Chakraborty added.But the film industry never really acknowledged her. No pivotal roles came her way. A biopic on her was announced but never got made. A Konkona Sen Sharma-directed webseries is on the cards. Despite being trained in various art forms, including Can-Can, Hawaiian hula and belly dancing, she didn’t become popular judge at any dance reality show. “That was my aunt’s biggest regret,” said her niece.Post her death, countless social media posts paying homage to her is perhaps society’s first attempt at celebrating a power woman who loved to describe her own life as “history”.

Title: Fibre-reinforced plastic statue to be erected for Shiv Jayanti
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Aurangabad: As the work to increase the height of the Chhatrapati Shivaji Maharaj statue at Kranti Chowk will not be completed by February 19, the civic body will install a fibre-reinforced plastic statue of the Maratha icon on Shiv Jayanti.

During the general body meeting on Thursday, Rajgaurav Wankhede of BJP asked the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation’s administration about the progress on the statue’s elevation. Wankhede reminded mayor Nandkumar Ghodele of his statement in the previous general body meeting — that the statue work will be completed by February 19.

Ghodele, in response, told Wankhede that he and all members in the House are sensitive to the issue. Wankhede asked why was the February 19 deadline not met with, even though it has been six months since the old statue was removed.

Executive engineer Hemant Kolhe said all the bids received in the first tender for installing the statue had faults, therefore, re-tendering had to be done.

On this, corporator Raju Shinde pointed out the flaws in the tender document prepared by the AMC. He said that the AMC should specify the material with which it wants the agency to prepare the statue.

When the BJP members asked if the state government has approved funds required for the project, Ghodele said that the project will not fall short of funds.

He added that the statue will be raised in a time-bound manner but the project will not be completed before February 19. As an alternative, AMC will erect a fibre-reinforced plastic statue.

Title: Waste management: Government seeks to put onus on local bodies
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

PANAJI: The government on Wednesday proposed to amend the Goa Panchayat Raj Act, to make panchayats directly responsible for garbage management. Panchayat minister Mauvin Godinho told the assembly during Question Hour that the act would be amended to make panchayats responsible for garbage management, while replying to a question tabled by former PWD minister Ramkrishna Dhavalikar.

Dhavalikar questioned the government’s authority in issuing a circular to panchayats, which are autonomous bodies, ordering them not to issue occupancy certificates to large construction projects and multi-dwelling units, if they do not carry-out proper waste management.

The circular in question, and another one linked to the first one, have been withdrawn, Godinho retorted. He also placed a copy of the revoked circular on the table of the House.

Dhavalikar was not satisfied. “You (panchayat minister) have no authority to issue such a circular to an autonomous body. You went beyond the act. Who gave you that power?,” demanded Dhavalikar.

Stating he was within his “administrative powers” to do so, Godinho said they were compelled to issue the circular as panchayats were not taking their civic responsibility seriously, and they (the panchayat directorate) were answerable to court in various petitions pertaining to waste management. “Panchayats are not answerable to court but the panchayat ministry is,” he said. After a note from advocate general Devidas Pangam, he said they decided to amend the act.

Opposition leader Digambar Kamat brought it to the notice of the government that many panchayats have not received the revoked circular, and Godinho assured that all panchayats would receive it shortly. Porvorim MLA Rohan Khaunte said no action is taken against illegal constructions, and said they were on the rise.

Title: Telangana: 25-year-old woman gives birth to baby
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

MEDARAM: Amidst news of more deaths, Medaram devotees found a reason to cheer after a 25-year-old woman delivered a baby boy on day 2 of the jatara on Thursday.

The woman, Shivani Govinda Chauhan is a resident of Pune and visited Medaram to offer prayers to goddesses, Sammakka and Saralamma. “The baby was born at an auspicious time, soon after the arrival of Sammakka. Both the mother and the baby – weighing 3.5kg, are safe,” said a local health official.Telangana health minister, Etela Rajender visited Shivani in the hospital.

Title: AMC to issue tenders for township DPR, construction
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The township will be built as part of the PMAY-U

AURANGABAD: The civic body will invite agencies who can prepare a detailed project report (DPR) and carry out the construction of a township under the Pradhan Mantri Awaas Yojna (PMAY)-Urban.

In the general body meeting, on members’ insistence, deputy municipal commissioner Sumant More was called to present the status of an affordable housing project of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation under the PMAY-U. More said the AMC has identified land for raising a township in Teesgaon.

“The AMC had written to the district collector on January 8 for acquisition of that land for Affordable Housing in Partnership (AHP), the third component of PMAY-U. Following the receipt from the district collector, the process for preparing DPR will be done and then the project will be raised under public-private partnership,” More said.

BJP member Raju Shinde said the approval from district collector is likely to come soon. He proposed that in the meantime, the AMC should begin the process of issuing tender. “The PMAY-U scheme aims to provide housing for all by 2022. To achieve this, the AMC must invite bids from an agency which can prepare the DPR and complete the project,” Shinde said.

Subsequently, Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele asked More to initiate the tender process within seven days in the way Shinde suggested. “The process should be initiated before the model code of conduct is implemented for the AMC election,” mayor said.

House leader Vikas Jain asked the AMC administration to ensure that the criteria laid out by the Centre are met with while issuing the tender. More said that once the site is approved, the land measurement has to be carried out.

Title: Yavatmal resident doctor suspended for not taking minister’s call
Content: YAVATMAL: A junior resident doctor at Yavatmal Government Medical College and Hospital has been suspended for eight days on the orders of district guardian minister Sanjay Rathod.GMCH in-charge dean Dr Milind Kamble issued the suspension order charging the doctor with showing disrespect to people’s representative Rathod, who is also the state forest minister, by not taking his call.According to sources, Dr Achyut Narote was on duty in casualty ward on Monday evening attending to 5-6 serious patients when an elderly man brought his son, who had reportedly consumed poison, to the ward. Worried about his son’s health, the man insisted Dr Narote attend to his son urgently. When the doctor asked him to wait, the man called a ‘bhau’ (brother in Marathi) to complain.After a brief conversation with ‘bhau’, the man asked the doctor to talk to the person at the other end. Not knowing that the ‘bhau’ on phone was minister Rathod, the doctor refused to attend the call saying he is busy and will talk only after 10 minutes or else ask the ‘bhau’ to come to the hospital.Rathod apparently overheard the conversation. He then contacted Dr Kamble demanding action against the junior doctor. Dr Kamble immediately suspended the doctor for eight days from Tuesday.Speaking to TOI on Thursday, Dr Kamble said he has suspended Dr Narote after verifying what had happened. He also informed that show cause memos have been served on two male nurses and a woman nurse who were on duty when the incident took place. “The three have been show caused for not attending the phone call of the minister when the doctor was busy,” said Dr Kamble.On Thursday, a delegation of resident doctors met the dean and requested him to revoke Dr Narote’s suspension. After the meeting, Dr Kamble announced a three-member committee, under chairmanship of Dr Surendra Gawarle, HoD of ENT department, to probe the matter and submit a report in two days.Meanwhile, local unit of Maharashtra Association of Resident Doctors (MARD) has threatened to launch an agitation if the doctor’s suspension was not revoked.Rathod admitted to having asked the dean to take action against Dr Narote. Narrating the incident, Rathod said on Monday a person from his constituency had called him to complain about the GMCH doctor not attending to his son.“When the worried father wanted Dr Narote to speak to me on phone, he not only refused to talk but also ‘insulted’ the elderly person,” said Rathod. “Three nurses on duty also refused to attend the call and hence I had to instruct the dean to initiate action against the ‘irresponsible’ doctor,” the minister added.“After the suspension, Dr Narote sent me a message apologizing for the incident. Since probe has been ordered, let the dean decide future course of action based on the committee report,,” said Rathod.

Title: Objections raised on ward reservation during GB meet
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The GB meeting was held on Thursday

AURANGABAD: The corporators of the Aurangabad Municipal Corporation (AMC) raised objections to the ward reservation process, for the civic election, in Thursday’s general body meeting.

However, after taking legal advice the discussion was closed with mayor asking the members to lodge formal objections by the prescribed deadline.

The AMC’s election department, under the guidelines of the State Election Commission, conducted the ward reservation allocation process for scheduled caste (SC), scheduled tribe (ST), other backward class (OBC), SC-women, ST-women, OBC-women and women (general) categories on Monday.

During the general body meeting, Sitaram Sure, the corporator of Surewadi, near Harsul, initiated the discussion.

He said the process had done injustice to the people of Harsul. There are nine wards in the Harsul area, and all of them had been previously reserved for the SC category. This time too, all of the wards have been reserved for other categories. Therefore, there is no ward here for the general category. He wanted a three-member inquiry committee to look into this matter.

Surekha Sanap, the Brijwadi corporator from Shiv Sena, objected to the name change of her ward to Savitri Nagar Chikalthana Naregaon East.

“In 1982, Brijwadi was amongst the 18 villages around Aurangabad that were included in the AMC. If the boundaries of the ward are same, why is Brijwadi’s name removed?” she asked.

Afsar Khan, Congress corporator from Jaisingpura, Bhavsingpura, questioned the basis on which 2,500 voters from other wards were included in his ward. Gangadhar Dhage, MIM group leader, alleged the ward reservations are done in a way that will ensure that MIM corporators do not get elected to the House again.

Mayor Nandkumar Ghodele said that after he spoke to the lawyer of the Election Commission (EC) and the AMC’s legal advisor, it has been decided that the discussion is closed.

“The window to file objections on the ward name, reservation, population and boundaries assigned by the EC is open until February 11. Those who have objections, including the public, can file objections in prescribed format,” Ghodele said.

Title: Telangana: Portal for online sale of TDR launched
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Till date more than 550 TDR certificates have been issued by GHMC,” read a statement issued by the civic body

HYDERABAD: An online portal to facilitate sale of Transfer of Development Rights ( TDR ) was launched by the Greater Hyderabad Municipal Corporation ( GHMC ) on Thursday.

The portal (http://tdr.ghmc.telangana.gov.in), known as TDR Bank , has features such as issue, utilise, sale of TDR certificates and data of existing certificates. It was launched by municipal administration and urban development (MAUD) minister KT Rama Rao.

Property owners who have lost land during land acquisition by the government, and do not want monetary compensation, can opt for TDR certificates. The certificate gives rights to the owner to construct additional built-up area to his property

The certificate acts as permission for additional built up area, which can be constructed anywhere in the city. If the property owner does not wish to raise additional floors or extend built-up area, he/she can sell the TDR certificate.

The government has extended the utilisation of TDR certificates issued by GHMC up to the limits of ORR in Hyderabad Metropolitan Development Authority (HMDA) jurisdiction. Citizens can view the available TDR in the TDR Bank application. The existing manual TDR certificate holders will be given an opportunity to convert the manual certificate into digital platform. As per norms only digital certificate owners can sell TDR certificates.

Till date more than 550 TDR certificates have been issued by GHMC,” read a statement issued by the civic body.

Title: Special trains for 808th annual Urs at Ajmer
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Aurangabad: The South Central Railway (SCR) has announced special trains in order to clear the extra rush of passengers attending the 808th th annual Urs festival at Ajmer. These trains will run between Nanded and Madar junction in Ajmer district via Aurangabad, an official release said.

Nanded-Madar special train (07641) will depart from Nanded at 4 pm on February 28 and is scheduled to reach its destination by 11.35 pm the next day.

In the return direction, Madar-Nanded special train (07642) will depart from Madar at 9.25 pm on March 4 and is expected to arrive at Nanded by 7 am on Friday.

These special trains will halt at Purna, Parbhani, Selu, Partur, Jalna, Aurangabad, Rotegaon, Manmad, Bhusaval, Khandwa, Itarsi, Bhopal, Sant Hirdaram Nagar, Sehore, Maksi, Ujjain Mandasor, Nimach, Chittaurgarh, Bhilwara, Bijainagar, Nasirabad, Nagda, Ratlam and Ajmer stations in both the directions.

These special trains will have AC II tier, AC III tier, AC chair car, sleeper class, and general second class coaches.

As per official schedule, the flag ceremony, as part of 808th Urs at Ajmer, is scheduled to be held on February 19, followed by actual commencement of the Urs festival on February 25. It is scheduled to conclude on March 4.

The dates are subject to change depending on the sighting of the moon, the shrine trust has said.

Title: Goa budget: House adjourned four times amid opposition protests
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The agitating members had to be whisked out by the marshals

PORVORIM: The state legislative assembly was adjourned four times on Thursday with the opposition creating uproar in the well of the House over the arrest of independent MLA Rohan Khaunte at midnight for allegedly wrongfully restraining BJP spokesperson Premanand Mahambre.

With the opposition unrelenting in its protest, no business other than the budget presentation by chief minister Pramod Sawant was transacted on day 5 of the session.

They raised slogans “we want justice”, “shame, shame” as Sawant started his budget speech at 3pm. No amount of warnings by speaker Rajesh Patnekar could silence the opposition members who rushed to the well of the House raising slogans.

The uproar continued for around ten minutes with the speaker repeatedly asking the protesting members to stop disturbing the House. On more than one occasion he asked them to either “withdraw or boycott” the House. Finally, the agitating members were whisked out by the marshals.

Earlier in the day, House proceedings were adjourned three times during the first half as the opposition did not budge from its stance — justice for the undemocratic treatment meted out to Khaunte, who was arrested while the House was in session.

As a mark of protest, the opposition members tied a black ribbon on their arms. When the House met at 11.30am, leader of the opposition Digambar Kamat said that what happened on the intervening night of Wednesday and Thursday was “undemocratic and irresponsible”.

“You (speaker) are our father in this House. You ought to have protected our interest,” Kamat said.

He also said that the speaker should have taken Congress MLA Pratapsingh Rane’s statement as he was with Khaunte when the alleged incident took place on Wednesday.

“How could you issue permission without an inquiry,” Kamat said. He was supported by GFP chief Vijai Sardesai.

The speaker told the House that he was intimated about the incident. “Under Rule 99 a prior permission was sought as the incident happened in the precincts of the House and it was granted,” he said.

The speaker’s response failed to satisfy agitating members and they once again raised slogans. “I have done my job as per the rules,” the speaker said before adjourning the House till 12pm.

Nothing had changed when the House resumed. Opposition members created a ruckus yet again, leading to a second adjournment within half-an-hour.

Opposition members objected to an alleged note submitted by some BJP activists to the speaker demanding Khaunte’s suspension from the House. The speaker said, “It (the note) doesn’t matter as I will not act on it.”

The opposition rushed to the well yet again, and House was adjourned till 2.30pm.

Speaking to reporters later, the opposition said they will continue to protest until the person on whose “false” complaint Khaunte was arrested, is also arrested.

Rane said, he was with Khaunte and nothing — as stated in the complaint — happened. Likening it to a “Gestapo raj”, he said it will not be tolerated.

“This is the first time in the history of Goa that the opposition was taken out at the time of presenting the budget,” Kamat said.

Title: T minority commission to hold nat’l-level conf in Mar
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Hyderabad: The Telangana minority commission has decided to conduct a national-level conference in March. This decision was taken at a review meeting held on Wednesday.

The commission also reviewed a number of petitions. A total of 1,053 petitions were received by the minority commission since March 2018 and 882 petitions were disposed of. A total of 171 petitions are still pending with the state minority commission.

At the meeting, a suggestion was also made to name a road in the state after General Manekshaw who served as the chief of the Army.

Title: Kin of nilgai, monkey attack victims too to get compensation
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020
