The additional job was tasked upon Airport Health Organization (APHO) — that operates under the Union ministry of health — last week after it was found that all three confirmed patients affected by novel coronavirus had come to Kolkata, before taking a domestic flight to Kochi in Kerala. While the first two patients had taken China Eastern Airlines flight from Kunming to Kolkata on January 23, the other person — who was diagnosed three days ago — had landed in Kolkata by an IndiGo flight from Guangzhou on January 25.“All the passengers on the flight as well as the crew members are susceptible to the infection now as the three patients were silent carriers of the disease and had developed symptoms only after reaching their homes. Our task is to track down all the flyers on the China-Kolkata and the Kolkata-Kochi flights and inform the Centre and the state governments concerned. It is the task of the state governments to get them quarantined and tested,” a senior official at the Kolkata airport said.The official said that to complete the task, they were working with the airlines to find out the seat numbers of all the flyers to find out their approximate distance from the confirmed patients while travelling on the flight. They will also check the CCTV footage at the airport to find out the distance their co-passengers maintained at the queues for immigration check and thermal screening.“Focus will be on those with a history of visits to Wuhan in China. We are also making a list of all the passengers screened so far. It’s a hectic and extremely time consuming process,” said another official.Meanwhile, based on the report sent by the APHO, the Bengal health department has traced a woman in Behala who visited Wuhan last month. “We have asked her to come to the hospital for tests,” a health official.Another airport official said every day the health officers are screening around 1,500 passengers from 12-15 flights. Till Thursday evening, 12,758 persons had been screened, but no one tested positive. Additional doctors and paramedics have been appointed at the airport to hasten the process.

Title: Medaram Jatara, Telangana’s Kumbh Mela, to see 1.5 crore pilgrims in four days
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

A massive congregation of over one crore people assemble in Medaram

MEDARAM: The religious jamboree at Medaram is south India’s answer to the Kumbh Mela held in north India. A massive congregation of over one crore people assemble in Medaram, a remote village in Telangana ’s Mulugu district every two years to fete goddesses -- Sammakka and Sarakka -- in what is now billed as Asia’s biggest tribal festival.

From the central festival area where the main deities are kept under a tree, it’s a sea of humanity stretching up to 7 km spread across over 300 acres of farmland nestled amid hillocks. Lakhs of people marching onto the banks of Jampanna Vagu, a small rivulet in the village, to celebrate the jatara is a sight to behold.

The jatara is held during the Magha Shuddha Pournami period to celebrate the valour of a tribal woman, Sammakka and her daughter Sarakka who took on the mighty Kakatiya dynasty over an unfair tax regime.

Chenchus, Gonds, Gothikoyas, Adivasis, Lambadas, Koyas, Nayakpods, Banjara Girijans, Muriyas, Mariyas, Dhurves and Rajagonds are some of the tribal sects who throng the jatara. In the last few years, domination of non-tribals has robbed the jatara some of its sheen. “It’s sad to see the management of the historic tribal festival falling into the hands of non-tribals,” complains former Mahabubabad MP A Seetaram Naik.

This spectacle of faith attracts not only people from Andhra Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu but also from Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra and Jharkhand. “People have unflinching faith in the sublime powers of Samakka and Sarakka,” explains tribal priest Mahesh.

On the road leading to this nondescript village, cars jostle for space alongside bullock carts, overcrowded buses and tractors. Official estimates put the number of visitors for the four-day carnival (held between February 5-8 this year) at close to 1.5 crore.

The observances begin with the arrival of deities (in the form of a vermilion-filled casket and a bamboo pole) of Sarakka from Kannepalle hillock. The deity of Sammakka joins her from another hillock, Chilakalagutta. “The celebration of their valour combined with their mystical powers has earned Medaram the sobriquet of a maha jatara in the Deccan plateau, next only to the Kumbh Mela,” says retired professor of National Institute of Technology, Warangal, M Pandu Ranga Rao.

As the mass of humanity advances towards the pedestals where the two deities converge, booming drumbeats entice pilgrims to dance in jubilation under colourful flags. Ardent devotees hurl fowl into the air as sacrificial offerings, while several others roll on the muddy road leading to the altar, allowing tribal priests to walk over them. Many pilgrims sprinkle the blood of animals in a show of reverence, sending a chill up the spines of first-timers to the festival.

Since the 13th century, Girijan and Koya tribals have been holding the jatara in memory of the two tribal women whom they revere as goddesses. “The jatara holds a mirror to the tribal customs, traditions and beliefs,” says tribals’ head priest Kokkera Narasaiah.

Decorated pandals and tents accommodate lakhs of people who gather to listen to soothsayers. Others get busy as they sacrifice goats & hens, cook meat and indulge in booze. Men dressed in exotic female costumes and colourful jewellery, apparently as per the goddesses’ wish!

Another prominent feature is the offering of ‘bangaram’ (jaggery).‘Siva Sattis’, women with turmeric-smeared bodies and matted hair, enter the waters in a tumult, blow conch shells and holler, “Jai Sarakka, Jai Jai Sammakka.”

While some devotees participate only on the day Sammakka is brought from the hillock, many others stay put in makeshift tents for four days. Surya Kumari, a housewife from Hyderabad, said, “It is spiritual magic at its best. In a country where mass congregations are common, the sheer size of the Medaram Jatara sets it apart from the rest.”

Title: Kolhapur: Youth held for stalking woman, threatening her
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

KOLHAPUR: Acting swiftly on a woman’s complaint, the Kolhapur police have arrested a 26-year-old man for allegedly harassing her and threatening her into accept his proposals.

The police are on alert about such complaints after a college teacher was set ablaze by a man in Hinganghat town of Wardha district .

The Kolhapur police received a complaint from the woman on Tuesday that the suspect had been harassing him for the past one year. The complainant works in a private firm in Kolhapur city. Around a year ago, the suspect spotted her and started following her. He tried to befriend with her but the complainant did not respond him.

She has told the police that the suspect would at times follow her from her workplace to her house. The complainant had told about him to her family members, who had told her to ignore him.

She told the police that the suspect obstructed her way recently when she was going home after her work and threatened her — telling her to accept his proposal. He also warned her of dire consequences if she turned him down. Scared of his threats, she rushed to the police and lodged a complaint against him.

The police have registered a case under section 354 (Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty) and 504 (Intentional insult with intent to provoke breach of the peace) against him. He was produced before a local court and was remanded in magistrates’ custody.

Sunil Patil, inspector in-charge of the police station where the case has been registered, said, “We took immediate action case as there was a threat to the life of the complainant and it was important to act immediately. We have produced him before a local court on Wednesday and the court sent him to magistrate’s custody,” he said.

He added that the police were gathering evidence to build a strong case against the suspect, to ensure a conviction.

The Kolhapur police have taken several initiatives for the security of women and girl students. They have deployed special ‘Nirbhaya’ squads too tackle incidents of eve-teasing, stalking and harassment of women. The police have appealed to women and girls to come forward and register complaint if they are facing any such problems.

Deputy superintendent of police Prashant Amrutkar said, “Our Nirbhaya squad and the respective police stations will immediately take action on their complaints and address their issues. If this complainant had approached us one year back, when she noticed the suspect following and harassing her, we would have initiated action against him then itself.”

Title: Doctors’ shortage affects critical surgeries at CMCH
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The Coimbatore Medical College Hospital , the tertiary care hospital for the entire western region, says they have a 10% shortage of doctors and an immeasurable shortage of nurses. The hospital’s performance in critical surgeries like organ transplants has been affected by the absence of enough nephrologists and neurologists.

According to the hospital records, 35 posts of specialist doctors are vacant, while it is short of around 90% “required” nursing staff. A senior official with the health services department said, “As per the Mudaliar committee recommendations, we need 1,200 staff nurses. But we have only around 10% of that strength.”

Pointing out that CMCH has only two nephrologists and a urologist in the transplant team, the official said, “The hospital has been sanctioned two more nephrologists, but the case is in court,” A few doctors have got a stay order from the court against the postings.

CMCH dean Dr B Ashokan, however, said they hadn’t so far turned away patients, citing shortage of doctors. “We have only three doctors in the renal transplant team. But we haven’t ever turned away any kidney failure patient in the outpatient department or denied them a bed.”

The hospital has performed just 24 renal transplants so far. But it is often compared with the Madras Medical College, which first did a transplant in 1996. “They have 10 professors and 12 assistant professors, while we have just two. Even the government hospital in Salem has more specialist doctors than what we have,” said a senior doctor.

The CMCH has placed around 60 patients in the waiting list of Transplant Authority of Tamil Nadu . Of them, 30 are active.

The health official said if the vacancies were filled, the hospital would be able to perform more renal transplants. “A transplant, especially a cadaver transplant, can’t be performed during the current shift timing of 9am to 2pm. There is only one nephrology professor and an assistant professor. They can only take a certain workload, as patients’ lives are at risk. If staff are available, we can have an assistant professor level doctor round the clock,” he said.

Title: Kolkata’s five-star hotels log best figures in a decade
Content:
The average room rent (ARR) in Kolkata went up from Rs 5,100 in 2018 to Rs 5,200 in 2019 despite the addition ... Read More

KOLKATA: The city saw one of best figures in room occupancy in a decade in the five-star and five-star deluxe categories over the last three months. Thanks to conferences, weddings and an effect of Biswa Bangla Convention Centre, the average room tariff also went up significantly during these months.The average room rent (ARR) in Kolkata went up from Rs 5,100 in 2018 to Rs 5,200 in 2019 despite the addition of nearly 509 rooms in the super deluxe category with the opening of ITC Royal Bengal.Over 500 rooms were also added in the business class category in the vicinity of the airport, including New Town. There were at least 20 days in November, December and January when the rooms at star properties were sold out. Sudesh Poddar, secretary of Hotel & Restaurant Association of Eastern India, told TOI that the winter quarter — September to December, extending up to January — was great for Kolkata hoteliers. “The occupancy during this time was as high as 85%-88% compared to the annual average of 65% in the city. The average room rent went up to Rs 8,500- Rs 9,000. The annual average is Rs 6,500. Some days even saw 100% occupancy,” he said.Westin general manager Subhas Sinha pointed out that the average room tariff during the period rose by around Rs 1,000. “The idea of Biswa Bangla Convention Centre has worked. It is now attracting lot of conferences. The average attendance in such conferences is over 2,000. So star category hotels are getting good businesses,” he added. According to him, Kolkata has also developed as a wedding destination over the last few years because it’s cheaper and offers good infrastructure and facilities.A top executive of another star hotel in the city said most of the big industrial families hail from Kolkata. In the last couple of decades, their major events, including weddings, have been held at hotels. “Weddings are a big business in Kolkata and sustains the hospitality industry. ,” he added.Atul Bhalla, regional head of ITC hotels, felt that Kolkata experienced buoyancy throughout December. “ITC Royal Bengal and ITC Sonar registered a growth of at least 77% in occupancy and average room tariff of over Rs 10,000. In January, we had conferences and exhibitions when we had an inventory of 600 rooms and 1 lakhsqft of banquet space was fully blocked,” Bhalla explained.An Oberoi Grand spokesperson pointed out that in the last two months the city experienced multiple events that pushed the hospitality sector growth. “This led to an increase in our average occupancy of 85%. We also saw multiple 100% occupancy dates,” he said.

Title: Agricultural career new call, Telangana government to set up more colleges
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Rising demand for agriculture as a career option among students has driven the Telangana government to set up more agricultural colleges in the state in the new academic year. Beginning AY2020-21, the Professor Jayashankar Telangana State Agricultural University ( PJTSAU ) will start a new constituent college in Adilabad, which will admit 60 students in its first batch.The insitute will offer BSc in agriculture, taking the total number of BSc in agriculture seats in Telangana to roughly 500. This institute will be in addition to six constituent colleges existing at Rajendranagar, Aswaraopet, Jagtial, Warangal, Palem and Sircilla. Currently, the intake for bachelor of science (BSc) in agriculture is close to 432 in addition to 200 seats in diploma, masters and research.Apart from this, plans are afoot to establish agriculture colleges in other districts too. “Due to increase in irrigation potential in Telangana and pro-agrarian policies, more number of graduates are coming forward to pursue a career in agriculture. In view of this, there is certainly a need to set-up more number of colleges to accommodate the demand for agriculture courses,” state agriculture minister Niranjan Reddy told TOI and added that a proposal in this regard will be submitted to chief minister K Chandrasekhar Rao shortly. “If the CM approves, the colleges will be operational from academic year 2020-21 itself,” Reddy said.According to sources, a private agriculture university is also proposed near Siddipet. The state government has sent the proposal to the Indian Council of Agricultural Research, New Delhi for approval following which the university is expected to consider admissions in four year BSc (Hons) agriculture and BSc (Hons) horticulture courses.At present, close to 9,000 students travel to neighbouring states such as Maharashtra, Karnataka and Tamil Nadu every year to pursue undergraduate agriculture courses owing to insufficient number of seats in Telangana. “After pursuing BSc in agriculture, the plan is to apply in banks and government jobs. Since I could not secure a seat in Telangana, I moved to Raichur considering its proximity to Hyderabad,” said Nagaiah G, a student of University of Agricultural Sciences, Raichur.

Title: Kolar judge scores a ton in Pocso convictions
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Second additional district and sessions judge BS Rekha

KOLAR: A district and sessions judge in Kolar created a record of sorts on Wednesday, pronouncing her 100th verdict under provisions of Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (Pocso) Act in about two and a half years.

In the 100th conviction, second additional district and sessions judge BS Rekha , 50, awarded seven years’ rigorous imprisonment to Anand from Hanumanthapura village, Kolar taluk, for kidnapping and raping a minor girl on December 22. He was fined Rs 10,000.

Judge Rekha has been able to prevail upon advocates to stick to the schedule and carrying the cases to their logical conclusion, Muniswamy Gowda, special public prosecutor who appeared for the state in all 100 cases, told TOI.

Advocate V Sreedhararmuthy said the judge treats every case on merit and doesn’t allow hypothetical questions to be raised during the proceedings. “Her systematic style of working ensures there is no scope for delay,” he added.

Another advocate, C Kondappa, said the judge is very helpful in ensuring advocates make their presentations with precision.

Coming from a family of advocates based in Tumakuru, Judge Rekha decided to pursue a legal career and became a district judge after passing judicial services examinations. She said in most Pocso cases, the accused commit the crime under the influence of alcohol.

She had earlier made headlines when she sent five people to the gallows in two separate cases on one single day. She had awarded death penalty to Ranjith Kumar for attempting to rape and murdering a class 10 girl when she was returning home on August 1, 2019. The judge pronounced her verdict on September 15, 2019, with the framing of charges, remanding and court proceedings being completed in record 45 days, recalled Gowda. The same day, the judge had awarded death sentences to another four people accused of gang-raping a minor girl in Masthi police limits.

Title: Named Sasi benami, resort owner moves HC against tax department
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

CHENNAI: A resort owner accused of being a benami of V K Sasikala and aiding her benami transaction to the tune of Rs 148 crore in demonetised currency, has approached the Madras high court claiming it was a commercial transaction, that too cancelled as Sasikala’s option.

Naveen Baalaji, who was alleged to have sold a resort in Puducherry — Ocean Spray — to Sasikala, wanted the court to quash a provisional attachment order passed by the income tax department in connection with the cancelled transaction. Admitting his plea, Justice Anita Sumanth directed the tax department to file its reply by February 19.

According to Naveen, his family is into jewellery business in Puducherry. “In 2000, we ventured into foreign exchange and travel-related services and started Bonjour Bonheur Private Limited. In 2009, it ventured into hotel and hospitality business by promoting a resort — Ocean Spray,” the petitioner said. As the new ventures were failing, they decided to dispose the resort in 2016. As a prospective buyer, representatives of Sasikala approached him and offered Rs 168 crore for the property. Since demonetisation was announced, he was compelled by Sasikala to accept Rs 148 crore as advance in demonetised currency, he said.

When he was about to return unutilised Rs 37 crore of the advance to Sasikala, her representatives told him the transaction has been cancelled and demanded that he return the advance. It was at that point the tax department raided various places of Sasikala, including the petitioner and arrayed him as her benami. Even as he was contesting the actions of the department and sought permission to cross-examine Sasikala and others, the authorities on January 20 passed an order to provisionally attach the properties under Benami Act, he said.

Title: Goa: KTC fleet to get 50 electric buses, charging stations
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Pramod Sawant

PANAJI: To establish Goa as a “model for international standards for electric vehicles (EVs)”, chief minister Pramod Sawant has proposed to bring 50 electric buses in the state this year. These will be added to Kadamba Transport Corporation’s (KTC) existing fleet and will be introduced along with associated infrastructure such as charging stations at all KTC bus stands.

“Electric vehicles are widely gaining markets across the globe. The automotive industry is rapidly shifting from traditional fuel-based technology to eco-friendly technologies,” Sawant said in his budget speech on Thursday.

KTC is placing an order for the buses under the second phase of the FAME India (Faster Adoption and Manufacturing of Hybrid and Electric Vehicles in India) scheme, initiated by the ministry of heavy industry (MoHI) to assist states in purchasing EVs.

KTC had requested for 250 electric buses in July under the scheme and received a green signal for 50 e-buses.

The corporation was scheduled to open the financial bid for these buses by November 5 while the order letter for the procurement of 50 EVs was to be issued by November 15. This deadline was, however, postponed.

The crumbling bus stands at Mapusa and Quepem will soon receive a makeover, while proposed bus stands at Bicholim and Sakhali will see speedy completion, Sawant said.

To help water vessels navigate with ease, he also resolved to take up reconstruction of the lighthouse at Campal. Heavy erosion and salinity have affected the structure.

Title: Coronavirus Hyderabad: Chilkur Balaji temple prays for coronavirus to go away
Content:
Representative image

HYDERABAD: Devotees gathered at the Chilkur Balaji temple on Thursday and offered prayers with a hope to prevent the spread of the Novel Coronavirus (2019-nCov). Over 2,000 devotees took part in the recitals that lasted for over 45 minutes.“We have urged Lord Balaji to stop the spread of Coronavirus and prevent deaths. For this, we are chanting two shlokas — apamarjana stotram and sudarshana ashtakam,” said one of the priests.A special pooja was also performed in front of the inner sanctum. “These special prayers were held amid the fast-spreading Coronavirus outbreak which has taken a toll on the whole world,” said temple trustee, C S Rangarajan. He made an appeal to the other temples in Telangana and Andhra Pradesh to follow the same recital programme for the protection of all from the virus.The ‘aparjana stotram’ is a prayer, which calls on the various forms of Vishnu to use his Sudarshana Chakra to clean the body and mind from various ailments. After the rituals, divine water was sprinkled on the devotees.

Title: Pvt hospital issued warning over tests
Content: A prominent corporate hospital was issued a warning by authorities for collecting a sample of a 6-month-old and sending it to Gandhi Hospital for testing. This, despite instructions issued to all private and corporate hospitals to refrain from admitting any 2019-nCoV suspected cases or collecting samples. TNN

Title: Beige is the new white: Bengalureans prefer hue for floors, walls
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

A Hyderabad house designed by architect Suresh Kumar. He says beige marble makes the space look larger

BENGALURU: White marble that renders a Taj Mahal look to walls and its greyish variant that makes floors look elegant are passé in Bengaluru, with property owners increasingly embracing beige.

Stone industry experts confirm that beige is the new hue that Bengalureans want their buildings, especially swanky villas and high-end flats, to don. Beige embodies luxury and sophistication, said Manoj Kumar Singh, Federation of Indian Granite and Stone Industry vice-president, adding: “These shiny pieces of stone are mostly imported from Turkey and are in high demand in the southern part of the country, especially Bengaluru.”

Singh, who also runs a marble factory in the city, said they have been getting orders for beige marble not only from star hotels and malls but also villas and bungalows spread over 2,000 to 2,500 sqft. There are over 200 shades of beige marble. “Unlike Mumbai and Delhi where the trend is to combine beige with darker shades to create borders or a pattern, in Bengaluru, the demand is for plain beige,” Singh told TOI.

But why are Bengalureans going for beige? Architect Suresh Kumar of DSK Architects said: “When it comes to showcasing luxurious life, shades of beige dominate. Earlier, darker tones in marble and granite were in fashion. Lately, beige marble has gained popularity due to its high-gloss surface that signifies luxury. Beige marble creates a whole new ambience and along with warm lighting, it makes the space look larger and brighter.”

Though the realty market is currently slow, property buyers are not ready to sacrifice sophistication. “Beige has become synonymous with status enhancement,” said Kumar, who has been specialising in the luxury realty segment.

City-based interior designer Rafida Asmia, who claims to have designed 45 homes in two years, said around 25 opted for beige marble. “Earlier granite was in vogue, but now we don’t even suggest it unless the client insists. Increasing number of villas and independent houses are opting for beige marble as it’s aesthetically pleasing and affordable.” Some of her clients have insisted that even entrance walls be covered with Botticino marble (beige). “It doesn’t hit your eyes like extremely white or dark shades of marble do,” she added.

Suresh Hari, chairman, Confederation of Real Estate Developers Association of India (Credai), said: “Makrana marble (white) was in high demand years ago in the city. It’s not a common sight any more. The shift in trend is because people have realised that maintenance of white marble is a pain as compared to the beige variant.” However, procuring quality marble remains a challenge, he maintained.

“Biege marble is being imported from Turkey. It has become affordable too as the price has reduced from Rs 500 per sqft to Rs 250. A majority of middle-class home owners opt for cutter-sized slabs that are around 3ft, whereas the normal-sized ones are 6ft. Smaller-sized slabs means more joints, which doesn’t look as neat as bigger tiles. But even this slight adjustment is working for a lot of people,” Singh explained.

Title: Home guards at RTA unpaid for three months
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: After drawing flak for delay in dispatching smart cards to applicants of vehicle registration and driving license, the Regional Transport Authority (RTA) is now facing heat for non-payment of salaries to home guards working at RTA offices.

Each home guard is paid Rs 20,000 a month, and there are 100 employees in Hyderabad and Rangareddy districts.

“With no salary from past three months, most of us are now in debts,” said Ravikanth (name changed on request), a home guard working at Khairtabad RTA. “Every home guard has to be paid Rs 60,000 pending salary by the department. I request the officials to give us our salaries without any further delay.”

A home guard from Secunderabad RTA said, “I took a loan of Rs 50,000 to pay my house rent and other bills. I was threatened by my house owner twice in these three months to vacate the house for paying rent late. The entire loan has gone to pay the house rent, bills and school fee of my two children. Now, we hardly have any money left to even buy groceries.”

“Home guards had faced a similar problem last year in May when they were not paid their salaries for four months,” said M Dayanand, general secretary, Telangana Auto, and Motor Welfare Union. When contacted, joint transport commissioner (IT), C Ramesh said, “We have released the budget, but they did not receive it yet because there is a problem in salary payment process. Our officials are looking into it and the problem will be solved in a day or two. If it is not solved, I will take it up personally and see that it is sorted.”

Title: Namakkal village gets 110KV substation
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

NAMAKKAL: Electricity minister P Thangamani inaugurated 110-KV electrical substation at Yemapalli in Tiruchengode taluk here on Thursday. The substation was set up at a cost of Rs 10.28 crore. “The trail run will be initiated from today (Thursday),” the minister said.

Addressing the public, he said the farming community had repeatedly been demanding for an electrical substation in the area to curb low voltage issue. “That’s why we have set up the 110/22 kilo watt power substation at Yemapalli. After the trail run for a few weeks, chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami will dedicate the substation for public use,” Thangamani said. The minister also hoped that farmers in Yemapalli and Putlur would benefit from the move.

Until a few years ago, the Tamil Nadu Electricity Board (TNEB) used to set up only 60 substations in a year. “But our government has erected 480 substations in four years. Our aim is to make the state power surplus,” the minister said.

Thangamani said his department had set a target to set up 130 electrical substations in the state in the current financial year. “We have set up 119 substations so far.”

When asked about the compensation for farmers, who gave consent to erect electricity towers on their farmlands, the minister said steps were being taken to issue them compensation at the earliest. Collector C Megraj, Tiruchengode revenue divisional officer P Maniraj and TNEB officials participated in the event.

Title: Bengaluru: Didn’t know she had killed her mom, claims techie's boyfriend
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Sridhar Rao and Amruta (right) in police custody

BENGALURU: A 27-year-old man arrested along with his techie-girlfriend — accused of murdering her mother — in Port Blair, Andamans , has told police he was clueless about her deeds and was holidaying with her as planned.

The woman had also attempted to murder her brother at their Ramamurthynagar house on Sunday.

C Amruta, 33, meanwhile, is sticking to her version that she killed her 54-year-old mother and attempted to murder her brother as she had incurred a Rs 15 lakh debt and was worried about the taint it would leave her family with.

Her friend , Sridhar Rao, a Banaswadi resident, told police Amruta never told him about the murder she had committed before leaving with him for Port Blair on Sunday morning.

Amruta and Rao flew to Port Blair from Kempegowda International Airport around 6.30am. While she did not carry her mobile, he switched off his device soon after landing at 9.30am. “Rao says he did so since the connectivity was poor,” a police officer said.

“Rao’s claims are hard to believe. Why did he switch off his mobile soon after landing at Port Blair airport? He could have used the hotel WiFi but didn’t. They were trying to get a temporary sim card in Port Blair,” the officer added.

Rao and Amruta worked together in a private company in Whitefield between 2015 and 2017. A Bachelor of Business Management (BBM), Rao is currently pursuing MBA through correspondence, police said.

Rao also maintained that Amruta had told him they would stay in Andamans for a week. “We are in a relationship. In the third week of January, she told me we would fly to Port Blair and she would bear the expenditure,” police quoted Rao as having said.

On Sunday morning, Amruta allegedly hacked her mother C Nirmala to death using a digging bar around 4.30am. She later stabbed her brother C Harish in the neck. Harish collapsed and thinking he was dead, she left the house. CCTV evidence later revealed that Rao arrived on a scooter near Amruta’s residence and the two rode to KIA.

She would slip into depression

According to a close family member of Amruta, she had tried to kill herself when she was in college. “Amruta would slip into depression for many days. Since December, she had been working from home. She suffered from sleep disorders too. We may take her to a psychiatrist if needed,” a senior police officer said.

Title: Fake Lottery Case: 10 officers framed businessman in fake lottery case
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

File Photo of CBI office

BENGALURU: The Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) has given a clean chit to a small-time businessman who was called the kingpin of an alleged lottery scam and arrested in 2015.

In a chargesheet filed recently, the agency, which inquired into the case, has revealed that there was no lottery scam and 10 police officers conspired to falsely implicate the businessman, Parirajan. The officers, it alleges, planted bogus evidence during a raid at Parirajan’s residence in BEML Nagar in KGF.

The chargesheet was submitted to the XVII additional chief metropolitan magistrate court, and the CBI has sought sanction from the state government to prosecute the officers.

Parirajan, known as Rajan to friends, had a brief moment in the limelight in 2015 after he claimed in a sting conducted by a Kannada TV channel that he ran a lottery business and had connections with some IPS officers. On May 1, 2015, officers from the KGF excise enforcement and lottery prohibition wing raided his house.

The team later said it had seized computer-printed lottery tickets with different names, chequebooks and result sheets.

The CBI chargesheet now states that the raid was staged with “mala fide intention” and material seized from Parirajan’s house was planted there. As part of its evidence, the CBI has submitted the analysis of a hard disk seized from the police team behind the raid. The analysis, conducted at the Central Forensic Science Laboratory in Delhi, showed that the result sheets that the police team cited as evidence against Parirajan were actually printed at the police station a few hours before the raid. Sub-inspector Raviprakash took the printouts, according to the chargesheets.

After Parirajan was arrested, IPS officer Alok Kumar’s name was linked to the scam and he was suspended. The suspension was later lifted.

“I stand vindicated. My name was unnecessarily dragged into the case. The CBI has informed the state government that I had no role in the matter,” Kumar, who is now the additional director general of police, told TOI.

Title: Two Chinese nationals among new suspects admitted to Gandhi Hospital
Content: Two of the 18 people who were put in isolation wards, on Thursday, are Chinese nationals , said Gandhi Hospital sources. The two IT professionals who have been working in the city for many years, had visited China recently. The returned to Hyderabad only 20 days ago. “They displayed some symptoms — of high fever and cough — and have been quarantined. Their swab samples have been collected and sent to the National Institute of Virology, Pune and we hope to get the results by Friday,” the source said. The techies who work in an office in Hi-Tec City, have been living in Banjara Hills. TNN

Title: Telangana: Government jobs fuelling interest in agriculture
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: Large number of government jobs available at district and mandal level as agriculture field officers has fuelled interest among students to pursue degrees in agriculture and horticulture . In the last four years, Telangana government appointed 2,100 agriculture extension offers in addition to filling up 2,000 posts for Mission Bhagiratha and Mission Kakatiya.

“Agriculture graduates secure employment opportunities in nationalised banks as field officers, in seed and fertilizer companies apart from government jobs. There is also massive requirement in agricultural research,” said Sudheer Kumar, registrar at Professor Jayashankar Telangana State Agricultural University ( PJTSAU ).

With large number of Agri-tech and agriculture startups mushrooming, there is also potential in working with various companies that are revolutionizing agriculture sector. Apart from this, there is also huge demand in dairy science, horticulture, agro-forestry, agriculture marketing and cooperation etc.

Title: Identify all potholes, fill them by March 31: Karnataka HC to BBMP
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

A bus plies thorough a dilapidated road in Bengaluru (File Photo)

BENGALURU: The high court on Thursday directed Bruhat Bengaluru Mahanagara Palike ( BBMP ) to undertake a fresh survey of all roads in Bengaluru to identify potholes and take necessary steps to fill them. The civic agency has to complete the exercise by March 31 .

A division bench headed by chief justice Abhay Shreeniwas Oka also directed the Palike to appoint the civil engineering department of Indian Institute of Science (IISc) to conduct audit of pothole-filling work undertaken on 74 roads, which the civic body claims are crater-free.

BBMP has been directed to ensure all ongoing works, including TenderSURE project and those undertaken by other entities like Bangalore Water Supply and Sewerage Board, Bangalore Electricity Supply Company and Gas Authority of India Limited, are completed as per schedule.

Regarding availability of compensation in pothole-related accidents as well as grievance redressal mechanisms available to citizens of Bengaluru, the court directed BBMP to give wide publicity to the matter. Referring to BBMP’s claim that newspaper advertisements could be costly, the bench said the agency can choose other modes.

Notices to mayor, his deputy

In a related development, the court directed the registrar general to issue notices to mayor Goutham Kumar Jain, deputy mayor CR Ram Mohan Raju and five others.

The court has sought their response by March 16 regarding the assertion made by BBMP commissioner BH Anil Kumar in his affidavit filed on November 27 last year. The Palike chief had stated he’d held a meeting with these people in connection with July 31 and September 9 orders of the court saying BBMP is bound to compensate victims of pothole-induced accidents and has to publicise the same.

However, in another affidavit filed on February 4, he said he only held consultations with the mayor and others and there was no meeting. Use of the term ‘meeting’ in his November 27 affidavit was inadvertent and unintentional, he said.

Notices have also been issued to KA Muneendra Kumar, leader of ruling party in BBMP; Abul Wajid, leader of opposition; Lavanya Ganesh Reddy, chairperson of the standing committee for major public works; SP Hemalatha, chairperson of taxation and finance committee, and Mujahid Pasha, chairman of standing committee for public health.

The court is hearing a PIL filed by Vijayan Menon and others seeking a series of directions, including one to BBMP to place a report on action taken to repair killer potholes. The next hearing is fixed for April 1.

Title: 76 per cent Hyderabadis on protein-deficient diet, reveals study
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Losing Muscle

HYDERABAD: Whether Hyderabad has the best Biryani or not is something that may be open to debate, but a study has revealed a startling fact — Hyderabadis seem to be fussy about having their daily glass of milk and consuming other dairy products and end up consuming a protein-deficient diet .

As per a study conducted by Neilsen for Mumbai-based dairy FMCG player Parag Milk Foods Ltd (PMFL), 76% of Hyderabadis lacked protein in their daily diet and were even unaware of its adverse lifestyle effects such as poor concentration, muscle loss, constant hunger, Anaemia, low immunity, hair loss, skin peel, ridges in nails and Polycystic Ovarian Disease (PCOD), among others.

As per the findings of the study, 79% of Hyderabadis suffered constant tiredness, 73% often fell sick and 99% of them reported irregular eating habits due to a protein deficient diet . The number of people consuming a protein deficient diet was much lower in other cities like Mumbai, where it stood at 47%, followed by Kolkata (63%) and Delhi (64%).

The all-India figures suggest that 63% consume insufficient protein in their diet and 7% are borderline protein deficient, it added. Similarly, due to lack of adequate protein in diet, 59% of Indians suffered constant tiredness, 60% complained of poor concentration, 47% suffered from muscle loss, 63% were facing hair loss and 92% suffered constant tiredness, the study revealed.

Commenting on the findings of the study, Devendra Shah, chairman, Parag Milk Foods Ltd said: “Given the changing fast-paced lifestyle, Indian consumers are adapting to a healthier and balanced diet, yet 80% of vegetarians are protein deficient. This is a wake-up call for us to take action and ensure an adequate in-take of protein on a daily basis.”

Title: Ex-IAS: Why is permission required for indoor meets?
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

HYDERABAD: Former special chief secretary of the state Mohammad Shafiquzzaman on Thursday approached the Telangana high court and filed a public interest litigation (PIL) questioning the police for its alleged insistence on applying for permission even for indoor congregations. The plea also questioned the police’s last-minute denials for public meetings.

“Even in cases where they accord permissions, they are doing so after changing the venue and imposing restrictions on the number of people to be assembled,” the former official said. He filed this plea along with another petitioner Syed Ghouse Mohiuddin Quadri. “The right to public meeting or procession flows from the right to assemble which is often exercised to express protest against the government or any social injustices,” they said in their plea, adding: “ Freedom of assembly promotes public discourse and diversity and acts as a tool to achieve changes in the society.”

They contended that neither the Indian Police Act nor the Hyderabad Police Act envisage that organisers apply for permission. Referring to reports, the petitioners complained that the police had thwarted attempts made by organisers for an indoor meeting with former Jawaharlal Nehru University student union president, Kanhaiya Kumar. The petitioners alleged that while the police denied permission for the meet, they had also threatened the owner of the venue.

“In fact, there is no mandatory requirement to seek police permission to hold such indoor meets...This is nothing but interfering with fundamental rights of the people guaranteed by the Constitution,” the petitioners said and sought a direction to the police to not insist on permissions for holding indoor meets.

Title: Complaint lodged against forest min
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Madurai: Members from the Dravidar Viduthalai Kazhagam have lodged a complaint against Forest Minister Dindigul C Seenivasan with the Melur police station urging the station inspector to register a case in connection with the incident that took place in the Nilgiris, where he asked a boy to unbuckle his footwear.

A video of the forest minister, who visited a temple in the Nilgiris district, asking a boy to unbuckle his footwear was telecasted on news channels on Thursday.

In the petition addressed to the station inspector, district secretary of the organization Mani Amudhan stated that the forest minister should be booked under sections of the Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribe Prevention of Atrocities Act for asking the boy, who belongs to a tribal community, to unbuckle his footwear.

“The minister knew that he was tribal boy and asked him to do the job for him with casteist mindset. Along with the minister, officials and police personnel, who were present at the spot should also be booked under the same sections, he said.

Title: Shops selling banned tobacco fined
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

DINDIGUL: The district food safety department on Wednesday fined four shops in Nilakottai selling banned tobacco products targeting school students. In total, 12kg of banned tobacco worth Rs 12,000 was seized. The shopkeepers were fined Rs 5,000 each.

Officials said the search was conducted in the shops at Pallapatti and nearby areas near Nilakottai. Of the 32 shops searched, four shops were found to be selling banned tobacco items. A range of products were unearthed.

The search was carried out by the team led by designed officer for food safety, Dindigul district, K Natarajan. The designated officer said that the search was carried out based on information that shops in the particular area thrive by selling banned tobacco items to children.

Title: Coimbatore: Dead fish in stream raises concerns among residents
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The stream comes from Vellalore check dam and flows to Singanallur tank after reaching the check dam in Nanjun... Read More

COIMBATORE: Several dead fish were found floating in a stream near the check dam at Nanjundapuram in the city on Thursday. Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB) officials have collected water samples from the spot for analysis to identify the cause of fish death.

The stream comes from Vellalore check dam and flows to Singanallur tank after reaching the check dam in Nanjundapram.

Residents in the area said they had in the past three days seen fish rising to the stream surface for breathing. V Shanthamani, a local resident, said, “Even three days ago, some fish had died. But on Thursday, the number increased. There must be around thousand dead fish. The stench is unbearable. We are unable to eat or carry out daily chores.”

Environmental activists said the problem started at Selvapuram. “There are bleaching units in Selvapuram. They bleach old clothes. Bleaching effluents from the units can be found at Puttuvikki Bridge across the stream. There are also effluents from other units. Domestic sewage also gets mixed in the stream. This might have caused their (fish) death,” said R Manikandan, a member of Kovai Kulangal Padhukappu Amaippu. “Another reason might be lack of oxygen.”

Pollution control officials have conducted preliminary inspection of the water. “The total dissolved solvents level in the water is around 1,000. This is not too high to cause their death. We guess it might have been caused due to oxygen depletion resulting from dense water hyacinth in the stream. We have collected water samples. Only after analysis we can say for sure,” said P Manimaran, district environmental engineer (south), TNPCB.

Environmentalist Manikandan said the level of total dissolved solvents at Chithirai Chavadai, the origin of Noyyal river , was 160 and that the same increased with the river’s course. “At Perur, it’s 250, at Vellalore it’s 1,000 and at Nanjundapuram it’s around 1,160,” he said.

Singanallur MLA N Karthik visited the stream on Thursday. He said he had taken up the issue with city corporation officials for immediate action. “I had submitted more than 50 petitions to the civic body to desilt and preserve waterways such as Sanganur Odai and Raja Vaikkal. But the civic body is yet to take any action. Fishes have died because of their negligence,” he said.

Title: 108 ambulance workers’ association to stage protest
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: The Tamil Nadu 108 ambulance employees’ welfare association on Thursday passed a resolution to protest against transfer of employees to Kerala. In a press meet held in Madurai , the members of the association said the state government has been continuously ignoring their various demands, including transfer of employees to Kerala citing shortage of staff.

“On January 5, across Tamil Nadu, our association submitted petitions to district collectors and later directly to state authorities, with various demands, which included demand for new ambulances to be sanctioned to replace damaged old ones and sudden transfer of employees to Kerala, without informing the association,” said M Irulandi, the association’s state president. However, repeated pleas have since been ignored regarding transfer of the employees.

“When we spoke to media, 15 employees were again transferred. Later, when we threatened to not serve during jallikattu this year, the government temporarily suspended transfers. On January 23, talks were also held but there was no definitive action. We realized that the authorities were just letting us drag till our contract term expired at the end of last month,” explained Irulandi. The association is however still yet to decide on the date of protest and whether it will be across Tamil Nadu or just outside the state secretariat.

The association also passed various other resolutions at their meeting held on Thursday, including sanctioning of funds of Rs 53,700 each for the families of two ambulance drivers, who were killed in accidents last year.

Title: Coronavirus in Madurai: Public places in Madurai vulnerable
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Health department officials have not issued specific instructions to the sanitary staff of the railway station... Read More

MADURAI: Mass transit public places in Madurai like the railway station and MGR bus stand continue to remain vulnerable to the spread of infections despite efforts taken to keep the places clean.

However, health department officials have not issued specific instructions to the sanitary staff of the railway station and the bus stand to pay extra attention to cleanliness with respect to nCoV.

“We work several shifts on a rotational basis and keep the station clean and tidy, including platforms and toilets. We have also been provided with protective gear like masks and gloves,” said a sanitary worker.

However, with commuters openly spitting and littering and drinking water taps and basins used for washing as well, it becomes vulnerable for the spread of infectious germs. Toilets and wash basins also lack soaps or hand sanitisers.

Sources at the railway junction said so far no official instruction has been given to intensify cleanliness measures with regard to nCoV. “If an order is issued, we will comply. We have adequate water supply,” said a source.

Meanwhile, at the MGR Bus Stand at Mattuthavani, which witnesses thousands of commuters every day, hygiene is a concern as workers try to keep the surroundings clean round-the-clock. Many spots have garbage piling up despite the presence of dustbins or have water leaking and stagnating from wash basins or drinking water taps.

“We are continuously putting in efforts to maintain cleanliness in the bus stand. Ultimately, when it comes to the spread of infections like nCoV, it is more about an individual’s personal hygiene,” said a city corporation health official.

Title: Joka Metro: Stretch till Taratala may open first
Content:
Metro Railway’s general manager Manoj Joshi inspects the Joka-BBD Bag stretch on Thursday

KOLKATA: With the possibility of completion of the Majerhat station in the Joka-BBD Bagh stretch looking bleak till construction of the Road Over Bridge (ROB) next to it is completed, Metro Railway is concentrating on work till Taratala. If all goes well, the stretch from Joka to Taratala will be thrown open in Phase-I.On Thursday, Metro Railway general manager Manoj Joshi inspected work along the stretch and held detailed discussions with officials of Rail Vikas Nigam Ltd ( RVNL ), the agency implementing the project.“The GM started his inspection from the depot at Joka where land issues have to be sorted out. He then visited the stretch between Majerhat and Mominpore where land will have to be acquired to complete the project. He was also told how there are certain encroachments between Behala Chowrasta and Behala Bazaar that are holding up construction. All these issues will be taken up with appropriate agencies for speedier resolution. The GM expressed satisfaction with the RVNL’s efforts to complete work in the stretches where there are no problem,” said Metro Railway CPRO Indrani Banerjee.The Joka-BBD Bagh stretch has not been able to make as much progress as other ongoing Metro projects in Kolkata. This is primarily due to the problems faced in in acquiring land. Work at the Joka depot is yet to start as only about 85% of the land is in RVNL’s possession at the moment. There has been no transfer of land for the last seven-eight months, an official said.Unless this matter is resolved and work can start at the depot, no tentative date of completion can be fixed even for the stretch up to Taratala. Metro and RVNL officials also plan to sit with the state government on the issue of the embargo imposed on construction work at Majerhat.

Title: AICTE fixes 1:15 faculty-student ratio for deemed universities, autonomous colleges
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The All India Council for Technical Education ( AICTE ) has fixed 1:15 faculty-student ratio for deemed universities, autonomous colleges and accredited engineering colleges . The approval handbook for 2020-21 was released on Wednesday.The latest move of the AICTE, which in 2018-19 diluted the 1:15 faculty-students ratio to 1:20, resulting in more than 22,000 faculty members losing their jobs in Tamil Nadu alone, is expected to increase the demand in TN. Many teachers from the state are now employed in states such as Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka, say sources. “Deemed universities and autonomous colleges are not the same as other institutions. They were given special status for providing quality education. So, they need to ensure 1:15 faculty-students ratio,” a senior AICTE official said.However, the decision to relax the faculty-student ratio for PG courses from 1:12 to 1:15 may not affect many, say faculty members, pointing out that PG admissions have come down and many faculty members have been given pink slips.The AICTE also said technical institutions should have 60% of their courses to be accredited in the next three years and asked the expert committee to ensure faculty availability by the annual salary paid statements in addition to their physical presence. Institutions should not demand original degree certificates from faculty members at the time of joining the institution, it said, adding that doing so would attract punishment including ban on admission for one year and withdrawal of approval. This follows the suicide of T Vasanthavanam on November 12, 2018, after he was denied the original certificate from a city college where he worked.K M Karthik, founder of All India Private Colleges Employees Union, said the new faculty-students ratio would bring down unemployment.A few autonomous colleges said it would be difficult to recruit 25% additional faculty before the March 5 deadline. “We may have to recruit more than 50 faculty members. It is difficult to recruit more members before first week of March. We need more time,” said B Chidambararajan, principal of Valliammai Engineering College, Chennai. “The regulation does not specify whether the 1:15 ratio will apply from 2020-21.”

Title: Unassessed apartments: Kolkata Municipal Corporation’s ‘hidden treasure’
Content:
Kolkata Municipal Corporation

Times View Unassessed property is a waste of valuable revenue that can be used to add to and maintain the city’s existing infrastructure. The KMC is correct in pursuing this. But it should ensure that penalties are levied only on property owners who have wilfully defrauded the KMC exchequer; no one should be penalised for systemic problems.

KOLKATA: In a startling revelation, the Kolkata Municipal Corporation (KMC) assessment department has found that the civic body could make a fortune by bringing 40,000 flats, which have so far remained unassessed, under the ambit of its property tax assessment .Of these unassessed flats, 35,000 belong to the high-rise category and 30,000 are located in areas off EM Bypass. The rest lie scattered in Behala, Tollygunge and Jadavpur areas. “If properly monetized, the newly found ‘gold mine’ can yield Rs 200 crore-Rs 250 crore revenue every year,” said a senior KMC revenue department official.KMC assessment department sources said officials stumbled upon the ‘hidden treasure’ when they began a hunt for revenue launched a year ago. An official said the civic body’s revenue department inspectors and officials conducted surveys of unassessed properties , especially in added areas like Behala, Tollygunge, Jadavpur and EM Bypass.The official was surprised at how the growth of the high-rises off EM Bypass and in Behala had gone unnoticed. “A casual walk in five-six wards will tell you how these localities are changing. Similarly, some areas in Behala, Joka, Tollygunge and Jadavpur have registered a steady growth of high-rises,” he said.Sensing a huge potential of revenue, the KMC has chalked out a plan to fill up the civic coffers. “We have formed a team that will meet the owners of the unassessed flats. If needed, we shall send our inspectors with the requisite papers so that a flat owner does not have to face difficulties at our offices,” another official said.However, monetizing the unassessed properties won’t be easy as a section of flat owners are not willing to get their properties assessed. “Some flat owners are yet to respond to our appeal. We shall assess their properties and issue suo motu bills to them,” he said.

Title: JICA consultants conduct survey at AIIMS site in Thoppur
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

MADURAI: About 10 representatives from the Japan International Cooperation Agency (JICA) visited the site for the proposed All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS) in Thoppur on Thursday to conduct survey.

“Once the land for AIIMS was sanctioned, a preliminary project report was prepared by HLL, a government of India healthcare enterprise. Four teams from JICA will now be conducting surveys at the site for one month and submit a report,” T Sabeetha, deputy director of medical education, who accompanied the team from JICA, told TOI. She added that around 40% of the work for the compound wall has been completed.

“Once the JICA team completes the report, a plan will be prepared and discussions will be held in Tokyo in March. By April, they are expected to submit the plan to the Indian government. Later, as per administrative procedure, the government and JICA would reach an understanding,” she added.

The deputy director further said that it was still too early to say when the construction of the medical college and hospital would begin. The more than Rs 1,200 crore-worth AIIMS project in Madurai was first proposed in 2018.

Earlier this week, senior doctors at the Government Rajaji Hospital (GRH), JICA representatives and the deputy director held a consultation meeting regarding the Rs 330 crore JICA project at the hospital. “We held meetings with senior doctors of various departments for the proposed seven-storey JICA facility. We prioritised the necessary funding for the required equipment and prepared a preliminary report,” said Sabeetha.

The project boasts of introducing state-of-the-art advanced operation theatres, post-operative care and intensive care units. In December 2019, a JICA consultant had also visited GRH to discuss the skill development and technological needs of the doctors for the project. “The demolition and construction for the ongoing project at GRH is likely to start by June,” she said.

Title: Fire breaks out at government school in Tuticorin
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

MADURAI: A fire broke out in the campus of a government primary school near Kovilpatti in Tuticorin district on Wednesday evening, destroying books and supplies. However, the school students remained unhurt.

The fire broke out at the library room in Kayathar government primary school in Asoor. Residents noticed smoke coming from the school and immediately informed the school authorities. Upon opening and inspecting the school, it was found that a fire was spreading inside the library room. With the help from residents, the fire was soon extinguished. Around 50 students study in Classes I to V at the primary school, taught by a teacher and a headmaster. The Kayathar police have registered a case. Since there was no electric wiring that could have caused a fire, the police suspect that miscreants might have caused the fire.

Title: CPCB puts Tamil Nadu thermal unit on notice
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The central agency has written to Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB), asking why it has failed to ... Read More CHENNAI: Following Union finance minister Nirmala Sitharaman’s announcement in the budget that highly polluting thermal power plants would be phased out, the Central Pollution Control Board ( CPCB ) has tightened the noose around Unit 1 of North Chennai Thermal Plant II, with a capacity of 600MW. The central agency has written to Tamil Nadu Pollution Control Board (TNPCB), asking why it has failed to prevent pollution from the particular unit. The show-cause notice has given 15 days to the power plant to respond. The central board has pointed out that the unit is emitting sulphur at levels much higher than permissible limits. Units 1 and 2 at North Chennai, each with a capacity of 600MW, were commissioned in 2014. Notice, however, has been issued only to Unit 1. The CPCB has threatened to close the unit if action is not taken within a stipulated time. “Unit 1 of North Chennai Thermal Power Station-II had submitted that feasibility study for installation of flue gas desulphurization for compliance of SO2 emission limit has been completed,” said CPCB chairman S P S Parihar. But the station has failed to comply with the directions issued under Section 5 of the Environment (Protection) Act in December 2017 for compliance of emission limit of SO2 and impacting ambient air quality in and around the thermal power plant, the chairman said. “In exercise of power vested under Section 5 of the Act, North Chennai station is hereby directed to show cause as to why Unit 1 of the plant should not be closed, and environmental compensation be imposed for the continuing non-compliance of the directions,” the chairman warned. In the coming days, the power demand is likely to increase due to change in weather and if the Unit 1 is closed, there will be a loss of 600MW and the discom will have to look at purchasing power from private companies or the market. “We are looking at the notice and will act as early as possible. The notice has been issued to TNPCB and once we get an official notice, we will respond,” said a senior Tangedco official.

Title: Ex-AIADMK minister R S Raja Kannappan to rejoin DMK
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

MADURAI: Former AIADMK minister R S Raja Kannappan , known for switching his loyalties between the AIADMK and DMK is moving over to the DMK again when party president M K Stalin visits the city on February 23.

Kannappan, who participated in the anti-CAA signature campaign conducted by the DMK in the city in the presence of Madurai north district secretary P Moorthy, told reporters that he was going to join the party under the leadership of the next chief minister and Tamil Nadu’s promising star Stalin. “It would be a gala event with about two lakh people gathering there and me and my supporters would be joining the DMK,” he said.

Kannappan said that it was important that the next rule in the state was one of integrity and that would be for the people of Tamil Nadu. There may be many Dravidian parties but Stalin is the only person who is conducting the party in the real Dravidian path and fit to be a a leader of these parties.

“AIADMK is there but there is no leadership, and they are just giving up the rights of Tamil Nadu by trying to please the central government, be it the CAA or the hydrocarbon issues. They do not have the power to oppose these anti-peoples projects. This has become a rule of commissions and corruptions, and they just want to be in power as long as they can. Hence, I am moving over to the better party which is working for the people of Tamil Nadu,” he said.

Kannappan was a member of the AIADMK founded by MGR in 1972. He then floated his own party Makkal Tamil Desam in 2000. He dissolved the party and joined the DMK in 2006, quit it and joined the AIADMK in 2009.

Content: Drug link in SSR case: My son wrongly framed, there are bigger names involved, says father of the accused

Title: Five micro composting units inaugurated in Madurai
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The corporation is constructing 41 micro composting units in the city at a cost of Rs 33.50 crore to manage we... Read More

MADURAI: State minister for co-operatives Sellur K Raju on Thursday inaugurated five micro composting units, constructed by the Madurai Corporation under Swachh Bharat scheme and Smart City Mission .

The corporation is constructing 41 micro composting units in the city at a cost of Rs 33.50 crore to manage wet waste collected from houses. Twenty-five have been taken up for construction work in the first phase. With the inauguration of five more MCCs a total of eight have been brought to use so far. Thathaneri, Menendal and Thirupparankundram have been functioning already.

Two MCCs in Kochadai , one in Sekkilar Street in Ward 5, one in II Salai in ward number 71 and one at Anupanadi were inaugurated by the minister on Thursday in the presence of various officials including corporation commissioner S Visakan. Earlier in the day, the minister inaugurated road works at cost of Rs 40 lakh at various places including Pykara, Thiruvalluvar Nagar 9, 10 and 11 streets, Devi Karumariamman Kovil first and second main roads. They have been taken up under the Tamil Nadu Urban Road Infrastructure Fund (TURIF) for 2019-20. A total of Rs 25.56 crore was allotted last year for road laying works. Various roads have been developed under the fund so far, officials said.

Title: Draft industrial policy targets Rs 3.5 lakh cr investment by 2024
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Vijayawada: The draft Industrial Development & Export Promotion Policy 2020-25 of the Andhra Pradesh government has targeted an investment of Rs 3.5 lakh crore in the state by the year 2024, even as it has projected that a total of 6 lakh jobs will be created during this time.

The last industrial policy, 2015-20, is due to lapse later this year. The draft of the new policy hopes to increase the contribution of manufacturing to GSDP (gross state domestic product) from 9.95% (2013-14) to 11.8% in 2019 to 16.6% in 2024. It aims to increase the contribution of industries to GSDP from 20.7% (2013-14) to 26.0% in 2019 to 27% in 2024. It claims to have grounded new projects worth Rs 2,20,024 crore by January 2020.

Andhra Pradesh expects to achieve the ambitious targets by strengthening DICs, district-sector studies, skill development as per industry needs, market access for MSMEs, provision of office space for prospective investors and the empanelment of trained professionals. The draft policy also proposes to offer, under fiscal sops, stamp duty/land conversion, non-claimable SGST, investment subsidy, and incentives for new technology, apart from 25% more incentives for special category enterprises.

The draft policy says it aims to create a competitive ecosystem for new industries and start-ups. The ecosystem would include a unique ID for each business, 100% of stamp duty and transfer duty, 100% of non-claimable SGST on construction of factory buildings in five years through equal instalments, and the front-ending of power supply at Rs 1 per unit for five years for new units or the expansion of existing units of all scales.

For new enterprises in the MSME sector 1.25% of land conversion charges—up to Rs 10 lakh—2.25% land cost rebate at industrial parks of up to Rs 10 lakh, interest subsidy of 9% term loan for five years, 15% investment subsidy on FCI (excluding cost of land) of up to Rs 20 lakhs for MSMEs.

The policy said that AP would be targeting investments in the agritech, agro-based and food processing industries, pharmaceuticals and chemicals electronics, aerospace and defence, textiles and apparel and auto and auto components. According to the draft policy, AP would be focusing on the export of marine products, processed food, spices, horticulture and agriculture produce, engineering goods, mineral & mined products, pharmaceuticals, textiles and garments.

The policy aims to promote a cluster-based approach for industrial investment. The clusters would be developed at Santabommali in Srikakulam district (1,272 acres) Atchutapuram (Expansion) DTA– (1,231 acres), Atchutapuram (de-notified area) (514 acres), and Dubacherla in West Godavari (543 acres) in north coast AP.

Clusters in the Rayalaseema region would include Kopparthy in Kadapa district (5,404 acres), Yerraguntla in Kadapa district (637 acres), Kurnool mega industrial hub (6,525 acres), Timmasamudram in Anantapur district (1,023 acres), Kosalanagaram in Chittoor district (1,500 acres), and Thatiguntapalle in Chittoor district (860 acres). Clusters in southern AP would include Thotapalli in Krishna district (460 acres), DMIH in Prakasam district (2,352 acres) and NIMZ in Prakasam district (1,783 acres)

The clusters would be developed by the AP Industrial Corridor Development Authority (APICDA). While the developer would bring in funds as equity, the government would provide land as equity, encumbrance free land, apart from wide approach roads to the national highway network, water and power supply and land conversion by the government.

Title: ‘CAA not against Indian Muslims’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Coimbatore: The Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019 (CAA) is not against the Indian Muslims and those who are opposing it, like DMK’s M K Stalin, are fighting for the citizenship of Muslims from neighbouring countries such as Pakistan, Bangladesh and Myanmar, BJP national general secretary Muralidhar Rao said here on Thursday.

BJP does not accept Stalin speaking out for the citizenship of Muslims from neighbouring countries, Rao, who was in the city to participate in the birth anniversary event of farmer leader Narayanasamy, told reporters. “We welcome actor Rajinikanth’s support for CAA. We will conduct campaigns in villages to popularise the government’s policies such as CAA, Kashmir and Ram temple.”

BJP is not discriminating between languages and sees both Tamil and Sanskrit equals, Rao said. “The relationship between BJP and AIADMK is good. Tamil Nadu BJP president will be announced after the Delhi election,” he said.

Economic slowdown had occurred several times before and now the Centre is taking steps to revive the economy, he said. tnn

Title: Barc develops technology to treat dry sewage
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: MoS for personnel, public grievances and pensions and PMO, Jitendra Singh said that Bhabha Atomic Research Centre (BARC) has developed a radiation technology to treat municipal sewage .

Replying to a question raised by YSRC MP Vijayasai Reddy in the Rajya Sabha on Thursday, the minister said the radiation technology utilises high energy gamma radiation from Co-60 gamma sources to treat dry sewage sludge.

As a result all pathogenic microorganism in the sludge is brought to a level that they can’t multiply further and the treated sludge is safe for human handling, he said. Department of atomic energy has set up a technology demonstration plant ‘Sewage Sludge Hygienisation Plant’ of 100 tonne per day capacity at Shahwadi in Ahmedabad. He further added that hygienised and enriched sludge from the plant is a rich source of micronutrients and organic carbon and can be used as organic manure for horticulture and agricultural. After commissioning the plant at Ahmedabad, Indore Municipal Corporation has come forward to adopt the technology and civil works have begun. tnn

Title: Coronavirus in Delhi: 2,782 from Delhi who visited China after January 15 identified
Content:
Medical staffs scan the body temperature of passengers at Delhi Airport (ANI Photo)

NEW DELHI: As many as 2,782 people from Delhi travelled to China on or after January 15 when the outbreak caused by the coronavirus was at its peak.The immigration department has sent a list of all such people, in addition to around 70 tourists visiting Delhi from countries affected by the deadly virus, to the Delhi health department to trace them. Central Delhi has a maximum of 2071 such people, followed by south-east (280), east (169), north-west (118), south (64) and south-west (21).As on Thursday, a government source told TOI, 144 people have been traced and efforts are on to find the rest in the next two days. “None of those traced has any symptom. But, as a precautionary measure, we have isolated them at their homes. Our team will be in touch with the families and flag any deterioration in health that may signal coronavirus infection ,” said the officer leading the drive.Virologists say the coronavirus is like SARS and MERS — two other viral infections that had caused outbreaks in the past. “A strict screening of people coming from affected areas is the only way to control its spread. If the infection spreads in India, it may not be easy to tackle as coronavirus is a respiratory infection,” said a senior virologist at AIIMS.India has so far reported only three cases, all in Kerala. As per the latest medical update, they are stable. The Centre on Thursday confirmed all 645 people, evacuated from China’s Wuhan and lodged at the quarantine facilities in and around Delhi, had tested negative. According to the Union health ministry, their samples will be re-tested on the 14th day of the quarantine period.Sanjeev Khirwar, health and family welfare secretary in Delhi government, said, “All available manpower starting from the district magistrates and district surveillance officers to ASHA workers and auxiliary nursing midwives have been trained and tasked to trace these people.” A 24x7 helpline at the district level, in addition to a centralised one, has also been started.One of the issues being faced by many states is the shortage of personal protective equipment such as N95 masks. Delhi has five lakh masks and 5,000 masks each have been provided to the 11 district medical officers for distribution among health workers, said Khirwar.According to the World Health Organization, people should frequently wash hands and avoid close contact with anyone having fever and cough. They should also seek immediate medical care in case of fever, cough and breathing difficulties and share their travel histories.

Title: M K Stalin: DMK President M K Stalin seeks committee to study dropouts
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

DMK president M K Stalin

CHENNAI: Expressing shock over the 100% increase in school dropout rates in three years in Tamil Nadu, DMK president M K Stalin on Thursday demanded setting up of a committee consisting of senior educationists to study reasons for increase in dropouts.

“The committee should analyse the reasons for dropouts at secondary level, including whether job cuts of their parents, are forcing them out of schools,” Stalin said in a statement. TOI had on Thursday reported that school dropouts in Tamil Nadu have increased from 8% in 2015-16 to 16.2% in 2017-18 quoting a reply by Union HRD minister Ramesh Pokhriyal in Parliament.

“The state government was giving wrong information about dropouts all along in the assembly. The policy note of school education department has given wrong information about dropouts saying 3.75% in 2015-16, 3.75% in 2016-17, 3.61% in 2017-18 alone dropped out from schools,” he said.

He further said the dropouts up to Class VIII have been brought down due to the no-detention policy in RTE Act.

“But, even that was also put to risk by announcing board exams to Class V and VIII and the move was withdrawn due to strong opposition from DMK,” he added.

AMMK leader TTV Dhinakaran also expressed shock and urged the government to take remedial action.

Title: 2 arrested for smuggling drugs to conduct party
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

COIMBATORE: The narcotics intelligence bureau (NIB) - CID on Thursday arrested two youths including a college student for smuggling methylenedioxymethamphetamine (MDMA) pills and lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) stamps from Goa to conduct a rave party in Coimbatore.

Deputy superintendent of NIB-CID R Vincent and team arrested J Deepak, 23 and B Srijith, 21, of Palakkad in Kerala from Nava India after receiving a tip-off. “Srijith is a BSc Electronics student in a private college at Nava India and Deepak is a Bsc Computer Science graduate. We seized 10 grams and 200 milligrams of MDMA pills and 20 LSD stamps. They were selling one milligram MDMA pills to youths for Rs 2,000,” a police officer said.

Preliminary inquiry revealed that the duo had attended the rave party held at a resort in Sethumadai near Pollachi last May. A team led by police superintendent Sujit Kumar had busted the party and detained 163 youths, mostly IT employees and college students, who hailed from Tamil Nadu, Kerala and Karnataka. Police had seized cocaine, hash, MDMA, ganja and alcohol. However, the duo managed to escape from the resort.

“The duo was planning to organize a rave party in Coimbatore and with the help of their friends, smuggled the drugs to Coimbatore from Goa via Bengaluru and Kerala. Two more youths are absconding,” said Vincent. “MDMA is a synthetic drug, which alters mood. It is commonly called ecstasy or Molly. Its use leads to liver, kidney and heart failure.”

Title: For ‘assaulting’ BJP functionary, Porvorim MLA Rohan Khaunte held in late-night raid
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

After opposition MLAs protested Rohan Khaunte’s arrest, marshals escorted them out of the House

Title: Kanyakumari: Student admitted in coronavirus isolation ward
Content:
Representative image

KANYAKUMARI: A 20-year-old girl, who is studying medicine in China and had recently returned to Kanyakumari, has been admitted in the novel coronavirus (nCoV) isolation ward at the Asaripallam government medical college and hospital in Kanyakumari district from Wednesday morning.Hospital authorities clarified that the girl did not have any symptoms for the infection but got admitted on her own. The girl from Puthalam village on the outskirts of Nagercoil town is pursuing medicine in Jiangxi province in China.Following the nCoV outbreak in China, the girl flew back to India. Health officials suspected that she could have come to the hospital following inhibitions of neighbours over her return from China. A senior health official in the government hospital said that she came to the hospital on Wednesday morning and had preferred being admitted in the isolation ward till she tested negative for nCoV.

Title: HC dismisses pleas on easing age norm for dist judge posts
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Chennai: The Madras high court on Thursday dismissed a batch of petitions seeking age relaxation for other backward class ( OBC ) category candidates in direct recruitment to posts of district judge (entry level).
