Just by painting the corridor green with bicycle symbols is not enough when there is already space crunch in the walled city,” said Ramesh Meena, an e-rickshaw driver.

The 2.2-metre wide green lane is adjacent to the parking area in the market. “Just for the sake of it, they have constructed the lane. The track is constructed adjoining the parking space. There is conflict between cars and NMVs. The civic bodies are wasting public money without proper planning,” said Devendra Singh, one of the shopkeepers at Kishanpole.

Title: Rajasthan: People up in arms over rising rape cases of minors
Content:
Locals protest at Kanwat village in Sikar on Thursday against the rape and murder of a 14-year-old girl from t... Read More

TimesView The recent rapes of minors have shown that in most cases offenders were known to survivors/victims. While the police are expected to conduct a swift investigation and bring the accused to trial, the onus lies on parents to ensure the safety of their children. Parents need to be cautious and make sure that their children are not left unattended at any given point of time. This is especially important when there are family functions such as weddings, like the recent rape of a minor at a marriage function in Jaipur, where perpetrators find opportunities to target children.

JAIPUR: The rapes of three minors within days of each other have invoked a sense of anger in the people of Rajasthan, who have now taken to protest against the brutality. Locals in Churu district protested against rape of a 10-year-old girl and completely shut down the town on Wednesday, while villagers in Sikar continued their protest on Thursday.Experts believe that unemployment, bad influence of social media, lack of education and a patriarchal society are the reasons due to which children are being assaulted.The police claim that they are conducting awareness campaigns, but truth remains that they get involved only after the crime is committed.Dr Prerna Puri, associate professor of psychology at Rajasthan University, analysing the present situation said, “The society as a whole has become more self-centric and everyone tends to only think about their own wants and needs. The value system has shattered and moral values are not taught anymore. While we tell our girls that they need to behave in a certain manner, the boys are not told how they have to behave.”Experts also said that parents most of the time do not even report rape or molestation cases, which in turn increases the courage of the perpetrators to repeat these crimes.Puri further added, “Lack of education is a big issue and the minds of the accused in these cases are limited. Pornographic material is easily available on internet now and such individuals have access to it, making them prone to execute crimes like these.”The cops and experts seem to be in agreement when it comes to bad influence of social media.Tejaswani Gautam, SP, Churu, where a 10-year-old girl was raped and left for the dead, said, “Social media has made everyone access content which was not possible earlier. This, added to the fact that in most cases, the accused are mentally unstable in some sense or the other and are likely to be unemployed because of which they have no outlet to take out their frustration and they find easy targets in children.”Officials also lamented that the society has only changed superficially but the core values remain the same and Gautam added, “While we encourage girls to go to school, the ground reality is that the patriarchal system still exists. Men and boys still look at women as well as girls as someone who are only meant for certain things. The mindset is same as it was many years ago.”Meanwhile police say that they try their best to expedite the investigation when they receive the reports. DGP Rajasthan, Bhupendra Singh told TOI, “We are organising outreach programmes to curtail such crimes and the investigation is also done swiftly. However, there has been no increase in these cases and they are reported every year and in these matters, police can do their job only after the crime has been reported.”

Title: Lucknow: Drunk man kills wife in Madiaon for refusing sex
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

LUCKNOW: A man in an inebriated state killed his wife after she refused to have sex with him in Madiaon on Thursday.

According to police, Ram Hirday (35), a daily wager, lived with his wife Munni in a rented house in Rahimnagar . The couple had been married for about 12 years. They had no children.

Recently, said police, Munni had begun suspecting that Ram was having multiple affairs. This lead to regular verbal spats between the two. About four days ago, the couple had a major fight when Munni accused Ram of having an affair with their neighbour.

On Thursday, Ram came home late in an inebriated state and tried to get physical with his wife but she snubbed him. An argument followed and in a fit of rage, Ram strangulated Munni, said police.

Later, he told his neighbours that he was out at night and returned to find his wife dead. However, the neighbours did not believe him and informed police.

Madiaon SHO Vipin Kumar Singh said, “Ram confessed to his crime during interrogation. An FIR of murder has been lodged by Munni’s father.”

Title: Ninder protesters refuse talks, say JDA ‘dividing’ movement
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Jaipur: Efforts to solve the issue of farmers in Ninder protesting against the acquiring of agricultural land by Jaipur Development Authority (JDA) seems to be in trouble. Ninder Bachao Yuva Kisan Sangharsh Samiti, on Thursday issued a statement that they are putting an end to the talks with the authorities.

“We were ready to solve the issue through discussion but the officials at JDA are busy indulging in cheap politics. Our group was asked to be present in the fourth phase of meeting with the JDA officials on February 6. However, we were informed that JDA officials have invited another farmers’ group for talks, which is not related to our protest or group. This way, the JDA is trying to divide the movement of the farmers. Hence, we have decided to end talks with the JDA,” said Nagendra Singh Shekhawat, leader of the Ninder protest. The protest was started in January 2020 against JDA forcibly acquiring their agricultural land to develop a housing colony.

JDA though has denied such intention to divide the farmers. “We trust CM Ashok Gehlot and MLA Mahesh Joshi. From now on, we will have discussions directly with the government representatives or this agitation will continue,” said Nagendra. TNN

Title: Delhi Polls: High-decibel noise for high-stake polls over
Content:
Narendra Modi and Arvind Kejriwal (Right)

NEW DELHI: A high-voltage campaign, marked by unprecedented vitriol and invectives, for the February 8 assembly polls in the national capital ended on Thursday at 6pm. The die has been cast and now it’s up to the voters.Last two weeks were marked by a blitzkrieg with both AAP and BJP trying to woo voters with rallies, roadshows, corner meetings and door-to-door canvassing across the city. Congress , which, otherwise, had an insipid outing, managed to catch some eyeballs with its top leaders addressing some public meetings in the last few days.Eventually, the entire election seemed to be boiling down to a contest between those who were in “support” of Shaheen Bagh — the site of anti-CAA protests —and those who who were “opposing” it with BJP linking it to national security. References to Pakistan and phrases such as “Jinnah wali azadi and gaddar” were frequently used by candidates and star campaigners of the saffron party. The high-decibel campaign revolved more around national issues like abrogation of Article 370 and 35A, the favourable judgment in the Ram Temple dispute, surgical strike on Pakistan and implementation of CAA even as AAP, the party in power, tried to steer it towards development issues, such as better health, education, infrastructure and clean air.Passions ran high as chief minister Arvind Keriwal was termed a “terrorist”, CAA protesters at Shaheen Bagh — mostly women — were described as potential “rapists” and a Union minister egged on the public to shout a “shoot the traitors” slogan.Election Commission of India found speeches and statements of BJP’s star campaigners violating the model code of conduct (MCC), forcing it to bar three of them — including Model Town candidate Kapil Mishra — from canvassing, addressing public meetings and giving interviews to media for different durations.Taking note of provocative slogans raised by Union minister Anurag Thakur, Election Commission barred him from campaigning for 72 hours while West Delhi MP Parvesh Verma was banned twice – once for 96 hours and again for 24 – for his statement on Shaheen Bagh and calling the chief minister a “terrorist”. Action against Mishra was taken for calling the election a “India vs Pakistan” contest.AAP’s Sanjay Singh, too, got an EC notice for saying that BJP could create trouble at Jamia and Shaeen Bagh on February 2. The EC also wrote to all political parties, urging them to restrain their candidates and make them comply with the provisions of MCC.The social media also witnessed the three players trying to outdo each other with photos, videos and memes, which were often found offensive by leaders of rival parties.Fighting on the development plank, AAP is looking for another term in office while BJP, in exile for 21 years, is desperate to form the next government. For Congress, which governed the national capital for 15 years before being completely whitewashed, it’s a struggle to stay afloat in Delhi politics. The result of the 2015 polls was one-sided with AAP winning a record 67 seats in the 70-member assembly and the remaining three going to BJP. Congress had failed to open its account.BJP campaigned in Delhi with all its might this time around. Apart from an army of over one lakh volunteers, the saffron party brought in over 240 MPs from across the country, chief ministers of 11 states and more than 50 ministers in the Union cabinet during the two weeks of active campaigning.According to a senior party functionary, close to 10,000 corner meetings, padyatras and roadshows were held since January 24, when Union home minister Amit Shah kicked off the poll campaign with a public meeting in west Delhi’s Matiala assembly constituency. He micro-managed the election and himself participated in five to six public events every day.AAP’s aggressive campaign, on the other hand, revolved around its five years in office and work done by the government. Besides door-to-door campaigns, close to 8,000 public meetings were addressed by the party’s top leadership and star campaigners at the assembly and ward levels.“The work done by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal-led Delhi government in the last five years in various sectors, including education, health, power and water remained our main focus. We also told voters our vision for the next five years,” said a senior AAP functionary.While the Congress looked completely out of action initially, its campaign started looking up only towards the end when former party president Rahul Gandhi addressed four meetings in two days. Former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh addressed one such meeting while Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh and other star campaigners participated in a few.

Title: ‘In 89% cases, offenders were known to victims’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Jaipur: According to the National Crime Records Bureau (NCRB) report of 2018, in Rajasthan in 89.2% of cases under Pocso that involved penetrative sexual assault, the offenders were known to the victims. In majority of the cases, the offenders were either family friends or neighbours. The data indicates an alarming trend wherein even those known to the family can turn out to be perpetrators.

For Sections 4 and 6 of Pocso Act, which are about penetrative sexual assault, the NCRB data showed that in 66 cases, the offenders were known to the victim.

In most of the cases in which children are raped, the offenders are known to them which makes it easier for them to lure the child. Also, in few of the cases, the offenders kill the child due to fear of being recognised. This was witnessed not just in the recent cases, but also in the past. Last year in December, a truck driver raped and then murdered a 6-year-old girl. The accused was known to the child and had been drinking alcohol since morning on the day of the incident and after the assault, he dumped the body in bushes. He claimed that he feared being recognised.

Recently a 14-year-old girl was raped allegedly by her neighbour who then strangled her in Sikar on January 27 and after fighting for her life, she died in Jaipur on Tuesday. A total of 488 Pocso cases were registered in 2018, out of which 74 involved penetrative sexual assault. In these cases, 75 victims were girls and one boy. According to the data released by Rajasthan police in January 2020, there was an increase of 22% in cases of rape under Pocso Act in 2019 as compared to 2018.

Title: IIT-Kanpur turns insect lookalike robots into a reality, AI bug can fly and spy undetected
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

AI device can cover all landscapes in every weather

LUCKNOW: How many times have insect-lookalike robots in sci-fi movies piqued your curiosity and made you wonder if they’d really help spot the enemy in the future? Well, that wait is finally over.

Meet insect-copter, an artificial intelligence (AI) device weighing only 22gm developed by IIT-Kanpur for what is famously known in the spy world as fly-on-the-wall surveillance.

The indigenous robot technology will be handed over by the premier tech cradle to Indian state-owned aerospace and defence company Bharat Electronics Limited (BEL), which after field trials will spawn the bug for use by the Indian Armed Forces.

Details about this high-end surveillance technology, currently employed in the West, was shared by IIT-K professor Laxmidhar Behera during a seminar on ‘digital transformation of defence services’ at DefExpo 2020 at Vrindavan Yojana on Thursday.

“Our AI bug can fly and spy undetected. It can cover all landscapes in every weather, infiltrate otherwise inaccessible buildings and navigating its own way out of enemy territory. We will hand over the prototype to BEL in March and based on its feedback, the final device will be developed by June,” Behera said. If the seminar augmented curiosity, the simultaneous exhibition at the venue fuelled enthusiasm.

One of the major attractions was the CornerShot gun, manufactured by Adani Defence and Aerospace, which was part of the counter-terror operations in Mumbai during the 26/11 attack. Its purpose is similar to that of the periscope rifle; it allows its operator to both see and attack an armed target, without exposing the operator to counter-attack.

Another highlight was a drone made of special carbon composite material. It comes in a special easy to carry drone backpack for soldiers during anti-terrorist operations.

Title: Delhi Polls: High-decibel noise for high-stake polls over
Content:
Narendra Modi and Arvind Kejriwal (Right)

NEW DELHI: A high-voltage campaign, marked by unprecedented vitriol and invectives, for the February 8 assembly polls in the national capital ended on Thursday at 6pm. The die has been cast and now it’s up to the voters.Last two weeks were marked by a blitzkrieg with both AAP and BJP trying to woo voters with rallies, roadshows, corner meetings and door-to-door canvassing across the city. Congress , which, otherwise, had an insipid outing, managed to catch some eyeballs with its top leaders addressing some public meetings in the last few days.Complete Coverage on Delhi ElectionsEventually, the entire election seemed to be boiling down to a contest between those who were in “support” of Shaheen Bagh — the site of anti-CAA protests —and those who who were “opposing” it with BJP linking it to national security. References to Pakistan and phrases such as “Jinnah wali azadi and gaddar” were frequently used by candidates and star campaigners of the saffron party. The high-decibel campaign revolved more around national issues like abrogation of Article 370 and 35A, the favourable judgment in the Ram Temple dispute, surgical strike on Pakistan and implementation of CAA even as AAP, the party in power, tried to steer it towards development issues, such as better health, education, infrastructure and clean air.Passions ran high as chief minister Arvind Keriwal was termed a “terrorist”, CAA protesters at Shaheen Bagh — mostly women — were described as potential “rapists” and a Union minister egged on the public to shout a “shoot the traitors” slogan.Election Commission of India found speeches and statements of BJP’s star campaigners violating the model code of conduct (MCC), forcing it to bar three of them — including Model Town candidate Kapil Mishra — from canvassing, addressing public meetings and giving interviews to media for different durations.Taking note of provocative slogans raised by Union minister Anurag Thakur, Election Commission barred him from campaigning for 72 hours while West Delhi MP Parvesh Verma was banned twice – once for 96 hours and again for 24 – for his statement on Shaheen Bagh and calling the chief minister a “terrorist”. Action against Mishra was taken for calling the election a “India vs Pakistan” contest.AAP’s Sanjay Singh, too, got an EC notice for saying that BJP could create trouble at Jamia and Shaeen Bagh on February 2. The EC also wrote to all political parties, urging them to restrain their candidates and make them comply with the provisions of MCC.The social media also witnessed the three players trying to outdo each other with photos, videos and memes, which were often found offensive by leaders of rival parties.Fighting on the development plank, AAP is looking for another term in office while BJP, in exile for 21 years, is desperate to form the next government. For Congress, which governed the national capital for 15 years before being completely whitewashed, it’s a struggle to stay afloat in Delhi politics. The result of the 2015 polls was one-sided with AAP winning a record 67 seats in the 70-member assembly and the remaining three going to BJP. Congress had failed to open its account.BJP campaigned in Delhi with all its might this time around. Apart from an army of over one lakh volunteers, the saffron party brought in over 240 MPs from across the country, chief ministers of 11 states and more than 50 ministers in the Union cabinet during the two weeks of active campaigning.According to a senior party functionary, close to 10,000 corner meetings, padyatras and roadshows were held since January 24, when Union home minister Amit Shah kicked off the poll campaign with a public meeting in west Delhi’s Matiala assembly constituency. He micro-managed the election and himself participated in five to six public events every day.AAP’s aggressive campaign, on the other hand, revolved around its five years in office and work done by the government. Besides door-to-door campaigns, close to 8,000 public meetings were addressed by the party’s top leadership and star campaigners at the assembly and ward levels.“The work done by chief minister Arvind Kejriwal-led Delhi government in the last five years in various sectors, including education, health, power and water remained our main focus. We also told voters our vision for the next five years,” said a senior AAP functionary.While the Congress looked completely out of action initially, its campaign started looking up only towards the end when former party president Rahul Gandhi addressed four meetings in two days. Former Prime Minister Manmohan Singh addressed one such meeting while Punjab chief minister Amarinder Singh and other star campaigners participated in a few.

Title: Over 10k cases of MV Act to be withdrawn at Lok Adalat
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Prior to bringing a notification for the implementation of Motor Vehicles (Amendment) Act, 2019, the state government has decided to give a gift to the violators of Motor Vehicles Act.

The state government has agreed to withdraw nearly 10,000 such cases during the Lok Adalat to be organised across the state on Saturday. The cases till December 31, 2018, will be withdrawn at various courts and high court benches of Jaipur and Jodhpur. This came a day after transport minister Pratap Singh Khachariyawas promised that two-wheeler riders will get a free helmet from the dealers on its purchase from April 1 onwards

Divulging details on the Lok Adalat, Ashok Kumar Jain, member secretary, Rajasthan State Legal Services Authority, said, “Of the total 10,000 cases in the state, nearly 6,670 are pending in Jaipur (Urban), which would be withdrawn at various metropolitan courts in Jaipur.” At Jaipur, metropolitan magistrate number 27 and 28 will withdraw the cases of MV act. The retracted cases include various violations like traffic penalities, druken driving, seizure of vehicle registration papers and seizure of driving licence. At Jaipur (Urban), Jaipur (Rural), Kota and Karauli, since it is a regular working day in courts, the Lok Adalat will be organised from 1.30pm on Saturday. Apart from the Motor Vehicles Act, nearly 1.67 lakh cases have been identified to be taken up at the Lok Adalat. “Of these 1.67 lakh cases, nearly 42,500 are related to cheque bouncing under the Negotiable Instrument Act,” Jain added.

Title: Tallah Bridge: Waiting time on Tallah diversions goes down
Content:
Tallah Bridge razing is on in full swing

KOLKATA: The road diversions devised to navigate around the Tallah Bridge shutdown seems to have worked out with waiting time reducing drastically on the new routes. Congestions around Shyambazar and subsequently, C R Avenue—especially on the south-bound flank—have eased considerably as the volume of vehicles there has been distributed to other stretches. But it’s not entirely a rosy scene.Trucks, which are mainly being diverted via Vidyasagar Setu and Belgharia Expressway to the city are leading to jams on the highway, often as far as Salap. Congestions are also being reported on B T Road, near the Indian Statistical Institute, Nivedita Setu and even Sodepur. The situation worsens at night as more and more trucks start entering the city. This, cops said, was the main reason they had been insisting on getting the work on the new level-crossing at the Chitpore yard done at the earliest. “Hopefully, a few trucks will use this other route. With the board exams round the corner—Madhyamik is slated for February 18—we do not want any examinee to get stuck. Specific plans are being drafted,” said a senior officer at Lalbazar. Echoing him, joint CP (traffic) Santosh Pandey said, “There is no denying that Tallah Bridge was an important link between the central and north Kolkata. But alternative routes have been identified for trucks to enter the city. Once the level-crossing is ready, we are expecting a better flow of traffic.”It has so far been decided that traffic load on two key roads—Pran Krishna Mukherjee Road and Seth Pukur Road adjoining the Lockgate flyover and leading to Tallah bridge — would be studied before a plan is finalised once the level-crossing is built.Cops said a second worry was the absence of additional parking space. “The board exams will see a lot of kids going to the exam centres in hired or private vehicles. We need to ensure parking space for the extra vehicles. Each school, which will double as exam centres, is being consulted,” said a Lalbazar officer, adding they were considering whether further restrictions were needed in the Tallah area or not.Work on pulling down the bridge has been on in full swing. One side of the bridge has been flattened out and a new layer of pitch has been laid to ensure heavier mechanical equipment can be moved into the area. “The idea is to use all possible alternative ways that can be utilised once the demolition begins,” said an IPS officer, part of the surveys of the spot. Senior officers said the area around Chitpore and Cossipore was a corridor, where trucks keep moving in and out of the railway yard, and hence, nothing can be planned by keeping them out.

Title: Rajkumar Hirani launches the official website of SFS OBA
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nagpur: Rajkumar Hirani, noted film producer, director and alumnus of SFS High School (Sadar) launched the official website of the ‘SFS School Old Boys’ Association (ww.sfsobanagpur.org) as a pre-sesquicentennial (150 years) celebration of the institute at a function held on Feb 2.

Principal, Father Samuel K, SFS OBA president Arunpal Singh Behal, general secretary Lijo Jose, treasurer Santosh George, joint secretary Ashok Sayre, executive committee members Nitin Dadar, Abhijit Gupta and Father Lijo were present on the occasion.

OBA president Behal explained how the website is going to help the alumni spread across the globe to come together for the benefit of the school and showed him different pages of the website, especially the Hall of Fame, OBA Shop and upcoming events.

The SFS OBA launched two unique projects — ‘SFS Shop’ & SFS OBA Privilege Card’ — probably for the first time in India by any alumni association. The ‘OBA Shop’ aims to boost employment and sale of products of its members. The online shop will sell consumer and homemade products of members. The ‘SFS OBA Privilege Card’ will provide discounts on hotels, restaurants, hospitals and other consumer items.

Jose spoke about the launch of a mobile application and also a ‘Film Festival’ depicting Hirani’s hit movies as a part of the celebrations.

The launching of the website was the start of the 150 years’ celebrations which will continue till the final function to be held in November. Behal stated that every Sunday there will be an event related to either sports, culture or any social activity. The celebrations will conclude with a grand function in which luminaries of the school, namely Chief Justice of India Sharad Bobde, Rajkumar Hirani and other VIPs will be present.

Title: NMC demolishes 19 illegal dwellings
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nashik: The anti-encroachment department of the Nashik Municipal Corporation demolished 19 illegal dwellings on a plot of land reserved for a civic school in the Satpur area of the city on Thursday .

The drive started around 7am under heavy police bandobast as the civic body feared retaliation by the squatters. A team of state reserve police force (SRPF) accompanied the local police and the civic officials. Bulldozers were used to raze the illegal structures.

“The drive was carried out at Pimplegaon Bahula village in Satpur that falls under the jurisdiction of NMC . Initially, some of the dwellers tried to resist but the huge police presence ensured smooth conduct of the drive,” civic officials said.

NMC officials said that the occupants of these structures were served notices by the civic body over a month ago to vacate them along with their belongings as the demolition drive would be undertaken anytime.

The owners of these dwellings shifted all their belongings from their houses before the demolition drive started.

“The plot where these illegal structures came up is reserved for a civic school. The local corporators of Satpur have been demanding an NMC-run school constructed on the plot for children in that area,” sources in NMC said.

However, later the civic authorities received a feedback that the dwellings exist on that same plot of land where the elected representatives were insisting to set up a school.

“We sought feedback about the plot of land from the office of the special land acquisition officer of the district revenue department. The latter informed us that the plot was reserved for a civic school. The NMC then decided to get rid of the illegal structures on the plot,” said civic officials .

Title: Karnataka: Railways replaces coach factory in Kolar with repair workshop
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The repair workshop can create about 2,000 jobs while a coach factory could have offered about 5,000 jobs

BENGALURU: The proposed factory to manufacture rail coaches in Kolar , 66 km from Bengaluru, has been scrapped and a repair workshop will come up there.

The railways ’ Pink Book , a budget document of detailed allocations of various projects and rail works, released on Wednesday, said Rs 495.3 crore was allocated for setting up a composite repair workshop in Kolar. This means Kolar will get only a railway workshop and not a rail coach factory as earlier proposed.

The factory was first proposed almost a decade ago by then Kolar MP KH Muniyappa, who was Union minister of state for railways. He managed to ensure the project was included in the 2011-12 and 2012-13 railway budgets. However, the project slipped into cold storage later.

In 2014, when Mallikarjun Kharge took over railway minister, he cleared the decks for setting up the factory. In fact, a foundation stone for the rail coach factory was also laid in Srinivasapur taluk of Kolar district that year, but the project continued to remain on paper.

The factory was proposed to manufacture about 1,000 passenger coaches per year. An agreement was signed between the railways and the state government to set up the factory at an estimated cost of Rs 1,460 crore on 1,123 acres of land. The project would have generated about 5,000 jobs. At present, rail coaches are manufactured in Chennai, Kapurthala and Rae Bareli.

Karnataka’s loss: Activists

Activists say a production unit generates more employment than a maintenance facility.

Karnataka Railway Vedike founder-member KN Krishnaprasad said, “This is the first-time the railways is admitting that a repair workshop and not a coach factory will come up in Kolar. The decision to drop a rail factory is a loss for Karnataka, particularly Srinivasapur which is a backward region. A coach factory would have generated huge employment opportunities for people in that area.”

“A workshop will do only secondary maintenance and repair of coaches and the number of jobs that would generate from that would be revealed only after railways releases a blueprint. From the railways’ point of view, three existing well-built coach factories may be enough for their requirements,” he added.

However, a senior SWR official said, “The existing three coach factories meet the requirements and no new proposals have been mooted. The life span of coaches is 20-25 years. The railway board has also decided not to set up new coach factories since it already has surplus capacity. The state government also delayed land acquisition for the project. In fact, the composite repair workshop in Kolar will be a huge facility and generate employment opportunities.”

Will create 2k jobs: MP

Kolar MP and BJP leader S Muniswamy said the workshop will come up in about 530 acres which is already acquired. “This will provide employment to about 2,000 people and sufficient amount has been allocated in the budget,” he said.

Last year, railway minister Piyush Goyal had said, “The rail coach factory set up at Bareli in 2012 was only utilised for refurbishing coaches. The first coach manufactured at this factory came out in 2014. Now, the factory has become a full-fledged manufacturing unit and is slated to produce coaches at 142% of its capacity. Similarly, the coach factory planned to be set up at Srinivasapur in Kolar will be utilised as a workshop for wagon maintenance to start with and in due course, it will be developed into a fully automated unit.”

Title: Lawyers oppose shifting of SDM court
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Jaipur: Hunderds of lawyers affiliated to the district bar association in Jaipur organised a ‘Maun Juloos’ (silent procession) from District Collectorate to Shahid Smarak at the government hospital on Thursday.

Lawyers have been protesting against the shifting of Amber SDM court from the Collectorate to Amber claiming this will affect the litigants, especially of the 136 villages that comes under Amber’s jurisdriction, but are situated on Sikar Road.

Lawyers holding placards participated in a silent procession. “Almost 50 days ago, the Amber SDM court was shifted from the Collectorate to Amber.

This is affecting thousands of villagers, of at least 136 villages that are situated on Sikar Road and Kalwar Road. We will continue to protest against it as it is impractical,” Sunil Sharma, president of the District Advocates Bar Association, told TOI.

“How can you expect the villagers from Sikar Road and Kalwar Road to bypass the Collectorate and reach Amber for their revenue related issues,” he added.

The association has given a written memorandum to chief minister Ashok Gehlot, deputy chief minister Sachin Pilot and state revenue minister Harish Chaudhary in this regard.

On Friday, the lawyers will organise a Sadbudhi Yagya at the Collectorate Circle.

Title: Tamil Nadu: Cops may not pull you up, but jaywalking is a crime
Content:
In 2018, 290 pedestrians were killed in Chennai. But the government has done little to encourage pedestrians t... Read More

CHENNAI: Every day, techies on Old Mahabalipuram Road play their own version of steeplechase. With a backpack on their shoulders, they run across the road, scale a three-foot- high median and dodge oncoming buses and cabs to reach the foyers of their offices. But they do not know that the city’s IT corridor has been recording the highest number of deaths due to jaywalking over the years.There are 15 foot over-bridges between the Madhya Kailash Junction and Siruseri, one every 1.5km, but they are rarely used. “It (jaywalking) does make me nervous,” said 32-year-old Vinay Nair, a techie working as project manager in one of the BPOs. “I have seen a young man die. But this happens every day in most places across the city,” he said.Vinay is not wrong. It is not just foot over-bridges on OMR, subways on Poonamallee High Road and GST Road remain empty.To reduce pedestrian deaths, the mobility plan policy document for Chennai says the government has planned to double the number of subways and foot over-bridges in the next five years. But there have been no campaigns to encourage people to use the existing facilities even though the number of pedestrians killed in road accidents remains high. More than 1,000 people are killed in accidents every year in Chennai. In 2018, 290 pedestrians were killed.Jaywalking is one among the top reasons for the deaths, police said. Yet, most pedestrians are not booked. “There is a law against jaywalking,” said R T L Chandar, a Madras high court advocate. “Pedestrians can be booked for obstructing traffic under Section 283 of the Indian Penal Code and Section 201 of the Motor Vehicles Act. But police prefer to book motorists (in case of accidents) so that pedestrians, even if they are violators, become eligible for compensation by insurance firms,” he said.Experts said walking, like driving, needed strict enforcement. “The problem is that the pedestrians don’t even think it is a violation or compromise on safety,” said IIT-M professor Ventakesh Balasubramanian, who works with the department of engineering design.“Jaywalking is a product of mob mentality,” said Preethi Manohar, counselor at Sooriya Hospital. “Pedestrians often cross the road in a herd,” she said.Pedestrians who spoke to TOI had their own excuses for jaywalking. Many said they did not want to climb stairs to reach the other side of a road.“We need bridges such as the one at Alandur,” said Antony Ruben, a civic activist from Thiruvottiyur. The Alandur FoB has escalators and stairs. “Stairs in most foot over-bridges are steep. Subways are dingy and ill-lit. Men drink and do drugs inside subways. Women find them unsafe,” he said.Urban planners reject the idea of adding more subways and FoBs and call for more pedestrian-friendly zebra crossings at street level. Aswathy Dilip, senior programme manager, Institute of Transportation and Development Policy, said according to Indian Road Congress guidelines, urban streets should have frequent pedestrians crossings — one every 80m to 150m (commercial areas) and 80m to 250m (residential areas).

Title: Run for cleaner air and do your best to improve environment: Experts
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

(From left) Race director Prasanta Saha, Olympic shooter and Arjuna Award winner Joydeep Karmakar, Apollo Glen... Read More

KOLKATA: More than 5,000 people, including marathon veterans of several years, are expected to join the inaugural edition of Apollo Gleneagles Times Half Marathon this Sunday.

Preparations at Red Road , where the marathon will be held, are already under way. Participants can register online at www.timesmarathonkolkata.com or at a special desk set up at Acropolis Mall on Kasba connector.

Apart from marathon runners, fitness experts, fashion icons, entrepreneurs, sportspersons and actors will also run. The half marathon will be flagged off at 6am on February 9 on Red Road.

“We are running for a cause—for fresh air—which concerns all of us,” said Prasanta Saha, the race director, at a news meet on Thursday evening, where he shared the details of the half marathon. “We are currently breathing air, which is harmful for us. Air pollution is claiming millions of lives worldwide every year. Let us run and take a pledge that all of us are going to do our best to improve the air quality for the sake of our future generations.”

The event will have a 3km ‘Fun Run’ and 10km ‘Timed Run’, which aims at promoting healthy living. The half marathon, named 21km Apollo Gleneagles Run, is aimed mainly at professionals, but even amateur runners can join in, where they they can showcase their strength and stamina. Refreshment stations will be set up every 2.5 km, where runners can avail of juices, fruit and water, to keep them energised. Washrooms, too, will be available along the route.

Shooter Joydeep Karmakar, who represented India in the 2012 Olympics, said fitness was of paramount importance and air quality could make or mar personal fitness. “We need to pay adequate attention to the air we breathe. It is critical to our fitness. I will be running half marathon, pledging for clean air. I request every citizen to run for clean air,” he said.

Every finisher will be awarded a medal and a certificate for participating.

Title: China-returnees isolated after 24 days
Content: JAIPUR: Almost 24 days after returning from China's Wuhan - epicentre of coronavirus (nCoV) outbreak - three medical students were quarantined at an isolation ward in Jaipur's SMS Hospital on Thursday. The delay could be a major lapse in preventing the virus in Rajasthan.Defending the delay in testing, health authorities claimed that these students were not cooperating with them despite repeated efforts were being made to convince them.Only after chief medical health officer Jaipur-I Narrottam Sharma directed his officials in Govindgarh to convince these students for testing for nCoV, the students agreed to undergo the test. "We issued directions to get the test done of these students immediately. If required take the help of the administration (even police)," Sharma told TOI .In Barmer five people have been quarantines. While in Jodhpur two more people were quarantined on Thursday. So far, 51 samples of people returned from Wuhan have been taken and out of those 43 have tested negative and report of eight tests is awaited. Moreover, 6,981 passengers have screened travelled in 48 international flights landed in Jaipur in 10 days. No nCoV positive case has been reported in the state so far.Rajasthan is at high-risk of nCoV as a lot of medical students, along with other students, have returned from Wuhan. At a time when Kerala has reported three confirmed nCoV cases, all those people returning from Wuhan are categorised as suspected cases for nCoV in the state.

Title: Rs 11 crore cyber fraud: Father, son nabbed from Delhi
Content:
Representative image

AHMEDABAD: The cyber cell of the city police on Thursday arrested a father-son duo from Bhajanpura in New Delhi for the Rs 11 crore cyber fraud , the biggest against a single individual according to the police. A textile businessman Pratap Avtani, a resident of Asavari Tower in Satellite, had lodged a complaint in this connection. The police nabbed Brijesh Giri, 50, and his son Saurabh Giri, 25, who used to work in a private bank as a telecaller. He had got the personal data of the victim while working in the bank, the police said. The complaint was lodged by Avtani on January 24.From March 2016 to December 2019, Avtani was cheated of Rs 11,06,71,824 as he was asked to buy lucrative ‘insurance policies’ of a private bank, and later to pay money for documentations as his investments had ‘grown to Rs 38 crore’.Deputy commissioner of police, Rajdeepsinh Jhala, said the money was transferred to 52 banks in 167 transactions over three years in different accounts. “There are 96 more accused in the case along with 196 account holders in whose accounts the money was transferred. We are hunting for them. We suspect that the father-son duo have cheated more people in the city,” said Jhala. “We have written to banks to freeze the accounts in which the money was transferred,” said Jhala.According to the cyber cell officials, the thugs lured him into buying different life insurance policies, and other investment schemes promising high returns. “During the investigation, we traced the phone numbers from which the duo used to call Avtani. The calls were traced to Bhajanpura in New Delhi. We sent a team to Delhi and with the help of Delhi police nabbed them,” said inspector V B Barad.Cyber cell sources said the accused deposited the money duped from Avtani in the bank accounts of their relatives.

Title: HC bars canal works by corporation, puts district collector in charge
Content:
Representative Image

KOCHI: All work required to prevent flooding in Kochi should be carried out under the aegis of the high-level committee headed by the Ernakulam district collector, the Kerala high court has ordered.Banning all other agencies, such as Kochi corporation and GCDA, from independently carrying out works, Justice Devan Ramachandran said only such a holistic approach would result in a final solution to the flooding. The directive was issued by Justice Ramachandran after considering a petition (WP-C No. 23911/2018) filed by Treasa K J through lawyer K P Pradeep.In the order, the court said: “I further direct that all works being done in the Perandoor Canal and other freshwater canals, except its periodic maintenance and cleaning, shall be done only under the aegis of the high-level committee and with their approval, so as to ensure that the work done by one agency does not stand in conflict with the proposals and work to be done by the others.”The court issued the order after noticing a report filed by Kochi corporation on its project ‘Thevara-Perandoor Canal Rejuvenation’. It was suggested in the report that the canal’s width should be increased from 21.8m to 28.7m on the eastern side of Pandit Karuppan Bridge until Kallupalam and that piling and slab construction in the area have be to commenced immediately. The court said it is precisely because the court does not want individual stakeholders to continue their work that it ordered for constituting a high-level committee, under the provisions of Disaster Management Act. Going by the directives issued by the court earlier, it is ineluctable that the high-level committee has been placed in charge of TP Canal and other freshwater canals, along with the drains in the city, so that they can take a holistic view on their restoration, maintenance, and future works, the court pointed out.Reports filed by amicus curiae Sunil Jacob Jose and Kerala Legal Services Authority (Kelsa) to the court after visiting various stretches of TP Canal had stated that the present condition is very unsatisfactory. The reports had highlighted the conditions at the mouth of TP Canal at Thevara and the culverts under the railway lines crossing the canal at Kammattipadam and Kallupalam. The culverts are only a metre or two in diameter and no steps have been taken by any agency, including Kochi corporation, to clean them for the last several years, the reports had stated. The observations by the amicus curiae and Kelsa in the report on the basis of the inputs gathered from the people of the locality are, prima facie, good, the court said.“The sum total is that even though the corporation appears to have cleaned the Perandoor Canal as is routinely done, these bottlenecks have not been addressed; and therefore, the efforts that have been commenced on the basis of the orders of this court may not obtain full results,” the order stated.A meeting of the high-level committee should be convened by the district collector urgently and appropriate decisions should be taken regarding the aspects mentioned in the reports of the amicus curiae, Kelsa, and Kochi corporation, the court ordered. Decisions so taken and the steps suggested should be informed to the court by the next hearing on February 24, the order said.

Title: ‘Garbage trucks’ from Kerala dump tonnes of toxic trash in Mysuru
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Mysuru: Hundreds of tonne of bio-medical waste, plastic and electronic waste from Kerala is being illegally transported across the border through trucks and dumped across Mysuru. While the state pollution control board and district authorities have flagged the violation repeatedly, the trucks continue to get through by bribing the guards at the border check-posts.

The trucks enter Karnataka from the Balavi check-post coming under Nagarahole Tiger Reserve, pass through HD Kote taluk, Moolehole checkpost in Bandipur Tiger Reserve and Gundlupet and reach Mysuru and Mandya, taking the Mysuru-Bengaluru highway.

The truck drivers collect waste – biomedical products, e-waste, plastic, used liquor bottles, clothes and paper – from hospitals, hotels and local businesses in Kerala and conceal it under secured tarpaulin sheets. Evasion is not of essence, though: officials in Karnataka admit palms are greased liberally at the checkposts so trucks get free passage more or less.

The waste is then dumped in various places in and around Mysuru, including on agricultural land, raising fears of contamination of groundwater and spread of diseases due to improper disposal of medical waste.

Karnataka State Pollution Control Board (KSPCB) officials say the smuggling of waste has been happening for the past few decades but the number of trucks has multiplied over the past five years. The drivers make anything between Rs 10,000 and Rs 20,000 per truckload while border staff allow free passage for as little as Rs 500 per truck, said officials. The racket, they added, included prominent politicians, hospital owners, businessmen and hoteliers in Kerala.

Deputy commissioner Abhiram G Shankar pleaded helplessness even as residents have filed several complaints about the risk to public health and environment from the proliferating garbage heaps. “Under the existing law, violators are punished under a compoundable offence (where charges can be dropped) and they get scot-free by paying a meagre fine. They become repeat offenders as there is no deterrent,” Shankar said.

KSPCB environmental officer M G Yathish told TOI that after several letters from the board, the district administration and police had tried to increase the men at the checkposts to inspect the vehicles. “But as the staff allow these trucks without inspecting by taking bribe, they are entering the state and the illegal activity continues without any hindrance,” he said.

“I have instructed police to file FIR against those dumping waste illegally but we are failing to stop such vehicles from entering in the first place. Due to gross violation at Gundlupet checkpost, these trucks are getting a free run,” said Abhiram G Shankar, deputy commissioner.

Title: 22-year-old unemployed man hangs self in Udham Singh Nagar
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

RUDRAPUR: A 22-year-old man hanged himself from the ceiling at his house in Shivnagar colony of Transit Camp in Udham Singh Nagar district headquarters in Rudrapur on Thursday afternoon. The deceased, identified as Anivesh Mali, was depressed over unemployment for the past one year.

Haripad Mali, the deceased’s father, told the police that Anivesh was depressed since he was unemployed since a year. On Thursday, he asked for some money from him while he was having lunch. After taking the money, he went to his room and locked it from inside. When he did not leave the room for over an hour, the family members knocked on the door but Anivesh did not respond. When they broke the door open, they found him hanging from the ceiling.

Police reached the spot after getting information and sent the body for postmortem. VD Joshi, SHO, Transit Camp, said, "No foul play is suspected. However, no suicide note has been recovered either. We are probing the case.”

Title: Tamil Nadu: Two Kollywood stars under a cloud
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Money matters of a different kind have put Rajini and Vijay in a spot

CHENNAI: Actors Rajinikanth and Vijay are the top two grossers of the Tamil film industry, with their new films costing Rs 180 crore – Rs 200 crore and collecting Rs 200 crore – Rs 300 crore at the worldwide box office. Money matters of a different kind have now put the two stars in a spot– one for causing losses to distributors and the other for causing loss to the government.

Rajinikanth’s ‘Darbar’ is in the news for a reported loss of around Rs 25 crore for distributors. As distributors complained that their efforts to recover the loss from Lyca Productions or Rajinikanth have been in vain, director A R Murugadoss has sought police protection.

In the case of Vijay, his last Diwali release ‘Bigil’ has come under the scanner of the income tax authorities who conducted simultaneous searches on the premises of the star, the film’s producer, a key distributor and a film financier. “The common thread among all these entities was the success of a recent film which was a box office hit collecting around `300 crore,” said I-T spokesperson Surabhi Ahluwalia in a statement.

While political circles discussed the possibility of the developments being linked to Rajinikanth’s recent utterances and Vijay’s admonition of GST in his film ‘Mersal’, film industry insiders said the two developments were a mere coincidence.

“Distributors asking lead stars to make good their losses in big ticket films and I-T searches in the film industry have been a routine for years,” said a distributor. “A member of the production house had kept harping on how big a hit ‘Bigil’ turned out to be. Naturally, I-T authorities came checking how true those numbers were,” said an exhibitor. Both did not want to be named.

“A substantial portion goes towards GST (18%), local entertainment tax (8%) in Tamil Nadu, theatres’ share and distributors’ commission among others. It might have got Rs 300 crore, but ‘Bigil’ was a loss-maker to most who released the film abroad,” said an overseas distributor of Tamil films.

Political memes referred to the relief Rajinikanth got recently from tax authorities over pending dues and his support for CAA. TNCC president K S Alagiri was more direct. “Developments are happening in the open and behind the screens. They offer relief for Rajinikanth, but summon Vijay from a shooting spot. This is an attempt to silence Vijay, who has a large fan following, mostly youngsters. No one can say there is no connection between the two developments,” Alagiri said.

Title: Titan Aviation to put $5 billion in defence corridor
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

LUCKNOW: With an investment of $5.2 billion over two years or roughly Rs 38,000 crore, Titan Aviation and Aerospace India Ltd (TAAIL), in collaboration with Ukrainian companies, has emerged as the highest investor in the defence corridor .

To come up in UP’s Bundelkhand district, the corridor will comprise an aerospace lab, aero university, manufacturing units for engines, aircraft components and air frames and an aircraft assembly line. In five to seven years, the company hopes to start a full production line for aircraft like AN 32, AN 74, AN 140 and AN 178.

K Giri Kumar, chairman and CEO of TAAIL, said the company hopes to use the expertise of Ukrainian companies to eventually produce aircraft using 3D printing along with other techniques.

“While it takes several months for an aircraft to be manufactured, this technology will help us deliver within three to four weeks,” he said.

“We would also like to replace traditional titanium with scandium alloy that will reduce weight of the final product by 30%,” said K Giri Kumar, chairman and CEO of TAAIL.

The company, Kumar said, was negotiating with the UP government for past several months and will finally be signing MoU on Friday. “By February 15, we hope to make our first payment. While 4,000 acre has already been acquired for us, the government has promised to acquire remaining 2,000 acre in eight weeks. Our initial investment will be $300 million,” he said.

The aerospace facility will be developed in three phases. In the first phase, the company will set up civil and defence simulators, air charter services and an aero university. For this, an air strip will also be laid. In phase two, an aerospace lab and R&D unit, and manufacturing plants for engines, components and air frames will come up in 900 acres. In the final phase, a maintenance, repair and overhaul facility will be set up, in which the company is expecting to service 1,000 aircraft annually. There will also be an assembly line for aircraft, which, over the next few years, will graduate into a production line.

“A Japanese firm will develop the facility for us. A township for about 3,000 expats will also be made at the site. We have requested the government to set up a container depot since there is no sea access here,” Kumar said.

Oleksandr Chechel, who heads the team in Ukraine, said 80 years have been lost between India and Ukraine. “We would like to use this chance to build political relations with India and bridge this gap,” he said.

Title: Injured man found in Pilibhit Tiger Reserve died of cardiac arrest: Report
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Rooplal had gone to collect wood and was found injured by a forest team on Wednesday. He may have been attacke... Read More

BAREILLY: A day after a 42-year-old man, who was found injured in Lalpur beat of Mala range of Pilibhit Tiger Reserve , died at the district hospital. The man had suffered injuries on the face and was probably attacked by a big cat. However, his postmortem report revealed a heart disease as cause of death.

According to sources, Rooplal (42) had gone to collect wood in the forest and was found injured by a forest team on Wednesday evening. The team took him to the district hospital, where he died. His postmortem was conducted on Thursday.

Divisional forest officer Naveen Khandelwal said, “The interim postmortem report stated that the man died due to cardiac arrest . He sustained injuries on the right side of his face after he was attacked by either a tiger or leopard. As he died inside the forest reserve, he is not entitled to government compensation but WWF-India will give his family a compensation of Rs 10,000.”

Title: Severe staff crunch hits teaching, research work at Mysuru varsity
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

University of Mysore

MYSURU: One of the country’s oldest varsities, the University of Mysore , faces a severe shortage of professors and other staff, a problem that has hit research work on the campus and raised concerns about the quality of education.

The numbers are staggering: about 75 per cent of positions of professors, 66 per cent of associate professors and 46 per cent of assistant professors are vacant. Overall, the university needs to fill 52 to 55 per cent of posts (teaching and non-teaching) in undergraduate and postgraduate departments.

However, the existing teams are expected to lose more members as some professors and assistant professors are due for retirement later this year.

The prolonged staff crunch — the last formal appointments were made in 2006-07 — has forced the university to rely on the services of guest lecturers.

Without enough full-time professors, the university has been consistently missing out on key research projects for the past 14 years. These are troubling signs for the 104-year-old institute which was supposed to be a role model for other educational centres in the state. The University of Mysore was Karnataka ’s first varsity and the sixth in India.

A university official said a committee of the National Assessment and Accreditation Council (NAAC) had noted the acute staff shortage while rating the varsity. NAAC rates all institutions of higher education.

EC Ningaraj Gowda, a syndicate member at the university, said several attempts were made to fill up vacancies, but successive governments didn’t provide the required support. No one can be hired without the government’s approval.

“We will send a delegation to the state government and request urgent hiring,” he said.

The government’s recent decision to make new appointments only through the Karnataka Examinations Authority is being seen as a stumbling block by varsity officials and academicians. They say that institutions of higher education are autonomous bodies with their own statutes approved by the governor, who is the chancellor of all state universities. All appointments must be made according to provisions of these statutes as mandated under rules, and not through the examinations authority.

University registrar R Shivappa acknowledged that the staff crunch had led to challenges, affecting the quality of teaching. “Students find it difficult to get research guides. We have been requesting the government to fill up the vacancies at the earliest,” he said. “On our end, we have appointed guest faculty members to cope with the situation.”

Guest lecturers can work for only eight to 12 hours a week as against a minimum of 16 hours that a full-time faculty member is granted. The total number of teaching hours at the university has fallen by 25%.

Title: Abandoned infant girl found crying in drain in Nainital’s sub-zero temperature; critical
Content: Nainital: An infant girl was found crying in a drain in Nainital’s sub-zero temperature on Thursday morning. The girl who was spotted by some local residents has now been referred to Haldwani hospital after receiving treatment at BD Pandey hospital. The girl is still on ventilator.Residents told TOI that they heard the girl crying early in the morning. When they came out of their homes, they saw her lying in the drain without any clothes. “Initially, we thought that maybe a child was crying in someone’s house. However, as the crying didn’t stop, we came out and found an infant lying in the drain. Nor did the girl have any clothes on or did she have a hospital tag. We immediately informed police who took her to hospital,” said Rashid, a resident.Officials of BD Pandey hospital told TOI that the girl is barely a day or two old. The doctors added that the infant had several injury marks on her body and is suffering from hypothermia. “Because she was lying in freezing temperature she is suffering from hypothermia and had several injury marks as well. We estimate her to be barely a day or two old,” said Dr Sanjeev Kharkwal, pediatrician at BD Pandey Hospital.Kharkwal added that the girl is still critical. “Though her condition is still very serious, but there are more than 50% chances of her survival,” he said.Police and the administration, meanwhile, said that they have started an investigation into the case and the parents of the child will be nabbed soon. “Police have been asked to investigate the matter promptly. Meanwhile, we have also announced that people can approach us for adopting the girl and if no one comes forward, the administration will bear the expenses of her education and marriage,” district administration officials said.

Title: Kolkata mayor goes live on Facebook to interact with citizens
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Firhad Hakim and councillor and IT advisor Sandipan Saha at the session

KOLKATA: City mayor Firhad Hakim hosted his first Facebook Live session on Thursday, taking questions on civic welfare from scores of citizens for over an hour from 7pm to after 8pm.

After ‘Talk to Mayor’, which started in July last year, this was Hakim’s second attempt at interaction with citizens.

More than 12,000 viewers were part of the interactive audience, who posed their questions at the mayor, live on KMC’s Facebook page. Councillor and IT advisor Sandipan Saha helped Hakim with the process as he answered the queries being posted in the comment section. The session ended with 339 comments, 223 shares and 14,000-odd viewership.

Among some of the major questions was about the lack of hygiene facilities for women in slums and what can be done for women who still did not have access to sanitary napkins. “We have set up sanitary-napkin vending machines at almost all government-aided schools in the city from where sanitary pads can be bought at a nominal cost,” Hakim replied. When another person suggested that similar vending machines be set up at KMC health centres, too, he said: “We will surely act on the advise and try to install them at civic health centres.”

There were questions on plans to protect the environment. Hakim replied that the KMC had already taken up urban-forestry initiatives and set up small urban forests in different locations.

Responding to a question on measures taken to stop wastage of water and to ensure potable drinking water for all, the mayor said, “Our moto is to ensure safe drinking water for all in Kolkata. We have seen a fair amount of purified water being wasted by people who wash cars on the road. We have strictly instructed our officials at all boroughs to take strong action against anyone using drinking water to wash vehicles. They have been told to spread awareness among garage owners to use only unfiltered water.”

Title: Kochi: Teen cooks up story, lands in police net
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative Image

KOCHI: A youth’s attempt to project himself as a hero backfired after his concocted story about rescuing a woman from abuse fell flat before the police. He was arrested on Thursday for spreading rumours and raising false alarms.

Alan Thomas (20) had posted a video on the social media a few days ago narrating how he saved a girl after a co-passenger tried to abuse her in a train.

Having introduced himself as an aviation student in a city institute, Thomas said in the video that the girl was in her twenties and was travelling in his coach to Ernakulam. By the time the train reached Ernakulam railway station in the morning, all except him and the girl deboarded the train. Just before the train departed, a man in his forties entered the coach and sat next to the girl though there were several other seats vacant. By the time the train halted at Ernakulam D Cabin, before the south railway station , the man groped the girl. Alan said he went to the girl’s rescue and started hitting the man. In the melee, he broke his nose as well, which started bleeding.

The girl ran ran out of the train and disappeared. Alan went on to claim in the video that he handed over the man to an RPF personnel when the train reached the south railway station, but to his utter shock, he was slapped with attempt to murder charges.

The video ended with his request to share it as much as possible till it alerted the girl whom he had saved so that she could come and corroborate his account and save him from the case which could legally affect his career and application to get a passport .

As the video went viral, RPF noticed it and summoned the youth but neither could he answer their questions satisfactorily nor could he present any evidence to back his claims.

“No such incident happened at our unit in south railway station and no charges were slapped on him. He could not even identify the RPF personnel to whom he claimed to have handed over the man,” said a senior RPF official. District police chief ( Kochi City) Vijay Sakhare also intervened in the issue and directed the police to collect the youth’s statement. After confirming it to be a cooked-up story, the police arrested him. “The youth has been facing some problems with his girlfriend and was perhaps trying to gain some sympathy by concocting a heroic story,” police sources said.

Title: BDA, fire department to jointly crack down on wedding halls without fire NOC
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

BDA officials said they are raising awareness among people so that they get their building layout plans approv... Read More

BAREILLY: The fire department and Bareilly Development Authority ( BDA ) will jointly crack down on wedding halls in the city that haven’t acquired no objection certificates (NOC) from the fire department. Of around 350 wedding and banquet halls operational in the city, only a handful meets the guidelines.

Sources at the fire department said a list of wedding and banquet halls in the city which are yet to acquire NOC from the department, or don’t adhere to rules and regulation, is being prepared. Chief fire officer of Bareilly, Chandra Mohan Sharma , said, “Around 350 marriage halls and banquets are operating in the city. Of these, only few have got a legal NOC from our department. Most of them either do not have it, or have not got it renewed. We’ll soon issue notices to the errant owners, asking them to get NOCs from us. Those who have got the certificate will be asked to get them renewed.”

A fire department NOC indicates the building is designed as per norms and regulations and is resistant to fire, or unlikely to suffer from a fire-related disaster. BDA officials said a building must be equipped with all fire safety measures in anticipation of a tragedy.

BDA officials said they are raising awareness among people so that they get their building layout plans approved from BDA before starting construction work. BDA vice-chairperson Divya Mittal said if guidelines are followed and building layout is passed by BDA, the authority ensures that a commercial building mandatorily obtains fire NOC.

Last year, BDA had served a warning notice to Bareilly Municipal Corporation (BMC) for starting construction of a new office building without first getting NOC from the fire department. The authority had to temporarily stall the approval of the building layout plan.

Title: ‘Search for truth an unending journey’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

M Leelavathi, cooperation minister Kadakampalli Surendran and M K Sanoo during the inaugural ceremony of Krith... Read More

KOCHI: Inaugurating the third edition of the Krithi International Book Fair and Knowledge Festival, noted literary critic and writer M K Sanoo on Thursday said that the search for truth is an unending journey and it does not end with believing in something as perfect truth. “One should have the humility to distinguish what one does not know while amassing more knowledge,” Sanoo said.

In her speech, litterateur M Leelavathi said that we are living in an age where writers have to show that they have the backbone. “It is doubtful whether we will be able to guard freedom with the knowledge that letters give us. Though people like Narendra Dhabolkar, Gobind Pansare, Kalburgi and Gauri Lankesh could guard freedom granted by knowledge, they lost their lives in the course of their battle,” Leelavati said.

The huge book exhibition hall is the main attraction of Krithi. Out of a total of 75,000sq ft total built-up area, the book exhibition hall alone has 46,000sq ft area. Spread across 250 stalls, around 150 publishers are displaying books in almost all categories. Cooperation minister Kadakampalli Surendran said the contemporary world demands literature of defence for the society. “Without the existence of freedom, secularism and democracy, art and literature won’t be able to survive,” he said.

Title: GMDA to assess carbon footprint of office hubs
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Gurgaon: The Gurugram Metropolitan Development Authority (GMDA) has started a survey to assess the carbon footprint of the city’s major commercial hubs — Udyog Vihar, Cyber City and DLF-4. GMDA will also study different factors such as the number of people per building, vehicles used, consumption of electricity and diesel, and pollution levels in these areas.

Once these figures are collected, they can be used to estimate the carbon footprint, GMDA officials said.

For the measurement of air pollution levels, the civic body will use its recently-installed, low-cost air quality monitors.

“We have asked our geographic information system (GIS) team to start mapping buildings in commercial areas and ascertain the values of various factors for calculating the carbon footprint. Once we have an idea of the current carbon emission in these areas, we can start on a plan to bring it down,” GMDA additional CEO M D Sinha said.

The team will also study green areas and solar power potential in the commercial hubs. “We have started with assessing the rooftop solar power potential of every building in these areas so that we can work towards utilising clean energy sources,” Sinha added.

Talking about the energy needs of commercial hubs, he said they will also work with the organisations operating in these areas, as well as discom Dakshin Haryana Bijli Vitran Nigam (DHBVN), to understand the power needs and the deficit between the supply and demand. “If there is a significant difference between the supply and demand, companies have to rely on diesel for electricity, which adds to both the carbon footprint and air pollution. In such cases, we can ask the discom to provide uninterrupted power supply,” the additional CEO said.

The issue of irregular supply of electricity in these areas has also been raised by industry bodies several times, who have pressed upon the point that in the absence of uninterrupted power supply, they are forced to rely on polluting diesel gensets.

In the recent pre-budget consultations with chief minister Manohar Lal Khattar, many organisations had highlighted environmental concerns.

Once the team has evaluated the carbon footprints, they will work with the stakeholders concerned to draw up a list of long-term feasible solutions.

For instance, diesel autos in these areas can be replaced by electric vehicles, companies can be asked to introduce shuttle services for their employees to bring down the number of cars per building, green areas can be increased and roads can be vacuumed to reduce dust pollution.

“Once we have identified the major concerns, we can work with the organisations to bring down the carbon footprint as well as the pollution levels. Our preliminary talks with the companies have evoked a positive response. If we have a successful pilot run in one sector, we can eventually scale it up,” Sinha said.

Title: Officials take no chance as coronavirus scare grows
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Bhopal: Fear of the spread of novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) remains a clear and present danger in Madhya Pradesh. A high-level state government meeting has been scheduled for Friday.

Test reports of about six suspected patients were still awaited from NIV Pune on Thursday. It includes test reports of a patient who travelled to China. He is under treatment at AIIMS-Bhopal with severe upper respiratory tract infection. So far, no positive case of the deadly virus has been reported from Madhya Pradesh.

Suspected cases have been reported from Gwalior, Indore, Bhopal, Khargone, Mandsaur and Ujjain. With increasing number of suspected cases of 2019-nCoV, the National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC) has issued a new clarification that a single upper respiratory tract sample does not rule out the 2019-nCoV infection.

NCDC has directed health officials to keep tracking suspected coronavirus patients for 14 days, even after the test has turned negative. A new directive on the Union minister of health website states: ‘Kindly correlate the results with clinical findings. A negative result in a single Upper Respiratory Tract sample does not rule out 2019-nCoV infection. Hence in such cases, a repeat sample should be sent. Lower Respiratory Tract samples (sputum, BAL, endotracheal aspirate) are appropriate samples for 2019nCoV testing especially in severe and progressive lung disease’.

NCDC discharge policy of suspected nCoV cases will now be governed by a patient’s provisional or confirmed diagnosis and it would be up to the treating physician to take a decision. Patient shall be monitored for 14 days after their last contact with a confirmed 2019-nCoV case. A patient from Mandideep, a businessman, suspected for 2019-nCoV, is still lodged in a hotel, said health department sources. Tracking report of other patients is being submitted by respective district health officials on a daily basis.

Title: Coronavirus in Ahmedabad: 50-hours ordeal for Gujarat-origin UK girl
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Jesal Patel

AHMEDABAD: It was 50 excruciating hours for Jesal Patel, 20, a resident of London and a law student at Brunel University. Her ordeal finally ended at the domestic airport in Ahmedabad on Thursday evening. Jesal, who had come out of a locked-down town of China due to the coronavirus scare, will be staying with her uncle’s family for the time being.

Her father Jignesh Patel told TOI that Jesal was on an internship with one of the top law firms in Shanghai as part of her course requirement. “She was living with a Chinese family that was very supportive. When the scare over the virus began, they relocated to Xinjiang, five hours from Shanghai. The cities and towns were getting locked down one after another,” said Patel.

The anxious family back in London wanted her back home even as the village in China had not reported any confirmed case. “I then took to social media, reaching out to all the top officials in the UK, seeking her safe evacuation from China. When it did not work, my family came out in support and booked her a ticket from Shanghai, which was not locked down yet, to Delhi — which was available earlier than the one for London,” said Patel, adding that his family including Jesal are all PIO card holders.

The family said that the five-hour taxi journey to Shanghai on February 4 was more expensive than an international flight. “She was subjected to multiple tests where she tested negative for the virus. She boarded a flight from Shanghai to Delhi on the same afternoon and landed at the airport at night. She was told at the airport that she will have to go back to Shanghai due to new directives of not allowing any foreign national travelling from China,” said Patel. Jesal tried to argue that she is a PIO card holder but the authorities remained adamant. She refused to board a flight and instead asked the authorities to arrest her if needed.

“The authorities finally paid heed to her constant requests and allowed her to take a flight to Ahmedabad. She landed in Ahmedabad on Thursday evening,” said Patel.

Title: Ward 18 braces for a tough triangular fight
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Mysuru: Candidates contesting the byelection to ward 18 of Mysuru City Corporation have promised to make it a model ward as well as be available to the electorate 24 hours.

Voting for the byelection will be held on Sunday.

Candidates from three major parties—BJP, Congress and JD(S)—are in the fray.

Stakes are high for the BJP as it is seeking to retain its hold over the segment. Given that the segment falls in Chamaraja assembly constituency represented by BJP’s L Nagendra, activists are keen to ensure a win so that the party continues as the single largest party in the corporation. Nagendra has campaigned for party candidate, BV Ravindra.

The Congress, which is seeking to wrest the segment from BJP, is canvassing with former MLA Vasu in the lead. MLC R Dharmasena, deputy mayor C Sridhar and a host of former mayors are campaigning for candidate, R Ravindra Kumar.

Enthused after its candidate was elected mayor, the JD(S) is campaigning with Tasneem Bano and city unit chief KT Chaluvegowda.

The bypoll was necessitated following the disqualification of BJP corporator Guru Vinayak over a ST caste certificate row. Counting of votes will be taken up on February 11.

The candidates have assured the voters that they will be available to them 24 hours a day and will address issues at the earliest.

While BJP candidate BV Ravindra has promised to open an office in the ward for easy access to him, his Congress counterpart R Ravindra Kumar, who lost to BJP in 2018, has assured voters that collection of garbage every day and installing streetlights will be his priority.

For JD(S)’ Swamy this will be his third election. He had contested from the Congress and as an Independent before.

Hunsur misses GTD

Hunsur is all set for the city municipal council election on February 9. Congress which won in the recently held assembly byelection has fielded candidates in all the 31 wards while JD(S) has field candidates in 28 wards and BJP in 22 wards.

The previous term saw Congress winning the council.

BJP which released a separate manifesto for the council has promised that it will find a permanent solution to the long pending civic issues dogging the town.

What has surprised many is the party's failure to field candidates for all 31 wards. According to SD Mahendra, party district unit president, the party didn't find candidates for the Muslim majority wards. “We hope to win 10-15 wards,” he said.

JD(S)’ campaign is led by Devarahalli Somashekar, the party's candidate in the byelection. Locals feel the absence of party veteran GT Devegowda is likely to affect the party’s fortunes.

Curbs in dist

The district administration has imposed prohibitory orders in Hunsur town from midnight of February 8 to midnight of February 9 and midnight of February 10 and February 11. The sale of liquor has been banned during this period in the city and villages. The district administration has also sought postponement of all festivals and celebrations on Sunday.

All in the family

*In ward no. 16, HK Venkatesh is contesting as the Congress candidate while his sibling HK Ganesh is contesting as a BJP candidate from ward no. 26.

*In ward no. 18 and 26 siblings HN Chandrasekar and HN Kumar are contesting as Congress candidates.

*Dhanalakshmamma S and husband Shivaraju who were elected last time are contesting this time too. Both are JD(S) candidates from ward no. 4 and 5 respectively.

Title: Aurobindo Q3 net profit dips 1%
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Hyderabad: City-based pharma major Aurobindo Pharma Ltd on Thursday said it has posted a marginal 1% decline in consolidated net profit for the third quarter ended December 31, 2019, at Rs 705 crore as compared to Rs 712 crore in the corresponding quarter of the previous fiscal.
