The labourers attacked them and shouted ‘baccha chor’, which triggered a frenzied mob attack that killed 38-year-old Ganesh Khati, and seriously injured the others.

Chief minister Kamal Nath condemned the violence and asked ministers Jitu Patwari and Tulsiram Silawat to visit the survivors in hospital. Patwari also attended the last rites of Khati.

The state government set up an SIT under additional SP Devendra Patidar, to investigate the crime and law minister P C Sharma said they are mulling a special law to deter lynching. Manawar police station in-charge Yuvraj Singh Chohan, SI Shobharam Patidar and constables Raghvendra, Naval Singh and Chandrashekhar were suspended after the victims gave statements about the late response of police, said the SP.

The barbaric attack sparked outrage across the state and cops from several police stations and the Dhar DRP Line began a manhunt for the accused. Several houses were raided in Borlai, Khirkiya, Junapani and Tirla villages. Nearby dhabas and hotels were also searched all night.

Junapani was the first to be arrested past midnight. Three other suspects — Satiya, Galiya and Roop Singh — were arrested in the morning, police said. Khirkiya and Borlai villages bore a deserted look on Thursday as almost all the men have fled, fearing police action.

Police say 36 people have been named in the FIR after reviewing video footage of gruesome incident. Three police teams are looking for the other accused.

The lynching set Madhya Pradesh politics on the boil, with BJP vice-president alleging that ‘jungle raj’ was prevailing in Congress rule, and Congress hitting back by tweeting an old picture of Chouhan blessing Junapani. BJP said the lynching was a blot on the state’s image. Leader of Opposition Gopal Bhargava said: “The Congress government has failed to control law and order. Madhya Pradesh has been turned into a ‘Talibani’ state.” Chouhan said: “This is a very unfortunate incident. Law and order have been completely destroyed in the state. There is no fear of the law. This is called ‘jungle raj’.”

Congress state media cell chief Shobha Oza retaliated by tweeting a picture of Chouhan with Junapani and said: “Former CM Shivraj Singh Chouhan is mysteriously hiding the fact that it is his hand on the accused sarpanch’s head.”

State Congress media coordinator Narendra Saluja condemned the lynching and said such a crime is a blot on any civilized society. Accusing BJP of “politicizing” a crime, he said: “BJP has done this in the past as well. Be it the killing of a Dalit youth in Sagar or abduction and murder of a minor tribal girl in Chhindwara, BJP has tried to mislead people by misrepresenting facts, which any responsible political party would not do in sensitive cases.”

In most of the crimes that BJP is talking about, the accused were found to be associated with BJP, Saluja said. “In the Manawar lynching , too, the person who incited the mob was Ramesh Junapani, an influential BJP leader of the area, who has been arrested,” he added. BJP’s Dhar district president Raj Barua confirmed that Junapani is a member of the party, but alleged that he was falsely implicated. “He had no role in the violence in Borlai village. Videos show Junapani was trying to stop people from beating those farmers,” he said.

Title: Government tables right to burial bill
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: The state government introduced a bill , The Kerala Christian Cemeteries (Right to Burial of Corpse) Bill, 2020, in the assembly on Thursday. This is intended to put an end to the controversy between the Orthodox and Jacobite Christian denominations over the burial of people from rival factions in the churches owned by them.

The bill, which was referred to the respective subject committee, replaced the ordinance issued on January 6 and is set to become an act during the current session of the assembly. “The recent incidents, which saw burial of dead bodies getting delayed due to rift between the two Christian denominations, were a shame on Kerala’s culture. If this continues, it will grow into a major social and religious conflict in the state,” said A K Balan , minister of law and parliamentary affairs, while presenting the bill.

The UDF members, however, opposed referring the bill to the subject committee demanding redrafting the bill as in its current structure, the bill raised concerns among other Christian denominations including the Catholics and referring it to the select committee instead. Legislators including V D Satheesan (Congress) and Mons Joseph (Kerala Congress-M), stressed the need to limit the bill to just two denominations and warned against new social issues if the government tried to interfere in the powers of the church.

The bill was drafted very badly by someone with least knowledge about Christian denominations and their traditions, they said adding that referring it to the select committee seeking public opinion would give the church heads an opportunity to submit their opinions.

Balan, however, said the government’s intention was clear and that the subject committee could make necessary changes to remove practical difficulties in enacting the bill and give more clarity on definitions and terminologies. “The tense situation still remains and the government cannot remain a mute spectator. The subject committee would meet soon to facilitate the legislation during this session of the assembly,” he added.

Title: Chandigarh: Woman ends life in Sector 46
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

CHANDIGARH: A 40-year-old woman allegedly committed suicide by hanging herself at her house in Sector 46 on Thursday.

The deceased has been identified as Saroj.

“Her son, who was studying in another room, raised the alarm on finding her mother hanging from the ceiling fan. He called up his father, who works as a storekeeper in Air Force,” said a cop.

On being informed, police reached the spot and took her to GMCH, where doctors declared her brought dead.

No suicide note was recovered from the spot, the cop added.

Title: Ahmedabad: VHP plans pro-CAA rally at same site as ongoing protests
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

File photo used for representative purpose

AHMEDABAD: The city unit of the Vishwa Hindu Parishad has planned to organize a pro-CAA rally at Morarji Chowk in Bapunagar, the same location where anti-CAA protesters have been staging a demonstration for the past 10 days.

Ashwin Patel, VHP general secretary (north Gujarat) said that the rally will be held within a week and a large number of people will participate in the rally. “It will be a huge rally which will begin from Morarji Chowk in Bapunagar. We will seek permission of the police for the rally,” he added. Incidentally, the VHP had said earlier that it will organize the rally on Wednesday, February 6, but announced that it has decided to postpone the rally.

Kalim Siddiqui, an office bearer of Dalit Muslim Adhikar Manch, said that the anti-CAA protesters do not want any confrontation with the VHP.

“It is the duty of the police and the administration to ensure that there is no disruption of the dharna against CAA. We want the cops to ensure that law and order is maintained,” he said.

Title: Telangana: Worker dies in attack, friend critical
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: A person was killed and another suffered injuries after assailants attacked them with sharp weapons in Patancheru on Thursday afternoon. The injured person, who was rushed to Gandhi Hospital , is said to be critical.

The deceased person, suspected to be around 30-35-year-old, was yet to be identified, while the injured person’s identity was established, K Ashok, 28, from Medak district .

Around 2.30pm, according to police , the two, who work as guides and friends, were in Rudraram village in Patancheru. “The duo usually work for lorry drivers who visit the city from other states as guides to tell them the routes in the city limits. While they were waiting near an eatery, the assailants attacked them with sharp weapons. “The eatery owner saw the attack and alerted us,” Patancheru inspector Naresh said.

The victim suffered multiple stab injuries on his head and left hand, while resisting the attack. He died on the spot, police said.

Injured Ashok sustained a stab injury on his head and has been shifted to Gandhi Hospital in the city for treatment. His condition was critical, police added.

Police were checking CCTV footage near the place to identify the assailants. A murder and attempt to murder case was registered against the offenders.

Title: Maharashtra: Driver fined for speeding, HSP chief says he wanted to check cops’ alertness
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

PUNE: A Highway Safety Patrol (HSP) team stopped an official car of the Maharashtra government at Karad on the Pune-Bengaluru highway on Wednesday afternoon and fined the driver Rs 1,000 for speeding on the same road the previous morning.

Unknown to the team, HSP’s superintendent of police Milind Mohite was travelling in the car. While giving a reward of Rs 500 to the police constable who issued the fine challan, Mohite claimed that he had himself directed the driver to exceed the prescribed speed limit on Tuesday morning as he wanted to check if the patrol team was taking action against speeding and lane-cutting on the highway.

Mohite had travelled in the car from Pune to Kolhapur on Tuesday and was returning to Pune the next day.

The state government has given interceptor vehicles to the HSP and all police units across the state. The teams are armed with speed guns and keep an eye out for speeding and rash and negligent driving on the state and national highways.

Speaking to TOI, Mohite said, “I had gone to Kolhapur to inspect work at the HSP office there. I asked the driver to speed while passing through Karad. I wanted to check how well the ground staff was using the interceptor vehicles and other equipment for taking action against speeding motorists and lane-cutting on the highway. My inspection got over on Tuesday evening and I was returning by the same vehicle to Pune on Wednesday.”

While fining the driver, the HSP team showed him the receipt which also had the photograph of the car. “I rewarded the police constable who issued the challan for executing his duties perfectly. The police must catch and fine government vehicles if they are guilty of speeding and rash driving,” Mohite added.

Title: IVRI working to develop vaccine for bovine coronavirus
Content:
Photo for representative purpose only

BAREILLY: As bovine coronavirus (bCov) affects cattle in India, scientists at the Indian Veterinary Research Institute ( IVRI ) are developing a vaccine for it. Scientists said the vaccine for bovine coronavirus is available in a few countries but importing it to India is both difficult and expensive.Bovine coronavirus is a livestock pathogen that causes diarrhoea in calves. Experts said the diarrhoea in calves can cause death and the disease impacts growth of cattle, leading to economic losses. The transmission of bovine coronavirus is through fecal-oral route. “It can be spread among calves if the infected calf contaminates the water, fodder or any utensil. The bovine coronavirus is prevalent across the country,” said an expert.RK Singh, director, IVRI, told TOI, “Bovine coronavirus, rotavirus cryptosporidium , E.Coli are responsible for calf diarrhoea. We are developing a vaccine for bovine coronavirus, rotavirus, cryptosporidium, E.Coli and we have kept a target to make it within a year. Though the vaccine is available in a few countries, it is expensive and importing it is a cumbersome process. Besides, the vaccine developed here will be more effective on Indian pathogens. If a calf is vaccinated, it will get protection for nearly a year.”Meanwhile, a national conference on “Challenges and threats of microbes to animals and humans” was held at IVRI on Thursday. Commenting on novel coronavirus (2019-nCov) which has spread from China, Gurdial Singh, vice-chancellor, Lala Lajpat Rai University of Veterinary and Animal Sciences, said, “Novel coronavirus may have spread after consumption of wild bats. Unlike India, people in China consume raw meat and do not cook it properly.”

Title: Wayanad forest dwellers cry foul over disparity in relief
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

KOZHIKODE: Hundreds of families belonging to the ‘entrapped’ villages located inside Wayanad Wildlife Sanctuary (WWS), who have either relinquished or expressed willingness to part with their lands by accepting Centre’s relocation compensaion of Rs 10 lakh, now feel discriminated against with the state government recently announcing a KIIFB-funded scheme for other forest areas, which has a compensation of Rs 15 lakh.

The new state-government funded relocation package, which will be implemented in the forest divisions of Kannur , Thiruvananthapuram , Mannarkkad and south Wayand, will see 438 families being given compensation of Rs 15 lakh per family to move out. Already, the government has allotted Rs 65 crore for the scheme.

Environmentalists say that the discrimination in compensation would scuttle the ongoing relocation programme in WWS, which is the prime tiger habitat in state. While 378 families have already moved out of the sanctuary accepting the Rs 10 lakh, over 400 families are awaiting the implementation of the programme in their settlements.

With the launch state government’s scheme, many people who have moved out said they were treated unjustly. “I gave up my 2.5 acres at Chettiyalathoor settlement by accepting the Rs 10 lakh compensation per family and the amount was insufficient to purchase agricultural land to continue farming which we had carried out for generations. We had to relocate to Malappuram, where my wife had some land. The state government should not discriminate between people who vacated their lands from inside wildlife sanctuary and those in territorial forest divisions,” said K Sreedharan.

N Badusha, president of the Wayanad Prakrithi Samrakshana Samiti and member of the relocation monitoring committee, said the Rs 10 lakh compensation was grossly inadequate as the families couldn’t even purchase a fraction of land originally owned by them to sustain their agriculture-based livelihoods.

Chief conservator of forests, wildlife (northern region) B N Anjan Kumar said that the department had taken up the matter with NTCA regional office authorities who have said that they have forwarded a proposal to the Centre to increase the compensation for the centrally-sponsored relocation programme to Rs 15 lakh. “Once it is approved, it will be possible to provide extra compensation for the new beneficiaries of the IDWH scheme,” he added.

Title: India's envoy to UN lauds Bengaluru’s green warriors
Content:
India’s ambassador and permanent representative to the United Nations Syed Akbaruddin

Climate Activism is growing among school children in India. “Wave Riders” from Bengaluru dropped by… https://t.co/eesQFMquRm — Syed Akbaruddin (@AkbaruddinIndia) 1580956375000

Students bat for sustainable living

BENGALURU: India’s ambassador and permanent representative to the United Nations, Syed Akbaruddin , took to Twitter on Thursday to applaud the efforts of four teenage green warriors who revived a Bengaluru lake recently.Akbaruddin met eight graders, Yathaarth Murthy, Mishti Kewalramani, Maitrii Patel and Ira Bhruguwar, at the office of the permanent mission of India to the United Nations in New York . The students of Vidyashilp Academy are in the US to present their ‘Manae lake revival’ project at the General Assembly on Friday. Another team member, Annika Saha, couldn’t fly with them.“Climate Activism is growing among school children in India. ‘Wave Riders’ from Bengaluru dropped by @IndiaUNNewYork to share experiences of helping revive the 4.5-acre Manae Lake. More power to them (sic),” tweeted Akbaruddin. Yathaarth’s mother Shilpa Spoorthy said the children were excited to meet the ambassador who not only listened to their success story but even answered their questions patiently.The lake on Kanakapura Road was revived in 23 days in October 2019, under the guidance of conservationist Anand Malligavad. The students revived the lake as part of an initiative by an NGO.Human beings are the major culprits for the devastating climate change being witnessed today. Deforestation and even the Australian bushfires are the result of human action, said students at the Times NIE Debate — North Zone, held at Delhi Public School, Bangalore North, on Thursday. Over 25 teams of class 8 students battled for the coveted prize as they discussed the topic currently at the top of everybody’s mind, Climate Change — A Myth or Reality.“Climate change is a real threat and we need to curb it and take immediate action. It is a gradual process that destroys everything if care is not taken. Climate changes leads to catastrophic conditions,” said a student at the competition.“The first contribution one can make is to reduce use of plastic, take up carpooling, stop littering and contain pollution. Basically, one must adopt a sustainable method of living,” said another student.Communication skills coach Ravi Ghai and educationist and counsellor Wg Commander K Balachandran, who were judges for the debate, gave the participants valuable suggestions.DPS North vice-principal North Geetha Kandaraji spoke about the importance of reading and using opportunities like the debate competition to explore one’s potential. Students must learn to express their thoughts and opinions across forums, she added.Pariksha Rao, co-founder and chief nutrition officer at sCoolMeal by Lil’Goodness said, “The students spoke about multiple facets of climate change. We at sCoolMeal are making sure our next generation is fuelled with age-appropriate portions of proteins, carbs and healthy fat. It’s the best brain food for these little geniuses.” Each of the winners received vouchers from sCoolMeal, a trophy and a certificate. Refreshments and prizes were sponsored by sCoolMeal.

Title: Garlic price soars to an all-time high
Content:
The price of garlic is between Rs 250 and Rs 300 per kilogram in the retail market

JAIPUR: Though prices of onions have come down with supply from Maharashtra, Gujarat and parts of Rajasthan, another essential item of kitchen is touching an all-time high price.The price of garlic is between Rs 250 and Rs 300 per kilogram in the retail market. Wholesale traders are expecting prices to come down from April onwards when the fresh crop would be harvested and imported to Jaipur.Traders at the Muhana Mandi in Jaipur attributed the rising prices of the garlic to the poor supply and heavy rainfall which hit the crop. “This year’s supply has been badly affected due to poor production of garlic in Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Gujarat. Compared to 2019, our supply is 30-40% less compared to what we usually get here in Jaipur,” said Abdul Sagir, a wholesaler trader at the Muhana Mandi.The prices of the garlic are showing rising trend since September 2019 when the curtailed supply started from Nasik (Maharashtra), Bhavnagar (Gujarat), Kota (Rajasthan), Jhalawar (Rajasthan) and Bundi (Rajasthan).At the wholesale market, the prices of garlic are ranging between Rs 120 and Rs 160 per kilogram which is being sold at Rs 250 to Rs 300 per kilogram in retail market.“Fresh supply of garlic is expected from the first week of March and as indicated by the farmers of Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh and Gujarat we will get adequate supply from April onwards. By April, we are expecting the prices of garlic to be around Rs 60 to Rs 80 per kg in the wholesale market which would be sold between Rs 100 and Rs 120 per kilogram in the retail market,” said Mukesh Totlani, a wholesale trader of garlic at the Muhana Mandi.Traders said that for the first time the prices of garlic touched Rs 300 per kg in the retail market. “Retailers should ideally be selling it at Rs 200 per kg, however, they are charging just double that what they are getting from us,” said another wholesale trader.Consumers too have curtailed their purchase of garlic. “We are using merely 100 grams of garlic for a whole week. In winters it is an important ingredient in the curries and many use it as sauce by grinding it with tomatoes,” said Savita Jaiswal, a homemaker.

Title: iPas to be implemented across state
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nashik: The Integrated Planning Office Automation System ( iPas ), which was implemented successfully in Nashik district on a pilot basis, will now be replicated across the state. The system is nothing but movement of files electronically, making the office paperless .

Launched in 2013-14 and completed in 2019, the district planning office has so far executed more than 2,700 works related to various government agencies involving funds from the state government.

“It is a revolutionary system where you can literally carry your office wherever you go. The robust, transparent and easy to use system has put an end to duplication of works, unnecessary delays and bring in balance development across the district,” district collector Suraj Mandhare said.

Now that the system is running successfully, representatives linked to the district planning committee (DPC) will be given log-in rights and citizens will also be given access to the current status of projects.

“With the log-in rights, the elected representatives — members of legislative assembly and council and members of Parliament from Nashik district — will be able to log in and present their proposals,” district planning officer Yogendra Chaudhary said.

“Earlier, the concerned officers from the government offices or MLAs (MLA-Fund) and the MPs (MP-LAD Fund) would present their proposals to the office in hardcopy format which would then move from table to table in the form of files. Either these files would get misplaced or the seniority would be fiddled with. Now, as soon as a complete proposal is filed, all the papers are scanned and a title for the project is created,” the officer said.

The file then moves from desk to desk without having to be carried physically. Also, there is no need to wait for the officer or the employee to be in office or even at the desk to sanction the same.

Even if the sanctioning officer is travelling, he/she will have access to iPas and will be able to take action.

Henceforth, government agencies and the elected representatives can simply complete the formalities from their offices and initiate the set procedure to get a particular work sanctioned or payment released.

The officer also said that the works undertaken would be available for viewing in public domain and they will also have GPS tagged photographs to get the real-time picture. “This will help the administration understand what works were taken where and when and the status of the same. As senior officials move along, the works would pop up on the screen of the computer making them aware of the projects undertaken along,” the officer added.

Title: Telangana: Child trafficking racket busted; two infants rescued
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Police produce the eight accused before the media on Thursday

HYDERABAD: Two infants were rescued and eight offenders were arrested in a child trafficking racket on Thursday. During investigation, police found that the accused were buying baby girls from poor families by offering their parents thousands of rupees and selling the infants to childless couples for a handsome amount of money.

Acting on specific information, Alwal police and Special Operations Team (SOT) sleuths of Cyberabad arrested KM Samanthakamani (41), a housewife from SBI Officer’s Colony in Moosarambagh and K Renuka (35) of Balaji Nagar in Yapral while they were in possession of a baby girl. “Both women were arrested and the girl was handed over to the staff of Sishuvihar in Medchal. During the custodial interrogation, the two women revealed that the racket was being operated by V Babu Reddy and V Gangadhar Reddy,” said Balanagar DCP PV Padmaja.

Based on the information provided by the two women, police arrested V Babu Reddy (43) from his house in Dammaiguda, V Gangadhar Reddy (33) of Qutbullapur, their associates B Ramesh (30) of Santosh Nagar, M Raja Naik (26) of Guntur district in Andhra Pradesh, J Sunitha (33) of Musheerabad and V Laxmi (25) of Ram Nagar. “We rescued another baby girl from the house of one of the accused. She has also been shifted to Sishuvihar,” the DCP said.

The DCP said that Babu Reddy and Gangadhar Reddy have a criminal record. “Babu Reddy has a case filed against him at Secunderabad railway police station and Gangadhar Reddy has eight cases registered against him in Chandrayangutta, Balapur, SR Nagar, Chatrinaka, Shamshabad and Madannapet police stations for similar offences,” the DCP said.

Gangadhar and Babu Reddy confessed to the police that they have been working as agents at various fertility centres in the city, providing egg donors and surrogate mothers on commission basis to the couples through the staff of fertility centres. “The fertility centres have been providing Rs 3,000 to Rs 5,000 for providing egg donors and Rs 30,000 to Rs 70,000 for providing surrogate mothers,” police said.

While arranging surrogate mothers and egg donors, Babu and Gangadhar met couples who were desperate to become parents and were willing to pay lakhs of rupees for a baby. “The duo activated their network of associates at ground level asking them to look for poor families with multiple girls or women who gave birth to unwanted children. They started buying infants by paying Rs 20,000 to Rs 30,000 to the parents and then selling the baby to couples by charging them Rs 4 lakh to Rs 7 lakh. We have identified the parents of a girl from Yadadri-Bhuvanagiri. Parents of the second girl, who is from Warangal, are yet to be identified as we are yet to nab the absconding accused Seetharam,” the DCP said. Police said they will seek the custody of the accused to see how many children have been sold and if they have also kidnapped any infants.

Title: SC lens on waqf’s ‘unlisted assets worth lakhs of crores’
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

NEW DELHI: Entertaining a PIL alleging non-enumeration of waqf properties worth lakhs of crores of rupees, resulting in their misuse and illegal transfer to builders, the Supreme Court has sought responses from the minority affairs ministry, all states and waqf bodies . Petitioner-advocates Rauf Rahim and Ali Asghar Rahim presented startling statistics before a bench of Justices D Y Chandrachud and K M Joseph. They said in West Bengal , the value of Shia waqf properties was around Rs 5,424 crore and that of Sunni waqf was Rs 13,126 crore.

In Tamil Nadu , Shia waqf properties were valued at Rs 688 crore while that of Sunni waqf was Rs 99,311 crore. And yet, neither the states nor the waqf bodies had prepared a list of properties, or their current usage, they alleged. The petitioners said the value of waqf properties in other states would be similar or much higher. And yet, no waqf board or state had complied with Section 4(1A) of the Waqf Act, which came into effect on November 1, 2013.

The law mandated every state government to maintain a list of waqf properties after conducting a survey within one year from the 2013 Act coming in to force.

After more than five years, no such survey of waqf properties has been carried out, they said. The petitioners told the SC that Section 4(1) of the Act made it obligatory for a state government to appoint a ‘survey commissioner of waqf’ and as many additional survey commissioners as necessary to enumerate waqf properties. This too had not been implemented, they said.

“It has been reliably learnt that proper records of waqf properties are not maintained by the boards and several such properties have been illegally transferred by waqf board officials who are acting in concert with builders/developers by destroying and/or fudging records,” the petitioners alleged.

Requesting the court to order enumeration of waqf board properties within six months, the petitioners said the survey for this purpose should indicate the list of properties which have been transferred and/or alienated in the past four decades by way of lease, sale or tenancy. “Waqf boards across the country are already taking huge amounts as waqf contribution (up to 7%) and yet are not following statutory requirement of surveying and enumerating the waqf properties,” they said.

Because of this, several tenancies of waqf properties were constantly changing hands at the whims and fancies of muttawallis/waqf board officials who often conspired among themselves to make unlawful gains, they added. “Waqf estates across the country have lost crores to unscrupulous management and officials of waqf boards in this manner and valuable properties have been/are transferred by creating new tenancies for a paltry sum under the nomenclature of development/donation,” the PIL said.

Title: Assembly urges Centre to scrap changes to I-T Act
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative Image

THIRUVANANTHAPURAM: Kerala legislative assembly unanimously passed a resolution on Thursday seeking the Centre to withdraw the proposed amendment in the Income Tax Act , ‘which will affect the non-resident Indian (NRI) status of Indian citizens working abroad, especially those working in Gulf countries, and Kerala’s economy’.

As per the Union finance bill tabled in the Lok Sabha on Saturday as part of the Union Budget, the proposal is to amend Section 6 of the I-T Act, 1961, to bring down the minimum residing period in India for being considered as a resident (for income tax purposes) from the current 182 days in a year to 120 days, with effect from April 1, 2020.

“This amendment, intended as a step to prevent tax evasion, will deny a major section of people from Kerala working in Gulf countries an opportunity to come and stay with their families back home. They come and reside in their home country not to evade tax but to handle family matters,” said the resolution presented by chief minister Pinarayi Vijayan.

The resolution pointed out that such an amendment would bring down significantly the income of small-scale NRI entrepreneurs in West Asian countries, ‘who otherwise will have to stay in their residing country for a minimum of 240 days to retain their NRI status .’ “The amendment could also affect people working in oil rigs abroad who have the opportunity to reside in India, thanks to several months of off duty they are eligible for,” it said.

Stressing on the significant contribution by non-resident Keralites (NRKs) to the state’s economy, the resolution said the income thus received from outside contributed to about 15% of the state’s gross domestic product. “The consumption and other expenditures the NRKs make in Kerala during their visits is a major trigger for the growth of sectors including industry and commerce in the state,” the resolution said.

Besides, it has also been proposed to impose tax on NRIs who don’t pay tax in their residing countries, ‘which will adversely affect people working in countries sans individual income tax or with which India doesn’t have double taxation agreements (DTAs)’, the resolution said.

“Though the Centre issued a press release on February 2 (after the state raised its concerns) stating that the amendment was not intended to bring NRIs under the purview of income tax, we cannot expect a different situation if Section 6 of the I-T Act, 1961, gets amended as proposed by the Finance Bill 2020,” the resolution said.

Title: Mescom seeks 62 paise more per unit of power sold
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Mangaluru: Power consumers under Mangalore Electricity Supply Company (Mescom) may have to brace for a hike in power tariff come April 1. This is thanks to a move by Mescom, which in its tariff filing before the Karnataka Electricity Regulatory Commission (KERC) for 2020-21, has sought upward revision of 62 paise per unit of power that is sells to its customers spread across Shivamogga, Udupi, Dakshina Kannada and Chikkamagaluru.

Mescom, in its tariff filings, stated that the average cost of supply is Rs 7.6/unit while the average revenue realisation is Rs 7/unit, leaving it with a deficit of 62 paise. The company will debate its case for this upward revision before KERC at the mandatory public hearing that is scheduled at the office of the deputy commissioner here for February 13. The company as on date has received 12 objections to its tariff filings directly, and others are with KERC.

Incidentally, 62 paise hike in power cost for 2020-21 sought is less than Rs 1.4/unit it sought in 2019-20.

The KERC in its tariff order for 2019-20 allowed Mescom to hike the price by 33 paise per unit. The projected annual revenue requirement and expected revenue from existing tariff charges for Mescom for 2020-21 as per tariff order 2019 is Rs 3884.8 crore against revised estimation of Rs 4251.4 crore, leaving it with a deficit of Rs 346.1 crore.

Sources in Mescom, privy to the tariff filings before the KERC, told TOI that with the average load growth across four revenue districts under its jurisdiction in the past five years being 2%-3% against 5%-6% in five years prior to that. Against total consumers across categories of 23 lakh in 2017-18, the company added 1 lakh new consumers in the following fiscal, and this has been approximately half the consumer growth registered in 2018-19 as on date.

On the moderate growth in consumer base and growth in load, sources said this is in keeping with the general trend across power supply companies in Karnataka. Against 4956.9 million units (mu) of power sold in 2018-19, the company is looking at projected sale of 5596.2 mu of power during 2020-21.

Most of this growth in power sales will come from domestic consumers who account for 65%-70% of its consumer base, IP sets 15%, commercial 9% and industrial 0.1%.

The move by Mescom to pare down its transmission and distribution losses from 11.3% in 2017-18 to 10.5% in 2018-19, is expected to come down further in 2019-20, increasing awareness among consumers on power saving measures and use of star rated equipment too has led to a plateauing of power consumption.

With focus on quality power supply, the company is doing everything in its power to meet KERC directions in tariff orders, the sources said.

Title: 1 more arrested in Rakhial for CAA protest
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Ahmedabad: Rakhial police on Thursday made a second arrest in the case registered on January 19, for taking out a rally against the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and National Register of Citizens (NRC). Police sources said a social worker, Kalim Siddiqui, was arrested on Thursday while a man named Sufiyaan Rajput was arrested on Wednesday. Rakhial police officials said a rally had been organized with about 500 people on January 19, without police permission. This was the day violence broke in the Shah-e-Alam. Police sources said Siddique was produced before a court which released him on bail. TNN

Title: Telangana: Kidnapped girl rescued in two hrs, auto driver held
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

A cop with the rescued girl Simpi

HYDERABAD: A two-year-old girl who was kidnapped at Thondupally was reunited with her family within two hours on Thursday. Police arrested an autorickshaw driver, S Sandeep, for allegedly kidnapping the toddler.

At 10.20am on Thursday, Sonu Kumar, a worker at a brick kiln in Thondupally, lodged a complaint with the Shamshabad police stating that his daughter, Simpi, went missing while playing in front of the brick kiln around 9.30am.

During preliminary probe, police found that the girl was abducted by an autorickshaw driver. “A ragpicker from Bihar, who was collecting bottles near the brick kiln, saw the girl, who was crying on the road, being taken away by an autorickshaw driver,” ACP, Shamshabad S Ashok Kumar Goud said.

Police teams launched a manhunt to nab the offender and obtained the autorickshaw’s registration number after analysing CCTV footage.

Using the vehicle registration details, police contacted the owner of the autorickshaw, who informed them that one S Sandeep (35) from Maharashtra, was riding the three-wheeler. The autorickshaw owner then took police to Sandeep’s house in Rallaguda area of Shamshabad.

“We found the girl asleep inside Sandeep’s hut. Sandeep tried to fool us by saying that he took the girl home as she was alone on the road. He should have informed police or locals. We have arrested Sandeep and the girl has been handed over to her mother,” the ACP said. “Sandeep is married, but they have no children,” police said.

Title: Bridge without approach roads irks high court
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative Image

KOCHI: Construction of a bridge across Vembanad Lake at a cost of Rs 48 crore without approach roads on both sides depicts the sorry state of affairs in Kerala, said the high court .

Justice A Muhamed Mustaque has now ordered the state government to immediately acquire lands on both sides of Nerekadavu Bridge at Vadakkemuri across Kollam-Kottapuram Waterway. Once the bridge is joined with the approach roads, it would provide connectivity between NH-66, at Thurvaoor, and state highway-15 between Tripunithura to Vaikom, at Udayanapuram.

The court considered a petition by 74-year-old NM Thaha of Vaikom through advocate KM Sathyanatha Menon for acquiring lands for approach roads. In the order, the court said, “The case depicts a sorry state of affairs… pointing out lack of coordination among different agencies involved in the construction of a bridge.”

Construction of the bridge between Makkekadavu and Nerekadavu was entrusted to Cherian Varkey Construction Company Pvt Ltd in 2016. The construction started before the acquisition of land for the approach roads. As of now, there is a bridge that is of no use, as per court records.

“… With all common sense, one could understand without acquiring land on both sides, no bridge can be put to use. It is not known why tender was awarded in a haste… This is a case where Court should have ordered for a vigilance enquiry… However, the Court will not be restrained from passing such an order if so warranted. The immediate concern… is acquisition of the land…,” the court said in its interim order.

The court ordered the PWD secretary to take immediate steps for acquiring the land and report before the court by the next hearing scheduled on February 14.

Title: Man held with spurious liquor
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Hyderabad: Excise sleuths arrested a person manufacturing spurious liquor at LB Nagar. They intercepted a Skoda and seized 30,000 bottle metal caps of a popular whiskey, three litres of rectified spirit and three litres of diluted liquor from P Mahendar of Shamshabad. They later raided a house and seized 90,000 metal caps of the fake whiskey and 48 empty bottles of the brand. tnn

Title: Min: State fully geared up to meet coronavirus challenge
Content:
Ready for worst: Minister B R Sriramulu addresses a press conference in Mangaluru on Thursday

Mangaluru: The state health machinery is fully geared up to tackle any case of coronavirus outbreak in the state, said minister for health B R Sriramulu on Thursday.“Screening has been stepped up at international airports with focus on passengers with a travel history to and from China and other coronavirus affected areas, at seaports and of people coming into the state from neighbouring Kerala, where active cases of this disease have been reported,” he said.Interacting with the media at the BJP office here, Sriramulu said he has directed all government, private and taluk hospitals in the state to reserve beds for people suspected to have contracted the disease. At least 10 beds will be set aside in each of these medical facilities to the extent possible, the minister said, adding test reports of 57 people believed to be symptomatic of the disease in the state, have come up negative on screening.In addition, the department has taken steps to create awareness among the masses, especially in rural areas, on new and emerging contagious diseases such as coronavirus by way of LED display vans that he inaugurated recently. These vans will create awareness about such diseases in villages, he said, adding the department will purchase 15 more such vans so that the message can be spread in all districts of Karnataka.To a query on interns attached to Wenlock Hospital not receiving their stipend for the past 10 months, Sriramulu said this is an issue for the department of medical education and Manipal Academy of Higher Education to sort out amicably. “I have discussed this issue with Dr C N Ashwath Narayan,” Sriramulu said. He said he will draw the attention of the minister once again to the issue, so that it can be resolved.

Title: Shahjahanpur youth booked for raping a woman from Bareilly
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative Image

BAREILLY: Bareilly police have booked a youth for allegedly raping a woman in Nigohi area of Shahjahanpur district . The survivor, who lives in the cantonment area of Bareilly, has claimed she got to know her tormentor in July 2019. He promised to marry her, and between August 2019 and January 2020, they kept having physical relations. Then on January 25, he broke his pledge of marriage , and thrashed and threatened to kill her, which is why she had remained quiet for several days.

Eventually, she mustered courage and filed an FIR at Bareilly cantonment police station on Wednesday. According to her police complaint, Abhay Pratap of Nigohi promised to marry her and met her parents in Bareilly for the purpose. Thereafter, he often kept taking her to a room in Nigohi and forced himself on her. But when on January 25, she visited Abhay’s house in Nigohi with her mother to fix the date of marriage, Abhay refused the proposal, and with the help of family members, thrashed her.

SHO Dharmendra Singh of Bareilly cantonment police station told TOI, “We’ve filed an FIR against Abhay and four members of his family, under IPC sections 376 ( rape ), 147 (rioting), 323 (voluntarily causing hurt) and 504 (intentional insult). The victim’s statement has been recorded under Section 161 CrPC, and will be recorded again in front of a magistrate on Friday. The accused is likely to be arrested after the court issues a warrant.”

Title: P T Usha appointed Kannur University’s dean of faculty of sports
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

P T Usha

KANNUR: Olympian P T Usha , who represented India in many international sports events, has been named the dean of faculty of sports and physical education of Kannur University . This is the first time in Kerala that a sportsperson gets such an academic honour and Kannur University’s move may be the first in the country although officially it could not be verified.

The name of the Olympian was selected by governor Arif Mohammad Khan , who is the chancellor of the university, from the list of three persons proposed by vice-chancellor Gopinath Ravindran , and this was officially communicated to her on Wednesday. “Though the usual practice is to appoint a dean from the academic circles, we don’t have such personalities in the sports field and hence the decision to appoint Usha, who is an eminent sports personality, with global recognition,” said the VC.

This is an honorary post, and she is not expected to take classes, but she would have a key role in the activities related to the faculty, he added.

“This part of the state can do a lot in sports and since Usha is also from the region, she would be able to give a facelift to the sports scenario here, and we are hopeful that it would benefit the university as well,” Ravindran added.

Usha, who is an alumnus of Kannur sports division at Government Vocational Higher Secondary School here, has won many national international laurels, including Padma Shri , Arjuna Award, Best Athlete in Asia Award, Adidas Golden Shoe Award and World Trophy for best Athlete, to mention a few.

It was the 1984 Los Angeles Olympics that made her a star when she came fourth in 400m hurdles. In that event she lost the bronze by 1/100th of a second. In 1985, in the Asian Athletics Championships held at Jakarta ( Indonesia ), Usha bagged five gold medals, which is a record. Now, she is focusing on her career as a coach and managing her institution, Usha School of Athletics, dedicated to advancing promotion and practice of sports.

Usha said the appointment was a pleasant surprise and she felt honoured. “I’m yet to realize the enormity of the offer, and I’m waiting for more information from the varsity officials in this regard,” she said on Thursday.

Though she would not be able to take classes, she is ready to help the students of the department in whatever ways possible.

Title: Hyderabad: Man draws water illegally, FIR filed
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

HYDERABAD: An FIR was filed by the Kulsumpura police against a resident of Mustaqpura in Ziaguda for drawing water illegally on Thursday.

The vigilance sleuths disconnected the water connection immediately and the police registered an FIR under relevant sections of the IPC at Kulsumpura police station.

Title: Bareilly: Three samples test negative for novel coronavirus
Content:
Two more samples sent to Lucknow for test

BAREILLY: Samples of three persons who had travelled to China in January were tested negative for novel coronavirus (nCov-2019). The health department received the test report on Thursday. Of three cases, two were from Bareilly and one from Pilibhit. Besides, the health authorities in Bareilly collected two samples of a mother-son duo on Thursday.Of the two samples which were collected from Bareilly, one person is a city-based industrialist who returned from China on January 12. Officials said another person, who is a native of a village under Sheeshgarh police station in Bareilly district , is an agriculturist in New Zealand and returned to India on January 17. His flight had a changeover in China. Similarly, a 55-year-old woman from Pilibhit’s Puranpur had travelled to Canada but she had to switch her flight in China.The health department had collected their samples for coronavirus test on Tuesday after these three persons had fever and cough following their return to India. The immigration department had provided a list of 47 persons to health authorities in Bareilly who had travelled to China since January. Health teams had contacted them and checked if they have any flu-like symptoms.Additional chief medical officer, Bareilly, Dr Ranjan Gautam, said, “Out of 47 persons, the travel history of 17 persons to China has exceeded 28 days and there is no risk from them. The health department has to monitor a patient who returned from China for a period of 28 days. Of 30 persons who visited China last month, we took samples of four while the rest of them are fine. Two persons were tested negative for novel coronavirus while we have sent sample to Lucknow for test of a woman and her son on Thursday. Their test reports will arrive soon. No person from Bareilly went to China's Wuhan and the situation is under control.”Officials said a woman and her son whose samples were collected and sent to Lucknow on Thursday had returned from Melbourne but their flight halted at China for nearly half-an-hour.Chief medical officer, Pilibhit, Dr Seema Agarwal, said, “We had collected sample of a woman in Puranpur and she tested negative for novel coronavirus. There is no other suspected case in Pilibhit district.”Meanwhile, the health department in Bareilly will conduct a mock drill on novel coronavirus on Friday to create awareness among public. The health officials have also roped in a few private medical colleges in Bareilly to conduct awareness programme.

Title: Fake Doctor : Student poses as doctor at Gandhi Hospital, held
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Suprajeet Panda being whisked away by the police

HYDERABAD: A 26-year-old degree student was nabbed by the Chilkalguda police at Gandhi Hospital on Thursday for running a clinic as a ‘doctor’ without any proof of qualification.

The accused, Suprajeet Panda, a resident of Uppal, had opened a community cardiology centre at Hanuman Sai Nagar in Uppal.

“He has been using a fake ID card posing as a doctor and was operating a clinic since January 1 this year. The accused was caught after a security guard grew suspicious of Panda when he visited Gandhi Hospital to invite patients to his clinic,” said Chilkalguda inspector AC Balagangi Reddy.

According to the police, the accused was running the clinic without proper degree or documents and charged his patients consultation fee. The accused, in the guise of a cardiologist, would visit Gandhi Hospital and distribute his fake visiting card requesting people to visit his clinic.

On Thursday, the accused was nabbed after a security guard, Pradeep Kumar, from Gandhi Hospital caught him in the canteen. Later, the staff, along with the resident medical officer (RMO), confronted him and alerted the police.

The accused was booked under IPC Sections 170 (personating a public servant), 419 (cheating by personation), 420 (cheating), 467 (forgery) and 468 (forgery for purpose of cheating) and relevant sections of Telangana Medical Practitioners Registration Act.

Title: Ahmedabad police cite rioting to justify Section 144
Content:
Stones and brickbats thrown at cops in Shah-e-Alam area of Gujarat in December last year. (File photo)

AHMEDABAD: While the political leadership has been boasting that there have been no disturbances in Gujarat after the 2002 riots, Ahmedabad police told the Gujarat high court that there had been 496 incidents of rioting in the city in the last three years.City police cited this figure before the high court, to justify its continued imposition of Section 144 of the CrPC and Section 37of the Bombay Police Act, which prohibit the gathering of more than four persons at a public place.City police claimed that removal of these restrictions “would lead to chaos in law and order situation in Ahmedabad”. City police filed an affidavit to this effect to oppose a petition filed by five persons including a faculty member of the Indian Institute of Management, Ahmedabad (IIM-A), challenging the continued imposition of these sections. The petition was filed last month after people were detained from outside the IIM-A campus while protesting the Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA). The petitioners claimed that the continued imposition of these sections violate the people’s fundamental rights to express themselves, to protest.The affidavit said Ahmedabad is a very politically and socially active city. Any incident, whether it takes place in or outside Ahmedabad, creates a sensitive situation in the city. “There are many incidents within Ahmedabad as well as outside it, which have created a situation, wherein there have been massive rallies, protests etc. across the streets of Ahmedabad,” the affidavit said, and went on to enumerate agitations that have taken place since 2015, after the Patidar reservation movement.Besides major agitations like the Patidar stir, the post-Una Dalit movement or the mass exodus of people from northern states following a rape case, police cited controversies over events such as the suicide of a Bhadra court employee and the Nithyananda ashram.“There is a history of many incidents of similar nature having serious bearing on peace and public order from 2002 to 2015 also,” the affidavit said.Apart from major protests when rioting took place, police claimed that the number of offences registered for rioting in Ahmedabad was 146 in 2017, 201 in 2018 and 149 in 2019. Still, city police took credit for controlling the violence, “Had the police authority not acted swiftly to control these offences, any of these incidents might have the potential of turning into a major law and order situation.”Interestingly, police also claimed that the application of Section 144 of the CrPC has been made for certain “benign” purposes.

Title: Godavari on ventilator, says water conservationist Rajendra Singh
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nashik: Various government agencies in the district have drawn sharp criticism from district guardian minister Chhagan Bhujbal for their alleged failure in tackling Godavari pollution problem. He has warned the officials concerned of strict action if they fail to initiate immediate steps to deal with the issue.

Bhujbal and renowned water conservationist Rajendra Singh inspected some stretches of the river in the city on Thursday. They were accompanied by officials from the district administration, the Nashik Municipal Corporation (NMC), the Smart City cell, the Maharashtra Pollution Control Board etc.

Singh, a Magsaysay awardee, was appalled to see the severity of the pollution in the Godavari. He described the river as a “patient on a ventilator support.”

Singh was also upset with the NMC administration that had put up sprinklers to deal with the problem of foam formation — as untreated effluents are directly being released into the river.

“Untreated effluent is draining out directly into the river. Instead of taking corrective measures to improve the river’s health, the authorities are carrying out more concrete works on the riverbed,” Singh said.

Talking to reporters, Bhujbal said Nashik will fail to become a smart city if it did not pay attention to the important issue of cleanliness — including that of the river.

“I have told the officials to ensure that industrial effluents are not discharged into the river without treatment. The officials will face the consequences if they do not implement this rule,” he added.

The district guardian minister has also directed the officials to give him the details of the works done by various agencies to tackle river pollution. According to him, the authorities must stop all concrete construction on the river bed, which, he said, would be a death knell for the Godavari.

Bhujbal has cautioned contractors operating the sewage treatment plants to ensure that the plants operate smoothly. Or else, they would face action. “Our state government is committed to tackle the problem of pollution in different cities and it is working on it seriously,” he said.

The Bombay high court has directed the Nashik administration to deal with Godavari pollution after a city environmentalist, Rajesh Pandit, had filed a public interest litigation a few years back. Pandit, who accompanied Bhujbal and Singh, said the comments should be eye-openers for the officials.

Magsaysay awardee meets yatra participants

Rajendra Singh met with and greeted people taking part in the Aviral Nirmal Godavari Saksharta Yatra, which had kicked off three days ago from the origin point of the Godavari river at Brahmagiri in Trimbakeshwar. The yatra, organised by Namai Goda Foundation to reconnect the river with people, will culminate at the mouth of the river in Andhra Pradesh’s Rajahmundry.

Title: Why India lags in tackling online child sex abuse
Content:
Representative image

CHENNAI: The content on the dark web, the part of the internet not indexed by search engines and accessed through specific software, is truly a dark world — offensive, degrading and downright horrific. Navigating through it to access child pornography in anonymity is easy. But, so too is accessing such material on the open internet.Hundreds of groups thrive under the radar on WhatsApp, Facebook and Telegram, exchanging offensive visuals and pornography involving children, toddlers and even newborns. As India grapples with child sex abuse material ( CSAM ) invading digital platforms like never before, the enforcement authorities struggle with very little tools, skills or knowledge to track the criminals online.The sheer digital complexity of the crime requires support of global agencies. For instance, it was Interpol that recently flagged India’s high number of online offences. Strangely though, India is not a member of Virtual Global Taskforce yet. Nor is it a member of the WeProtect, a global alliance with heads of states as members to stop online child sexual abuse and exploitation.Though the country claims to have access to Interpol’s International Child Sexual Exploitation database, of late it depends heavily on US-based NCMEC (National Centre for Missing and Exploited Children) for alerts. Interpol’s database holds more than 1.5 million images and videos and has helped identify 19,400 victims worldwide. It is not clear though if CBI has access to this database.India has neither a ministry of internet safety and security nor eSafety commissioners — all essential to crack down on the offensive websites of dark operators steering a multi-million market that trades in children’s dignity. The ministries of home affairs, external affairs and women and child development coordinate for international cooperation in cracking child offensive sites and hunting down perpetrators of the crime, said Rakesh Maheshwari, group coordinator, (cyber laws and e-security) of the ministry of electronics and information technology. "We would definitely like to be a part of all these international groups. The ministries are working on it," said Maheshwari.Operating without international assistance could prove a tough battle in the cyber world. "The cyber space does not have boundaries. The offensive content can originate from any country," said Cyber Peace Foundation founder Vineet Kumar. "What’s missing is cooperation among countries, which is essential in cracking the crime," said Kumar. His foundation, a civil society organisation and a cyber security think tank, has been working on safety of children online. "It is not just the dark web. Children are stalked and trapped on surface webs," said Vineet.On January 12, an ad-hoc committee led by Congress MP Jairam Ramesh submitted a 21-page report with 40 recommendations on dealing with the ‘alarming issue of pornography on social media and its effect on children and society as a whole’. A suggestion was that Prime Minister Narendra Modi take the lead in building a global political alliance to combat child pornography on social media. "The committee is obviously not aware that other countries have long since been cognisant of the issue and taken multifarious initiatives in handling this complex crime. In fact, India is just playing catch-up game," said Vidya Reddy.The committee also failed to get consensus on a crucial recommendation on safeguards for minors engaged in sexting and selfies. "This was the only recommendation where we could not get an unequivocal view. So, we kept it open," said Ramesh. Some members felt the possession of all sexual material by minors must be banned outright and some felt that young adults between the age group of 16-19 should be covered under this exception. Some others opposed this ban. "The committee seems to be existing in a time warp, to conflate children watching porn with children used in creating sexual material. We are living in a sexualised world, not just online but in a real-time world too," said Vidya Reddy of Tulir, a Chennai-based Centre for the Prevention & Healing of Child Sexual Abuse.In all the rush of hi-tech tracking and trapping offenders, a crucial aspect of creating awareness among children and a specialised counselling of those who have been traumatised are yet to gain traction. "Teachers, parents and other stake holders should be roped in. Counselling should be high up on the agenda," said advocate and cyber victim counsellor Debarati Halder. A proactive approach that begins with providing programmes to prevent prospective offenders from committing a sexual offence against a child, is a step towards a safer environment.

Title: Two men arrested by Kochi police for raping a Thai woman
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative Image

Title: Madhya Pradesh may have NSA-type security adviser
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

BHOPAL: The Madhya Pradesh government plans to create a ‘state security adviser’ (SSA), on the lines of NSA. If approved, MP would be the second state in the country after west Bengal to have a special officer for ‘internal security’.

A presentation has been made before chief minister Kamal Nath on this, said sources. According to the proposal, the SSA would be a retired IPS officer who reports directly to the chief minister. He may have a term of three years, with provisions for further extension, sources said.

Perks and privileges would be equivalent to the highest post holders in terms of financial remuneration. Coordinating with NSA would be one of the key responsibilities of SSA, said an officer privy to this information. Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee had created such a post in 2018, giving the SSA sweeping powers over security and law enforcement agencies.

Current SSA of West Bengal is Surajit Kar Purkayastha – retired IPS officer of 1985 west Bengal cadre. Similarly, principal advisor (internal security) there is an MP cadre IPS officer, Rina Mitra , who retired on January 31, 2019. Though a strong case has been made before CM Nath for creating this post, a group of IAS officers in Madhya Pradesh has expressed displeasure, say sources. A senior officer said ‘internal security’ is the Centre’s affair, but state governments can create any post.

Title: Yesudas’s brother found dead in Kochi backwaters
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

KOCHI: K J Justin , who was found dead in the backwaters near Vallarpadam container terminal here on Wednesday was the youngest of the seven children of Kattassery Augustine Joseph and brother of K J Yesudas .

Justin, who is younger to Yesudas by 18 years, was not short on musical talents while he was young but it was never seen beyond stage programmes. “He was better known for his business skills and efficient management of overseas rights of all Tharangini albums,” said Shajan C Mathew , journalist and author of Ithihasa Gayakan, a book on life of Yesudas. According to people close to him, Justin’s business declined after he allegedly lost the rights to manage Tharangini albums. Last year he fell into severe depression after one of his sons committed suicide. Justin is survived by wife Gigi and a son.

The body was initially marked as unidentified but was later identified by brothers of Justin’s wife, Mulavukad police said. His kin had registered a man-missing complaint in Thrikkakkara police station on Wednesday.

Postmortem report concluded that the death was due to drowning and police suspect it to be suicide. “As per his relatives, Justin and family and had debts and the family was not in a position to repay them. He had been showing suicidal tendencies for the past week,” police said. tnn

Title: Under fire, NID to hold convocation at month-end?
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Ahmedabad: One day ahead of the scheduled date of the now cancelled 40th convocation of the National Institute of Design (NID), members of NID’s governing council met at the institute on Thursday. The meeting lasted a marathon five hours and also had participants join via teleconference.

Sources privy to the developments said the authorities seem to have caved to the pressure of angry students and other stakeholders, and have resolved to hold the convocation. The management was not forthcoming on a possible date though.

All eyes were on the council meeting, even as students from NID’s Bengaluru and Gandhinagar campuses arrived at the Ahmedabad campus, some with parents in tow. One faction of parents and students spoke to the NID director Praveen Nahar about the issue. The director, who has chosen to stay mum about the cancelled convocation, reportedly assured them that ‘the convocation will take place soon’. He reportedly said they are ‘hopeful of announcing the new date by next week’. The NID management continued to dodge mediapersons who tried to meet the director and members of the governing council on Thursday afternoon. Purandar Datta, head of communications and media relations (CMR) at NID, barred the entry of media citing the ‘ongoing meeting’ while refusing access to the director or council members.

“What is the secret NID is hiding? Has the institute cowed to political pressure while teaching students not to shy away from raising their voice in a democracy? The lack of transparency from such an iconic institute is disturbing ,” said a student on Thursday. Students, upset at the cancellation, spent most of the day debating the issue at impromptu meetings.

A few students rued that their parents, who had come to Ahmedabad for the convocation, will not be able to come back again even if the convocation is rescheduled. Meanwhile, mention of 40th convocation vanished from NID’s website. The website till Thursday morning mentioned the 40th Convocation to be held on February 7. The tab disappeared on Thursday.

Title: Hyderabad: Experts inspect Nehru Zoological Park
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

File photo of Nehru Zoological Park

Hyderabad: An evaluation team of the Central Zoo Authority (CZA) inspected the Nehru Zoological Park to prepare a plan and upgrade it to global standards.

Sources said that a committee constituted by CZA will also look into futuristic, technical, financial and scientific aspects while preparing the plan for 10 years.

Title: Muslims to stake claim on Babri mosque debris, set to move apex court
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

AYODHYA: Babri Masjid Action Committee will shortly move Supreme Court to stake claim on the debris of the demolished mosque before construction of the Ram Temple picks up pace by the newlyappointed trust.

Babri Masjid Action Committee convenor Zafaryab Jilani told TOI, “We have discussed with our counsel, Rajiv Dhawan, and he is also of the opinion that we must claim the Babri debris soon. The committee will hold a meeting in Delhi next week to hammer out the procedure for moving court. I have been assured by Muslim residents of Ayodhya that land will be arranged for dumping the debris.”

Chairman of the Babri Masjid cell in the All-India Muslim Personal Law Board, SQR Ilyas said, “We will move SC through our litigants in the Ayodhya title dispute and it’s important the mosque debris is removed before temple construction begins.”

Prominent Ayodhya cleric Sayyad Ekhlaq Ahmas confirmed that he has zeroed in on the land where the debris could be kept.Reacting to the claim of Muslims, Friend of Ram Lalla , Triloki Nath Pandey said, “We have no objection to the Muslims collecting the mosque debris. This will strengthen brotherhood and communal harmony.”

Title: Respect, don’t fear us, says transgender group
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Hindi Mahila Samiti organised a programme 'Kinnaro Ke Saath Ek Sham' and interaction, at Utkarsh Sabhagruha, V... Read More

Nagpur: The transgender community, which often doesn’t get opportunities to speak about its problems, on Wednesday shed light on the trials and tribulations faced by them. “All we ask of you is to respect us and not look at us with fear in your eyes,” pleaded a group of transgenders at an informal interaction organized by the Hindi Mahila Samiti.

The event ‘Kinnaro (transgenders) Ke Saath Kuch Pal’, was held at Mor Bhavan . Samiti president Rati Choubey said, “People look at the transgender community with a different perspective, often with disrespect. They have been existing for thousands of years and their existence is credited to Lord Shiva. There have been mentions of them in the Ramayana, Mahabharata, various Puranas and even the Kadambari. Still, they are ostracized by the society, kicked out of their own homes and left to fend for themselves.”

Choubey laid emphasis on the societal problems which arise due to such thinking. “It causes loneliness, feelings of abandonment and often gives rise to criminal behaviour and other anti-social elements,” she said.

The group of transgenders at the event included Meena Nair (Guruma), Zarina, Karishma, Kareena, Heena, Simran, Rakhi, Reshma and six-year-old Bulbul. They explained that when a family realizes that their child is possibly transgender, they give their children to the community. One of us was given away when she was barely two months old, they said.

One of them said, “We don’t miss our families. We have never even had a chance to see them. So, we don’t know what familial love feels like.”

When Choubey asked them whether they would like to find jobs, they replied in the negative. Still, some of us are trying to educate ourselves. We want to devote time to god and bring light into the world, they said.

Choubey pointed out that though the government had announced and recognized a third gender on April 15, 2014, the transgender community still faces a lot of persecution. She said, “They are ultimately humans with legitimate feelings. Until we improve our mindsets, the society will not improve either.”

The event was conceptualized by Choubey, working president Chitra Toor and Aisha Chatterjee. Joint secretary Neelam Shukla, vice-presidents Rekha Pandey and Sujata Dubey were also present.

Title: Centre: Assam was told to free non-Muslims from camps
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

GUWAHATI: Junior home minister Nityanand Rai told the LS that the Assam government had been advised to release all non-Muslims from Pakistan and Bangladesh - "who have been forced to seek shelter in the state before December 31, 2014, with expired or without valid documents" - from detention centres.

Rai said under the Citizenship (Amendment) Act, 2019, persons covered under this Act can submit applications for granting of citizenship after appropriate rules are notified by the Centre. He said the name "detention centre" has been changed to "holding centre". He said as per information from Assam government, 761 detainees were released from these centres in the last three years.

Replying to a query by Assam Congress MP Abdul Khaleque whether the government had taken any initiative to release those declared foreigners belonging to Hindu, Sikh, Parsi, Buddhist, Christian and Jain communities residing in detention camps, Rai on Tuesday said, "No specific instruction has been issued by the central government regarding the release of such migrants from detention centres after enacting the CAA ."

"However, in January, 2016, the Centre had advised Assam to examine the cases of all persons covered by various court cases filed in Gauhati HC and release them from detention centres if they satisfy the conditions and requirements of the two notifications issued by the central government on September 7, 2015, exempting such persons by or under clause (c) of sub-section (2) of Section 3 of the Passport (Entry into India) Act, 1920 or from the application of the provisions of the Foreigners Act, 1946 or any rule or order made thereunder," Rai added.

Rai said that the apex court had also issued a notification in July last, providing for conditional release of declared foreigners, who have completed more than three years in detention centres.

Title: Mundhe wields the stick, asks NMC staff to fall in line
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nagpur: With a view to improve work culture in the Nagpur Municipal Corporation, municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe issued few more circulars instructing civic employees to follow the same strictly else face action.

On Thursday, Mundhe issued four circulars prohibiting display of posters on walls, work tables and work stations of employees. One of the circulars also instructed NMC officials and employees that “henceforth they cannot leave the city (headquarters) without permission even on public holidays”.

Some of the other instructions include: salary cut for any unapproved leave, a day’s salary cut for reporting late three days a month, mandatory use of e-governance system for officers and employees, all employees having to share work-related necessary information with department heads and administrative action in case of misconduct by officers and employees.

Mundhe has ordered that employees adhere to punctuality and directed the general administration department to release salary only after going through biometric reports of staff attendance.

Meanwhile, Mundhe directed the health (sanitation) department not to lift unsegregated wet and dry garbage from citizens with immediate effect. Though it is mandatory to lift and transfer segregated garbage to Bhandewadi dumping yard, both the firms engaged for garbage collection are allegedly mixing the waste at transfer stations.

Title: Congress: PM Modi misleading House to justify CAA
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

NEW DELHI: Congress on Thursday said the Nehru-Liaquat agreement of 1950 explicitly mentioned that citizenship would be religion-neutral as it accused Prime Minister Narendra Modi of misleading the house to justify the controversial CAA .

Congress slammed Modi's speech in Lok Sabha as "oscillating between stand-up comedy, half-truths and rank communalism". AICC leader Rahul Gandhi accused the PM of distracting the country by talking about everything except youth unemployment.

After Modi quoted first premier Jawaharlal Nehru's pact with Pakistan and his communications with Assam 's first chief minister to say that Nehru too wanted citizenship for minorities, AICC spokesman Manish Tewari slammed him for selectively quoting "his illustrious predecessor" and demanded that he apologise to the country. Congress said Modi had compromised national pride by mentioning Pakistan seven times in his speech and undoing the success of UPA regime in de-hyphenating India and Pakistan.

Title: Anjuman-e-Islam’s protest against CAA, NRC enters 12th day
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Hubballi: The protest against the controversial Citizenship Amendment Act (CAA) and the National Register of Citizens ( NRC ) spearheaded by Anjuman-e-Islam, Hubballi entered its 12th day on Thursday.

The protesters have been sitting in a dharna in front of the Mini Vidhana Soudha for four days a week, urging the central government to repeal CAA and NRC. Former corporator of the Hubballi-Dharwad Municipal Corporation (HDMC) and vice-president of Anjuman-e-Islam Altaf Nawaz Kittur said that their protest would continue till the Centre yielded to their request. “CAA and NRC are anti-constitutional and they attempt to divide society on the lines of religion. These laws threaten the communal harmony of Indian society,” Kittur told TOI.

Pointing out that residents from across the twin cities had been participating in the protest, he added, “So far, people from nearly 60 localities have participated in the protest, and will only intensify in the coming days. We are expecting more people to join the protest.” he

Mohammad Yusuf Savnur, president of Anjuman-e-Islam, MA Pathan, AM Hindasgiri, SIkandar Basha, Syed Ahmed Sargiro, Khawaja Mainodin Maniyar, Fazlu Kalebudde, Munna Marker and Ashfaq Kumtakar were among those who participated in the protest on Thursday.

Title: Gardens, greenery make Muktidham in Gadag a one-of-its-kind graveyard
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Gadag: Tourists visiting Gadag usually have these places on their itinerary — Bhishma Lake, Veereshwar Punyashram, ancient temples of Veeranarayan and Trikuteshwar and Binkadakatti Zoo. Now, ‘Muktidham’ is added to the must-visit places, thanks to the efforts of locals and government departments. Muktidham in Betgeri is a cemetery involving Hindu and Muslim graveyards.

Due to its greenery and sustained development, Muktidham has been drawing the attention of environmentalists. What otherwise is meant for graveyards has now turned into a garden for morning and evening walkers and joggers. It is also a favourite spot for children to play, and for elders to catch up. The 22acre cemetery has three lakes, as many borewells, ‘Gourav Ghataka’ and hi-tech washrooms where the visitors can take bath after attending the last rites. It also has an open garden where condolence meetings and national festivals like Indepence Day and Republic Day are celebrated. Martyr Memorial reminds one about the contributions of freedom fighters and the valour of soldiers.

Ganesh Singh Byali, president of Betgeri Muktidham Samiti, said the idea of developing the cemetery was pitched some five years ago to bust myths and fear about graveyards. “The cemetery is unique for the fact that its 18acre accommodates graves for 24 castes of Hindu religion, and 4acre for Muslims. When we approached then district minister H K Patil with the idea of developing it as a garden, he instructed Gadag district administration, Gadag-Betgeri City Municipal Council (GBCMC), Nirmiti Kendra and other government agencies to assist the project. It’s been developed at a cost of Rs 4.50 crore over the last 4-5 years,” he explained.

Samiti member Mohammad Shalgar said Muktidham has a broad message to convey that one will go to soil irrespective of religion and caste. While the last rites are performed, ‘Raghupati Raghav Rajaram’ is played on the 10 speakers put up at different places in the graveyard . “The tranquil and green atmosphere helps console bereaved families. They can also take bath in hitech washrooms. There is a provision to conduct condolence meetings at the garden,” he added.

Advocate William Gundi, a local, said apart from government help, many citizens are contributing for the development and maintenance of Muktidham. “Myself and my wife Sudha involve in gardening activities daily. This gives us immense satisfaction,” he shared.

Title: Flood results in extensive damage to chilli crop in Dharwad, Gadag
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Hubballi: Unseasonal rain and floods having ravaged nearly two-thirds of the area under chilli cultivation, the price of dry chilli has skyrocketed in the retail market, much to the displeasure of the customers. Data from the horticulture department indicates that, of the 27,000 hectares used for cultivation of chilli across Dharwad district, floods damaged crops across 18,500 hectares.

Neighbouring Gadag district, also renowned for cultivation of chilli, has been adversely affected owing to torrential rain. Of the 13,120 hectares used for sowing of chilli in the district, crops across 11,171 hectares have been destroyed. Fortunately, damage to chilli crop was minimal in Haveri district – crops across 3,130 hectares of the 13,039 hectares used for its cultivation were destroyed.

Managing director of the Karnataka State Spices Development Board Manjunath Narayanpur said that the four districts accounted for a king’s share of the chilli crop grown in the state. “The area we targetted came up to around 1.3 lakh hectares, but the yield was much below our expectations owing to the flood,” Narayanpur said.

He added that the board was keen on promoting the cultivation of spices among farmers, given its profitability. “We are encouraging more ryots to take up cultivation of chilli, and various measures are being taken to increase its production,” said Narayanpur.
