The spice board chief said that, in a bid to bridge the gap between the farmers and the customers and to provide a platform, wherein ryots could directly market their produce, a three-day chilli mela was being held in Dharwad starting from Saturday. “The mela is being held by the board in association with the Karnataka Chamber of Commerce and Industries, Agriculture Produce Market Committee, Hubballi and the horticulture department. The mela will be held on the premises of the Moorusavir Math,” said Narayanpur.

Pointing out that this was the tenth edition of the mela, Narayanpur added that nearly 110 stalls would be erected at the venue for farmers. “We will also have stalls for those merchants to market agro-based chilli products,” said Narayanpur, adding that nearly 120 farmers from across North Karnataka had participated in the last edition of the mela, wherein 45 tonnes of dry chilli cumulatively worth Rs 65 lakh had been sold.

Narayanpur said that a national-level enclave would be held in the second week of March, the focus of which would be on taking measures to create awareness on food safety and increase the quantity of dry chilli that can be exported.

The board’s general manager Chidanandappa, deputy director of the horticulture department Ramachandra Madivalar and Karnataka Chamber of Commerce and Industries member BB Patil were among present at the conference.

Title: Officials pin hopes on new taxiway to increase traffic at Vizag airport
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: With the airport traffic in Visakhapatnam airport coming down following the withdrawal of a number of airlines, airport officials believe that the commissioning of an N5 taxi track will lead to an increase in the number of flight movements.

The annual traffic handled by the Visakhapatnam airport has come down, according to statistics obtained from the Airports Authority of India. The number of aircraft movements saw a decrease with the withdrawal of a number of airlines including Jet Air, Alliance Air, Thai Air Asia and SriLankan Airlines.

The number of domestic aircraft movements up to December 2019 was 12,788, a significant drop from 22,376 movements in 2018-19. The number of international aircraft movements came down to 1,202 from 1,806 in the same time period.

Passenger occupancy in the domestic sector up to December 2019 was 17,22,387, a steep fall from 27,03,261 in 2018-19. Passenger occupancy dropped in the international sector as well, from 1,50,370 in 2018-19 to 96,561 till December 19.

Speaking to TOI, director of Visakhapatnam airport Raja Kishore said, “After the withdrawal of JetAir and other flights, aircraft movements per day came down from 80 to 60. This means that 24% traffic had come down and showed a decline in passenger occupancy.”

“There was a steep decline in passenger occupancy last year. However, we are bridging the gap with other flight operators which will increase connectivity from Visakhapatnam,” added Kishore.

The airport director further said that considering runaway limitations for operating civilian flights, the N5 taxi track will be commissioned in the airport soon. According to Kishore, the new taxi track will facilitate an increased number of flight movements.

“The commissioning of N5 taxi track is an operational solution and will increase flexibility in enhancing traffic movement,” said the airport director while adding that traffic at Visakhapatnam international airport will increase once the number of slots for operating civilian flights is increased. “We expect the number of flights to go from 75 now to 100,” he added.

Dr K Kumar Raja, vice-president of Andhra Pradesh Air Travellers’ Association (APATA) said, “Although there is good demand in Visakhapatnam, operations are limited due to a few restrictions. However, with the new taxi track and expansion of the terminal building, we expect aircraft movements and passenger occupancy to rise in the next financial year.”

“There is a demand for additional movements from flight operators. Addition of international flights is in the pipeline. We have already held discussions with SpiceJet to operate a few more domestic flights to destinations like Bhubaneswar, Nagpur, Chennai and Mumbai. SpiceJet is also waiting for approval to operate its first cargo flight from Visakhapatnam,” added Kumar.

Title: Lawyers demand setting up of CAT, SHRC in Port City
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: Andhra Pradesh does not have a Central Administrative Tribunal ( CAT ) office nor a State Human Rights Commission ( SHRC ) within its jurisdiction.

Both are still functional from the Hyderabad bench. With the city slated to become the executive capital in future, advocates want that these offices be set up in Visakhapatnam as all major central government offices are located here.

The Central Administrative Tribunal was established under Article 323(A) of the Constitution for adjudication of disputes and complaints with respect to recruitment and conditions of service of persons appointed to public services and posts under the Union government.

All metro cities and most state capitals have a CAT bench, which deals with disputes related to salaries, promotions, pension issues and arrears.

Senior advocate and president of Forum of Legal Professionals, Kuppili Muralidhar told TOI, “There are around 50 central government offices in the city and employees must be over a lakh. Thousands of central government employees work in key establishments such as the steel plant, shipping and port trust, HSL, DCIL, railways, airport, customs, excise, HPCL, insurance offices like LIC, science laboratories like NIO, CMFRI, CIFT and various public sector units. For settling disputes, they have to travel to Hyderabad, where the bench consists of a judicial member, mostly a retired high court judge and one administrative member like a retired IAS officer. Often, these posts are vacant and cases are pending for years.”

“It is high time that AP should have its own CAT, preferably in Visakhapatnam, which is slated to be the executive capital and has the highest number of central government employees in the state. Similarly, the SHRC should also be established in the state comprising a judge and members from the field of law and vacancies should be filled up immediately to address cases,” Muralidhar added.

Title: Andhra Pradesh faces shortage of 58 IAS officers
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

VISAKHAPATNAM: As many as 58 IAS officers posts are vacant in Andhra Pradesh , Jitendra Singh, minister of state for personnel and public grievances, informed the Rajya Sabha on Thursday, in reply to a query by YSRC MP Vijayasai Reddy. The total authorised strength of IAS officers in AP through direct recruitment and promotion is 239. But as on January 1, 2019, the total strength of AP cadre officers was 181.

The minister said this is an ongoing process and vacancies are progressively filled up either through direct recruitment, or through promotion/selection from the state cadre.

“Twelve IAS officers, including six through direct recruitment, were given AP cadre in 2017, while 21 officers, including 12 direct recruitments and nine promotees, were inducted in 2018. In 2019, 17 officers, including 11 direct recruitments and six promotees, got postings in AP,” the minister said. tnn

Title: Visakhapatnam: Video of teacher beating up two students goes viral
Content:
The incident had taken place a few days ago but came to light on Wednesday night

VISAKHAPATNAM: A video showing the head teacher of a private school beating up two of his students led to a case being registered against the teacher on Thursday. The teacher is alleged to have subjected the students to corporal punishment .The incident had taken place a few days ago, but came to light on Wednesday night, when a student of the school who had taken a video of the incident posted it on WhatsApp groups and the video went viral.Visakhapatnam district education officer (DEO) B Lingeswara Reddy visited the school in Anakapalle on Thursday and interacted with students and teachers of the school. He said that the head teacher of the school, K Seshagiri Rao, had beaten two class 10 students for allegedly not performing well in academics.On the basis of Reddy’s complaint, police have registered a case against Seshagiri Rao under relevant sections of the IPC. The school management has suspended the teacher.The DEO also issued a circular to managements of all private schools in Visakhapatnam district to initiate action against teachers who indulge in corporal punishments. Reddy said that teachers do not have the right to beat up students under pretexts like students not doing homework or performing poorly in academics.The child rights protection forum and other child rights groups condemned the incident and demanded action against the school management.In Video: On cam: Teacher thrashes 2 students in Visakhapatnam

Title: Girl’s burn injuries due to suicide attempt: Cops
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

VISAKHAPATNAM: Mystery shrouds the attack on a Class VII girl of a private school in Rajam of Srikakulam district who has been battling for life on sustaining 80 per cent burns.

Police officers TOI spoke to said they were on the verge of ruling out that it was an attack as the girl alleges because they were “unable to find any evidence” suggesting it was. Police suspect the girl attempted suicide.

The 14-year-old suffered burns near her home in Rajam on January 28 evening after she was allegedly doused with petrol and torched by the two youngsters.

Speaking to TOI, inspector of Rajam Police Station, GS Sekhar said their investigation had ended with no clues coming their way suggesting the incident was an attack. Though we kept quizzing a few persons, we have no leads. “The victim has given different versions to her family members after the incident. The girl initially said two youngsters torched her and later claimed that a senior student was involved in the crime. We have investigated the case from all the possible angles, but it is difficult to establish the girl’s version as the senior student is innocent in the case and the role of suspected persons hasn’t been proved,” Sekhar added. A senior police officer said that a student of the school had rejected the girl’s proposal and the girl was admonished by her teachers and mother after the boy informed the school’s management about what had happened. “The case has turned into a challenge for us, we are looking at all possible angles,” Sekhar said.

The girl has been undergoing treatment in a corporate hospital in Vizag city, where her condition is said to be critical.

Title: Electronics dealer asked to compensate customer
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Visakhapatnam: The consumer disputes redressal forum, Vizag-I has asked a leading electronic goods dealer and a manufacturer to refund the purchase price of a refrigerator— Rs 22,900 with interest to a consumer from the city. The forum has further asked the two firms to pay Rs 5,000 as compensation and another Rs 5,000 as legal costs.

R Anil Kumar, a resident of Simhadripuram in Visakhapatnam had purchased a refrigerator on November 20, 2017 from this retailer for Rs 22,900. The refrigerator came with a one-year warranty along with four years of additional warranty on the compressor of the refrigerator.

Within eight months, Kumar noticed that fruits and vegetables placed in the refrigerator were decomposing. Kumar lodged a complaint with the service centre associated with the dealership and the service engineers temporarily fixed the problem. However, a few days later, the problem recurred. So Kumar contacted the manufacturer’s service centre whose engineers too came in to fix the problem, but even their fix was temporary.

Exasperated, Kumar finally approached the consumer disputes redressal forum and lodged a complaint. At the hearing, the manufacturing firm entered a counter petition wherein it said that the customer had failed to follow procedure and was unaware of the workings of the refrigerator.

The forum, led by D Leelavathi (president) and KVR Maheswari dismissed the counter petition and observed that the manufacturer and dealer are ‘severally and jointly liable to return the purchase price’. The forum directed both firms to refund the purchase price of Rs 22,900 with 9 per cent interest, pay Rs 5,000 as compensation and an additional Rs 5,000 as legal costs.

Title: Mumbai cabbie drives Jaipur’s ‘anti-national’ poet to police station
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Bappaditya Sarkar at the Mumbai Bagh

MUMBAI: An Uber driver dragged a 23-year-old scarf-clad poet Bappaditya Sarkar, in Mumbai for the ongoing Kala Ghoda Festival and carrying a dafli, to Santacruz police station on Wednesday night as he suspected him to be a communist and a "danger to the country".

The police questioned both the driver and Sarkar, but did not initiate any further proceedings after finding no substance in the complaint. Santacruz senior inspector Shriram Koregaonkar declined to comment and said that no case had been registered.

At around 10.50pm, Jaipur-based Sarkar hailed the cab for a ride from Silver Beach in Juhu to Kurla where he was staying with a friend. "Twenty minutes into the ride, the driver, Rohit Singh, said that he needed to withdraw money. He reappeared within a few minutes with two police officers. I figured later that he had parked outside Santacruz police station," Sarkar told TOI on Thursday evening.

Sarkar, who had arrived in Mumbai on February 3 for a poetry reading session at the Kala Ghoda Festival, had also taken time out to participate in the ongoing protests at Mumbai Bagh, an anti-CAA gathering near Mumbai Central, inspired by Delhi's Shaheen Bagh. "I had been a part of the protests in Jaipur and wanted to do the same in Mumbai, but the taxi driver's reaction had nothing to do with that," said Sarkar, recounting his conversation on the phone with a friend in Jaipur during his cab ride that led to the fracas.

Title: 13-member board of Prasar Bharati stares at record 9 vacancies
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

NEW DELHI: Come February 8, Prasar Bharati , India’s public broadcaster, will have an unprecedented nine vacancies on its 13-member board, which is the key body entrusted with taking all decisions related to the general superintendence, direction and management of the affairs of the pubcaster.

The board, headed by the chairman, comprises one executive member who is the pubcaster’s CEO, a member finance, a member personnel, six part-time members, a representative of the ministry of information and broadcasting and director generals of All India Radio and Doordarshan as ex-officio members.

While Prasar Bharati’s incumbent chairman, A Surya Prakash , is set to retire on February 8, the posts of director generals of Doordarshan and AIR have been lying vacant since their last incumbents, Supriya Sahu and Shehryar, superannuated, respectively. Of the six part-time members of the board, only one is currently occupied by film actor Kajol.

Even the position of member personnel is currently vacant. Effective this week, the Prasar Bharati board will only have four members — its CEO Shashi Shekhar Vempati, member finance Rajeev Singh, I&B ministry’s nominee, Ali Rizvi, and part-time member Kajol.

While the pubcaster has already advertised vacancies for the posts of director generals of AIR and Doordarshan, finding a replacement for Prakash is unlikely soon.

Title: Mumbai: Lift technician dies in mishap at highrise
Content:
Sanjay Yadav

New PMGP Society in Mulund

Two technicians detained for Mulund lift death

MUMBAI: A 40-year-old lift technician , Sanjay Yadav , carrying out repairs on the 3rd floor of a housing complex in Mulund (E), died after it was accidentally started on Thursday morning and he got crushed between the lift and side wall.A resident of Vasai, the technician with Omega Lift Services was working above the lift with two others inside it around 11.40am at New PMGP Society after residents complained that the lift in a wing was not working properly and stopping intermittently, the Navghar police said, adding he died on the spot.Lack of staff and an independent charter of electrical auditors to certify the condition of lifts and ensure their timely maintenance has left no scope to hold the guilty accountable in lift/elevator mishaps in the state. Sanjay Yadav (40), a lift technician, died after it accidentally started in Mulund (E) on Thursday.“Other than appointing third party electricity and lift auditors to certify and monitor lifts, training lift operators, holding lift safety sessions should have been made compulsorily for residents along with fire safety. A proposal has been pending since the Mantralaya fire,” said a senior department engineer, pointing out that even the Centre had adopted the auditor policy. Sources said 40 major districts need electrical inspectors with support staff, but out of 500 posts, nearly 400 are vacant.Deepak Bobhate, a resident of the Mulund building said, “The lift was automatically stopping at the 7th and 15th floors due to shoddy work by the builder and poor maintenance. Two society members explained the problem to the technician. Yadav was doing some work above it, while his colleagues were inside, when someone on the 13th floor suddenly pressed the button, and it started, crushing him.”Residents alerted the fire brigade and Navghar police. Yadav was taken to Mulund general hospital, where he was declared dead before admission. Police said they were registering an accidental death report and are probing if it was a case of negligence.“We will find out if Omega employees took proper safety measures or there was negligence, and how the lift started moving when it was being repaired,” said a police officer. Police detained two other technicians for questioning. Omega officials said they do not know how the accident occurred as their employees were detained.Residents said the builder, who was not available for comment, should be booked for violations and negligence.

Title: Emami sells cement business to Nirma company NVC
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

(Representative image)

KOLKATA: City-based Emami Group has sold its cement business under Emami Cement to Nirma Group firm Nuvoco Vistas Corporation ( NVC ) in order cut group-level debt and pledged shares. More than 71% of promoters’ holding in Emami, the flagship of the diversified conglomerate, is now being pledged as per the latest filing in stock exchanges. Emami Group has said that it has divested 100% equity stake in Emami Cement for an enterprise value of Rs 5,500 crore.

Top officials of the group said that Rs 3,000 crore will be utilised to make Emami Cement debt-free and the remaining Rs 2,500 crore will be used to pare group-level debt and share pledge. Following this, the total debt will go down to Rs 600 crore from Rs 3,100 crore.

Emami Group promoters have divested 10% each in two tranches in the last one year to reduce debt. In the first tranche, promoters’ holding was reduced to a little over 62% from 72% in flagship Emami for Rs 1,600 crore to reduce debt at the owners’ level in early 2019. Later on, it was further reduced to 52.7%. At the current prices, the value of promoters’ stake in Emami would be around Rs 7,000 crore.

Emami scrip in the stock exchanges on Thursday dipped 1.3% to Rs 302.9 on Thursday. Emami Cement operates one integrated cement plant and three grinding units with a total cement grinding capacity of around 8.3 million tonne per annum. The company has a turnover of Rs 2,500 crore and is in a cash-positive zone. The acquisition will bring its total cement capacity of Nuvoco in eastern, northern and western India to 23.5 million tonne (which includes the ongoing capacity expansion project in its Jojobera plant) and over 60 ready-mix plants.

Hiren Patel, chairman, Nuvoco, said: “This acquisition is a momentous and transformational step in Nuvoco’s journey to becoming a major building materials company in India.”

Aditya Agarwal, director, Emami Group, said: “We are very proud of Emami Cement, which has achieved significant milestones in a very short span of time. It has successfully established a very strong brand equity in the market for its highest standard of operation and high-quality products, helping us get a good value. The Nuvoco and Nirma Group will continue from here and strengthen the business further.”

Commenting on the deal, Manish Goenka, director, Emami Group, added that this transaction is an important step in the Group’s stated objective of becoming debt-free. “With this transaction, we will substantially achieve this objective,” he said.

Shardul Amarchand Mangaldas acted as the legal advisor for the deal while Deloitte Touche Tohamatsu India LLP was the financial diligence advisor and Arpwood Capital the financial advisor.

Title: Does traffic noise hit health?
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nagpur: In a first for the city, an in-depth scientific study to assess the health effects of vehicular noise pollution is being carried out at ten locations.

After conducting noise mapping in 27 cities of the state, the National Environmental Engineering Research Institute (Neeri) and the Maharashtra Pollution Control Board (MPCB) have initiated the study to monitor and assess noise pollution with respect to number of vehicles, frequency of honking and speed.

The locations are Itwari, Dharampeth, Sitabuldi, Indora Square, Trimurti Nagar, Hasanbagh Road, Wardha Road, Rameshwari Road, Vitthal Nagar (near Manewada) and Dattatrey Nagar.

According to the scientists, the ten locations were selected based on the findings of noise mapping. “In Nagpur, we had monitored decibel levels at around 55 locations out of which, these ten turned out to be the noisiest,” said Ritesh Vijay, principal scientist and head of Mumbai zonal centre, adding that the study kick-started in the first week of January.

The locations include commercial areas, residential areas and major and minor roads. At each location, the monitoring is being done for 48 hours — 24 working hours and 24 non-working hours (Saturday and Sunday). “For one location, we are recording 1.72 lakh readings,” said Vijay.

Highlighting the aim of the research, the scientist stated that the focus will be on quantifying the level of decibels with vehicular traffic. “After we completed the noise mapping, the Bombay bench of high court further directed to conduct a more in-depth study to know the impact of traffic noise on human health. In this study, we are specifically quantifying the pollution in terms of noise emitted from honking and different vehicles with different speed,” said Vijay.

A similar study was carried out in Mumbai at 15 locations. The decibel levels have been recorded and are being analysed now.

In March 2017, TOI had reported about noise mapping study which was conducted in Nagpur, Amravati, Akola and Chandrapur. While hearing a public interest litigation on breach of noise pollution norms, the Bombay high court had asked the state government to file a detailed reply following which the agencies had proposed the idea of statewide noise mapping.

Recently, Neeri completed the country’s first noise pollution monitoring using bicycles. Launched in 10 cities of the state, the study focused on “real-time mapping”. Nagpur’s monitoring revealed that noise pollution levels were breaching the permissible decibel marks all across the city.

NOISE MAP

In-depth scientific study to assess health impact of vehicular noise pollution

Being conducted at 10 noisiest locations in the city

Monitoring being done for 48 hours — 24 working and 24 non-working

For every location, 1.72 lakh readings being monitored and analysed

Similar study done in Mumbai

Title: Deposit Rs 1.25L to prove bona fides, HC tells 5 petitioners
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur bench of Bombay high court on Wednesday directed five petitioners to deposit Rs 1.25 lakh with its registry to prove their bona fides , before hearing a case filed by them.

A division bench comprising Justice Ravi Deshpande and Justice Amit Borkar also issued notices to respondents, including Chandrapur collector, to file reply by next week.

The petitioners have opposed use of school ground in Chimur town of Chandrapur district for holding popular ‘Ghoda Yatra Utsav 2020’ and ‘Meena Bazaar’ from January 30 to February 21. The area belongs to Nehru Vidyalaya and Junior College run by Chimur Education Society.

Even as the petitioners have moved court, the yatra has begun there.

According to petitioners Nilam Rachalwar, Dharamsingh Varma, Yogesh Thune, Amol Junghare and Amit Dhobale, the playground cannot be used for commercial or religious purposes, but the school authorities have rented it out for the festival for Rs 12.50 lakh, that too during the peak exam period.

The petitioners also contended that the event would be lasting for 23 days and after that it would take a couple of days to clean the ground. Moreover, preparations for organizing the event had started about a month back, thus deprived students of sporting activities for over a month.

The judges, while orally questioning the petitioners’ motive behind filing the plea, asked them to shell out the amount if they want the court to hear their case. They further asked all five petitioners, who were present during the hearing, whether they were representing parents/students, as no complaint came from their side. Though the petitioners expressed inability to deposit the amount, the court asked them to complete the formalities before next hearing.

Title: Standing panel nod to Rs 68 crore works
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Nagpur: The Nagpur Municipal Corporation’s (NMC) poor fiscal health notwithstanding, the standing committee led by chairman Pradip Pohane on Thursday approved issuance of work orders and administrative approval to projects worth Rs61.36 crore and Rs7.05 crore.

Many corporators, including standing committee members, complained about civic administration not issuing work orders to contractors citing fund crunch.

Pohane too admitted that many corporators have been approaching him since January stating that work orders issued by the standing panel were not being executed by the civic administration.

Congress corporator and standing committee member Harshala Sable said that despite the panel’s nod, the civic administration is yet to issue work order for many important works in her prabhag.

Pohane said the proposals being given approval by the standing committee were already mentioned in his budget for 2019-2020. So far, no proposal outside his budget has been given approval, he said.

On Thursday, the panel gave its nod to the project department’s proposal to a housing scheme for economically weaker section (EWS) near Jaitala Square on Orange City Street.

With the standing panel’s nod, the department will now entrust the work to construct eight buildings comprising ground-plus six floors in each apartment at a cost of Rs56.57 crore to a private firm.

Pohane claimed that the work orders of proposals of various development works given nod by his committee will be executed by the NMC. He said though the NMC’s financial condition is not better, it will improve this month with the recovery of property tax.

Sources said new municipal commissioner Tukaram Mundhe took objection over budgetary provision of Rs50 lakh for Baisakh festival to be celebrated in next financial year. TOI had highlighted that despite reeling under financial crisis, the NMC was wasting taxpayers’ money on needless events.

Title: CBI arrests govt official for bribery
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Representative image

NEW DELHI: CBI on Thursday arrested a Delhi government official in a case of alleged corruption bribery .

The suspect, Gopal Krishna Madhav , is learnt to be a DANICS (subordinate services) cadre official who was reportedly attached with deputy CM Manish Sisodia ’s office, sources said.

While officials remained tight-lipped on the details, sources said that Madhav was allegedly caught red handed while accepting a bribe of Rs 2 lakh. He was being probed in a case of GST evasion, the source said.

Title: Use jhatka to deal with wild animals: Pravin Togadia
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Pravin Togadia interacts with journalists in Nagpur

NAGPUR: Pravin Togadia , former president of Vishwa Hindu Parishad (VHP) and now a vocal critic of Prime Minister Narendra Modi, has raised the cause of wild animal menace in agricultural land as he also called for a law to promote birth control in the country.

“One of the biggest problems dogging the country’s farmers is infestation of the fields by wild animals like deer, boar and neelgai (blue bull), to even lions in my home state of Gujarat. I have come up with a mechanism of scaring away the animals with low voltage AC current, in wires charged with solar power,” he said during his visit to Nagpur.

“Called Jhatka, I have been propagating method in different states of the country. Lately, I met Madhya Pradesh chief minister Kamal Nath over the issue,” said Togadia who was once the Hindutva poster boy of Sangh Parivar and has now distanced himself from the organization.

The animal need not step over the wire and the shock can be felt even by passing over it.

“I also plan to initiate a drive pressing for a law that will deny government benefits to a couple having more than two children,” he told TOI.

Togadia expressed his disappointment over the selections of members for the Ram Mandir trust. Except Vasudevanand Saraswati, only the loyalists of PM Narendra Modi have been included in the trust, instead of those who actually took part in the Ram Jamanbhoomi movement,” he said.

He said the economy is getting worse and the Modi government has failed to address the issue. The banks are ridden with NPAs and twice the government has dipped into the reserves.

Title: Thane: Strangled man’s body found in suitcase
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The suitcase with Umesh Patil’s body was dumped near the tracks

THANE: Thane police anti-extortion cell arrested a 27-year-old man for allegedly strangling a 56-year-old man, putting his body in a suitcase and dumping it near railway tracks, in Dombivli. The case was cracked nine hours after the body was found in Bavanchal.

The accused, Praful Pawar, is a tourist car operator from Dombivli, said senior inspector (anti-extortion cell) Rajkumar Kothmire, adding that the victim, Umesh Patil, was a Kopri resident who was an assistant accountant with the debt redressal tribunal office, Navi Mumbai.

The officer said Pawar got acquainted with Patil six months back. “The victim used to visit the house of the accused, who was not married, and both were believed to be in an intimate relationship,” Kothmire said. The accused married few months back and things soured between the duo, as the accused started “avoiding” him. Upset over that, Patil visited Pawar’s house in Dombivli, when his wife had gone to office.

“Both fought over the issue and the accused, in a fit of rage, strangled the victim, after he threatened to reveal their relationship to his wife. He packed his body in a suitcase and dumped it in bushes near the tracks. It was found on Thursday morning by passers-by,” police said.

A team led by Kothmire started a probe and on carrying out an “in-depth technical analysis” zeroed in on the accused, who was arrested at 6pm on Thursday. Police said that in 2013 a case of attempt to murder had been registered against Pawar with Vishnu Nagar police station, details of which are being gathered.

In the last few months, many killings have been reported in Mumbai and Thane district, where bodies have been dumped in suitcases. On December 4, 2019, the body of guitarist Bennett Rebello (59) was found stuffed in suitcases.

Title: Maharashtra: Bandh, rallies seek justice for Ankita
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

WARDHA/NAGPUR: Spontaneous shutdown was observed in the city on Thursday demanding capital punishment for Vikesh Nagrale, who had set on fire 25-year-old college teacher Ankita Pisudde in Hinganghat on Monday.

Protest rallies were also taken out at Deoli, Selu, Karanja, Samudrapur and Alipur in the district in which thousands participated to condemn the dastardly incident. Meanwhile, Ankita’s health continues to be critical though she is responding to treatment, said a press release by Orange City Hospital and Research Institute in Nagpur where she has been admitted with 35-40% burns.

At Wardha , all commercial establishments remained closed throughout the day. Demanding death penalty for the accused, the protesters took out a rally from Shivaji Square. The rally later culminated at Ambedkar Square near collector’s office and a memorandum demanding fast track justice to the victim was submitted to SDO Suresh Bagale.

Heavy police bandobast was deployed in the city in view of the public outcry over the incident. Congress women’s wing state president Charulata Tokas has written a letter to CM Uddhav Thackeray demanding laws for giving only death penalty for culprits of such heinous crimes.

At OCHRI, two sessions of debridement along with burns dressing and upper limb multiple fasciotomy has been done on Ankita, said sources. On Thursday, the doctors had noticed some fluctuations in blood pressure and heartbeats of Ankita for which she was administered medicine. She will undergo operation for burns dressing on Friday again.

Former CM Devendra Fadnavis, women and child development minister Yashomati Thakur and MoS for water resources and school education Bacchu Kadu visited the hospital to enquire about Ankita’s health.

Title: Maruti Suzuki set to review car prices in April
Content:
(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: Maruti Suzuki India (MSIL) will review the car price in April 2020 once the BSVI emission and revised safety norms kick in. The company had only a week ago announced a price hike up to 4.7% on select models due to an increase in the input costs.Speaking to TOI on Thursday, MSIL managing director & CEO Kenichi Ayukawa admitted margins were under pressure due to various cost hikes in recent months to conform to the regulatory requirements.“The cost of production has gone up. Customers are already impacted by the hike in third party insurance outgo and road tax hikes that some state government have announced. We do not wish to burden the customers further and have tried to absorb as much of the impact as we can. But given the recent hike in duty announced on palladium, a key input in manufacture of catalytic converters require for cars to meet the new emission norms, is a worry. We will undertake a comprehensive review of prices before taking a call on a hike,” said Ayukawa.According to the industry, cost of buying a car had increase by 6-14% in the past year and a half. This includes insurance and finance cost.Conscious that a price revision would adversely impact sales in the price-sensitive market at a time when sales industry-wide has been on a downward curve, Ayukawa hoped the government would review the duty hike on palladium that was not available in a India. “We as a company have a mission: to provide affordable cars to Indian customers. If we can increase volumes, I believe we can absorb the cost,” he said.On products being introduced from the Toyota stable, Ayukawa said it was likely to be a sedan but not one that was already in Toyota India’s portfolio. He further confirmed that Toyota was likely to introduce the Brezza, the second product from the Maruti Suzuki stable after Baleno (rechristened Glanza), before MSIL introduced a Toyota car. Though it was earlier announced that MSIL could sell the rebadged Toyota Corolla, it has since decided to wait for a new sedan.“The agreement between Suzuki and Toyota goes beyond just product introductions. There is technology sharing that is happening. Toyota is a leader in hybrid technology. While we have our own hybrids, the tech sharing will help evolve new strong hybrids in our cars, particularly those sold from the Nexa,” he said.In the statement issued last year from Japan by the two companies, they had announced enhancement of efforts to procure components locally to the extent possible toward the achievement of the “Make in India” initiative promoted by the Indian government.“Toyota and Suzuki remain committed to the widespread acceptance and use of less fuel-consuming vehicles to help India reduce its environmental footprint and enhance energy security,” read the statement.

Title: Maruti Suzuki set to review car prices in April
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

(Representative image)

NEW DELHI: Maruti Suzuki India (MSIL) will review the car price in April 2020 once the BSVI emission and revised safety norms kick in. The company had only a week ago announced a price hike up to 4.7% on select models due to an increase in the input costs.

Speaking to TOI on Thursday, MSIL managing director & CEO Kenichi Ayukawa admitted margins were under pressure due to various cost hikes in recent months to conform to the regulatory requirements.

“The cost of production has gone up. Customers are already impacted by the hike in third party insurance outgo and road tax hikes that some state government have announced. We do not wish to burden the customers further and have tried to absorb as much of the impact as we can. But given the recent hike in duty announced on palladium, a key input in manufacture of catalytic converters require for cars to meet the new emission norms, is a worry. We will undertake a comprehensive review of prices before taking a call on a hike,” said Ayukawa.

According to the industry, cost of buying a car had increase by 6-14% in the past year and a half. This includes insurance and finance cost.

Conscious that a price revision would adversely impact sales in the price-sensitive market at a time when sales industry-wide has been on a downward curve, Ayukawa hoped the government would review the duty hike on palladium that was not available in a India. “We as a company have a mission: to provide affordable cars to Indian customers. If we can increase volumes, I believe we can absorb the cost,” he said.

On products being introduced from the Toyota stable, Ayukawa said it was likely to be a sedan but not one that was already in Toyota India’s portfolio. He further confirmed that Toyota was likely to introduce the Brezza, the second product from the Maruti Suzuki stable after Baleno (rechristened Glanza), before MSIL introduced a Toyota car. Though it was earlier announced that MSIL could sell the rebadged Toyota Corolla, it has since decided to wait for a new sedan.

“The agreement between Suzuki and Toyota goes beyond just product introductions. There is technology sharing that is happening. Toyota is a leader in hybrid technology. While we have our own hybrids, the tech sharing will help evolve new strong hybrids in our cars, particularly those sold from the Nexa,” he said.

In the statement issued last year from Japan by the two companies, they had announced enhancement of efforts to procure components locally to the extent possible toward the achievement of the “Make in India” initiative promoted by the Indian government.

“Toyota and Suzuki remain committed to the widespread acceptance and use of less fuel-consuming vehicles to help India reduce its environmental footprint and enhance energy security,” read the statement.

Title: Karnataka Cabinet: Even with 10 new ministers, swathes of Karnataka unrepresented in BS Yediyurappa cabinet
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

KC Narayanagowda with wife and daughter after he took oath

BENGALURU/HUBBALLI: Kalyana Karnataka and coastal Karnataka, the BJP’s stronghold in recent times, and the old Mysuru region have virtually gone unrepresented in chief minister BS Yediyurappa’s cabinet, despite threats and protests from a handful of legislators.

From Kalaburagi to Dakshina Kannada and from Davangere to Mysuru, 12 of the state’s 30 districts are not represented in the cabinet even after Thursday, when 10 new ministers joined the 17, who took oath in August. In a first, Bengaluru has the lion’s share with seven ministers out of 28 (including the CM).

Ahead of the expansion, more than 10 MLAs under Shorpur’s Narasimha Nayak (Raju Gouda) had exerted pressure on Yediyurappa to ensure fair representation to the backward districts of Kalyana Karantaka. But only Anand Singh (Vijayanagar constituency of Ballari district) was given a berth.

Amarnath Patil, president, Hyderabad Karnataka Chamber of Commerce and Industry, said the Dr Nanjundappa committee report had recommended at least eight MLAs from the region should be made ministers for it to develop. But the government has only two — Singh and Prabhu Chauhan from Bidar.

“In the absence of fair representation, most of our problems will remain unsolved. With only two representatives, it is not going to help overall growth of the region,” said Patil, while ruing the fact that the region — comprising six districts — lacks a strong voice.

A supporter of Gouda said Kalyana Karnataka has got a raw deal and urged the CM to consider at least three more MLAs during the next round of expansion. Failing this, he said, the BJP could suffer in future elections.

It’s not Kalyana Karnataka alone. The coastal districts of Udupi and Dakshina Kannada have no MLAs in the cabinet. Barring Muzrai minister Kota Srinivas Poojari from Udupi, who is a member of the legislative council, the two districts voted in as many as 11 BJP candidates of a total 12 constituencies.

“Fairness in district representation should be automatically considered by our senior leadership,” said S Angara, seven-time Sullia MLA. “While we representatives of Karavalli [coastal] districts understand political compulsions, we hope the leadership considers the need for fair district representation.”

As for old Mysuru, the BJP lacks MLAs from the region. However, Yediyurappa was expected to swear in at least one of three senior MLAs — SA Ramdas (Mysuru) and KG Bopaiah and Appachu Ranjan (Kodagu). The three had lobbied hard for a ministerial berth but to no avail.

Title: Mumbai to Delhi in 12 hours as Railways plan Rs 11,000 crore revamp
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Train speed is expected to increase to 160kmph from the current 130kmph

MUMBAI: With major upgradation plans to increase train speeds, travel time between Mumbai and New Delhi is likely to come down to 12 hours, saving commuters over three hours. The Indian Railways has drawn up a plan to boost infrastructure, which includes providing fencing and strengthening bridges along the entire 1,384-km corridor so the trains can run at160 kmph, instead of the current 130 kmph.

The upgradation work is pegged at Rs 11,188 crore, including Rs 4,011 crore on Western Railway.

Western Railway’s chief public relations officer Ravinder Bhakar said, “Currently, the travel time between New Delhi and Mumbai Central is 15 hours and 30 minutes . Once the upgradation work is completed in three years, the travel will come down to 12 hours as speed will increase and bottlenecks will be removed.”

To achieve this, the Railways will have to undertake upgradation of tracks, bridges, signalling and over head equipment installations, besides removal of some permanent speed restrictions (PSR). The Mumbai-New Delhi passes through seven statesand four zonal railways – Northern Railway, North Central Railway, West Central Railway and Western Railway. Of the 1,384-km route, around 694 km is through WR territory, between Mumbai Central and Nagda.

Bhakar said, “The estimates will be sent for approval and tenders will soon be invited and contractors approved as work has to be completed by December 2023.” Fencing (RCC walls or wire fencing) will have to be provided throughout the route to prevent trespassing and cattle from being run over. The cost of boundary wall/fencing in WR’s jurisdiction from Mumbai Central to Nagda alone is Rs600 crore.

All 186 manned level crossing gates will have to be eliminated and ROBs or subways built to ensure a speed of 160 kmph. Also, permanent speed restrictions will have to removed so that trains can achieve the desired speed. Besides, bridges on the route will have to be strengthened.

The cost of rehabilitation of bridges will cost around Rs550 crore in the Western Railway jurisdiction up to Nagda. New OHE mast as well more substations and improvement in signalling system will also have to be undertaken.

Title: Bengaluru: Free snacks from five hotels keep students focused in special classes
Content:
Before free snacks, students couldn’t focus as they were hungry by the time special classes began

TimesView We laud sporting achievements, rewards for excellence, space programmes, stock-market performance and corporate results, but what we should also be celebrating is humanity — those little acts of kindness that may not mean much to the doer, but are of great significance to the recipients. The gesture of the five restaurateurs shows how things can be turned around in public schools if the community joins forces with stakeholders: The school management that thought of special classes to improve results, the citizen-activist who noticed hungry children and the restaurants that heeded her call to respond to the problem.

More than willing to help kids study, say hoteliers

BENGALURU: When the bell rings at 3.30pm at Government Boys' High School, 18th Cross, Malleswaram , Class 10 students rush out of their classrooms. Before the next two-hour session begins, they sit in the school corridor and dig into snacks sponsored by eateries from the area to help them remain focused on studies.For a week now, some 35 students find preparatory classes for SSLC exams no sweat, thanks to the free snacks arranged by five restaurants. The menu changes every day: Vada Pav, noodles, pulao and idli.With the SSLC exams beginning on March 27, the school started special classes, after school hours, in the third week of January to improve its results from 46% last year. The school starts at 8.30am, midday meals are provided around 12.30pm and free snacks at 3.30pm.Anupama Harish, from Sadashivanagar who works closely with the school and runs a Facebook page on Malleswaram, noticed that the children preparing for SSLC exams were going hungry. "I wondered why not ask nearby restaurants to get them snacks. When I approached them, five happily agreed," she said.Shuchi Ruchi, Mumbai Bistro Resto Cafe and Iyengar Bakery in Malleswaram, Chung Wah in Vyalikaval and Udupi Sri Krishna Bhavan in Balepet are taking turns from Monday to Friday to supply snacks to the students. The special classes are on till March 25.“We thank the restaurants for their gesture,” said GP Latha, who heads the school.Ismail Shuchi Ruchi, proprietor of Shuchi Ruchi, said he was 16 and penniless when he came from Bantwal to Bengaluru. “I’ve established myself as a hotelier in the past three decades. I can relate to the plight of government school students. I could not study beyond SSLC. I was happy when Anupama approached me. It’s an opportunity to do my bit,” Ismail said.Rashmi Holla, who heads Udupi Sri Krishna Bhavan, said many people are ready to bail out the needy, but one must seek help. Dengra Govind of Chung Wah said, “If it helps better students’ results, there’s no better takeaway.”Hitesh Kumar of Mumbai Bistro said everything should be done to motivate the children. Ramesh Iyengar of Iyengar Bakery said he was more than willing to offer help: “Why not assist children when they are studying hard?”

Title: Vijay IT Raid: I-T sleuths search 38 places linked to Vijay & others, seize Rs 77 crore
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

The cash was seized from hideouts believed to be owned by financier Anbu Chezhiyan

Title: Ortho-mattresses for Bengal MLAs
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Kolkata: If the long Budget assembly session that begins on Friday threatens to give MLAs sleepless nights, here’s something that promises to provide them better shut-eye after a day’s work, while taking excellent care of their spines. After several MLAs staying at the MLA hostel on Kyd Street complained of backache and arthritic problems, the Bengal legislative body has decided to replace all old mattresses there with high-quality ‘orthopaedic mattresses’.

Assembly sources said the decision to purchase mattresses was taken after MLAs — mostly from the districts, who stay at the hostel when the House is in session — complained of poor living facilities. “Speaker Biman Banerjee directed the House Committee, headed by Tapas Banerjee, the Trinamool Congress MLA from South Asansol, to submit a report regarding improving infrastructure at the hostel,” said a senior official. “One of the recommendations was to purchase these ‘ortho-mattresses’, as many of the MLAs were found suffering from backache and spondylosis. The speaker then asked for a tender so that the mattresses could be bought.”

An orthopaedic mattress is one that’s designed to support the joints, back and overall body, created to combat problems one might experience with a bad back or joints by providing a firm surface that offers targeted support. But since there is no government standard or official designation that qualifies one mattress to be orthopaedic, the modern use of the term “orthopaedic” is largely a marketing term.

“The mattresses we are replacing had been purchased at least 20 years ago, and all of them were in a very bad condition. So, the new mattresses had to be purchased,” said Tapas. “As most MLAs are elderly and have orthopaedic problems, the committee recommended ortho-mattresses. The MLAs have to sit the whole day — not less than six to seven hours at a stretch — and they need comfortable sleep.”

A total of 200 mattresses have been bought for each bed at the hostel. Nearly 60% of these 200 MLAs who regularly use the hostel are aged 60 and above.

New TV sets and curtains have also been installed. At the House itself, special massage chairs have been installed on the first floor.

Title: ‘I didn’t believe in love at first sight, until it took me 10 seconds to fall for Pallavi’
Content:
‘I worked really hard to woo her, date her and win her heart’

‘My fully filmy proposal in Goa was a spontaneous gesture, and she loved it’

‘Pallavi’s stayed with me through thick and thin; I think we make the perfect match’

I can’t believe I’m getting married in two months,” exclaims actor Nikhil Siddhartha , as we finally manage to get hold of him. The past few days have been a whirlwind for the actor — he went down on one knee and popped the question to the love of his life, Dr Pallavi Varma , at a romantic seaside locale in Goa. She said yes, of course. And then, the two got engaged formally in a private ceremony here in Hyderabad on Saturday. But how did the party boy of Tollywood decide to get ‘domesticated’ so easily, we can’t help but wonder aloud. “Trust me, I wasn’t even thinking of settling down anytime soon,” he says, laughing. “But then, six months ago, Pallavi walked into my life and everything changed!”From meeting to mangni and shaadi, all in six months? “Guess what, it took me exactly 10 seconds to fall in love with her. I knew the moment I saw her that she was the one for me...” he confesses, eyes twinkling. “I met her at a party in Hyderabad. we were introduced through common friends. And it just clicked. Had it been anybody else, I would’ve laughed at the idea of marriage, but with Pallavi, I immediately felt certain that I wanted to spend the rest of my life with her,” he adds.Although it was love at first sight for Nikhil, winning over his lady love was, confessedly, easier said than done. “I had to run after her, woo her and win her heart. It didn’t happen instantly, nope! but over time, she too fell for me, I guess...” he gushes. So, what clinched the deal? “The thing is, right from the start, I was serious about this relationship. I wasnever going to keep it casual. I always looked at Pallavi as a life partner. I felt she truly understood me. I could be myself around her and I think that’s why she liked me too,” he says.the Karthikeya star made sure that his fiancee got a fully filmy proposal — one she’d remember for the rest of her life. “To be honest, it was a spontaneous decision. I was confident that she liked me, so I decided to take her to Goa and surprise her by popping the big question. She has friends from all over the country, so I called all of them there and then went down on one knee and asked her to marry me. Yes, it was super filmy but she loved the surprise and said ‘yes’,” the actor shares, adding, “It wasn’t my plan to get engaged, but at the spur of the moment, I decided to pull off this proposal and after she accepted, we exchanged rings in a private ceremony in Hyderabad, where only our families and close friends were present. It was beautiful.”Dr Pallavi, who hails from Bhimavaram in Andhra Pradesh, is an MBBS graduate from MVJ Medical College in Bengaluru and is currently preparing to do her post-graduation in Hyderabad. “As an actor, I work long hours and at odd timings. On some days, I have to work for over 16 hours. Being a doctor, Pallavi gets that, because she too is a workaholic. It feels comforting to know that my life partner will be someone who understands me. She also stayed with me through thick and thin — first, when Arjun Suravaram faced issues and got delayed, and later when it became a success. It was only fitting for me to propose to her after the film’s success,” Nikhil reveals.With the couple getting hitched on April 16, preparations are on in full swing in both households. “The best part about getting married is the celebrations. There’ll be plenty of parties leading up to the wedding and I can’t wait for all the madness to begin,” he says, signing off.

Title: Pravalika, Mahesh get hitched in a star-studded ceremony
Content: Late director and writer Kodi Ramakrishna ’s youngest daughter Pravalika tied the knot with businessman Mahesh in an extravagant ceremony on Wednesday. The wedding, which was attended by around 6,000 guests, including Tollywood stars, politicos and bureaucrats, took place at an upscale convention hall in the city, which was decked up in an ornate temple-themed décor.Speaking to Hyderabad Times, the bride's sister Deepthi reveals, “It was an arranged marriage and they got engaged in October last year. They were actually classmates in school but got back in touch only after their match was fixed. They have a whole lot of friends in common and they all attended the wedding. It was one helluva celebration.”The who’s who of Tollywood including one of the bride’s closest friends, Bellamkonda Sai Sreenivas was seen at the wedding that also had Chiranjeevi , Mohan Babu and Balakrishna in attendance. Politicos like Botsa Satyanarayana too came to bless the newlyweds. The guests were treated to a lavish spread of Indian, Chinese and Italian fare at the wedding.

Title: Save LIC if you are a desh bhakt, Abhishek tells BJP
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

New Delhi: Trinamool Congress will oppose the proposed disinvestment of LIC in Parliament, and take to the streets if necessary, against the Narendra Modi government’s bid to sell out “jewels” of the country.

TMC MP from Diamond Harbour Abhishek Banerjee took on the government during the Budget debate and appealed to the opposition and BJP members to stand up and save LIC from privatisation if they are true “desh bhakts”. Addressing the treasury benches, he said: “You talk about desh bhakti and patriotism. If you have a spine, save LIC from privatisation. The jewels of the country are on sale. We will oppose it. Yeh hamara desh bhakti hai. Hamara koi farzi desh bhakti nehi hai (This is our patriotism. We do not subscribe to any fake patriotism).”

Abhishek, also Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee’s nephew, told the Lok Sabha the Centre is out to disinvest an organisation that enjoys the trust of 70% insurance policy-holders in the country. “Like 37% of people who voted for the current ruling party, LIC also placed its trust in you. There have been occasions when this organisation bailed you out. It funds most government projects. And you are dragging it to the market. Sadly, LIC authorities didn’t foresee this and carve out a policy to save its own life,” he said.

Abhishek added that the government can’t disinvest LIC without passing an amendment act. “It seems the government has to bring an amendment before implementing the LIC disinvestment decision,” he said.

He expressed concern over the condition of Food Corporation of India. “The government has slashed food subsidy by Rs 70,000 crore. If this is one side of the picture, the other side is that unpaid bills by the Centre to FCI add up to Rs 2 lakh crore. This will bring a severe fund crunch for which FCI will have to borrow to sustain itself. I fear FCI is going to be next,” he added.

Title: Guv remarks on farmers unfortunate: TMC
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Kolkata: Trinamool Congress on Thursday termed as “unfortunate” governor Jagdeep Dhankhar ’s comments in Santiniketan, where he said it “pained” him that Bengal’s farmers did not get their dues.

The governor paid tribute to Rabindranath Tagore for his “unalloyed affection towards farmers” and then pitched for a central government scheme: “The Pradhan Mantri Kisan Samman Nidhi is a revolutionary scheme for farmers.” He then said it “pained” him that Bengal’s farmers did not get this money. “There should be no politics when it comes to development,” he added.

Trinamool minister Ashis Banerjee responded: “It is very unfortunate that the governor has made a remark without getting full information. CM Mamata Banerjee has done enough for farmers’ welfare.”

Dhankhar reached Santiniketan for Magh Mela by the state government-provided helicopter on Thursday but made it clear that the granting of the chopper service should not be seen as a means to broker peace between the governor and the government. “It is up to the state government whether it will provide the service or not. I would have left Kolkata for Santiniketan at 4am, not 8 am, if I was not given helicopter,” he said.

Title: Jagdeep Dhankhar: Govt, governor in war of nerves over Budget speech
Content:
This story is from February 7, 2020

Santiniketan/Kolkata: The war of nerves between the Bengal government and governor Jagdeep Dhankhar continued a day before the assembly Budget session on Friday, with the government insisting it would not amend the speech it had prepared for him (to be read out to the session) and Dhankhar responding that “a new history” would be written in the assembly.

Dhankhar received the draft of the governor’s speech from the state government on Sunday. He responded by sending his suggestions to the government, hoping that they would be incorporated in the speech and making it imperative for the chief minister to call an urgent state cabinet meeting and consider the “suggestions” before accepting or rejecting them.

But the state government told Raj Bhavan on Thursday evening that the text of the governor’s address it had already sent stood as “final”.

Dhankhar said on Friday that he would go by the Constitution and would not cross the “Lakshman Rekha”. “The government is within it rights to put in the governor’s address all it wants. It can put its policies, ideas, achievements in the speech as decided in the cabinet meeting. I too, as the Constitutional head, can give my suggestions. The government has acted in its right to prepare the governor’s address. I have acted in my right to give suggestions. I hope that the government may consider my suggestions,” he said in Santiniketan on Thursday morning.

He, however, did not elaborate on his Constitutional position. “This is the first time a governor born in independent India will address the inaugural session of the assembly. I can assure you that I will act cent per cent according to the Constitution,” Dhankhar said.

The state government prepares a speech for the governor to read out before the Assembly’s Budget session and, by convention, the governor reads out this prepared speech. Governors may, however, take recourse to Article 159 of the Constitution (the oath-taking clause) that mandates them to “protect the Constitution and devote himself/herself to the service and well-being of the people”, Constitution experts say, which “leaves a lot that may be open to interpretation”.

Trinamool minister Chandrima Bhattacharya said she had never heard of such an impasse. “This is the budget session. The state finance minister will place the budget. Have you ever heard of the president of India or any state governor making suggestions? I fail to understand what he is saying,” she said.

Bengal CM Mamata Banerjee is scheduled to reach the assembly at 11 a.m. on Friday and will attend the business advisory committee meeting and is likely to hold a meeting with Trinamool MLAs ahead of the Budget session.

Title: Happy Rose Day 2020: Images, Quotes, Wishes, Greetings, Messages, Cards, Pictures, GIFs and Wallpapers
Content: The countdown for the much-awaited Valentine's Day begins almost a week before the day arrives. Each day of the week (starting from February 7) preceding Valentine's Day has a special significance attached to them. The first day of Valentine's Week, which falls on February 7, is celebrated as Rose Day. On this special day, people give roses to their loved ones and friendsThere are no hard and fast rules that only lovers can give each other roses on this particular day. Anyone can do that. Also, every rose has a special significance based on its colour. It does not come as a big surprise that red is the most-favoured colour when it comes to choosing a rose for a lover because red rose signifies passion and love. But if you want to give your friend a rose on Rose Day, you should choose a yellow rose because it stands for friendship. White, considered the purest of colour, also stands for peace and a new beginning. A symbol of purity and innocence, white roses are meant for people who have just started liking each other and just like children, their relationship is full of innocence and purity. Similarly, a pink rose stands for happiness and thankfulness; purple rose signifies intense passion; Orange rose stands for vitality and enthusiasm. So, in case you are planning to give a rose to someone special or a friend, make sure to choose the right colour.To make your day a little more special, we have compiled a list of lovely Rose Day wishes, quotes, and messages with heart-tugging teddy day images and wallpapers."What's in a name? That which we call a rose by any other name would smell as sweet."– William ShakespeareBeauty is an ecstasy; it is as simple as hunger. There is really nothing to be said about it. It is like the perfume of a rose: you can smell it and that is all.– W. Somerset Maugham"One of the most tragic things I know about human nature is that all of us tend to put off living. We are all dreaming of some magical rose garden over the horizon instead of enjoying the roses that are blooming outside our windows today.– Dale Carnegie“A rose dreams of enjoying the company of bees, but none appears. The sun asks: ‘Aren’t you tired of waiting?’ ‘Yes,’ answers the rose, ‘but if I close my petals, I will wither and die.’”– Paulo Coelho“The optimist sees the rose and not its thorns; the pessimist stares at the thorns, oblivious to the rose.”– Kahlil Gibran“The rose is a rose from the time it is a seed to the time it dies. Within it, at all times, it contains its whole potential. It seems to be constantly in the process of change: Yet at each state, at each moment, it is perfectly all right as it is.”– Paulo CoelhoEven if love is full of thorns, I'd still embrace it for I know that in between those thorns lies heaven. A rose that's worth all the pain. Happy Rose Day!Red is for love,Yellow is for friendship,White is for peace,And Pink is for gratitude,But this whole bunch of red roses is for You.Because you are the love of my life.Happy Rose Day!There is no distance that a rose cannot delete. Today, I am miles away from you, my dear love. But this bunch of roses will carry the fragrance of our love to you. Happy Rose Day, darling!You came in my life with the fragrance of happiness.You are as beautiful as a rose. Happy Rose Day!Your love is like the fragrance of roses; it refreshes me when I am feeling weary; it comforts me when I am hurt; it cheers me up when I am sad. Roses for you and lots of love too.

Title: veterinary college: Can-i(ne) donate blood? (Wo)of course, you can!
Content:
Blood donation by dogs is slowly coming up in Indore, and vets are asking for more awareness on the same

Save a life

Much-needed online directory





The who and what of canine blood donation

Busting a myth







It was a chilly winter evening in November when Rimjhim Joshi’s Rottweiler, Ruby, donated a unit of blood for a sick puppy who needed urgent blood transfusion. "That was the first time that I ever heard of a dog donating blood. I was anxious initially but the vet guided us through the process and I am happy Ruby could save another pup's life," says Rimjhim.Like Rimjhim, many of us are unaware of this process, but cities like Chennai, Hyderabad and Delhi NCR have dedicated animal blood banks for those in need! Even Indore is opening up to the idea through queries on social media network, online apps and more, giving pets and pet parents a chance to save lives of fellow canines.“Much like humans, animals also suffer from life-threatening diseases and accidents where they need immediate blood transfusion. Most commonly, dogs get affected by the Parvo virus which leads to a lot of blood loss," says Dr Sandeep Nanavati, a city-based vet, adding, "When pet donors come forward to donate even one unit of blood for such ailing animals, we are able to save lives.”He maintains that whenever such a requirement comes in, they start floating messages via texts through animal rescue and activist networks in the city. “There is need, but awareness of the process is missing. In such a case, when animal activists guide the pet parents about it, they come forward for donation," he says.And this is not restricted to pets alone. Even strays stand to benefit from the donation. Reshma Motwani, an animal communicator who also works in rescue and rehabilitation of dogs, shares, “Sometimes we need blood donors for accident cases involving strays. I recently shifted from Pune and there, it's a common practice. So, when pet clinics get in touch with a requirement, I contact pet parents of healthy dogs that can donate blood."While a Hyderabad-based professional Shiva Kumar launched a national blood donation directory for animals last year in June, Indore is catching up and creating an online group of donors that pet parents or doctors can peruse in times of need. “We are setting up an online directory for the city's animal lovers as well as veterinaries which can be accessed immediately in time of need," adds Rimjhim.Since dogs have over 12 blood groups, vets recommend a blood test and identification of their pets’ group. “For the first donation, blood groups needn’t be matched as dogs, unlike humans, do not have naturally occurring antibodies that oppose blood types in their bodies before transfusion. But it is better for pet parents to have complete knowledge of their pets’ blood type in case there is a need or they want to donate for the same blood type,” shares another vet Dr Narendra Chouhan, who conducted the blood donation for Ruby the Rottweiler.- It takes approximately 30 minutes to get one unit of blood – 450 ml- A dog can donate once in three months- Any dog that weighs 25 kgs or more can donate- The donor should not be on any medication“Many pet parents think the process may be painful and detrimental for the pets’ health. But just like humans, the dog does not feel drained out or weak after the donation. No normal activities of the animal are hampered by donating one unit,” explains Dr Chouhan.As of now there are only 7-10 pet donors in the city who are aware and ready for donation. But there are more number of canines that need transfusions every month. A canine blood donation camp is the need of the hour right now. It will also help in busting myths and doubts about the process.– Kushagra Rathore, HR professional and animal loverSince Indore lacks a proper animal blood bank and only a few pet clinics provide such a facility, more serious cases are referred to the Veterinary College and Hospital in Mhow. But chances are, a pet may not have that much time to make it to the place. So, a bigger network of donors is required in the city.– Dr Sandeep Nanavati, a vet

Title: Kolkata: NRC scare fuels rush for birth certificates at KMC headquarters
Content:
The crowd at the birth certificate counters at KMC’s headquarters

KOLKATA: KMC authorities have doubled the number of birth certificates issued per day, owing to a sudden rush for the document at its SN Banerjee Road headquarters , triggered by the CAA-NRC scare .While the civic counters had so far been issuing 100 birth certificates a day, municipal commissioner Khalil Ahmed has instructed the corporation’s health department employees to step up the rate and issue 200 each day in the interest of citizens who are gripped by the fear.The last few days have seen long queues at the birth certificate counters, and they have only been getting longer. It’s an indication of the palpable fears over NRC and CAA among a large section of the population, despite Bengal chief minister Mamata Banerjee’s repeated assurances that the exercise would not be held in Bengal.Ahmed has also asked the department’s officials at the borough offices to cater to the additional demand for birth certificates.A civic staffer who sits at one of the birth certificate counters at the KMC headquarters said the number of applicants for birth certificates was going up by leaps and bounds, and the corporation didn’t have the manpower or training to handle the sudden rush.“In September last year, we noticed a sharp increase in the number of applicants. And the number is growing every day,” said a KMC health department official. “While the staffers at three counters can at best issue 100 certificates after clearing all requisite parameters, the target has now doubled. Even then, we will be forced to reject many applicants as these days as many as 400 applicants are turning up per day.”According to the department’s officials, it is not only youths who have been turning up for proof of their birth. “We are noticing that people born in the 60s and 70s are also visiting in large numbers,” said an official.TOI visited the KMC birth certificate counters on Thursday and saw a heavy rush. Businessman Bashir Ahmed, a resident of Picnic Garden who was seen standing impatiently, said it was his third visit to the civic headquarters in a fortnight. Explaining his urgency for repeatedly visiting the civic headquarters, Ahmed said he needed the certificate as a “credible document” that could be produced before any competent authority if his citizenship was challenged.Tanmoy Bose, a private firm employee and a resident of Vidyasagar Colony, close to the Baghajatin Market, was seen happily emerging from a counter, a couple of birth certificates in hand. Bose said he was fortunate that all documents submitted by him matched the records of KMC’s health department.
